PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia our head of State and as in duty bound will ever pray. God save The Queen.

PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned,
(i)are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii)call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by ICAO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition, by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said "The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth and as stated in our Federal Constitution—"Relying on the Blessings of Almighty God. . .
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.
(1)The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem—"God Bless Australia" to the tune of "Waltzing Matilda".
(2)The adoption of a Christian National Motto—"One Nation Under God", for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
(3)The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.
(4)The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.
(5)The retention of "God Save the Queen" for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
(6)The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our State Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
(7)Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in Syria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
WHEREAS:

(a)The Syrian Government has adopted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and is a signatory to the International Covenant on civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on the Elimination of all forms of Racial Discrimination;

(b)In violation of Universal Declaration of Human Rights Articles 2 (Freedom of Religion), 13 (Right to leave) and 14 (Freedom to Emigrate), the Syrian Government oppresses and discriminates against certain of its citizens on account of their religion and/or ethnic identity and prohibits them from emigrating;

(c)In further violation of its international obligations, the Syrian government punishes those of its citizens who attempt to exercise their internationally-recognised right of emigration with arbitrary imprisonment without charge or trial and with beatings and torture of the most cruel and barbaric kind; and

(d)As a consequence of those repeated and grievous violations of international law, the Syrian government has been censured by the European Parliament and the governments of a number of democratic nations.
YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE PRAY THAT THE AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT RESOLVE TO:
ICONDEMN the government of the Arab Republic of Syria for:

PETITION.PARA: (1)Its denial of fundamental rights including the right of all its citizens to emigrate and to family reunification; the right to life, liberty and the security of the individual; protection against arbitrary arrest and detention; the right of an accused person to a fair public trial before a jury of his or her peers; the right of free expression, assembly and association.

(2)Its use of the police, law courts and other state organs to carry out arbitrary arrests, detention, beatings and torture in respect of certain of its citizens and otherwise to exact arbitrary penalties against such citizens solely on the basis of race, religion, sex, national or ethnic origin or political belief.
(3)Its use of government-controlled communications media to incite hatred and prejudice against its Jewish and other minorities.

PARA.TAB: IIRAISE the foregoing matters for public discussion in the United Nations and other international forums with a view to imposing economic sanctions upon Syria until the aforementioned abuses cease.

IIIENCOURAGE AND ASSIST inter-government bodies, non-government human rights organisations and International Jurists to bring political and public pressure to bear on the Syrian government to honour its international commitments to respect the human rights of all its citizens.
AND your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian War Memorial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and The Honourable Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:

PARA.TAB: "We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the proposal that an admission charge be made for entry into the Australian War Memorial. We believe that it was erected as a Memorial to the dead and that the material on display is as much of a memorial nature as the building itself".

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX 1991
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That attention is drawn to Australia's location and involvement in the Asia/Pacific region where there exists a number of actual and potential conflicts, along with several countries which can ill afford to pay for the importation of military equipment yet feel obliged to do so.

That Australia is increasing its role in the arms trade in this region, and in particular, it is supporting and participating in AIDEX `91. The arms trade is detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from health, education, social welfare, and is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of people of the Asia/Pacific region.
The petitioners therefore appeal to the Australian Parliament to:
Stop all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people

Direct those Government Departments participating in AIDEX `91, i.e. Defence, Austrade, Industry, Technology and Commerce, to cancel their bookings for space at the exhibition and withdraw their support for AIDEX `91.
Redirect all monies currently being used in promoting the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
Explore the possibilities of setting up an Agency for the development of techniques for conflict resolution.
Increase overseas aid to counteract the reduction since 1983/4.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Hon. the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the Petition of the undersigned showeth:

PARA.TAB: That the Australian Government is making Australia an active participant in the international arms trade by its official support for the Australian International Defence Exhibition (Aidex 91) to be held in November 1991.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should—
request the Government to withdraw all official support and participation from Aidex to regain our international standing as an advocate of disarmament and arms control.

PETITION.TITLE: Consumption Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
i) are alarmed by talk of a consumption (goods and services) tax which we feel would have a devastating effect on the lives of the people on low to middle incomes.
ii) call on the Senate to express its total opposition to the introduction of a consumption (goods and services) tax.

PETITION.TITLE: Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth; that we support your efforts to strengthen our family and community life particularly by increased penalties for "drug pushers" and distributors. We, however, wish to register our firm opposition to any legal changes which would increase or encourage the distribution or availability of so-called "soft drugs" such as marijuana. We believe such drugs to be harmful to the physical and psychological health of the individual and therefore to the interest of the community of which such individual is part. Although there is current controversy concerning the question of such harm it appears to us quite foolish to legalise and encourage the use of such drugs unless or until it be shown that such drugs are in fact harmless. The serious social problems of alcohol should provide sufficient warning to our society.
Any efforts to legalise or decriminalise usage or distribution of such drugs will have the following results:

PARA.TAB: 1. Encourage and inculcate a social acceptability towards such drugs.
2. Increase the volume of usage of such drugs in schools and the community by present users and by "drug pushers" through the proposed one ounce legal possession.
3. Extend the usage of such drugs to persons who would previously have abstained because of the legal sanctions.

4. Put pressure upon Parliament to establish and license import, growth, manufacture and/or distribution of such drugs, that is, to regulate another destructive industry contrary to the best interest of the individual and society.
5. There would be the probable temptation to tax such drugs as another source of Federal revenue.

We urge the Government to increase the medical and counselling facilities for the assistance of drug users and to expand existing Drug Referral Centres and Clinics. We have general confidence in the existing law and its sympathetic implementation by the Police and Courts.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will firstly take no measures that could extend the major social problem of drug usage and secondly will oblige those who are promoting marijuana and/or similar drugs to prove without doubt that such drugs are harmless before any legalisation or decriminalisation of use is introduced. And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BELL

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petition, from 116 citizens, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
A humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Attention is drawn to Australia's increasing role in the militarisation of the Pacific region and in particular to the current Government-led arms export drive.

The arms trade is not only detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from socially beneficial areas—for example, health education and social welfare—but is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of the people of the Third World.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Cease all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people
Direct all Federal and State Government Departments and instrumentalities to withdraw from participation in and support for AIDEX and similar arms fairs in Australia and overseas.
Close down AIDEX 1991.
Establish a register of all applications for arms transfers and offset agreements which would be subject to public scrutiny.
Redirect all monies currently being used to promote the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: NATIONAL ROAD TRANSPORT COMMISSION BILL 1991
I take great pleasure in introducing to the Senate the National Road Transport Commission Bill 1991.

The Bill will establish a National Road Transport Commission and bring into effect the Inter-governmental Agreement signed on 30 July 1991 by the Prime Minister and Heads of Government of all the States and the Australian Capital Territory.

The Bill provides for the Commission to be responsible for the development and recommendation of national road transport legislation and road use charges. This includes the preparation and provision of guidelines and principles of administration. The functions and powers of the Commission will be those that are set out in the Inter-governmental Agreement which is included as a schedule to the Bill.

This Bill provides the administrative framework for the National Road Transport Commission. National road transport legislation will be developed by the Commission once it is established and will be introduced as separate legislation.

Under the terms of the Inter-governmental Agreement, national road transport legislation will be limited in its coverage to vehicles with a gross vehicles mass of more than 4.5 tonnes. Extension of the jurisdiction of the Commission to include light vehicles is currently under consideration through the Special Premiers' Conference processes.

I would like to emphasise that this Bill does not in itself affect current road transport legislation or charges. It simply establishes an institutional framework for a national, co-operative approach to the development of future road transport legislation which is consistent across jurisdictions.

The Commission will be required to develop and recommend national road transport legislation and charges to a Ministerial Council. The Ministerial Council consists of a Minister representing each of the States, the Australian Capital Territory and the Commonwealth Government. Each Minister has equal representation on the Council.

The Northern Territory does not have a member on the Ministerial Council as it is not a signatory to the Inter-governmental Agreement. Although it decided not to sign the Agreement, it does support the establishment of the Commission. The Northern Territory has stated that it will implement non-charging regulations which are agreed to by the Ministerial Council. In recognition of this commitment, the Northern Territory has been granted observer status at the Ministerial Council.
In discussing the contents of the Bill, I will outline the issues that will be considered by the Commission and the work that it will be undertaking.
This Government is committed to a competitive and efficient transport system. Cheaper and more efficient transport means greater success in ensuring Australia's industries are more competitive.

More rational road use charges will provide the signal to improve the economic efficiency of the vehicle fleet and use and management of the road system. The road asset is one of the community's largest investments and increasing returns on this asset will provide significant lasting benefits.

Transport has a strategic role to play in improving Australia's international trading performance. It employs around 400 000 people and contributes about eight per cent of Gross Domestic Product. Road transport alone accounts for about four per cent, or approximately half of the transport component of national income.

More importantly, it is an intermediate service that is used by almost every industry and consumer. Virtually every product has at some point been carried by a road transport vehicle. Manufacturers rely increasingly on just-in-time deliveries. The quality of the service directly affects the efficiency of the rest of the economy. Thus, any initiative that improves the performance of road transport will have a positive effect on the rest of the economy.
Transport has a pervasive influence over the efficiency of our economy and improvements in the system will have significant national benefits.

The Industry Commission has estimated that a more efficient land transport system, including a more efficient rail system, alone could realise an additional six billion dollars in Gross Domestic Product every year.

We have demonstrated our commitment to gaining an efficient rail sector through the establishment of the National Rail Corporation earlier this year. The National Road Transport Commission will also play a pivotal role in developing an efficient, national operating environment for road transport.

The Federal Government has been striving to improve the operating environment for the road transport industry since it came to office in 1983. It has achieved significant improvements in industry efficiency in recent years through the development of more uniform technical and operating standards for heavy vehicles, particularly the adoption of uniform mass and dimension limits. Most progress has been made on technical issues where the Commonwealth has the clear power to legislate.
The introduction of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 has ensured that uniform national design standards apply to all vehicles new to the Australian market.
The Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 provided the Federal Government with the means to encourage the harmonisation of regulations affecting heavy vehicles.

This legislation introduced the Federal Interstate Registration Scheme (FIRS) for vehicles engaged solely in interstate trade. The Scheme enabled the achievement of a uniform 42.5 tonne mass limit throughout Australia which delivered major productivity gains to road transport and the Australian economy.
Most recently, the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Act 1991 has allowed B-Doubles to be registered under FIRS.

Previous attempts to introduce harmonisation across different regulatory and charging environments have relied on two factors: agreement being reached in the Australian Transport Advisory Council; and, on the implementation of these agreements through policy directive and/or complementary legislative change.

As ATAC is only an advisory and consultative body with no powers to require individual jurisdictions to implement agreed proposals, this process has had limited success in achieving a nationally consistent approach.
Each State and Territory still has its own legislation covering the registration, regulation and charging of heavy vehicles.

What makes the Commission different from previous attempts at such a co-operative process is that it alone will develop charges and regulations for consideration by Governments. The Ministerial Council will be a determinative body overseeing a streamlined legislative and regulatory process.

A fundamental aim of the Inter-governmental Agreement is to ensure that a transparent road use charging system is developed which provides a clear link between road use and the contribution to the costs of road maintenance by the road transport industry.

Currently, there is little clear relationship between road use and damage caused by heavy vehicles, and charges paid by road users. A road transport operator sees little or no direct connection between his use of the road and what is paid for this privilege.

The Inter-governmental Agreement requires the introduction of a national charging structure comprising a nominal administration charge, a road use charge component of Commonwealth diesel excise and a registration or mass-distance charge for vehicles which do not meet their road costs through fuel payments alone.
The road use part of diesel excise is to be structured to avoid the imposition of mass-distance charges on most of the heavy vehicle fleet.
The level of charges will be developed by the Commission based on the following principles:
-full recovery of all road costs while minimising over-recovery from any vehicle class;
-a common methodology;
-charges to be determined and collected in a way that achieves a reasonable balance between administrative simplicity, efficiency and equity in the charging structure;
-improved pricing, leading to a better allocation of resources, with investment decisions being based on more relevant demand signals; and
-minimising the incentive for operators to `shop around' for lower charges and undermine the integrity of the national charging system.

In recognition of the varying road costs in different parts of the country, two zones have been established for the purpose of charging. These zones generally reflect on the one hand the States with higher road costs, and those with lower road costs on the other.

The establishment of the National Road Transport Commission is the direct result of the resolve shown by all the States and the Commonwealth through the Special Premiers' Conference to develop an efficient national structure for land transport. It will be the focal point of a more efficient and clearly defined process for gaining nationally consistent charges and regulations relating to heavy vehicles.
I now turn to the provisions of the Bill.

The Bill provides for the Commission to have three part-time members who will be chosen for their ability to bring an independent view and range of experience to the Commission. Each member will be appointed by the Governor-General, on the recommendation of the Ministerial Council, for a term of three years and may be reappointed only once. From the three members, one will be appointed as Chairperson of the Commission and another as Deputy Chair.

The objective of the Commission will be to facilitate improvements in road transport efficiency and road safety, and reductions in the costs of administration of road transport through a cooperative process between local government, the States, the Australian Capital Territory and the Commonwealth. The implementation of lasting reform is only possible with the cooperation of all levels of Government and affected transport providers and user groups.
Part 3 of the Bill sets out the functions and powers which will enable the Commission to achieve its objectives.

In particular, the Commission will have those functions and powers that are conferred upon it in the Inter-governmental Agreement. The Commission will exercise responsibility for the development of road transport legislation and for overseeing its administration by the States and the Australian Capital Territory.
The key aspect of the work of the National Road Transport Commission will be the development and recommendation of road use charges.
The Commission will be required to report on or provide advice to the Ministerial Council on any matter relating to its powers and functions.
While there is clear emphasis on the accountability of the Commission to governments through the Ministerial Council, the Commission will be reflecting the broader interests of the community.

To assist it in discharging its responsibilities in this regard, the Commission will consult widely with interested parties including the road transport industry, industry in general, and people and government organisations from rural and remote regions.
It may also appoint committees to assist it in discharging its duties under the terms of this legislation. These committees will have such membership as the Commission considers appropriate.

I now turn to the administrative provisions of the Bill. This part of the Bill sets out the conditions relating to members of the Commission. It also establishes the basic meeting procedures for the Commission and provides for disclosure of interest by individual members.

The staffing provisions will enable the staff of the Commission to reflect the Commission's national character. The Commission will be able to employ staff, within the limits of its budget, from the public and private sectors.
A Chief Executive Officer will be appointed by the Commission to manage the operations of the NRTC according to the directions and policies determined by the Commission.
Staff may also be employed through secondment arrangements with Commonwealth, State or Territory administrations.

Under the finance provisions of this Bill, the Commission will receive funding from the Commonwealth, the States and the Australian Capital Territory. The funding share of each Government will be determined by the Ministerial Council as set out in the Inter-governmental Agreement.

The establishment and running costs of the National Road Transport Commission will be jointly funded by the Commonwealth and the States and Territories party to the Inter-governmental Agreement. At the first Ministerial Council meeting it was agreed that the Commonwealth would contribute a 35 per cent fixed share of costs with the remainder being shared by the States and Territories based on heavy vehicle registrations. It is anticipated that the Commission's annual budget will total $3-4 million. The Commonwealth has included a provision of $1 million in this year's Budget as its contribution to the establishment and maintenance of the Commission in 1991-92.
I now turn to the final, miscellaneous provisions of the Bill.

In regard to the powers and functions of the Ministerial Council, the Ministerial Council may delegate any or all of these to any one or more of its members. Such delegation must be made through a unanimous decision by the Members of the Ministerial Council.

The legislation will cease to be in force after six years. At least six months prior to this, the Commission is required to make a recommendation to the Ministerial Council as to whether the legislation should be re-enacted. This follows the procedure established in the Inter-governmental Agreement.
All Members of the Ministerial Council and the Australian Local Government Association have considered the Bill and agree that it reflects the letter and spirit of the Inter-governmental Agreement.

The establishment of the Commission will reduce duplication of work between the States and the Commonwealth. It will also ensure that all Governments will be working from a common perspective. No longer will we be in the situation where nine different bureaucracies are working to develop nine different sets of regulations affecting road transport. For the first time we will have nationally consistent regulations governing heavy vehicles. This is a significant achievement and is a clear demonstration of the maturity of Australia as a nation.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
NATIONAL RAIL CORPORATION AGREEMENT BILL 1991
I take great pleasure in introducing the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill 1991.
The purpose of the Bill is to allow the Commonwealth to approve the Shareholders' Agreement relating to the establishment of the National Rail Corporation (NRC).
The Bill represents another major step in the implementation of the Government's micro-economic reform program which is directed at creating a more productive, efficient and flexible economy.

The Bill involves significant restructuring: in this case of rail institutions, technology, management and work practices. Without such initiatives we will be unable to meet the community's current needs, let alone our future needs.

It is an important transport reform. Transport affects almost every area of Australian economic and social activity. As a significant intermediate cost, efficient transport is vital to the competitiveness of the economy.
Even small improvements in the efficiency of our transport system offer potentially large economic and social gains.
This is highlighted by a number of major studies in recent years, which have exposed the deficiencies in our transport system and the potential gains from reform.

In 1989-90 the Industry Commission estimated that a more efficient land transport system, including a more efficient rail system, alone could realise an additional $6 billion in Gross Domestic product every year. Of this, $4.4 billion was attributable to rail.
More recently, in its October 1991 report on rail transport, the Industry Commission confirmed the importance of reforming the rail industry.
Australia cannot afford to ignore such gains, particularly given their potential for contributing to economic growth and our standard of living.

One of the major problems in the rail industry is the inability of the existing systems to obtain their proper share of interstate freight, particularly on the eastern seaboard. This is due in the main to the quality of the service that rail delivers. Terminals are inadequate, work and management practices need improvement, and reliability needs to be greatly improved. It is widely acknowledged that much of the problem lies in the fragmented management of rail.
That said, the position is not irredeemable. Industry has said that it would make greater use of rail if a reliable, quality service were provided.
Indeed, rail can confidently be said to have a bright future, provided it can be operated efficiently.
There are some types of traffic where rail beats the competition hands down. The most obvious example of this is the carriage of freight over medium to long distances.

If rail undertakes the tasks to which it is best suited, and is efficient, it can carry goods at a lower cost to the community than road transport. And there will be savings in terms of accidents, air and noise pollution and energy costs.

Accordingly the Federal Government has positively promoted the revitalisation of the interstate rail freight system. This is part of a broader set of transport industry objectives within which each of the transport modes can undertake the tasks to which it is best suited. It is not a matter of favouring one mode over another. What the Government is striving for is an integrated transport system that will provide the community with an efficient and competitive land transport system.

That rail can be a success in Australia has been clearly demonstrated by the Commonwealth's own railway: the Australian National Railways Commission (AN). AN has long practised the commercial approach that will be taken by the National Rail Corporation (NRC) and its success is clear for all to see. The Industry Commission acknowledged this achievement in its recent rail report.

I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate AN, its employees and management for the efforts they have put in since its creation in 1978. Indeed, I expect that the skills and expertise built up by AN will prove to be a valuable asset for the NRC.

Recognising the need for change, the Commonwealth and all the mainland States except South Australia, signed an agreement establishing the National Rail Corporation (NRC) at the Special Premiers' Conference in July 1991. For the first time all interstate rail freight operations will be brought under one management structure.

South Australia supports the Corporation and proposes to sign the agreement after a range of issues under its Railway Transfer Agreement with the Commonwealth are resolved through bilateral negotiation. Queensland chose not to become an equity participant at this stage although it has committed itself to giving every assistance to the NRC. Provision has been made in the Agreement for Queensland and South Australia to become equity participants, if they wish.

The NRC has been incorporated under the Companies Code as a strictly commercial corporation at arms-length from government. The directors of the Company have to comply with all relevant provisions of the Company Law, including the obligation to act in the interests of all shareholders.
The Company has been established for the purpose of conducting interstate rail freight operations on a commercial basis.
The Company will:

PARA.TAB: operate on a strictly commercial basis, with a financially viable corporate plan, and be subject to the Trade Practices Act 1974;
have access (by ownership or other appropriate arrangements) to the assets, including track infrastructure, necessary to achieve commercial viability;

operate under labour arrangements incorporated in an enterprise award, which reflects best practice in productivity standards through efficient work and manning practices, determined by the technical capacity of its equipment and commercial considerations.;
have the capacity to contract out activities where that is the most efficient approach;
provide access on a commercial basis to the NRC network and to terminal facilities for private and public sector operators;
have the capacity to provide services to Governments, with the charging for such services being on a strictly commercial basis;
not be responsible, financially or in any other way, for redundancies that may arise in rail authorities resulting from its formation and transfer of functions and assets to it;
be subject to all rates, taxes and charges;
not have Shield of the Crown; and
be treated as an ordinary incorporated company.

SPEECH.PARA: Any new rail projects undertaken by the NRC will be subject to the normal State and Federal environmental legislation.

It is expected that the cash equity injections of $415 million provided for by the Agreement, together with commercial borrowings by the NRC, will lead to the speedy elimination of interstate rail deficits. The NRC is expected to break even within three years and become totally self supporting after five. The meeting of this target will in itself be a major achievement. Interstate rail freight deficits are currently around $375 million a year.
The NRC was incorporated in September and Directors were appointed to the Board.

The Board is recruiting a management team who will negotiate an enterprise award with the unions and develop a Corporate Plan (including an investment strategy). These must be completed prior to the injection of capital funds by the shareholders.

The enterprise award to be negotiated by the NRC with rail unions will reflect the most efficient work and staffing practices, determined by the technical capacity of its equipment and commercial considerations. It is proposed that the NRC employ only those people that it needs for its operations: other employees will remain with the existing rail systems.

The NRC is scheduled to commence actual rail operations early in 1992, beginning with marketing and terminal operations. Customers will then no longer have to deal with up to five separate rail authorities to transport freight across the country.

The establishment of the NRC heralds an historic development in the revitalisation of Australia's rail industry. The Corporation will provide a strong impetus to overall reform in the rail industry and the land transport sector in general.

For the first time in the history of this country, the NRC will ensure that rail investment decisions are based on commercial considerations with the needs of a national network being paramount. Problems of the past, which led to three different track gauges, different signalling technologies and varying work practices, will not be permitted to continue.
I now turn to the provisions of the Bill

The Bill provides for the Commonwealth to approve the Shareholders' Agreement relating to the establishment of the National Rail Corporation (NRC). A copy of the Agreement is provided in a Schedule to the Bill.

The Bill also provides that the Company does not have the protection of the Crown. That is, it is simply a Company incorporated under the Companies Code, subject to all Commonwealth, State and local government legislation.
The Bill provides for the legislative transfer of assets and contracts, and for any third parties to be compensated if they suffer any damages as a result of such a transfer.
The Bill also provides that the Governor-General may make Regulations consistent with the Act.

The Bill provides that the Commonwealth may pay money in accordance with the Shareholders' Agreement, but does not of itself appropriate such moneys. These are appropriated in the Budget. The Commonwealth's cash equity contributions to be under the NRC Agreement amount to $296 million over the next six years, including $40 million in 1991/92.

In addition the establishment of the NRC will have an impact on the deficits of railway systems. Total losses on interstate rail freight (including AN) was estimated to have amounted to $377 million in 1989/90. The NRC is expected to break even within three years and be fully self sufficient within five years, leading to a reduction in the call on all taxpayers, State and Federal.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum for this Bill.
INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No.3) 1991

The Bill proposes amendments to the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989, the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976, the Navigation Act 1912, the Pipeline Authority Act 1973 and the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991.
The provisions of the Bill are explained in detail in the accompanying Explanatory Memorandum. I will, therefore, confine my comments to the broad thrust of the amendments.
Amendments to the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988
The amendments to the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (known as the CERC Act) are contained in Part 2 of the Bill.

The Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees (which operates as Comcare), was established under the CERC Act in December 1988 to effectively manage the Commonwealth public sector workers compensation function. The legislation introduced income-related benefits and emphasised the Commission's role in the prevention of workplace injury and disease through improved occupational health and safety practices and the rehabilitation of injured workers.

The amendments implement changes based on a recent review of the Comcare program. The Review was conducted by Mr Ron Brown, a management consultant. He was commissioned in December 1990 to carry out a comprehensive review of the Comcare program including the self administrators.

Comcare provides the full workers' compensation insurance function to around 250 Commonwealth public sector agencies. Australia Post and Telecom, however, have been operating as "self administrators" on a two year trial. Under the self administration arrangements, these two organisations are responsible for all aspects of the administration of the CERC Act in relation to their own staff.
The Review was asked to consider the effectiveness of the Comcare scheme and any policy and legislative changes needed to better achieve the Government's objectives.

The Review acknowledged the success of improvements in workers compensation arrangements and policy achieved by the Commission since its establishment. Nevertheless, it targeted additional areas where effectiveness could be enhanced.
In particular, the Commission, is to be restructured to separate its regulatory and service functions.

Under the new provisions, the restructured Commission will be a tripartite body responsible for regulatory functions associated with the CERC Act, including determining and setting premiums, occupational health and safety and licensing of compensation self administrators. A new statutory body to be called Comcare is to be established, with responsibility for commercial and service functions under the Act.

The amendments create a new position of Chief Executive Officer of Comcare. The Chief Executive Officer is to be a member of the new Commission and to have responsibility for all functions under the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991 and the CERC Act, other than those performed by the Commission.
The new Commission and the Chief Executive Officer of Comcare will be subject to Ministerial direction and will be required to prepare Annual Reports.

The majority of the amendments made in this Part of the Bill provide for the separation of the powers and functions of the current Commission between the new Commission and the new body to be known as Comcare. The Bill also provides for the transition from the current legislative scheme, to that which will result from the amendments, to ensure an orderly changeover. A number of other consequential changes are also made.
Amendments to the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989

The amendments to the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989 are contained in Part 3 of the Bill and are designed to assist industry in the development and the use of chemicals and are therefore consistent with the government's policy of enhancing industry development.

The Act establishes the National Industrial Chemical Notification and Assessment Scheme. The Scheme requires that importers and manufacturers of new industrial chemicals submit a package of data on the chemical to Worksafe Australia in order that the chemical can be assessed before its introduction into Australia.
The Bill amends the Act to allow for a joint application to be made for an assessment certificate in relation to a new industrial chemical.

Currently, the Act does not allow a joint application by two or more persons for an assessment certificate in relation to the importation and use of the same new industrial chemical. Where two or more persons wish to have the same chemical assessed, the Act currently requires separate applications to be submitted to the Director of Industrial Chemicals and the required information to be supplied by all applicants. This results in overlap in the information provided to the Director. It has also inhibited co-operation between applicants, usually companies, in the manufacture and use of industrial chemicals. The practice also leads to unnecessary duplication and inefficiency in the chemicals industry.

The major amendment, at clause 29 of the Bill, will allow two or more persons, manufacturing or importing the same new industrial chemical, to make a joint application for assessment of that chemical.

The other clauses in Part 3 of the Bill are consequential upon introducing a legislative scheme that allows for a joint application for assessment. For example the amendments made by clause 31 of the Bill provides for each party to a joint assessment to be issued with an assessment certificate. Other amendments made in Part 3 of the Bill are of a minor, consequential or technical nature.
Amendments to the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976
The amendments to the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976, which makes provision for long service leave for Commonwealth employees, are contained in Part 4 of the Bill.

The amendment in clause 36 of the Bill will enable regulations to be made under the Act to provide that certain categories of payments are excluded from "salary" for the purposes of calculating long service leave entitlements. In addition the regulations shall be able to provide the extent and circumstances in which payments in those categories are excluded from "salary" for the purposes of the Act. Currently, regulations may only be made to prescribe those payments which are to be included as `salary' for long service leave purposes.
Amendments to the Navigation Act 1912

The proposed amendments to the Navigation Act, which are in Part 5 of the Bill, arise out of the Government's initiative to increase the number of Conventions of the International Labour Organisation ratified by Australia.

As a general rule Australia does not ratify a Convention until law and practice in all relevant jurisdictions complies with the requirements of the Convention. The proposed amendments are intended to achieve compliance with three maritime Conventions, thus enabling them to be ratified. The Conventions are:

PARA.TAB: The Medical Examination (Seafarers) Convention, 1946 (No.73);
The Accommodation of Crews Convention (Revised), 1949 (No.92); and
The Accommodation of Crews (Supplementary Provisions) Convention, 1970.

SPEECH.PARA: Each of the Conventions is regarded as appropriate for ratification once compliance has been achieved. Although there is substantial compliance in practice, some States and the Northern Territory do not have legislation giving effect to the Conventions.

The three Conventions apply to sea-going ships. Most sea-going ships in Australian waters are engaged in inter-state or overseas voyages and therefore come within the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth and are, therefore, covered by the Navigation Act. A small number of sea-going ships, however, come within the jurisdiction of a State or the Northern Territory.

The proposed amendments, which have been developed in consultation with the States and the Northern Territory, will enable regulations and orders to be made under the Navigation Act to give effect to the Conventions in respect of all sea-going ships in Australian waters. These orders and regulations will not, however, apply where any existing or future law of a State or of the Northern Territory gives effect to the Conventions. This will ensure that the Conventions are applied to all sea-going ships in Australian waters, while preserving the jurisdiction of the States and the Northern Territory in respect of the matters covered by the Conventions.
Amendments to the Pipeline Authority Act 1973

The amendments to the Pipeline Authority Act 1973 are contained in Part 6 of the Bill. The Pipeline Authority Act establishes the Pipeline Authority which is the body charged with the function of constructing pipelines for the conveyance of petroleum to cities.
The proposed amendments to the Act are minor and correct an amendment made by the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Act 1991 Act No. 122 of 1991.

An amendment made to the Pipeline Authority Act by that Act was not in accordance with the Government's intention that the Pipeline Authority be able to grant part-time members leave to be absent from meetings of the Authority. The amendment proposed in clause 41 of the Bill gives effect to that intention. The Minister retains the discretion to grant a full-time member of the Authority leave of absence.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
BANKRUPTCY AMENDMENT BILL 1991

This Bill will strengthen and improve the working of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 in significant respects. It introduces a range of amendments directed at substantially reforming the law relating to discharge from and annulment of bankruptcy, contributions by bankrupts to the bankrupt estate from their income, and practice and procedure at meetings of creditors.
I shall briefly outline the administrative and legislative context in which the Bill has been prepared, and some of the principal amendments proposed.

Bankruptcy has traditionally had two principal aims, the first being the return of funds to creditors, and the second being the rehabilitation of the bankrupt. The mechanisms in the Act for obtaining income contributions from bankrupts who are able to make some contribution to their estate have proved in recent times to be less effective than they should be. There have also been expressions of concern in the community that legislative measures should be taken to make the mechanisms more effective, but not in such a way as to disadvantage persons with low incomes. Similarly, access to early discharge from bankruptcy has been denied to many bankrupts because of the legal costs associated with obtaining an early discharge.

The two main purposes of the Bill are, first, to establish a more efficient and effective means of securing contributions from the income of a bankrupt and secondly, to enhance the opportunities of those bankrupts, with levels of debt that they have no prospect of repaying, to be able to return to full participation in the community after a suitable period of financial rehabilitation.
The more significant features of the Bill fall into the following main categories:

PARA.TAB: substitution of the Court based (ordered) early discharge system with an administrative system based on clearly specified eligibility and disqualification criteria;
clarification of the grounds on which a bankruptcy can be prolonged by self executing objection, and provision for objections in certain circumstances to extend bankruptcies to periods of 8 years;
imposition of a prohibition on overseas travel by bankrupts liable to make contributions from income without court approval;
introduction of a compulsory income contributions regime applicable to bankrupts who have an income above a specified threshold amount;
introduction of new administrative enforcement mechanisms to facilitate the recovery of property into bankrupt estates, and to enable efficient collection of contributions;
expansion of powers of Official Receivers to obtain information and to undertake inquiries in relation to the financial affairs of bankrupts, including inquiries overseas;

clarification and codification of creditors' meeting procedures to ensure that creditors are fully informed before making decisions relating to the future course of a bankruptcy administration, and enabling the removal of a trustee of an estate by majority in value (rather than by majority in number and at least three fourths in value) of creditors voting on a proposal for removal of a trustee;

technical amendments to correct references to other legislation, and make consequential amendments previously omitted to be made, and provision of regular indexation of various money amounts specified in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, for the first time, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will be given jurisdiction to review decisions of trustees and officials of the bankruptcy administration in connection with the proposed new discharge and income contribution arrangements.
Administrative Discharge System

The Act currently provides by section 150 that a person may apply to the Court at any time after the date of bankruptcy for an order of discharge, either before the three year statutory period expires, or in a case where the bankrupt is otherwise disentitled to automatic discharge, or where an objection has been entered to the bankrupt's discharge. Only a very small proportion of bankrupts avail themselves of the early discharge provisions, because of the costs involved with making an application to the court. In almost all cases where early discharge is sought, the order is granted.

Low income earners are greatly disadvantaged by this system and have no real opportunity to avail themselves of it. Commonly, persons who succeed in obtaining orders for discharge have become bankrupt as a result of failed business activities, and seek early discharge so as to enable them to resume such activities. These are usually also persons who have the capacity to contribute to the estate from income, but do not do so. The proposals in the Bill will restore equity to the operation of the early discharge system, and the eligibility and disqualification criteria are designed to ensure that where a person has become a bankrupt because of commercial culpability, he or she is disqualified from early discharge.

Under the scheme proposed in the Bill, a bankrupt will be able to apply for early discharge after 6 months from the time when he or she files a statement of affairs with the Registrar. The trustee must evaluate, on the basis of information available to him or her, whether the bankrupt is eligible for and is not disqualified from early discharge. The proposed eligibility criteria are that:

PARA.TAB: the bankrupt has no or insufficient divisible property to enable a dividend to be paid,
the bankrupt has not disposed of property in a transaction that is void against the trustee, and
the bankrupt earns an income which is less than the actual income threshold amount applicable to him or her at the time the application for early discharge is made.

SPEECH.PARA: This is provided for in proposed Subdivision C of Division 3 of Part VII of the Act, to be inserted by clause 27 of the Bill. Disqualifying criteria include where:

PARA.TAB: the bankrupt has previously been a bankrupt;
the unsecured liabilities of the bankrupt exceed 150% of his or her income in the year prior to the date of bankruptcy;
more than 50% of the bankrupt's unsecured liabilities are attributable to the conduct by the bankrupt of business activities; and
the bankrupt has given false or misleading information about his or her assets, liabilities or income.

SPEECH.PARA: The disqualification criteria are set out in proposed Subdivision D of Division 3 of Part VII of the Act, to be inserted by clause 27 of the Bill.
Decisions by trustees in relation to early discharge will be subject to review by the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy and by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
Income Contributions

Section 131 of the Act currently provides that a bankrupt is able to retain income for his or her own benefit, subject to any order of the Court to the contrary. Section 131 has not been a particularly useful instrument for trustees in bankruptcy to employ. The court process is costly to invoke and, frequently, neither has the trustee funds available to initiate the process nor are creditors willing to advance funds to the trustee to enable the trustee to take action. Frequently, once made, orders are not complied with by the bankrupt. The only sanction for non-compliance with a contribution order is imprisonment for contempt of court. This is a severe sanction, and not particularly useful—an imprisoned bankrupt cannot earn income to contribute to the estate.

Many bankrupts earn quite large incomes but, for the reasons I have mentioned, they are not required to make any repayment to creditors from that income. In a case where the bankrupt has few, if any, divisible assets, the creditors will get nothing out of the process notwithstanding that the bankrupt may have a considerable capacity to pay. Furthermore, some bankrupts manage to put their assets out of the reach of creditors, and channel income away from themselves while still retaining a benefit, through the use of associated individuals, companies, partnerships or trusts, which are referred to in the Act as `associated entities' of the bankrupt. These associated entities may, and usually do, provide the bankrupt with substantial non-cash benefits, such as free or low cost housing, motor vehicles, boats, and payment of expenses. Very often the entity employs the bankrupt, and by virtue of that employment, the entity is able to generate substantial income. If the bankrupt ceased to be in the employment of the entity, its capacity to derive income would be lost.

The Bill tackles these difficulties. The term `income' is defined to include not only income according to ordinary conceptions and usages, but also to include benefits, which, if they were provided by an employer to an employee, would be taxable as fringe benefits under the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986. `Income' will also include the amount of any money or the value of any other consideration, received by a person other than the bankrupt from another person or associated entity as a result of work done or services performed by the bankrupt.

A trustee in bankruptcy will be able to make an assessment of the full extent of the income likely to be derived by the bankrupt during the contribution assessment period. The contribution assessment period will be an annual period beginning at the commencement of bankruptcy, or the commencement of the amendments, and subsequently on each anniversary of that commencement, until the bankrupt is discharged, or the debts of the bankrupt are paid in full. Where the debts are paid in full, the bankruptcy will be annulled by operation of law.

In making an assessment of the bankrupt's likely income, or income likely to be derived during a period, the trustee will be able to have regard to any information about the bankrupt's employment or income, whether provided by the bankrupt or some other person. In a case where the bankrupt claims not to be in receipt of income, or claims to be unemployed but is nevertheless engaged in activities which resemble employment or other work, and which in fact generate or are capable of generating income for the bankrupt or some other person or associated entity, the trustee will be able to treat the bankrupt as being in employment and as deriving income. The trustee will be able to make an assessment of the bankrupt's income having regard to income likely to be derived by a person engaged in similar activities, under an industrial award or an arm's length contract of employment.

The Bill provides for a base income threshold amount equal to 3.5 times what at any time is the maximum basic rate of pension. This is prescribed under Item 3 Column 3, Table B, point 1064-B1, Pension Rate Calculator A in the Social Security Act 1991. As at 1 July 1991, this would reflect a gross annual income of $22,886.50 for a person with no dependants. `Income', for the purposes of determining the actual threshold amount and liability to contribute, will mean income net of tax and child support liabilities.

The actual income threshold amount will increase by percentages, based upon the child support percentages contained in the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989, according to the number of dependants—for instance, where there is one dependant wholly dependent on the bankrupt for economic support, the percentage increase in the base threshold is 18%, so that the actual income threshold amount applicable to such a person would be an after tax income of $21,388 ($411pw). Such a bankrupt, earning $22,308 per annum after tax ($430 pw) would have to contribute $9.35 per week. While a bankrupt with two dependants and an after tax income of $440.00 per week would be required to contribute $3.17 per week, a bankrupt with two dependants and an after tax income of $700.00 per week would have to contribute $133.17 per week. Proposed Division 4B of Part VI of the Act, to be inserted by clause 25 of the Bill contains the details of the assessment and collection process.

There will be provision for the Official Receiver in Bankruptcy to authorise departure from the relevant contribution level in cases of hardship for medical reasons, and other reasons specified in proposed section 139T of the Act. Decisions by trustees in relation to income assessments will be reviewable by the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy, and by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Persons whose assessed income is below the proposed `actual income threshold amount' will not be liable to make compulsory contributions, but may do so voluntarily.

The Bill also proposes the insertion of provisions enabling the Official Receiver to collect moneys owing by way of contribution from persons other than the bankrupt. The provisions enabling this to be done, proposed sections 139ZK and 139ZL, are based on section 218 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and corresponding provisions in other legislation such as the Social Security Act 1991, the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, and the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986.
Objections to Automatic Discharge and Related Changes
Section 149 of the Act currently provides for the entry of objections to the automatic discharge of a bankrupt on four grounds, namely that:

PARA.TAB: the conduct of the bankrupt has been unsatisfactory,
the bankrupt has failed to co-operate in the administration of his or her estate,
the bankrupt is likely, within 5 years from the date of his or her bankruptcy, to make a significant contribution to his or her estate, and
the discharge of the bankrupt would prejudice the administration of the estate.

SPEECH.PARA: These grounds are all rather vague and uncertain, and do not specify with sufficient particularity just what the obligations of bankrupts are, and what conduct is likely to result in an extension of the bankruptcy. The Bill proposes that these grounds be replaced by new grounds of objection designed to make the bankrupt fully aware of his or her obligations, and to encourage the bankrupt to co-operate with the trustee in carrying out the administration of the estate.

The new grounds for objecting to the automatic discharge of the bankrupt are set out in proposed section 149D of the Act, to be inserted by clause 27 of the Bill. They include matters such as the bankrupt continuing to manage a corporation contrary to the Corporations Law, failure by the bankrupt to provide information about assets, liabilities and income where required by the trustee to do so, departure by the bankrupt from Australia without permission or failure to return where requested to do so, and failure by the bankrupt to attend a meeting of his or her creditors, or an examination or interview about his or her affairs. Some of these grounds will extend a bankruptcy for a period of up to 8 years, whilst the remainder will extend the bankruptcy for a period of 5 years.

Two related changes involve making the period of bankruptcy run for 3 years from the date on which the statement of affairs is filed by the bankrupt, instead of from the date of bankruptcy itself, and automatic annulment of a bankruptcy where the debts of the bankrupt are paid in full. In the case of bankruptcy on a debtor's petition, the date of bankruptcy and the date of filing of the statement of affairs will almost invariably be the same, since a debtor's petition cannot be accepted by the Registrar unless it is accompanied by a statement of affairs. Currently, in the case of a bankruptcy by sequestration order on the petition of a creditor, the bankrupt must file a statement of affairs within 14 days of the date of the order. Quite often, however, the bankrupt refuses or fails to comply with the requirement to file the statement of affairs, and this seriously hampers the carrying on of the administration. To ensure that the bankrupt does co-operate from the outset of the administration, the Bill proposes that the period until automatic discharge will not begin to run until the statement of affairs is filed.

Where a bankrupt pays all of his or her debts in full, or makes a proposal for a composition or scheme of arrangement which is accepted by creditors in full satisfaction of their debts, amendments proposed by the Bill will have the effect of annulling the bankruptcy by operation of law. Under the Act at present, annulment of a bankruptcy can only occur by court order, even where the debts have been paid in full, or a composition or scheme has been approved. This is a costly and largely unnecessary procedure. The fact that upon payment in full of the debts the bankruptcy will be annulled by operation of law should act as a significant incentive to many bankrupts to make payment in full, or to come to a satisfactory arrangement with creditors.
Overseas Travel Restrictions

A bankrupt who is assessed as liable to make contributions to the estate from his or her income will not be able to travel overseas except by permission of the Court. Permission will be able to be granted for compassionate reasons related to the death or serious illness of a close relative of the bankrupt, or where overseas travel is necessary to enable the bankrupt to continue to derive income. It will be necessary for the bankrupt to make an advance payment of the contribution he or she would be liable to pay during his or her proposed absence from Australia, or to otherwise satisfy the court that arrangements will be made whereby the contributions liability of the bankrupt will be met. Permission will not be granted where it is established that the bankrupt has been guilty of conduct that would found an objection to discharge under proposed section 149D.
Recovery of Property by Official Receiver

The Bill will include provision to enable the Official Receiver, on behalf of the Official Trustee, and registered trustees to recover property, disposed of by a bankrupt in a transaction designed to defeat creditors which is void against the trustee, by administrative means instead of exclusively by litigation. Setting aside void antecedent transactions by litigation can cause difficulties for trustees, and bankrupts can arrange their affairs on occasions confident in the knowledge that no action will be taken to set aside the transaction because of the costs associated with doing so. The new administrative procedures provided for in proposed Subdivision J of Division 4B of Part VI of the Act to be inserted by clause 25 of the Bill are based on provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and will enable more cost effective setting aside of void antecedent transactions and a correspondingly greater return for creditors.
Official Receiver Powers to Make Inquiries

A significant measure included in the Bill, again based on a provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, is proposed Division 2 of Part V enabling the issue of `off-shore information notices' where evidence about a bankrupt's financial affairs and dealings is located in a foreign country. Where such a notice is issued, and the information is not provided as requested, the information will not be admissible in subsequent legal proceedings relating to the bankrupt, unless the person to whom the notice was directed proves that he or she was not in possession of the information, and that he or she could not have taken any reasonable steps to obtain it.
Clarification and Codification of Meeting Procedures

The Act currently contains only limited provisions to deal with the manner in which the business at meetings of creditors should be conducted, and in complex bankruptcies, where there are many creditors, difficult questions of procedure at meetings sometimes can arise. The Bill proposes the insertion of provisions to spell out clearly the procedure which ought to be followed at meetings of creditors, so that trustees are aware of their responsibilities, and creditors are aware of their rights.

The Bill also includes provision to enable creditors to remove a trustee by resolution, rather than by special resolution as at present. A resolution is passed when a majority in value of creditors vote for the proposal, and a special resolution is passed where a majority in number and at least three fourths in value of the creditors vote in favour of the proposal. It is considered that with respect to the important question as to who is to occupy the office of trustee, the creditors with the most significant financial stake in the administration should not be outvoted by more numerous small creditors, as can happen under a special resolution.
Technical and Consequential Amendments

The Bill will correct outdated references in the Act, and make amendments consequential to the enactment of other laws which have previously been omitted to be made. A number of areas of uncertainty, for example in relation to the right of a registered trustee to draw remuneration, will be clarified by the Bill. Mechanical provisions to aid in administration will also be included, such as a provision for the automatic indexation, in line with the Consumer Price Index, of various money amounts specified in the Act.

The Bill will make important reforms in bankruptcy, and will considerably modernise the Act's operation by extending the application of administrative law principles to decisions of trustees and bankruptcy officials, and by introducing Administrative Appeals Tribunal review.
Financial Impact Statement

The proposed income contribution scheme will result in more funds being available to pay creditors. It is estimated that in the second and subsequent years of operation, an additional $3.1m per annum will be available to Commonwealth creditors, especially the Australian Taxation Office, and a further $6.2m per annum will be available as increased dividends payable to community creditors generally. In addition, it is estimated that the Insolvency and Trustee Service, Australia (ITSA), the Division of the Attorney-General's Department with responsibility for bankruptcy affairs, would take additional fees and other income of $2.2m in the first year of operation, increasing to $3.3m including fees taken by the Federal Court of Australia, in the second and subsequent years.

Because the administration of the contributions and discharge schemes will be labour intensive, ITSA, which handles well in excess of 90% of all bankruptcies each year, will require additional staffing resources, costing approximately $1.09m in a full year of operation. Initial set-up costs, including the provision of computer connections, will cost approximately $507,000.
I commend the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.
THERAPEUTIC GOODS AMENDMENT BILL 1991
I take pleasure in introducing the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1991 to the Senate.

The amendments provided for in this Bill are necessary to accommodate certain changes to the drug approval process which were recommended by Professor Peter Baume in his "Report On The Future Of Drug Evaluation In Australia" and which were subsequently accepted by the Government for early introduction.

The principal thrust of these reforms is to give greater recognition to the need for early access by the Australian community to new drugs, provided of course that due attention is still paid to their safety, quality and efficacy. Thus one of the amendments is to the Objects of the Therapeutic Goods Act to provide specific reference to the pursuit of timely availability.

Following the introduction of certain changes to both application requirements and to the evaluation process it is intended to introduce certain target times for the processing of applications, with a financial penalty on Government in instances where those targets are not met. It is necessary to amend the Act to provide for the formal adoption of targets specifically recommended by Professor Baume.

Reducing the amount of information which is required in support of a marketing application means that greater responsibility rests with industry to report accurately and fairly on the various studies and trials which have been conducted and, where considered necessary, to provide ready access to supporting data. Professor Baume deemed it appropriate, and the Government has accepted, that companies should be penalised should they fail to honour this greater trust.

Another important aspect of the proposed reforms relates to access to unapproved drugs. In the case of patients who are seriously ill with a life-threatening disease it is proposed to leave the use of unapproved products to the patient and his or her practitioner to determine. In other cases the limitations on access are to be reduced. It is also intended to more widely delegate the authority for approving the supply of unapproved drugs. A number of amendments have been necessary to accommodate these changes.

It is intended that companies should be able to make, without prior approval, certain changes to the information provided to doctors concerning a drug. These are safety related changes, where it is important that the company make the changes as quickly as possible. Amendment to the registration procedures is sought for this purpose.

Apart from the changes made to accommodate Professor Baume's recommendations, a further amendment has been included in this Bill. This relates to certain labelling requirements presently applying to registrable therapeutic goods that are intended for export only. The Bill removes the need for sponsors of such goods to comply with labelling requirements that have relevance only for the Australian market.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
