SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No 4) 1991

The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No 4) 1991 gives effect to a number of Budget initiatives which were announced in the 1991 Budget, some non-Budget initiatives and some amendments of a more minor nature.

The earnings credit allows, on an annual basis, maximum rate pensioners to accrue the value of their weekly income test free area up to $1,000. The credit is offset against earnings which would otherwise reduce pension under the income test. Once the credit is used up, normal income test provisions apply.
The earnings limit is to be indexed from the first pension payday in July 1992 so as to maintain the limit in real terms as an incentive for pensioners to take up casual, full-time or part-time work.

The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No 3) 1991 provided for the implementation of two initiatives relating to rent assistance. When introducing the (No 3) Bill, it was indicated that a further initiative relating to rent assistance would be included in a bill to be introduced later in the current Sittings.

Currently, if a beneficiary under 60 years without children is receiving rent assistance and ceases to be entitled to his or her benefit for more than 4 weeks, he or she has to serve a 26 week waiting period to requalify for rent assistance. The No 3 Bill provided for this waiting period to be reduced to 18 weeks from 20 March 1992.

This Bill provides that from 20 March 1992, for job search allowance recipients under 60 years without children, the allowable break in basic entitlement to income support before a person will have to serve another waiting period will be increased from 4 weeks to 6 weeks. Similarly, for newstart allowance recipients under 60 years and without children, the allowable break in basic entitlement to income support will be increased from 4 weeks to 13 weeks.

Where a person ceases to be entitled to benefit for no more than 6 weeks or 13 weeks as the case may be, he or she will be able to count the number of weeks already served whilst in receipt of benefit towards the 18 week waiting period.

The Bill will also effect changes relating to the treatment of compensation payments from 20 March 1992. First, persons receiving certain social security pensions and benefits who are injured while doing part-time or low income work and who subsequently receive periodic compensation payments, will have their compensation treated under the normal income test rules. Secondly, sole parent pensions will be included in the group of social security payments subject to direct deduction as a result of the receipt of periodic compensation and a period of non-payment for receipt of lump sum compensation.

Where only one member of a couple receives income support, the maximum rate payable to him or her is the same as that for a single person. There is no clear justification for paying a higher basic rate of pension or benefit simply because the person's partner does not receive income support.

Accordingly, for claims granted on or after 12 March 1992, the maximum pension or benefit entitlement of a member of a couple living with a partner who is not receiving a social security pension or benefit or similar payment will be the married rate of pension or half married rate of benefit. This limitation will also apply to the rate of pharmaceutical allowance payable to a member of a couple with a non-pensioner or beneficiary partner. These measures will not apply to existing pensioners or beneficiaries as at 11 March 1992.

The payment of pharmaceutical allowance was introduced in November 1990 to offset the introduction of a charge for pharmaceutical benefits for persons who had previously received prescriptions free under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. As an interim measure, the Government decided that certain persons were to be eligible for payment of advances of that allowance until 31 December 1991.

The Bill will extend the period in which advances of pharmaceutical allowance will be payable until 31 December 1993. The Bill will also remove the special assets test limit that previously operated for the payment of advances together with some modifications to simplify the advance payment scheme.

The Social Security Act permits the Secretary to the Department of Social Security to prepay social security benefits if a client's normal payday would fall on a public holiday. A prepayment of social security benefit made to a client who is later found not to have been entitled to the payment will, from 1 December 1991, be a recoverable overpayment under the Act.

The Bill will make two beneficial amendments relating to child disability allowance. A person will be able to receive child disability allowance during periods when caring for a disabled child who is home `on leave' from an institution, even if the institution continues to receive family allowance for the child. Further, it will now be possible for payment of child disability allowance to be apportioned between two persons in cases where the care of a child is shared.

From the day of Royal Assent, penalties under the Social Security Act relating to fraud will be aligned with those applicable to similar offences under the Crimes Act. This emphasises the seriousness with which the Government views social security fraud.

Also from the day of Royal Assent, any copy of a determination by the Minister approving a scholarship or class of scholarships for the purposes of the Act will be subject to tabling in Parliament. This measure is in response to a concern made by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills when it considered the Social Security Legislation Amendment Act (No 2) 1991.

The Act provides for agreements between Australia and foreign countries relating to reciprocity in social security matters. Such agreements are incorporated into the Social Security Act as schedules to bring the Agreements into force so that they may modify the Act as appropriate. Agreements were signed with Ireland and Portugal on 8 April 1991 and 30 April 1991 respectively and will be inserted as schedules to the Act.

Amendments will also be made to the Act to revive the old reciprocal agreement between the United Kingdom and Australia. The old reciprocal agreement was omitted from the Act on the basis that a new Reciprocal Agreement had been signed by both countries and was to have been implemented by the beginning of 1991. However, as the United Kingdom has been unable to undertake all steps necessary to enable the new reciprocal Agreement to come into effect by that date, the old reciprocal agreement needs to be revived as an interim measure.
The Bill provides for some minor technical amendments to be made to the Social Security Act to enhance the efficiency of social security administration.
Amendments will be made to the Act to ensure that it accurately reflects the policy as it stood on 30 June 1991 in its predecessor, the Social Security Act 1947, before the latter's repeal.

Amendments will also be made so as to clearly indicate that money which is exempted by the Minister from the operation of the deeming rules will not use up the deeming-free amount ($2,000 per person). Further, the Minister will have a power to nominate the date of effect of his decision to exempt specified money from the deeming rules so that arrears can be paid from that date.

The Act will be clarified so that the wind up of a managed investment fund through transfer of assets to another managed investment fund will constitute a realisation for the purposes of income assessment. This rule applies to market-linked investments and accruing return investments.

An amendment will be made to the Act to allow a person holding a market linked investment, and the manager of that investment, to request the Secretary to determine the current rate of return on that investment with effect from the date on which the request was received, notwithstanding that the fund manager or investment product has not been specified in a notice in the Gazette.

Amendments relating to job search and newstart allowances, the Aboriginal Employment Incentive Scheme, the rates of benefit payable where one member of a couple is in receipt of ABSTUDY, the indexation of pharmaceutical allowance, the reciprocal social security agreement between Australia and Malta and the rules relating to the portability of wives/widows pension for those women who have more than 10 years of Australian residence will also be made.

Finally, a minor amendment will be made to the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990 to include the date of birth of a living spouse as one of the details that can be used in the data-matching process. This will further enhance the effectiveness of that process. The Privacy Commissioner has indicated that he has no objection to the inclusion of this detail.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991

This Bill proposes amendments to Veterans' Affairs and associated legislation to give effect to a number of measures included in the Government's 1991 Budget package which impact on veterans. These measures have been developed to improve the quality of life and health care for veterans and war widows and to generally improve the administration and delivery of these benefits. I must emphasise, however, that many of the 1991 Budget measures assisting veterans do not require legislation but are being implemented by other means.

Some changes, such as the provision from 2 January 1992 of emergency short-term home relief for veterans and war widows, the choice of in-home respite care and veteran support networks, the expansion of the Financial Information Service for Pensioners, the extension, from 1 December 1991, of Repatriation treatment benefits to Australian Merchant Mariners of World War I and World War II on the same basis that applies to Australian war veterans and the increase in the rate of mileage allowance for veterans who use their own vehicles from 12.28 cents to 18.5 cents per kilometre, are being implemented through administrative arrangements or delegated legislation.

One other improvement to benefits announced in the Budget, the replacement of the telephone rental concession vouchers with the payment of a telephone allowance, will be included in legislation to be brought forward in the 1992 Autumn sittings.

This Bill also contains proposed changes to give effect to a number of non-Budget measures. These relate to changes in the arrangements for payment of advances for pharmaceutical allowances, indexation of pharmaceutical allowance and changes to the operational areas in Schedule 2 to the Veterans' Entitlements Act to include the area of Iraq and Kuwait and to specify the periods during which certain areas are to be regarded as being operational.

In particular, this Bill gives effect to the decision to extend the co-payment arrangements for pharmaceutical benefits under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme to the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme from 1 January 1992. Some aspects of this decision do not require amendment of Veterans' Affairs legislation. The introduction of a patient contribution of $2.60 per prescription item requires an amendment to the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which is established in accordance with section 91 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. I have already signed and arranged for the tabling of the instrument to effect this change to the Scheme. That change will of course be dependent on the passage of this Bill.

Legislative amendment is required, however, for the payment of a fortnightly pharmaceutical allowance to offset the patient contribution. The Bill provides for this. It also includes proposed amendments to the National Health Act to ensure that existing safety net provisions will extend to Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme users.

These changes are an extension of the patient contribution scheme introduced in 1990 in relation to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme to address some of the problems associated with over-prescribing and over-supply of medication and to encourage sensible drug use throughout the community.

One other important change contained in the Bill is the provision for the maximum amount of earnings credit applicable to the ordinary income test, currently fixed at $1,000 per annum, to be indexed annually in line with movements in the consumer price index. Indexation of this amount will commence from 1 July 1992.

Mr Speaker, the provisions of this Bill, together with those changes which are proceeding by other means, represent an important step forward in the provision of benefits to veterans and widows and in the administration of those benefits.

The cost for indexation of the earnings credit account balance is nil in 1992/3, $20,000 in 1993/94 and $20,000 in 1994/5. The extension of the co-payment arrangements to the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and the corresponding payment of the pharmaceutical allowance will cost $1.1m in 1991/92, with subsequent savings of $10.5m in 1992/93, $11.4m in 1993/94 and $12.2m in 1994/95. The extension of the system for payment of advance pharmaceutical allowance, including advance payments to persons eligible for repatriation pharmaceutical benefits, will be $20,500 in 1991/92, $19,000 in 1992/93 and $8,500 in 1993/94. The changes to the indexation arrangements for pharmaceutical allowance, the concessional beneficiary charge and the general patient reduced charge are likely to result in net savings of more than $1m. The financial implications of the changes to the operational areas are negligible.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of Senator O'Chee and myself. We claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week, during House of Representatives Question Time, the Minister for Land Transport, Bob Brown, accused me and my National Party Senate colleague Bill O'Chee of outlandish statements and a deliberate misrepresentation over the new charges to apply to heavy vehicle registration under the National Road Transport Commission. Among other things, Minister Brown questioned our credibility, our integrity and our honesty and described our campaign to highlight the new charging structure as one of the most appalling exercises in political misrepresentation.

PARA.TAB: I must first place on record the fact that Senator O'Chee and I have worked vigorously and with gusto in raising the public awareness of the new charging structure. We have been in constant consultation with road transport industry representatives throughout the country and I have written to hundreds of shire councils, farmer organisations and media groups outlining the implications of the new charging structure.

The figures I have been quoting are derived solely from the working group's recommendations, which were noted but not endorsed at the July Special Premiers Conference. These figures show a two-stage charging system, with the first phase to be implemented from July 1993 to 1995, and the second phase to come in from July 1995 to the year 2000.

Under these figures it would cost $7,750 to register a six-axle articulated truck from July 1993 to July 1995 and the charges would go up to $14,400 from July 1995 for a typical road transport vehicle. As these figures are contained in the report released by the working group, I presume the Minister would not wish to contradict these figures.
It is the Minister who has engaged in misrepresentation. In a press release on 23 May 1991 Mr Brown said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Interstate Commission report into road user charging would not become the blueprint for Government reform in the land transport industry.

Let us compare that with the hard reality. Clause 20(3) of the Special Premiers Conference agreement signed on 30 July 1991 states that the National Road Transport Commission, in determining charges, is `to use a common methodology, initially based on the model employed by the Inter-state Commission in its 1990 report but enhanced with further research currently being undertaken by the Australian Road Research Board'.

Let us contrast the two statements. In May, in a completely misleading statement, the Minister said that the Inter-State Commission report into road user charging would not—I emphasise `not'—become the blueprint for government charges. Just one month later, the Special Premiers Conference, in line with recommendations from the officials of the working committee, wrote the Inter-State Commission's methodology into the agreement as a blueprint. The facts are clear. There is no doubt who is misleading the public and the road transport industry.

PARA.TAB: The working group's figures were devised using a complicated formula based on three factors: using a common methodology, initially based on the model employed by the ISC in its 1990 report, but enhanced by further research currently being undertaken by the Australian Road Research Board; initially adopting the expenditure allocation template to be endorsed by Austroads in the pay-go process; and making use of the Australian Bureau of Statistics survey on motor vehicle use of road task data, with appropriate upgrading as a source of this data. This formula was agreed to at the July Special Premiers Conference. In fact, full cost recovery is required except for road trains, which may attract a 50 per cent discount to the year 2000. In the Senate on 15 October, Senator Collins representing Mr Brown responded to a question from me by saying that the National Road Transport Commission would recommend charges by March 1992 to apply no later than January 1993 and that full cost recovery would be phased in by 1 July 1995, and 1 July 2000 for road trains.

The facts are clear. Clause 2 of the Special Premiers Conference agreement provides that `charging principles' means to fully recover distributed road costs while minimising over-recovering from any vehicle class, thereby achieving full recovery of all road costs. Clause 20 (3) provides:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Commission in recommending road charges and a road use charge to the Ministerial Council shall ensure that by no later than July 1, 1995 the principles it recommends comply with the charging principles, and recover fully the road costs of all vehicles based on average annual distance travelled, except for road trains, which are to receive concessions of up to 50 per cent of full cost recovery mass distance charges. Road train charges should achieve full cost recovery by July 1, 2000 at the latest.

There is absolutely no doubt that for almost all vehicles full cost recovery is to be achieved by July 1995. Moreover, in achieving full cost recovery there is absolutely no doubt that the National Road Transport Commission is constrained to use pay-go, use the ISC methodology, use the road expenditure allocation endorsed by Austroads and use Australian Bureau of Statistics figures.

PARA.TAB: Last week Mr Brown said that the total charge for six-axle articulated trucks would be between $7,000 and $8,000. If the Minister is fair dinkum about these charges, let him make a ministerial statement and provide me with a written assurance that his figures are right. If he fails to do this, I and the trucking industry will assume that my figures are correct. Will the total charge for a 42.5-tonne six-axle truck be $7,000 or $8,000 or will it be $14,400 in 1995? These are the questions that Mr Brown has to answer in the Parliament.

According to the Special Premiers Conference communique, page 18, fourth dot point, full cost recovery mass distance charges should be implemented with up to 50 per cent discount by July 1995 at the latest and be fully implemented by July 2000 at the latest. Under this charging structure the phase one charge from 1993 is to be $11,250. From 1995 the phase two charge will be $22,500 and the full figure of $46,400 is to be achieved by July 2000 at the latest. The trucking industry would love Mr Brown to indicate right here and now that those charges, as recommended to the Special Premiers Conference, will not be implemented.

I publicly challenge Mr Brown to tell us exactly what the charges will be. We know that the National Road Transport Commission will ultimately set the charges, but, in our opinion, the charges are locked in: they are based on ISC methodology which has been used by the working group to come up with its figures. The trucking industry is very cynical of Mr Brown and so too will be the public of Australia unless he can clarify this matter once and for all.

The Northern Territory Government has refused to come into the scheme because it knows the full implications of the charging structure and what they will mean for the Northern Territory. The trucking industry recently organised a series of meetings to air its concerns about the proposed charges. The meetings were held in country New South Wales, attracting 500 trucking operators. They were organised by an alliance of the New South Wales Road Transport Association, the New South Wales branch of the Transport Workers Union of Australia, the New South Wales Farmers Association, the Long Distance Road Transport Association, the Livestock Transporters Association of New South Wales, and the National Transport Federation. Surely, if everything was so sweet and rosy these organisations would not be holding such crisis meetings.

It is now time for Mr Brown to tell us honestly whether those charges will be $7,000, as he said in the House of Representatives, or whether those charges will be in the second phase of up to $14,400. But Mr Brown can no longer sit there and not give a clear definition of where those charges will end up when full cost recovery is implemented.
Debate resumed from 13 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night, prior to the adjournment of the Senate, I was pointing out the considerable pressure coming from the Opposition in relation to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. The Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, has finally come good with a definitive paper on the hardship clauses and the actual meaning of the liquid assets test. I must admit that he has done a fairly good job of that, and I am willing to support the Bill because I believe we now have a far more lenient hardship clause.

PARA.TAB: The most important aspect concerns amounts of money held in business accounts. The Minister's guidelines state that amounts held in such accounts are treated as liquid assets, except where the person can demonstrate that the funds are required for an essential and usual expenditure in operating a farm or business. This will mean a tremendous amount to small business and it will mean an incredibly lighter assets test burden for farmers. It will mean that working capital will be included. For instance, because it has not been stipulated that amounts from the previous year will be the only ones accepted as exemptions from liquid assets, if a farmer has not put superphosphate on his farm for several years it will certainly be considered as an essential expenditure if that were to be done in the following year, when the farmer would be looking towards the need for that extra fertilisation.

Not only that; superannuation lump sums and other payments will not be included as liquid assets. So the small businessman or farmer will not have to sell these assets to be able to apply for the hardship clauses. We could go through the whole list of assets that would not have to be sold prior to a farmer being able to apply for assistance under the hardship clause, but it really amounts to machinery, stock and anything applying to the business that is necessary for the running of that business or farm. That is why it was of concern to me when I heard Senator Harradine say that he believed that some farms would have to be sold before eligibility for the hardship clause was triggered.

Having dealt with the assets test for the family allowance, I would now like to spend just a very short time on the fifth point of my speech which covers the attempt to bring independent young persons into the Austudy entitlement. The Government knows that the term `independent young persons' is just a very nice way of referring to homeless youth. The situation has not been made better in the last few years, particularly following the promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that no child would be living in poverty after 1990.

We know that the number of homeless youths is increasing daily. We know that there have been homeless youths for some time. Indeed, I was chairman of a committee that looked into this very sad situation. I do not think that in the 16 years that I have been a member of the Senate, I have sat on a committee in the social welfare area that has really affected me quite so much as that committee which looked into homeless youth.

I am not saying that the Government has created homeless youth. The problem certainly existed when we were in government. No government can legislate for good parents. But the Government has done nothing following both the Burdekin report and our report, and the situation continues to get worse. Indeed, in the present situation, where we are in the middle of this depression we had to have, the numbers are only increasing. The Government's recognition of that is to try to bring these homeless youths into the Austudy entitlement.

I am not quite sure whether the Minister really understands the situation of homeless youths. He ought to go to the Kings Cross area and the shelters, follow them up and do as our committee did—go around every State in the Commonwealth and have a look at what these children are doing. Even though 15-, 16- and 17-year-olds may have grown up pretty quickly because they have been thrown out of their homes, they are still basically very young and inexperienced youths.

The main thing they lack is health care; they do not know how to go about it. Evidence given to us when we were in the shelters in Kings Cross, Sydney, was, `Please don't open any more shelters in Kings Cross'. I believe that any responsible person in charge of one of those shelters would also have given us that recommendation.

One person in charge of a shelter there said, `We do not take in any youth coming into the Cross now who does not originate from the Cross. We take him to a shelter outside the Cross because once he is established in the Cross he will not leave it'. This gentleman told us that he is really just there to pick up the pieces because the youths who work in the Cross do not even bother to get their unemployment benefits. Even though that unemployment benefit is no longer an entitlement for them, they are not even interested in going down and collecting the Jobsearch allowance and things like that as a substitute.

These young people find that prostitution and other methods of getting money are much easier. They earn far greater amounts of money than the paltry amounts—this is how it was put to us—`that you offer them and unemployment benefits are of no use to them and they do not bother to go down'. The shelters are only there when the whole of the prostitution racket gets on top of these young people and they fall to pieces; that is when the shelters take over and nurse them back to sanity. Once they step foot outside that shelter again, they are into it once more. The situation there is appalling.

I do not believe any of these young people would run away from home without unjust cause, for the reason that life on the street is far too difficult. We are led to understand that every one of those homeless youths who had been on the street for any length of time had been thrown out of their homes. I have said before in this chamber that perhaps the most horrifying story we were told was of a young brother and sister, younger than 15, who went home from school one afternoon to find that mum and the de facto father had just packed up and left the house, and there was no-one there to look after them. They went back to the school and slept under the school and in the school grounds until the teacher realised something was wrong and had them taken into care. One cannot legislate for good parents. I questioned one mother and asked her where her 15-year-old daughter was, and all she said to me was, `Don't talk about it; I don't want to know. My nerves won't take it'. We do not know what pressures that mother was under, but we do know that the daughter was under far greater pressures out on the streets.

I do not know whether the Minister believes that great numbers of these homeless youths will take up this Austudy entitlement or the entitlements being offered them under that scheme. I think one has to go a little further in the inquiries into homeless youth because the majority of them would not even contemplate returning to education or taking up those entitlements. We have to get at them before they reach that stage.

I must admit that our Committee did not bring forward any great recommendations that could possibly overcome the situation. We did try to bring forward recommendations on accommodation, because accommodation seemed to be the main assistance that they were requiring, and the accommodation that they were living in, particularly around the Cross, was unbelievably bad. If the Minister could start with the very basics of their needs—accommodation and health—and spend some money in those areas, I think far more homeless youths would be interested in accepting that sort of assistance. The Austudy entitlement is a wonderful thing, if only they would take it up, but I believe the numbers who will do that are very few and far between.

I am speaking only briefly on this Bill. There has been great concern about the hardship clauses. I will be following the committee stage in detail because I believe the hardship clauses are terribly important. On the hardship clauses of the family allowance assets test, I support very thoroughly the shadow Minister's amendment that the two-year restriction or time limit on those hardship clauses should be done away with.

We cannot say the recession in the rural community will last for only two years. Australia is a big country. In five years time there could be a dreadful drought and those hardship clauses must apply if that sort of thing occurs again. I hope that business will be able to recover from the recession in two years time, because we will be in government by then and I am sure we will be able to do something about it. In regard to the rural community, not even our government can say that there will not be another drought. Therefore, I support the shadow Minister's amendment on the abolition of the two-year clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief remarks on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991, particularly in relation to the hardship provisions that Senator Walters referred to in her closing remarks. As a result of negotiation and consultation in the past two or three weeks, progress has been made on the hardship provisions and whether a two-year limitation should be placed on their application.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) on the role he has played in addressing the many genuine concerns expressed around Australia about how the assets test will apply and how it will affect rural communities in particular. I congratulate the Minister on being very ready to discuss this matter and to ensure that the guidelines for the hardship provisions take into account these very many concerns. Of course, I recognise the role played by our shadow minister, Senator Alston, in negotiating these hardship provisions in consultation with the Minister.

From what we have been informed so far, we know that the hardship provisions will be very workable. They will recognise the reality out in the rural areas. The guidelines will be published and they will be tabled in this place. Through the normal channels of constituency inquiries, we will be able to monitor the effectiveness of those guidelines and, therefore, the effectiveness of the hardship provisions in rural Australia as they come into effect.

These hardship provisions are quite vital when we are bringing in an assets test. There now seems to be a bipartisan agreement that any form of Federal income redistribution, be it welfare or the family allowance supplement, needs to be targeted. As a nation, we cannot afford to hand out family allowances and other benefits to Australians who do not need them. It is important that we target income assistance to those people who are in genuine need. Using measures such as the assets test and the income test is one of the few ways in which we can achieve that targeting.

However, as we all know, no matter where we set the limit on any income level or assets test—$300,000 or $600,000 or, in the case of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), $2m; the figures become arbitrary—the value of farms and the depreciation in the value of farms and so forth becomes an issue. So it is vital to have hardship provisions which are workable. As I said, due to the negotiations that have taken place in the past three weeks, that has been achieved to a large extent.

In closing, I recognise the contribution that my colleague Wilson Tuckey has made in these negotiations. He has put a lot of pressure on members of our Party and he has reflected the views of many people in his constituency. From my point of view, this process has been a very good example of how the party structure can work—and I am sure that I speak for honourable senators on the other side of the chamber—if we have political parties that have an active membership and active cooperation between parliamentary members and lay members. We in the Liberal Party have received feedback from very many rural members, particularly in the O'Connor electorate. I make special mention of the president of the O'Connor division, Mr Murray Nixon, who has been very active in ensuring that Liberal Party senators in Western Australia are aware of the severe hardship in the rural areas of Western Australia.

The important thing about this two-year limit, as Senator Walters said, is that it is impossible for us to judge whether this rural recession—or rural depression—will come to an end in two years' time. The important point is, as Dorothea Mackellar said in her poem, that Australia is a wide brown land, and there is always a drought, a famine, a flood or a fire that affects some part of rural Australia. If these hardship provisions prove to be workable, which I am sure we can make happen across party lines, there is no reason to apply an arbitrary two-year limit.

The Opposition has spoken about a review after two years. I suggest that if we monitor these hardship provisions on a day by day basis, as cases come before us, that review can be on an ongoing basis and there is no need to say, `Let's review it in two years'. I have yet to hear the Minister give a good reason why there should be this two-year limit; I am sure he will refer to it in his closing remarks. I will certainly be supporting the shadow Minister's amendment to get rid of that two-year limit and ensure that the Parliament reviews the workings of the hardship provisions on an ongoing basis—whether it be after a year, two years, three years, four years or a decade.

I conclude by reiterating my congratulations and support for the sterling efforts of the Minister and the shadow Minister in making this Bill workable and meeting the interests of the very many people living in rural Australia who are suffering severe hardship in the current recession.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall endeavour to answer the concerns of most of the honourable senators who have spoken—I hope that the notes I have are adequate to do so. With respect to the comments made by Senator Campbell on the question of feedback and Mr Tuckey's interest in the matter, I think some of the views that were expressed by Mr Tuckey in the House of Representatives were echoed here by Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Panizza.

PARA.TAB: It is important to understand that there is no attempt to correlate the income test with the assets test in family allowance payments. We do not intend the $600,000 test to imply that we are deeming an income, if you like, of 10 per cent on the farm. I hope that can be explained to people. There are obvious ways we can tell that it is different. In any event, the amount is now not $60,000, it is about $62,000, and there are amounts to be included for children.

We have not attempted to have a correlation, and it is not meant to correlate. Rather, we are attempting to find a limit—and any limit is, of course, arbitrary. We have to settle on some limit and that has to be an arbitrary process by nature; it is always open to argument. We tried to set a limit which was pretty high, particularly when we are talking about net of debt. I think $600,000 is about right.

Senator Harradine has on many occasions raised the fact that when the family payments were introduced, particularly the family allowance payment, the Government stated at the time—I think it was ex-Senator Grimes—that these were not welfare payments. Some people suggested that if they are not welfare payments, they are payments to recognise the extra costs involved in having children and there should not be any targeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fraser Government introduced family allowances.

—We changed the system a bit. When we did, Senator Grimes made that statement, which I have actually quoted in the Parliament several times. In any event, while I accept the view that we should not have targeting in a tough sense, I believe that there can be room for some targeting, provided the income and assets limits are very high. In the case of family allowance, I believe that they are.

PARA.TAB: We have had some real cooperation on liquid assets and on working capital. We have had some requests for details from Senator Alston, which I hope we have answered to the satisfaction of the Opposition. In looking at an assurance that Senator Alston sought from me on the tabling of guidelines, there is no difficulty at all in giving an undertaking to do that and, further, to undertake to table any changes to those guidelines in advance. This is a matter of concern to honourable senators on both sides. I do not seek to have a process conducted in secret, so I have no difficulty in giving the undertakings which have been sought.

I now go through the amendments. We first have this argument about the two-year sunset clause, which was raised by Senator Walters, Senator Campbell and, I think, a number of other honourable senators. In having a two-year sunset clause I am not attempting to suggest that I can foretell the length of a rural recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —You won't have to worry about it, Graham!

—I think we will have to worry about if for years to come. When the Opposition announces its new tax next week, it will make that even more certain. Nonetheless, I do not believe that anyone can be prescient enough to make a guess on when the rural recession will end, and I certainly would not. All that one does with a two-year sunset clause is introduce an opportunity for the government of the day, whoever that might be, to review the situation. As Senator Sherry is saying, I am quite confident it will be us.

PARA.TAB: If one has eight years of relative prosperity in rural Australia, one wonders about the operation of hardship provisions. It is obvious that no form of social security payments should ever be used to keep farmers on the land if farms are not viable, and I certainly would not ever want to see that happen. We are not disagreeing about the operation of the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —When were the eight years of prosperity?

—The drought broke as soon as we got into government. There was no doubt that God was on our side; He has always voted Labor. We got here and down came the rains and from that day onwards things got better in rural Australia. I should hope that the Opposition and the Democrats understand that in saying there is a two-year sunset clause we are in no way suggesting that all this ends in two years. We are saying that is an appropriate period for review.

PARA.TAB: The system will have been in place then for quite some time. We can all see how it operates and have another look at whether it is still appropriate. If it is still appropriate then obviously it stays. But I do not believe that two years is unreasonable, and that is why it has been introduced.

The other amendment which will be coming from the Opposition concerns the reduction of eligibility for rent assistance from 26 weeks to 18 weeks. While the Opposition has now cleared up the obvious inconsistency it was going to have between Senator Patterson and Senator Alston on the young people about whom Senator Walters has expressed concern, I do not think that in any way weakens the force of the Government argument on this point. There is tremendous community pressure on waiting periods. I am constantly assailed by people who suggest that they are unfair and, particularly in times of recession, are causing undue hardship.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have always argued against that.

—I have continued to resist most of that pressure. It does not mean though that I do not examine the problems that people bring before me and see whether they have a case. When it comes to housing affordability there is a real case to be made. There is no question, looking at the data we got from the rent assistance evaluation, that DSS clients, especially if they are with children in the private rental market, have tremendous problems with housing affordability.

PARA.TAB: Even after receiving rent assistance the great majority—and that is about 87 per cent of JSA and Newstart recipients without children—pay more than 30 per cent of their income on rent. According to the national housing strategy that means that they are in financial housing stress. But 28 per cent of those clients are paying more than 50 per cent on rent. Looking at that, anything one can do to get quicker rent assistance to these people who are in obvious need will be the right thing to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why wait 18 months if that is right?

—The point is always trying to strike a balance. I have not walked away from the concept of waiting periods and do not seek to do so. But where they are operating harshly, and I am certain that this one is, then a modest reduction—Senator Lees would abolish the lot; I do not think she would advocate a reduction from 24 weeks to 18 weeks, she would be about none, and I do not propose to go that far—of a few weeks is the right way to go.

PARA.TAB: A number of honourable senators—I would not be exhaustive about this but including Senator Patterson and Senator Walters—spoke about the problems of the young homeless. I have been out to talk to young homeless people, I must concede not in every capital, only in Sydney and Melbourne, and Senator Walters is quite right. That is why the number of people receiving the allowance we have for them is so small compared with the number of children in this difficulty. Many of them are reluctant to approach any form of government because they fear authority. Many of the younger ones mostly fear being sent home and tend to shy away from government interference as they see it, and that will be a real problem for us.

In looking at how to address their problems one of the difficulties that is very quickly discovered is that even if they do receive any form of government allowance they do not have much in the way of life skills, having just left home at a very young age and, not having been taught these things, the art of financial survival has escaped them. Therefore, when they receive payments, they tend to blow them in the first day or two days and then are in some difficulty. So by attempting to pay them weekly we might in some way get around that part of the problem. We will make our financial information service available to them as well as to age pensioners and sole parent pensioners and, hopefully, they can have some budgeting done for them if we can get them that far.

By expanding the number of social workers in social security I hope we can target young homeless much more than we have in the past. One of the difficulties is that there have been so many cutbacks by the States—I do not single out any State because one can say all of them—in welfare that the number of social workers available to help these young people in need is very few.

Practically all of them are living by prostitution and larceny, which is hardly an acceptable way for anyone in our society to live, and the conditions in which they live are appalling. For both young girls and young boys rape is common. It is not an exception; it occurs every day. It remains unreported but because it is not reported it does not look any less horrible. The experiences of some 14-year-olds are really too horrible to contemplate.

I intend to try very hard to take the Commonwealth further into the area of homeless youth. That no doubt will be resisted by some of my colleagues, but I intend to make that my main push in next year's Budget. I do not know exactly where that runs with regard to the niceties of Commonwealth-State relations. All I know is that these children are missing out; they are falling through the net completely.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get some assurance of support money back for them.

—We are getting it back. I notice Senator Patterson is wrong again in her press release today but that is something we can cover later, at least I will. I think we as a Commonwealth should do more for them, and I intend to try to do exactly that. In reference to Senator Lees's comments, I am surprised really that the Democrats would oppose an assets test outright, especially one that is as high as this one at $600,000.

PARA.TAB: I do not think anyone in Australia really believes these days that governments have enormous amounts of money to spend on a whim wherever they like. Some targeting is absolutely necessary. In setting this amount, I think we have struck the right balance and, by introducing hardship provisions on which I think there is largely agreement, we have taken that right balance even further.

I note that, on the assumption that this arrangement fails, the Opposition thinks the family farm should in some way be excluded. This whole Bill really recognises the difficulty of those who are asset rich and income poor. That is what it is largely about. The rural community in particular is facing a hard time because not only does it have to deal with the recession but also it is faced with a downturn in some commodity prices, which makes life very difficult. So we are primarily about assisting those who are in small business. It is beyond me completely how one can exclude the family farm and even pretend that there is some form of targeting. As we go into the argument in the course of the next few minutes—or the next few hours, depending upon the wish of the Senate—we can flesh that out. But I do not believe that the measures we are introducing are harsh. Certainly, by allowing for hardship provisions we will make sure that people can still survive with dignity.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 25, page 10, paragraphs (c) to (h), lines 31 to 38, omit the paragraphs.
2.Clause 26, page 11, paragraphs (c) to (h), lines 8 to 15, omit the paragraphs.
3.Clause 27, page 11, paragraphs (c) to (e), lines 24 to 26, omit the paragraphs.
4.Clause 28, page 11, lines 28 to 34, leave out the clause.

These amendments relate to the proposed reduction from 26 to 18 weeks in the waiting period for various benefits and entitlements. For the first time, it is proposed to extend a rent assistance entitlement to the young homeless. I want to make it clear in moving these amendments that the Opposition is supportive of the extension of the entitlement for rent assistance to that group. But we do not accept the arguments advanced by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) in relation to the reduction in waiting periods.

PARA.TAB: I might just say that I think the Minister has withstood a great deal of pressure from various quarters. The argument seems to proceed on the basis that, because we are in a recession, somehow there is a more urgent need to make benefits available at an earlier time. The logic of that argument escapes me. It is perfectly clear that, as a result of this deliberate recession, many hundreds of thousands of people are in need of income support and will, therefore, have entitlements in due course. But it does not follow that the financial situation of these people has deteriorated any more so than in normal times. Therefore, the concept of waiting periods ought to be a valid one through good times and bad.

If, as the Minister says, there is a sufficient ability to isolate effectively from the outset a category of people who, it is said, are in urgent need of rent assistance, it does not make sense logically for the Government to be proposing a reduction from 26 to 18 weeks. I am sure the Australian Democrats will argue that everyone ought to be entitled to everything immediately.

I must say that the Government amendment has all the hallmarks of simply genuflecting in a particular direction so that the Government is able to claim that it is doing something in this regard. But the amendment does not appeal to us. We are not convinced that there is that need. Indeed, various other forms of assistance are available to people. The concept of a waiting period is deliberately structured in such a way that it is only after a certain period that one is regarded as being in need of assistance. Presumably one has moved from being a short term temporary recipient to having every prospect of being a permanent recipient. It is in those circumstances that the view is taken that such people ought to be given assistance.

There may be a better way of tackling the whole problem. We could try to target people from the outset rather than extending rent assistance across the board, irrespective of need. Whilst there may well be some people who are in dire straits from the outset, there will equally be some people who are not. I have certainly had people say to me, `It is all a bit odd, you know. I was on the unemployment benefit for six months and then I got a bonus'. They did not quite understand what it was. All they knew was that an extra amount was paid to them. It turns out that that extra amount is rent assistance. So the logic escapes even many of the recipients. That being the case, I think there is an argument for examining the actual needs of particular people. If it is demonstrated from the outset that the need arises, one attempts to deal with that situation. But where the need does not magically deteriorate or become more acute after a certain period—whether it be 26 or 18 weeks—one does not pay the money.

The Government's blunt approach, which may ultimately be necessary because in many instances one cannot deal with these things on a case by case basis, is probably the best we can do. But it does not in any way follow that, because some people may be in need from the outset, there is a justification for reducing the waiting period across the board.

The amendments support the extension of eligibility for rent assistance to one category of people who have been denied it to date. But I make the point that we are not persuaded by the Government's logic that the recession ought to be used as an excuse for somehow throwing a bit more money in a particular direction. A lot more thought ought to be given to how one ought to cater sensibly for people who are genuinely in need.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the four Opposition amendments. As I said yesterday, we welcome this long overdue and certainly very badly needed move. We believe that there is room for further consideration, particularly for those who are in need. But we certainly will not be supporting something that effectively takes us back to the status quo. I think Senator Alston would understand the problems if he spent some time with some of the welfare groups.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I covered this matter in summing up, but I will quote one figure in continuation of that. In May 1991, 59 per cent of all beneficiaries without children in receipt of rent assistance were spending between 30 and 50 per cent of their income on private rent, while 28 per cent were paying over 50 per cent. These are enormous figures. When there is that kind of desperate need, something ought to be done about it.

PARA.TAB: It is not a matter of the recession. The recession certainly puts more people in this category, but there would still be a lot of people in this category whether there was a recession or not. If there are people with housing stress then we have a duty to address it. I do not think that a reduction from 24 weeks to 18 is a major step in any way, but it is a useful step and one that we ought to take. If we are concerned about homelessness and do not do this, then all we do is condemn more people to it. I believe that requests put forward just have to be examined. The operation of this, as shown by the data on housing affordability, has been too harsh. That is why the Government is seeking to amend it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The corollary is that if there are 50 per cent of people in that category, there are 50 per cent of people who are not in that category. That is why I say that this is a very blunt instrument.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could help Senator Alston: 59 per cent plus 28 per cent is closer to 90 per cent. I would like to comment on what the Minister was saying with regard to homeless youth and his comments that he will be pursuing this issue. I suggest that he begin back in the State education systems which, by and large, are cutting many of the services they offered, such as truancy support, particularly through counselling. South Australia is even getting rid of behavioural support units and units that work with disadvantaged kids because, the argument is, it will save a few dollars. I suggest to the Minister that he consider looking at what the State governments are pulling out of and the way they are basically leaving kids on the streets to fend for themselves.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Clause 40, page 17, subclause (2), lines 37 and 38, omit the subclause.

This amendment deletes the sunset clause in relation to the two years. A number of my colleagues have pointed out that hardship will endure well beyond the two-year period which, presumably, is meant to be a proxy for the current recession. We all hope that it will be well and truly over before the end of next year; nonetheless, there has to be a recognition that there will always be people in conditions of hardship somewhere around the country at some time for various reasons—whether cyclical downturn, a fall in particular commodity prices or any other reason.

PARA.TAB: We have also made it clear that we are not persuaded by the Minister's response which is, essentially, `Initially, two years is an appropriate period but we will review it at the end of that time'. If the Minister were seeking to justify two years, he would be saying, `There is no need for a review. There is no need to talk about "initially". We are putting in two years for a very good reason, and this is it'. He has not said that. He has basically said, `This is stage one. We will have a think about it later'. Intellectually, that statement concedes the point that there will clearly be hardship situations after that time, unless he wants to stand up and say that there will not be.

On that basis we think this is a very important amendment that will clarify the fact that one simply has to recognise hardship whenever it occurs and not just simply for a limited time period. The Minister, having made a number of very important and welcome concessions in a range of other areas, should not spoil his track record on this occasion. He should, therefore, make the most of the plaudits that have been delivered to him from this side of the chamber and, presumably, elsewhere outside. If we can end up being in heated agreement on this one, it would be one of the Minister's greatest success stories that might somehow make up for all of those other failings that have been besetting him in recent times.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment, although we consider it is really tinkering around the edges. The hardship provisions in other areas of social security do not work when it comes to farmers. The Minister himself admitted this in a joint press release about 2 1/2 weeks ago when he acknowledged that farmers were finding it impossible to get into the real income support area, which is unemployment benefits, without actually putting the farm on the market. I understand there are so many of these cases that they are building up in the Welfare Rights Centre in Adelaide, and, indeed, many are being sent on to the Minister. I understand he will be getting another one today from 95 kilometres out of Wudinna. This is a family that had been living by eating only sheep for a number of weeks until its local doctor put it in touch with the local councillor.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, I have no faith that this hardship provision will really help those in need. What it is doing is assisting other Australians with incomes of up to around $60,000—indeed, I think that on my income I would still qualify for family allowance—whereas farm families have to be living under the poverty line. I do not accept that as justice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to the Minister's explanation that he would not accept the removal of that two-year provision because he hoped or presumed that the rural recession would be over by then. On another matter to do with homelessness he went on to say that it really was not about a recession.

PARA.TAB: I wonder whether the Minister is fully aware of what can happen in rural areas. The rural areas may return to a booming or good period any time from now on, but that does not mean that there will not be a pocket drought. He probably does not understand what a pocket drought is. I have seen rain shadows in a drought that have a radius of about 80 kilometres or 50 miles. That can happen for the whole year. In fact, there is a place in Western Australia, where Senator Crane comes from, where this has happened this year. It is a very isolated area and one could probably drive right around it before lunch.

As has been mentioned before, there can be other things such as a flood. A flood can wipe out a crop. Fire and hail can be insured against—and any prudent person would do so—but not flood. A pocket drought or a flood can happen at the best of times. I remember that in 1983 the drought in the eastern States was over and the price of wheat boomed, but Western Australia had the killer drought that the eastern States had the year before. We had high wool prices and high wheat prices, but what was the use of them because in Western Australia we had a drought.

Taking away those two years takes away the hardship provisions for hardships that can happen even if Australia is booming in the agricultural, manufacturing or mining sectors. Hardships can happen. That is why I cannot understand why the Minister will not agree to it. It is not going to affect the Budget this year or next year's Budget either. It can be reviewed in six months, 18 months, 24 months or at any time. I cannot understand why he is sticking on that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister a couple of questions about clause 40 of the Bill. First of all, I would like to place on record, as others have done, the genuineness of the Minister, the shadow Minister, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, Senator Lees and a large number of other people who were involved in bringing matters to the Senate's attention last night.

PARA.TAB: Before I ask the Minister a couple of questions, I say this by way of preface: we are here dealing to a large extent with the family farm and families on farms in Australia. Those families exist generally without subsidies because of our agricultural policies. I was a member of a recent delegation to the EC. As our principal mission, we had to show the problems that will emerge, both for the EC and for ourselves, and indeed for access by third countries, from the common agricultural policy.

It is clear that that policy subsidises production. There is a move now, including by the EC Commissioner responsible, Mr McSharry, that that perhaps should not be the case and that one should look at the need for income support for family farms in Europe. There are a number of reasons for that, not the least of which, of course, is that without subsidies farm families will have to move to cities where there are no jobs. Also, of course, the farmers are the manicurists of the environment and in that respect, if that were to occur, there would be some degree of devastation in Europe.

The same thing, of course, will apply here. I think we have to take that broad view when considering the question that is currently before us. We also have to remind ourselves of the fact that family allowances were never intended to be a social security welfare measure. They were intended, as has been stated time and time again, both by Labor and Liberal governments, to be part of the tax transfer system which recognises that a family with dependent children, at whatever level of income, has outgoings, including outgoings for indirect taxes, which are far greater than for families without children.

These people on the farms who are now battling because of the recession and because of drought and other aspects are behind the eight ball at the present moment. Am I correct in stating that in 1991 a family with four children is losing $49.60 per fortnight compared with the real value of the original 1976 family allowance payment? Those are the figures that I have developed and I would like to have them confirmed. If that is so, they are starting well behind the eight ball. The result will be that a number of families will be forced to sell their farms to become eligible under the current hardship provisions.

These hardship provisions take account, do they not, of assets but that the family concerned has to run the gauntlet of the income test as well? The fact is that many of them are in the situation of having repayment commitments on farm implements, harvesters and the like.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stock.

—As Senator Lees says, stock. I know of one case where a family had worked until their fifties in the furniture removal business. Two or three years ago they went into a farm, put everything into it that they had saved, and they borrowed money to buy the sheep. One might say in hindsight that that was a business decision which was not wise.
—They didn't know interest rates were going to climb so high; how could they plan for that?

—That is right. There are a number of factors that they could not foresee. Now, of course, they are stuck: they have to sell the farm. They have interest repayments, and the interest repayments and other commitments mean that their income, though it is above the income test, is not sufficient to meet their circumstances; therefore, they have to sell the farm.

PARA.TAB: That is what I am talking about. It is not only an assets test that we are talking about; it is also an income test. I would like the Minister perhaps to comment on that. I recognise that he is aware of the problems and has been working quite strenuously and taking representations and I congratulate him for that. I know that his position is very difficult indeed. But I come back to the point of principle: if we had stuck to the principle that family allowances are not a social welfare measure but a tax transfer system, we would not be in the position of having to determine hardship provisions.

As to targeting, the Minister, in his reply to the second reading debate, stated that there needs to be targeting. I agree. I was one of those, through the SDA, the shop owners and all the rest of it, to make a case out for the lower paid, but that is a welfare case. FAS is a welfare situation. I was one of those to indicate my support for that. I thought that I owed the Committee of the Whole that explanation, and I would like to hear the Minister's response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) say that former Senator Grimes had stipulated, when he made alterations to the family allowance, that it was not a social welfare payment. May I briefly state the history of this payment, as I did in my earlier remarks. Child endowment was a direct tax transfer in full recognition that the family with children had more expenses than the family without children. If it had remained as child endowment, I doubt whether the Government would be introducing this legislation. Indeed, I doubt whether it would have introduced an income test on the family allowance. With the best intentions in the world, the Fraser Government altered child endowment to make it family allowance so that the mother, who is the primary carer for children, would actually get in her hand the dollars that we believed were needed for the benefit of children.

PARA.TAB: In the true sense of the word, it was no longer a transfer of tax; it was paid directly to women. When we did that I can remember a number of not only women but also men saying, `What an awfully good idea'. For once, the mothers got the money. It was not just that the husband no longer paid quite as much tax; the mother got the money. It was a very important alteration. The intention was still that it was a transfer in the tax situation.

The Department of Social Security made the payments of family allowance purely for convenience, nothing else; it was nothing more than that. That was acknowledged, as the Minister has said today, by Senator Grimes who said, `It is not a social welfare payment; it is just a transfer'. He acknowledged that, for convenience purposes alone, the allowance was paid through the Department of Social Security. Yet in the second reading speech in the Senate the Minister said that family allowance is the only major social security payment not subject to an assets test.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a social security payment.

—The Minister can muck around with splitting hairs, if he likes, but he is saying there that it is not a transfer of tax, with the acknowledgment that those families with children have additional costs that families without children do not. The Minister is saying that it is the only major social security payment not subject to an assets test. It was done for pure convenience by the Department of Social Security, not as a social security payout. I believe that the second reading speech is contrary to what the Minister has acknowledged in winding up the second reading debate today. I would like him to clarify that aspect.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the Minister is now saying, `Children are a luxury; if you want them, you have to support them. If you are poor or you are on a lower income'—we have all spoken of the assets test and given descriptions of what is occurring in the rural community today—`and you want them, you will have to pay for them. There will no longer be a tax situation. It is a social security payment'.

That is why I am against the whole concept. But I am supporting the Bill because the Government's hardship clauses are more generous than I thought they were going to be. They are generous, given the working capital situation of a small business, a farm or any other industry in the rural community. A lot of people feed off the rural community. When the rural community goes bust, many small businesses go bust with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —And farmers around all the major cities of Australia if that happens.

—That is right. I am thinking of some of the machinery businesses which are not making two bob because the farming community is not renewing machinery. The Minister has made it clear that the farmers will not have to sell their stock and working capital will be allowable. The working capital plus the $13,000 income which will be permitted could take income levels to $60,000, if you like, so long as it can be established that the remainder of the amount will be spent on the business or farm. I would like the Minister to readdress that basic concept of family allowance. Just what is it in the eyes of the Government?

—Senator Lees has already indicated that the Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment, not so much because we share Senator Walters's faith that the hardship provisions achieve a lot. In fact, we believe they are difficult to comply with and difficult to gain anything worthwhile from. Perhaps it is because of something that Senator Panizza was saying, and something that is true. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) may well believe that the present recession in the rural areas of Australia will retreat in the near future and in two years time hardship provisions may not be necessary. Those who understand Australia's rural situation, like Senator Panizza, know that at any time throughout Australia's history there have been people in rural Australia who have been suffering one form of hardship or another.

PARA.TAB: Surely, if a family is eligible for hardship provisions to apply it is eligible and if there is no hardship, if everything is hunky-dory in the country, the family is not eligible. Why there is a need for a two-year sunset clause escapes me entirely. The measures are there to provide for people who are in hardship and it is not for us to apply a timetable as to whether hardship will occur. If hardship is there, it is there. If people are eligible, they are eligible. Why put a timetable on it? I just want to emphasise that. I cannot see the need for us not to support this amendment. As Senator Lees has indicated, we will be doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to reiterate some of the comments that have been made. It is beyond me why a sunset clause is included in the legislation. Hardship, as we know and as I mentioned in my speech during the second reading stage, can occur in good times and bad times. It can occur within a particular industry when world commodity prices are high and it can occur because of fire, flood and a whole host of different reasons.

PARA.TAB: I would like to address a number of questions to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) about the hardship provisions. I raised these in my speech in the second reading stage last night. I have to acknowledge that the hardship provisions have come a long way from where they were a fortnight or so ago. The first point I want to raise relates to shareholdings in public companies which are suppliers of products to the people in a specific industry. In Western Australia—I believe this applies in other States where there are monopolies in the manufacture of fertiliser—many farmers have very small shareholdings in Wesfarmers Ltd, for example. They can range from $500 to $5,000. The shareholders get a substantial rebate in the price of the fertiliser because they hold shares in the company. More importantly, it allows the farmers to keep control of the operation of the fertiliser works.

Exactly the same situation applies to another Western Australian company—I could go through a number—S B S Rural Ltd, which was established by virtue of the action of farmers to help themselves. Originally it was a private company, but it is now a public company. Once again, we have a situation where a large percentage of the farmers have a small shareholding in the company. The principal role of those companies, particularly S B S, is to supply farm merchandise. It would seem to me that, because a small investment has been made in those companies so that there can be some competition in the marketplace with the pastoral houses and others, it would be totally counterproductive to force people to quit those shares to become entitled to the family allowance. As I said before with regard to the fertiliser works, it would stop farmers getting the rebates they get when they trade with those companies and it would be part of the process of moving control of the companies out of the hands of the people who utilise them.

I raise that point with the Minister. I make a plea to him that these situations be taken into consideration in the further development of the guidelines; otherwise it will be counterproductive in the long term. These are not shares from which people get huge dividends; the main benefit is in the rebate for trading.

The other matter I want to raise relates to the IEDs. As I said last night, I accept that IEDs are a realisable asset. However, I ask that consideration be given to the fact that, in times of drought, when people are forced to sell stock they may put the realisation from those sales into IEDs for the purpose of restocking. I ask that that be considered and that we not have a situation where IEDs used for such a purpose have to be realised; otherwise the purpose—the practice that has been used on a number of occasions—would be defeated.

The other matter I want to put to the Minister relates to the situation which exists in relation to education. There are examples—I happen to be one of them—where people put aside money, over a number of years, for the education of their children. Many people have no other choice, because of their geographical isolation, than to educate their children through the private school system. If people have designated funds for the education of their children in later years—children who are often seriously disadvantaged in terms of the education system—I think it would be totally wrong if those funds were to be considered a realisable asset. I request that the Minister give consideration in the guidelines to allowing any moneys that have been set aside and designated for education purposes not to be considered as part of realisable assets.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to address all of the points that have been raised. When I first came into the chamber this morning I acknowledged that the family allowance was a payment to recognise the extra costs that families incur because they have children, and I have not changed that view. Senator Walters pointed to the words in the second reading speech. Senator Walters is probably right: while those words are technically correct, because family allowance is a social security payment, it is not social welfare. That distinction could have been made, and I wish it had been. I do not dispute it, but it is still technically correct. It is not as though the honourable senator can say that the second reading speech is wrong.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine made the point that a family of four would be $49.60 per fortnight worse off in 1991 than it would have been in 1976 had appropriate increases been paid since then. My departmental officials are unable to verify that exactly. They would have to do some calculations, but they feel it is probably close to correct. That is because in the years of the Fraser Government the payments were increased only twice and they were not indexed. They were ad hoc amounts which did not even pretend to cover what the increases might have been.

All I can say to Senator Harradine is that we must all understand that in the Budget process, when the ERC sits down to draw up a Budget, this has to be done on the basis of compromise. It is not as though every proposal I bring in gets up. I wish it did, but I have not found a way to achieve that yet—nor can anyone else; we are all in the same boat. So the proposals honourable senators see before them are not necessarily those that I thought would be perfectly appropriate. I have to balance priorities within the portfolio and the ERC has to balance its priorities across government. So while I can acknowledge what Senator Harradine and Senator Walters have said—it is undoubtedly valid—at the end of the day we still come back to where the priorities lie in expenditure.

I think what we have done here is about the best that can be done. As soon as an income test was put on the family allowance, the pristine nature of its simply being a transfer payment and therefore not subject to any form of targeting was lost. The battle was lost when that was done. From my point of view, when I am trying to frame a social security budget which will give some relief to the rural community—essentially that is what we are talking about; more so than small business—and I have to come up with a balance, I think I would rather be looking at an assets test at $600,000 or more, with a hardship provision for people with high assets who are nonetheless income poor, earning less than $13,000 or whatever the figure is in here; it is a pretty low figure. I think that is about as fair a proposal as we can come up with. It is not what I would advocate in an ideal world but, as honourable senators are only too well aware, this is not an ideal world. This is a compromise, but it is, nonetheless, as fair a compromise as I could come up with.

In terms of the comments of Senator Panizza and Senator Bell about the two-year limit, it still comes back to what I am talking about: a question of balance. These are only some of the provisions we will put up to assist farmers. Honourable senators should appreciate that when we resume there will be amendments to the next social security Bill that will go further and involve the RAS scheme and assessments there, which will mean assistance for another couple of thousand farmers. We are talking about quite radical changes to the social security system. They are not minor. The next lot of proposals actually change the definition of unemployment, which is about as fundamental a change as one can get.

Naturally enough, the economic Ministers are concerned to ensure that the changes that, if you like, undermine what has been a longstanding principle do not lead towards a further undermining of the system.
