So, where we get a hardship provision that in certain circumstances allows for the income test on family allowance, for example, to be virtually disregarded, there are those who are concerned that there is an inevitable flow-on effect and that income testing, which is so important as a basis in social security, can suffer. So there is a concern to ensure that there is a two-year limit.

I said earlier that I would not pretend to nominate two years as marking the end of the rural recession. If we are talking about the recession at large, I hope it is over a long time before then; but I am not really sure about the rural recession. These are the reasons why the Government regarded it as quite important to have a two-year sunset clause—to see how it worked and then review it. I agreed in the end that this was a fair thing to argue for. Had I not been prepared to accept those kinds of concerns from economic Ministers during the Budget deliberations, honourable senators would not have these proposals before them. So I am caught betwixt and between. I cannot back off on this question of two years. I am bound to stick with it, and the Committee will have to divide.
Senator Crane raised some queries. The first point related to public companies. He was talking about Wesfarmers Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wesfarmers and SBS Rural Ltd.

—Yes, that is right. It is very difficult to just look behind a public company to see where these exceptions would be made. I also think that there are probably definitional problems. One difficulty is that when hardship provisions are introduced they have to operate consistently and across the board. If they do not, not only is their administration a nightmare but we get into all sorts of problems with people not understanding the rulings. The more they are varied, the harder it is for clients to understand.

PARA.TAB: I do not know how we are going to get out to 17,000 people around Australia an adequate mechanism for judging which public companies should come within the ambit of this legislation and which ones should not. We have already excluded producers' cooperative companies. Most of them are public companies. I do not know how much further we can go. If there is a way of doing this under guidelines that are clear—

TALK.START.PARA: —Couldn't they be looked at on an individual basis?

—It is very difficult to just allow individuals to be assessed without rules because then there will be an inconsistent application across 300 offices around Australia, and we cannot have that. I could not support that idea. If there is a way—and I am happy to look at it—of making a definition that will not lead to too great a problem or too great a floodgate, I am happy to try to have a look at that with the Opposition.
—What about allowing a minimum parcel?

—I said that I am happy to have a look at this with those opposite. I am just flagging that there is a difficulty because I have to have a system that is consistent across the board. But I am happy to have a talk to Opposition senators about how we might best do it. Perhaps they could give some thought to the definitional difficulties in the meantime. But I am happy to have a look at it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane also commented on people putting aside money for school fees. I am not as sympathetic to that idea. There is a difficulty in that, right across the board, people put aside money for school fees; I did a few years ago and I dipped into it a few times when other things occurred. That happens right across Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like a Labor Party levy.

—I do not think that I will comment on that. Right across the board families make provisions for their future, be it education or other things. All sorts of Australian families have to change their plans because their circumstances alter. I do not think that there is any proper way of saying that families in rural Australia can put all that aside because I have no doubt that they are dipping into those funds now. It is not as if every family has money that is kept aside for school fees and it stays there forever in perfect condition until the children go to school.

PARA.TAB: It is also worth noting in the operation of this test that people can prepay, which many families do. If they wanted to, or if they are of a mind to and they are determined that they will never vary their intentions regarding this money that they put aside, they can prepay it. I admit that is difficult if a child is just born, but in many cases people would be able to do it. I am not as sympathetic and I do not think that I can make Senator Crane a promise regarding that proposal. It would be very hard to implement.

Equalisation funds was another matter that Senator Crane raised. These funds will be counted but once spent on restocking, hardship provisions can apply. So I do not think that is such a great problem in any event. If we have the money today and it has to get spent on restocking, once it is restocked people can apply and get the payment. I am not certain that will be all that great a problem because it is really only a question of timing. Once that is understood, I do not believe that it will be such a great problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens if the gap is three years?

—Again, one of the difficulties is to what purpose moneys get put. Farmers are obviously different in some respects from other people; they live a different life to the one I lead. It is obviously a tough life and at the moment it is tougher than usual. But the idea that all farmers can put aside funds and always stick to what they put those funds aside for is really the same as for anyone else in a business; it does not always work that way. It is hard for us to give a general rule when, even on farms, it does not always work that way. I find that idea very hard to implement.

PARA.TAB: I really worry about the effect this has on all the staff who would have to administer it. If I cannot give them a clear and distinct direction, we simply finish up with a mess. Appeals become impossible because the Social Security Appeals Tribunal also has no idea what rules it will assess it under. So I do not think that proposal makes for good government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make one comment on the Minister's last point and clarify precisely what I said. I said that in the situation of drought, where the funds which were realised from the sale of stock were put into IEDs for the purpose of restocking, they should be able to be left there until such time as the drought broke. That is very precise and it is not difficult. All people would need is the receipt showing what they receive from their stock, be it cattle, sheep or whatever. I do not believe that alongside that receipt it is at all difficult; it is a very simple exercise.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —The essential test with IEDs or anything else is whether people can get at the money. It is liquid if they can get at it. I do not know the details; I would not pretend to. If people are in a situation where the money is tied up and they cannot get at it for a period but, at the end of it they can get it and restock, I do not have a problem with what Senator Crane is saying. But if people can get at it, it is liquid. If it is liquid, that is the very purpose of having this test. When it is liquid, it gets used for all sorts of things. With all the best intentions, it is not as if the plans that any of us can lay down for where we will be in three years necessarily get fulfilled.

—I want to quickly comment on what Senator Crane said. If people can see that a drought is looming and they sell their stock and put it into IEDs to buy stock later on when they come out of the drought, surely that can be classed as working capital that the Government will exempt. Is that not right?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite happy to also have a go at implementing this. I am not trying to be difficult. I will certainly agree to consider what honourable senators are saying. I will meet with them over the next few days and see whether we can settle on a definition in the guidelines that will do this. I just want them to understand that I must have a consistent rule; I do not have a choice on that. The only times I am going to have a difficulty is with what is referred to as liquid. I want to settle this question. I am not trying to make it hard for farmers. If I can fix it up in the guidelines, I will.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that we will not need to move an amendment in that we will simply be opposing clause 38. However, I ask the Minister for Social Security to pick up something Senator Harradine mentioned earlier. The Government has been advising other nations, particularly European nations, to internalise their support for their farmers, rather than, as they are doing at the moment, using trade and tariff support. If the Government is encouraging other nations to support their farmers in this way, why is it that here in Australia we do not support our farmers either through direct tariff assistance or through the welfare system, the social security system? I am sure that the Minister will agree that getting access is very difficult for farmers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I will answer that part of the question relating to tariffs. I will allow that to occur in other debates with other Ministers. I would not pretend to have it within my portfolio, and my colleagues look too closely over my shoulder whenever I seek to comment outside it.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Lees asks why we do not support our farmers through the social security system, the first thing that should be noted is that there are about 4,000 farmers and their spouses on social security benefits, mainly JSA, at the moment. It is not as if it can be claimed that there are none; there are quite a few. The purpose of the exercise today is to increase the number, and it will be further increased in two weeks time. That does not in any way encompass the numbers of people who are getting the family allowance supplement; there are a lot of people in that category. So I do not think it is fair to say that we do not support them through it.

Having said that, and I mentioned this earlier, what still has to be decided is whether or not it would be economically sensible to allow the payment of social security benefits to keep people on the land if their farms are not viable. There must always be a judgment made about that. It is not a judgment that should be made by my Department for the reason that it does not have that kind of expertise. That is why, in the legislation we will be dealing with in the week after next, it will be the people within the RAS scheme who will make these decisions rather than the Department. I was quite insistent about that. It is not an expertise we have, nor is it one we would seek to acquire.

So there is a threshold question there that has to be answered. If we answered it by saying that it would not matter whether or not the farms were viable in the long term, and we simply paid the unemployment benefit, I do not think that would be to Australia's advantage. Rather, Social Security has to be concerned with individuals and we are certainly living up to those obligations with the 4,000 who are receiving payment now and the extras who will receive it as a result of this legislation and the next piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lees, are you moving amendment No. 1 or are you moving more than that?
—Dealing with amendment No. 1, my comment related to how exactly it would be dealt with. I understand that we simply oppose the clause, rather than move the amendment formally.

—I know we are covering a fair bit of ground, but I thought it would be appropriate to raise another matter now and give the Minister the opportunity to take advice on it. As to the education entry payment, we support the idea of enabling sole parents to take advantage of the $200 payment. However, clause 14 provides that a person will be eligible for that education entry payment if the person is a sole parent pensioner and is qualified to receive an education supplement under the Austudy eligibility requirements for full time study, whereas the explanatory memorandum suggests that the EEP will be available for both full time and part time study. I would like that matter clarified.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be some changes made to ensure that Austudy is available for those in part time education. That should clear up the problem that Senator Alston raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just state finally why the Democrats will be opposing clause 38. This particular assets test is the one we have problems with. To continue with what the Minister was saying earlier, targeting is desirable as long as we do not target to the point where we are cutting out people in need. I see no problem at all with an assets test that talks about luxury assets, and assets that can be easily realised at a time of need so that one can have the cash necessary, but to include the tools of trade for farms and small business is not desirable.

PARA.TAB: As we have heard from many speakers, the farming community is in a situation where it cannot borrow any further and it certainly cannot sell off a paddock here and a paddock there to put food on the table. We are getting to the point where many very viable farms are being let go and many families are being forced off the land into cities to simply add to unemployment queues. While I do acknowledge that there at least has been some movement by the Government on hardship provisions, some recognition that we do have a major problem in rural Australia, I still do not believe that the Government understands that its free market policies have been causing most of these difficulties. The farmers are not to blame. At last it is nice to see in some of our major dailies some recognition of the fact that government policies are causing these problems. I will quote very briefly from an article by Russell Mathews in today's Canberra Times. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Free-market policies are killing the Australian economy and causing hardship and financial ruin for millions of Australians.
He goes on to say:

The financial system is in tatters as a result of its own greed and extravagant lending policies, carrying the fortunes of hundreds of thousands of farmers, small businesses, home owners, superannuants and investors with it.
He further says:

In sum, free-market policies have proved to be an unmitigated disaster. They have not even been uniformly applied. Free trade applies to imports, but, because of the policies of other countries, not to exports. Structural reforms entrench existing privileges and inefficiencies and do not reform.
I stress that the Democrats will be opposing this clause. As I realise we do not have the numbers—the Opposition has made that very clear—we will not be calling for a division.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that clause 38 stand as printed.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.After clause 38, page 14, insert the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "38A. After section 838 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Exemption from assets test for family allowance for primary producers

PARA.TAB: `838A. In calculating the value of a person's assets for the purposes of paragraph 838(1)(d), where:

TAB.TAB: (a)the person has his or her principal home on a farm that is owned by the person, the person's partner or the person and his or her partner; and
(b)the person ordinarily works in a full-time capacity as a primary producer on the farm; and

(c)the value of the whole or part of the land comprising the farm including the value of any improvements to or on the land would, but for this subsection, be included in the value of the assets of the person; and

(d)the value of items of plant or articles owned by the person, the person's partner or the person and his or her partner, and used wholly and exclusively for the purposes of primary production would, but for this subsection, be included in the value of the assets of the person;

SPEECH.PARA: the value of the assets of the person does not include the value of the land referred to in paragraph (c) or the value of the items of plant or articles referred to in paragraph (d).`.".

Now that we have an assets test on the family allowance, I wish to remove the assets test from the family farm, from the tools of trade. I will explain this amendment again. It is very specific. It is for the benefit of farm families. Paragraph (a) of the amendment reads:
The person has his or her principal home on a farm that is owned by the person, the person's partner or the person and his or her partner.

The second paragraph states very clearly that the person ordinarily works in a full time capacity as a primary producer on the farm. So the amendment is very specific. It is not for large corporations. It does not involve luxury assets. It is talking specifically about the family farm. If the Minister has acknowledged the hardship that is in rural Australia, why does the Government continue to refuse to acknowledge that the family farm simply should not be in an assets test?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I really acknowledged this when I was summing up at the end of the second reading debate. If we were to exclude the family farm from the assets test, there would be no point in having an assets test at all. Just because the farm is owned by a family does not make it a good, bad or indifferent farm. Farms will obviously vary depending on location and on the quality of management. In any event, as I think Senator O'Chee pointed out, the way this legislation is written, excluding the family farm would not help those that are set up as companies, and many of them are. Apart from that, basically what Senator Lees seeks to do here is undermine the concept of the test with which we have just agreed. I cannot accept that.

—I indicate that we take that view. Excluding the family farm is effectively dismantling the whole concept of the assets test. The Democrats tried it on the first leg and did not succeed. It has been acknowledged almost universally on our side of the chamber that the line has to be drawn somewhere, and all they are really doing is chipping away once again. We will not be supporting any of these amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As it now looks as though we will not be getting support for this amendment either, I ask the Minister whether he will be prepared to assist farm families to find their way through these new hardship provisions by supporting welfare rights centres in all States for at least 12 months with some additional funding; in this way the Government can assist farm families to find their way through these new hardship provisions as well as those that are already in existence.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I saw representatives from welfare rights centres around Australia. They acknowledged that there is not a welfare rights centre in rural Australia. If I were to assist the welfare rights centres, I would be assisting everybody except farmers, unless farmers were prepared to go into the cities.

PARA.TAB: Although this has nothing to do with the legislation before us, I have indicated to welfare rights centres that I will be supporting a submission next year for them to get some money, as I did this year. I got rolled this year, but given the recession and the extra load imposed I may be successful next time. I doubt very much whether even welfare rights centres would claim that would be of any assistance to farmers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Adelaide Welfare Rights Centre is working extensively with farmers; in particular, it is looking for a long term OO8 number so that farmers can get ready access by phone, at least, and also some support for brochures and other information that can put farmers in touch with the necessary assistance. I acknowledge that it would not be terribly feasible to have welfare rights workers wandering around the countryside, but the South Australian Government has given some short term assistance and it is being used very effectively. We now need to look at ongoing assistance throughout Australia so that farmers can, firstly, know where to go and, secondly, access that assistance fairly readily.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to prolong this part of the discussion. If I were seeking to help welfare rights, it would never be on the basis of helping farmers—there are other organisations better set up to do that. I think farmers are entitled to assistance. I would have thought that organisations such as the National Farmers Federation would be in a better position to help farmers than welfare rights centres—they are really not set up for it. I will still support welfare rights centres getting some money.

—I ask a question of the Minister now that we have an assets test. I understand from the Bill that the assets test will commence on 1 January, which is not very far down the track. Does the Minister envisage that the assets will be in place by 1 January? How will the farmers and others who are receiving payments know whether they will lose the payments? They will be wondering whether they will still be getting the payments. Is there enough time to get everything done between now and 1 January, bearing in mind that the silly season is coming and that at Christmas everything shuts down for a week or so? I would like an opinion. It is all right for the ones who will continue to receive the payment, but now is a very awkward time for those who lose it. What is the situation? Can the Minister comment on that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Social Security never sleeps. The Department is there to serve and it will serve all the time. I do not doubt that we can be ready in time. When it comes to these asset valuations, it has to be remembered that, mostly, they will be done by self-assessment. It is only where people put the value of their farm at $599,999, or close to $600,000, that we will be seeking—
—You would advise them not to, would you?

—No; if the farm is valued at that, fine. From what I have read this week, the AVO timetable is 60 days at the moment. From memory, we accept about 80 per cent of the valuations which are self-assessed. It is not as though we need a long lead-up time for this.

—In other words, the Government will send out a form to all of the families receiving assistance and they will have a certain time to reply if they want to keep their entitlement; is that correct? How is the Government going to go about it?

—We have actually sent prior notice of this out. I have explained to Senator Panizza before that we have to do that occasionally, particularly when we have indications that a measure will be supported. Everyone who is on family allowance will get a notification of what the details are. They will be encouraged to contact our officers if they believe that they will fall foul, if you like, of the new provisions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of questions on the method of assessment. Will the AVO be the final arbitrator in terms of what the value is? Are we going to have the same situation as we have with Austudy where, if some four months, five months or 10 months down the track the recipient is reassessed, they have to pay the money back?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —Where there are disputes, we will accept the AVO valuation as being authoritative. I do not think there will be many disputes. As I said, most self-assessments are accepted. In fact, we are not having many arguments about this at all at the moment. I do not expect that the number of disputes will grow. It has to be remembered that there is an appeal mechanism; people can appeal where they feel aggrieved.

—I will ask that question again: if some five or 10 months down the track the AVO goes in, after an assessment has been accepted, and reassesses the value just above the threshold, does the recipient—as with Austudy—have to pay back the family allowance?

—The answer is no. I do not understand how we get to that position. If the Department has accepted a person's assessment that a property is valued at $X, it will not be sending the AVO in. The AVO will be called in only in the minority of cases where there is a particular reason, information, to suspect that a valuation is incorrect or where the nominated value is very close to the limit.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to dwell on this, but it is a particular problem with Austudy. In South Australia I have 40 or 50 cases where the value was accepted at the time of application and Austudy was paid. In one case, it was nearly two years before the family's property was revalued and they now owe over $6,000, which they are being forced to pay back. I am trying to make sure that we have it on the record that, if a valuation is accepted—in other words, the farm family self-values and someone in the office picks up the valuation and says, `Right, we start paying the family allowance'—and some time down the track the farm is revalued by AVO, the family does not have to pay the allowance back. The Department does spot checks such as on Austudy. This is what alerted me to the problem. The AVO valuations in South Australia are consistently well above State valuations and local council valuations. In good faith, many hundreds of people have been caught out by a revaluation that is significantly higher. We need to get it on the record here that, once someone has accepted the valuation and family allowance is paid, down the track—no matter how many months later the property is revalued—there is no question that the family ever has to pay the allowance back.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give the assurance that Senator Lees seeks. I really do not believe that it will be a problem because it just will not happen.

—I thought that it would be only in a situation where someone had put in a self-assessment that was not in good faith, and the Government discovered down the track that there had been clear, fraudulent intent, that the Government might seek to recover payments. If it is simply a matter of coming up with a bigger and better valuation in due course, for whatever reason, and the Government accepted that the earlier valuation had been in good faith, the Government would seek to cut off the allowance from that point.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —We would only insist on moneys being returned where fraud is involved. Where fraud is involved, no deals are available—the person pays back the money, and other action may be taken against that person. That has always been the case and will remain so. In the very unlikely case of a revaluation—I do not think it will happen at all—we will not ask for the money to be paid back.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We still have a loophole and a problem. I state to the Minister very clearly that this is happening now with Austudy.
—But it is not happening with us.

—Fine. But the Government is now going to be using the AVO, which is the same system as we have had problems with in South Australia. The Minister is saying that if a family goes in and self-values on its council rates or on the valuation from the South Australian department the Government will accept that and there will never be any question of fraud later on down the track.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to labour the point. The only circumstance under which we would be seeking to get the money back would be if someone had misrepresented a valuation to us. It would have to be a clear case where that person had deliberately misrepresented the valuation to us. If that person has misrepresented the valuation, there is no problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief because this is not the time to debate the question apropos of clause 38M and proposed clause 38B. Let me place on record what former Senator Grimes said on 12 April 1983 at the National Economic Summit Conference:

SPEECH.PARA: It is often forgotten, however, that the family allowances are not and were never meant to be a welfare program in the strict sense. Rather, they are designed to achieve a broad measure of equity in the tax transfer system between those with and those without dependent children. They recognise that at any level of income those with children face higher costs than those without.

PARA.TAB: Seen in this light, family allowances offset to some extent the tax liabilities of those with children so that their net contribution to revenue is reduced in reflection of their lesser ability to pay. Immediately prior to 1976 this was achieved by the dependent child tax rebate. I point out that no one at that stage had ever suggested that this tax rebate should be means tested.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that should be on the record. I understand what the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) said. I have read between the lines and appreciate what he has said. But I really do feel that we are digging a big hole for ourselves here. If or when the GST comes in—

TALK.START.PARA: —When.

—If the GST comes in, the action that is now taken which is undermining that principle so clearly announced by the then Minister will result in large numbers of families paying extra by virtue of the fact that this family allowance measure is not regarded as a tax transfer system.

PARA.TAB: As I read in the Australian this morning, Dr Hewson proposes targeting offsetting provisions only to those who are presumably eligible for FAS—all other families can go to blazes by the sounds of it. I do not want to pre-empt what he might say next week, I think it is, when the Opposition will make some announcement. But I do believe that what is being done here is setting a precedent for a further undermining of that principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although it does not follow on logically from the remarks made by Senator Harradine, and although we have had indications from the coalition that it will not be supporting this amendment by Senator Lees, perhaps a last ditch attempt might not be misplaced to convince the coalition that to support this would not be inconsistent with the policies and philosophies it has espoused in other places at other times.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees used the analogy of the problems with valuations with regard to Austudy qualifications from the AVO. I should like to use the analogy of Austudy again in pointing out to the coalition that its shadow Minister for education, Dr Kemp, received considerable publicity recently in the Australian. The report said:
Dr Kemp said a Coalition government would temporarily suspend the assets test for families in "extreme economic hardship".
"It would mainly apply to farm families," he said.

SPEECH.PARA: In saying that, Dr Kemp received immediate and considerable support from the Executive Director of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Rick Farley, and some several column inches of the Australian were devoted to saying what a good idea this was and how wonderful it would be. But that was a promise which could only be delivered by the coalition when in government. The coalition had that opportunity to deliver that very policy some six or so months ago and it has the opportunity here and now to act in a manner which is consistent with that statement. Either that claim is meant or it is just a kite that has been flown around to attract the attention of people such as the National Farmers Federation.

PARA.TAB: It is all very well to gain support and to achieve publicity by saying that something will be done. Here we have the opportunity to act in accordance with that very statement and to follow that philosophy. But what do we find? We find excuses being made for not following it. Senator Alston has said that it is an attempt to dismantle the whole concept. I do not think it is, but I do think that the whole concept at the moment is not working too well and it would not be a bad idea to modify it slightly. Yesterday we had Senator O'Chee suggesting that this amendment as worded would not help certain farm families. A little cooperation from the coalition might have helped it come to terms with that and develop an amendment which did not suffer the inadequacies identified by Senator O'Chee, if there are any. I do not believe there are any but, rather than find an excuse not to support it in that way, a little cooperation might have helped the coalition reach the point which was identified by its spokesperson on education.

In this process we do not see the coalition demonstrating a real concern for rural Australia. What we see is a set of excuses being found for not taking a step which will actually do something and have the most immediate effect for rural Australia. I get a little tired of these excuses being trotted out. When an opportunity is presented, when will the coalition take some action to actually assist people?

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I am being asked to respond to that very broad-brush stuff which does not take account of any of the concessions that jointly we have managed to achieve in relation to hardship. Dr Kemp was saying that there are circumstances of hardship that ought to be recognised, particularly in rural areas. They will continue to recur—that is why we have taken out the two-year provision—and we will be looking to ensure that the hardship provisions remain permanently available across the field. That will be our position in due course and the Australian Democrats can wait until they see the detail of that. But what they are doing here has nothing to do with hardship; this is all about trying to retain some shell of an assets test, which will then involve a whole series of assessments as to what should or should not constitute an asset.

PARA.TAB: If one then takes out the family farm, the land, the value of the business and all these other bits and pieces, I am not really sure what one is left with, apart from the ski lodge and the second boat. As far as we are concerned, the approach that ought to be taken is the hardship track and not the successive emasculation of assets test provisions, and I am sure the Democrats will understand that if they apply their minds to it; they are quite different concepts.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lees's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Amendment negatived.
Progress reported.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to direct a few remarks to the question of industrial relations in this country, concentrating particularly on the housing industry, and to link in what is happening with the overall thrust by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, to impose upon the industrial relations system a higher and more entrenched position of power for the trade union movement, as against the way in which the ethos is moving in all industries to see a lessening of trade union power and an empowerment of individuals—which is, of course, in line with the Opposition's policy.

PARA.TAB: There has been much speculation on what might be contained in the statement that we shall hear today concerning employment. Indeed, perhaps there will be some statement relating to the better cities program and just what that is meant to be. But it is important to put on the record some of the things that that better cities program may, in fact, be really about. In other words, is there a second agenda, and, if so, what is it? It is important to look at what might be the second agenda in light of the sorts of statements that we have had from Senator Cook over the period that he has had responsibility for industrial relations.

I begin by referring to a statement that he made on 19 December entitled `A Presentation of a National Reform Strategy for the Building Industry', a reform that was initially developed to affect the non-residential building industry. However, it is important to put on the record what Senator Cook said were the most important principles or elements that would be involved in the strategy.
He said that there were seven principles that were important in the building industry, and that those seven principles were:

SPEECH.PARA: One:
adherence to awards and formal industrial agreements;
Two:
adherence to National Wage Case principles;
Three:
implementation of award restructuring, in practice on site;
Four:
adherence to contracts that conform to a national standard which excludes provision for increases other than those permitted on a strict rise and fall basis or fixed price;
Five:
compliance with established national standards for occupational health and safety;
Six:
prohibition of "all-in" or "cash-in-hand" payments;
Seven:
continuity of employment practices.

This last principle means that through effective superannuation, severance and redundancy schemes, building workers will be given the option of establishing long term career paths in the industry rather than having to wander from job to job chasing work. Of course, that seventh principle must be seen in light of the Government's and the ACTU's—and bear in mind that in one sense they are really one and the same, in that the Labor Party is the political wing of the trade union movement—long and committed fight against the right of subcontractors to remain subcontractors, to remain outside the unionised work force, and to be able to conduct business in their own right.

PARA.TAB: When we look at just what the better cities program may entail, it is most important that we understand that the ACTU and the Government are opposed to the rights of subcontractors. In particular, they are opposed to the success that the Melbourne firm Trouble Shooters had in opposing the trade union movement and the now acknowledged right of people to act as subcontractors.

When one looks at how this national reform strategy has changed from its initial perceived task—and that was to look at the non-residential building industry—it is interesting to see that it is now being administered in conjunction with Mr Howe, and that somehow the residential building industry, which has up to now been pretty successful in keeping the trade union organisers at bay, could be an avenue by which the Building Workers Industrial Union in particular might be able to extend its power.

I understand that there was a nice little meeting held at the beginning of October which involved none other than Mr Sharkey, and involved the Minister, Mr Howe. I understand that the meeting also involved Senator Cook. As a result of that meeting the BWIU sent an invitation to people in the industry to come and talk about how they may all be acting together.

I now turn to the better cities program to look at the way in which the Government may use that program to try to extend union power. Let us suppose we take one of the designated sites which is to have mixed development—both commercial and residential. Let us suppose there is an over-arching agreement reached between the ACTU and a major contractor or a prime contractor or, indeed, an industry organisation. Let us suppose that home builders—people who are normally involved with building residential buildings—were allowed to tender but were allowed to take part in one of these developments only if they adhered to and conformed with the over-arching agreement that had been reached between the trade unions and another party. This would give the unions the ability to be involved in the residential building industry, which, as I said, they have been kept out of until now. Quite clearly, it was the intention of those people who are engaged in that industry to work as they do with subcontractors.

The industry is itself quite determined and quite clear on what it believes it is entitled to do. The industry regards as inviolate the rights of the self-employed contractor and his right to employ and work alongside award employees. The industry believes that the recruitment by unions and employer groups of on-site workers should be voluntary. There is a feeling, as I said, that the better cities program might be seen by the building unions as allowing them an opportunity to impose working conditions on housing sites which previously have applied only to the commercial and industrial sector. There is a strong feeling that to change the way in which that part of the industry works at the moment and to be subject to the sorts of work practices and conditions as have been in existence in the industrial and the commercial sector, and thus change the working relationship that exists in the housing sector by somehow using a contrived definition of housing, would certainly be an unwarranted interference.

In addition to the two matters that I have raised, there is a third ingredient. I understand that there is to be a building construction industry council. That council is to have attached to it a reform agency which, it would seem, is to be charged with the responsibility of allowing the trade union movement to move its power into the housing sector—from which, as I said, it is at the moment excluded. People are happy with the way that they work and they do not want that involvement of unionised power.

The other thing that is quite worrying about this council is that the rumour mill has it that the chief executive of this so-called reform agency is to be paid, or receive a package of, something in the vicinity of half a million dollars. That is a pretty attractive sort of payment. Maybe it will go to what we might call one of the favoured sons of the trade union movement, who will be given plenty of leeway to be able to extend union power.

We already have the situation where Minister Cook made it quite clear in the last industry statement that he brought down that it is his aim to do away with common law rights, that he wants to get rid of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act and that he wants to see a labour court administering a labour law which would meet the trade union definition of a suitable industrial framework.

Indeed, that is quite at odds with and quite distinct from the Opposition policy which, as I said before, is to give rights and empowerment to individuals and allow the quite radical thought that employees and employers ought to be able to have discussion together without the intervention of a trade union. That would allow a freeing-up of the workplace, which would enhance productivity and perhaps let us finally begin to make repayments of our overseas debt.

The main thrust of what I have had to say today relates to the housing industry. People who are engaged in the building of residential dwellings have fiercely fought for their right to be independent of the very strict and damaging unionised movement; they cherish and, indeed, adhere to the principle of the right to have subcontractors; and they believe that individuals have the right to employ themselves and to work alongside people who are employees, and be distinct from them. The Opposition certainly admires the way in which they have conducted themselves. We must put people on alert that the better cities program is not to be used as a Trojan Horse for the trade union movement to extend its power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer today to one of the projects which I understand was to be fast tracked in order to create jobs for some of the one million people who are unfortunately unemployed at the moment in this nation of ours. I refer to the extremely unsatisfactory situation that has developed at Kambalda in Western Australia. The events that have occurred there in the last week are beyond belief. They have been caused by what I would term the stupidity of the leaders of the Australian Workers Union (AWU) in turning their backs on the agreement that was reached between Western Mining Corporation and the AWU, under the chairmanship of the Deputy Premier of Western Australia, Ian Taylor, who also happens to be the State member for the area.

PARA.TAB: I have a copy of the agreement. The following words at the bottom of that agreement, signed by Ian Taylor, are worth reading:

I confirm that the above correctly reflects the understanding reached between WMC and the AWU at the meetings which I chaired in respect of future underground work practices at Kambalda Nickel Operation.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the impact of what has happened, we find that an additional $103m-odd will not now be spent at Kambalda to expand that operation and create some jobs, and that some 150 jobs will be lost.

PARA.TAB: In addressing this agreement, it is worth noting what has happened there. Some months ago Western Mining Corporation gave notice that it was going to expand the operation at Kambalda. In order to do this and extract the easy-to-get-at ore and the higher grade ore, it is necessary for the company to go to full rostering, seven days a week, 24 hours a day. That practice operates in all States of Australia except Western Australia, my home State.

It is worth mentioning a number of aspects of the agreement that was put together. A fundamentally contractual arrangement has operated at the mine. The average take-home pay of the people who are involved is $63,000 a year, so one can hardly suggest that they are not reasonably well paid. If this agreement, which was signed by the Deputy Premier of Western Australia, had gone ahead, the average take-home pay would have gone up by about $7,000. On top of that, in accordance with the negotiated agreement, the contract bonus would have gone from 5 per cent to 7 per cent of the profit and an additional one week's holiday per year would have been provided, plus five days additional roster time.

When one analyses the changes one finds that, in return for working seven days a week on three eight-hour shifts, additional holidays and additional leisure time off, each individual involved would contribute one half-hour per week. That is not a lot when one considers the advantages of keeping the mine operating with the modern machinery in which the company has invested.

I want to make a couple of points. First of all, after having agreed with Western Mining Corporation on behalf of the AWU, Mr Wilson, who represented the AWU at the discussions which were chaired by the Deputy Premier, put the proposal to the people it affected and added another clause. The proposition he put to them was that, on top of what was already agreed to, they pursue further industrial action to try to get more benefits. In my view, this is absolutely outrageous and unforgivable.

Last week the Industrial Relations Commission made a decision about agreements. It is absolutely essential that, when an agreement has been made, it stays put and is not replaced by something else. It is also quite ridiculous and unacceptable that, an agreement having been made, further industrial action is pursued. Today and yesterday headlines such as `Mining Stops. Rosters key to profit from Western Mining Corporation' have appeared in the West Australian.

But it is a lot deeper than that. It is the key to whether Kambalda, a very successful nickel mining town in Western Australia, will exist any longer. Through the breaching of this agreement, which was put together last week, Kambalda's future is now very limited. The whole town—the people who work there, their families, the schools, et cetera—will close down prematurely.

It is the hierarchy within the AWU in Western Australia that is responsible, not the work force. The workers there have made it clear that if the coalition's industrial relations policy were in place in this country at present, they would be prepared to sign an agreement with management to keep the mine operating. They recognise that they are well rewarded for what they put into the operation.

The workers also recognise that it is essential that if a company such as Western Mining Corporation is to keep operating, at the end of the day it must utilise its capital investment in the mine. It must have a profit if it is to continue to expand and to move into some of the other nickel operations, its main strength, its forte, in terms of mining in Western Australia.

I emphasise that it was a significant number of months beforehand when Western Mining had to make its decision about whether to expand its operations and change its work practices to make it possible to expand. All the people involved in the mining operation were notified, as were the people in Kambalda. This was done by direct letters and also by advertisements in the paper, so there was no secret about what was going on. It was a clear-cut case of economics involving the livelihoods of the people working there, their families and the infrastructure of the operation of Western Mining Corporation in Kambalda.

It is an absolute tragedy and a disgrace that we see an operation that has been so successful and has done so much for the State of Western Australia being prematurely wound down through sheer stupidity. I would like to know from the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook—and I emphasise now that I informed him today that I would be speaking on this matter in the chamber; but maybe Senator Robert Ray can tell us—what action the Federal Government is taking on its fast-track proposals, which we shall hear a little more about today. What action has the Government taken in terms of making sure that this project does not collapse? It is a fair and valid question. The Government should let this side of the chamber, and the people of Australia, know what action has been taken to make sure that Kambalda does not collapse.

We might also hear today a little about what is happening with Marandoo and Yakabindie, two other possible developments in Western Australia that are being held up by every form of red tape or whatever else one can think of. This is at a time when not only my State of Western Australia, which had the highest level of unemployment in the figures brought down last week, but also the rest of Australia need those jobs. We also need the export income to assist in balancing our current account.

I wind up my comments by reiterating the stupidity and the tragedy of what has occurred in Western Australia at Kambalda. It is a case of lost opportunity, not only for Western Mining Corporation and Western Australia but also for the people who live in Kambalda, some of whom are second and third generation people in the town. It has all come about because of total inflexibility and the reneging on an agreement by the leadership of the Australian Workers Union in Western Australia. As I said before, I have a copy of it here, signed by the Deputy Premier of Western Australia, the State Labor member for Kalgoorlie, Ian Taylor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak about a matter which touches on some of the issues that were raised so well by my colleagues, Senator Bishop and Senator Crane. The particular focus of my remarks relates to the Food Preservers Union of Australia. I have received a letter from Mr Tom Ryan, the General Secretary of the Food Preservers Union—I am pleased to say that it was not an impolite letter—in which he put to me a firm view and sought from me comments and evidence to sustain the remarks which I made some weeks ago in this Parliament about the effect that actions of the Food Preservers Union were having on investment.

PARA.TAB: In his letter, Tom Ryan referred to a speech which I made on 17 October. I will quote from that speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The second example is the bans and other tactics by the Victorian Food Preservers Union which have led to a decline in investment in Victoria in this important industry, as Senator Button will know from his constituents.
Tom Ryan went on to say:
While a lot of people may dismiss such allegations as not important, I find such unsubstantiated allegations a serious attack on the membership of this union.
As I said, he made some firm comments to me. He then went on to say:

I have not been told by any company that this union is the cause of any decline in investment in Victoria. If you have any information I should be aware of, I would be pleased if you would share that information with this union so that we can include that knowledge in our considerations during our decision making procedures within the union.

So I am very pleased, as I said, to respond to the request by Tom Ryan. I do not know Tom Ryan well. I suspect the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), who is at the table, may know him well. For all I know, he may well be a close friend of Tom Ryan. I have noted that some people have referred to Tom Ryan as being a member of the tomato Left. Is that the case, Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —The union is disaffiliated from the Victorian branch.
—As I said, it was a serious letter and I plan to respond in a serious manner.

PARA.TAB: The evidence which I use to sustain the remarks that I made in an earlier speech came from a fairly substantial document—and I have to say I am rather surprised that Tom Ryan was not apparently aware of it—put out by the Committee of Melbourne and entitled Impediments to Cost Competitiveness in Victorian Food Processing.

The report highlighted the fact that the food processing industry in Victoria has great potential as a value added industry which could be, and indeed should be, making an important contribution to Australia's balance of trade position.However, it is clear when one reads the report that these opportunities are not being taken advantage of. In fact, the report indicated that the industry was in serious decline because of a number of factors—they are effectively identified—which combine to make Victoria a high risk investment for this type of activity.

The most important factor which was identified by the study was what it termed `the need for improvement in industrial relations in Victoria'. From time to time, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, has something to say on this subject. We had a debate recently on the effectiveness of the policies of this Government and the Kirner Government in improving industrial relations in Victoria. Those of us, like Senator Ray, who are Victorians know names such as Wally Curran and others that make it fairly hard to sustain that sort of position. I suspect, having gone through extensive press cuttings on the Food Preservers Union, that Tom Ryan's history has not been altogether constructive in ensuring harmonious industrial relations between management and workers.

But as I said, the report put out by the Committee of Melbourne said that for many products in the food processing industry, improvements on these industrial dimensions would have a greater impact on the value of an investment than the removal of all other impediments combined. Tom Ryan does not seem to appreciate that interviews conducted in the course of this study identified over $160m-worth of investment which could go ahead if changes were made to labour relations in Victoria in the food processing industry. The report indicates:

SPEECH.PARA: Current industrial relations are a significant contributor to the perception that Victoria is high risk. . .

and it notes that this is especially important in the high value-added product areas such as vegetables and baked goods. As I said, Tom Ryan does not appear to be aware of this very large, important report which, on checking through the media of the time, I found had received fairly extensive press.

PARA.TAB: The study points out that it is not only a question of wage rates, which are competitive with other developed countries; it is one of labour productivity. Labour productivity is severely hampered by high penalty rates, inefficient work practices, a lack of union discipline and a high level of industrial disputes. This is the State that Senator Cook has drawn our attention to on a number of occasions as being something of a model in the area of industrial relations.
I quote from the study again:

SPEECH.PARA: Three main areas of concern were highlighted: penalty rates, which discourage asset utilisation on more than a one-shift basis, work practices, which are estimated to increase labour costs by around 10%, and unpredictable, `irrational' work stoppages.

PARA.TAB: This study gives the highest priority among its recommendations to measures designed to address these problems, including negotiated workplace agreements.
One company executive is quoted in the report as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't think anything meaningful will happen until we get site agreements.
In other words, the onus is very much on the relevant trade unions to achieve the conditions for growth in investment. As the report says, what is needed is a commitment by the unions:
. . . to create [an] industrial relations environment conducive to investment in [the] processed food industry.

PARA.TAB: The report does give some mention to the Food Preservers Union, Tom Ryan's union, in the industry. As Senator Ray could probably confirm, it has a reputation as a hard Left union. Perhaps those of us who are somewhat older in this chamber will recall that a former secretary of that union was Baghdad Bill Hartley.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never!
—Is that not correct? In that case, I had better check my sources.
—Vice-president.

—Thank you. However, I have to say, on looking through the press cuttings, that the close relations between certain leaders in that union and Baghdad have been effectively continued, I understand, by Tom Ryan, who at one stage during the Gulf War was reported as musing in the press about whether he might join a group that was planning to go to Baghdad.

PARA.TAB: An article in the Sunday Age on 17 February 1991 said, `Hartley, unions to visit Baghdad'. One of the reports said:

SPEECH.PARA: The secretary of the Food Preservers' Union, Mr Tom Ryan, said that although he had not received an invitation from Iraq, Mr Hartley had discussed the delegation idea with him.

PARA.TAB: "Bill has mentioned it to me. I've been to Iraq several times and would like to go back again. It's something I would consider if the invitation is issued".

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think he did go to Baghdad so I do not want to go on record as implying he did, but what I suggest is that the affection that certain leaders in that union have had for Baghdad seems to have been continued at least to a certain extent by Tom Ryan.

PARA.TAB: I was very pleased to read, at the end of Mr Ryan's letter to me, that this union accepts that it has a responsible role to play in the future of the food processing industry in Australia. He says that the union is proud of its record in working with the industry to further the interests of all sectors, including growers, processors and employees, and that he would be pleased to receive the information I had referred to in my speech to the Senate. I shall be posting to Mr Tom Ryan a copy of the remarks I have made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fax it.

—'Fax it', says the Minister. I may fax it, on his advice. If Mr Tom Ryan has not got a copy of this report, I would be very pleased to see whether I could obtain a full copy of the report for him. I will also be able to draw to his attention some other press cuttings which he apparently was not aware of. Senators in the chamber may be aware of the notorious Heinz dispute which occurred earlier this year in which the Heinz factory in Victoria effectively had to close down, causing enormous losses to tomato growers. Of course, one of the unions involved in that particular dispute was the Food Preservers Union. I shall be very happy to respond to the letter of Mr Tom Ryan. As I said, it was not a threatening letter by any means; it was a letter seeking the evidence on which I had based my remarks.

PARA.TAB: What I have done today is to stand up in this chamber and provide the evidence that the Food Preservers Union in the past has not altogether played a very constructive role in the industry and that investment in the industry has been affected by its particular activities. I hope that what Mr Tom Ryan says in his letter, that he believes the union should play a responsible role, indicates that we are seeing the Food Preservers Union and its leadership turning over a new leaf.

My final comment is that he felt that my letter was a reflection on the workers in the Food Preservers Union. I have always been fairly careful in this Parliament, as indeed many of my colleagues have, in that we often have to draw, and very appropriately, a distinction between the union leadership and the union workers. Never has the distinction been sharper, I think, than under this Government in recent years where union leadership has been able to increase its powers and privilege, but the living standards and the jobs of ordinary workers have been greatly diminished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak today in this debate on matters of public interest against a background of almost one million of our fellow Australians out of work, against a background where this Government keeps spending lavishly on its own rorts and increasing the bureaucracy, and against a background where ordinary Australians are more and more penalised by this particular Government. With that background, I wish to draw to the Senate's attention a classic case of waste of government expenditure and of lavishness in looking after Government Ministers.
—Those are copious notes.

—This relates, Senator Robert Ray might be interested to hear, to Senator Collins's north Queensland office, which is based in Townsville. That office, which is set up by the Minister in Townsville for his use, was used by him in the year 1 July 1990 to 31 July 1991 on one occasion. On only one occasion was that office used. The Minister was there on that one occasion for three whole days. Having an office in that town for a whole year, the Minister used it for three days.

PARA.TAB: I asked the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, for some information about the cost of this office. I was told that the cost of the office in one year was $154,000-odd, which included one permanent ministerial adviser on the payroll at $46,000, rent of about $20,000, and cleaning and electricity, fit-out fees, furniture, transportation of furniture, telephones and installation, and office equipment, to a total of $154,000.

Senator Bolkus did not tell me about the cost of the additional staff member there who gets a salary of about $37,000; he did not tell me about the Comcar bills and the plane travel for the staff; and he did not tell me about the overtime. I would estimate those at $10,000. So, if we add those costs to the $154,000, we get to about $200,000 in one year for running that office in Townsville. This is all for an office that the Minister uses on one occasion for three days.

Why does the Minister have the office in Townsville? Could it possibly be argued that the Government needs a liaison office in the Townsville area to keep the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australian abreast of what is happening in that particular part of the world? One wonders what all the other Federal government departments are doing there. Townsville is served by offices of DAS, Australian Construction Services, Attorney-General, Australian Customs Service, ATSIC, Australia Post, Austrade, Australian Electoral Commission, Australian Federal Police, the Australian Government Solicitor, AIMS, ASC, the Office of War Graves, bankruptcy administration, Bureau of Meteorology, CAA, CES, the Director of Public Prosecutions, DSS, health, CSIRO, Defence, DEET, FAC, the Family Court of Australia, GBRMPA, Industrial Relations, Immigration, Primary Industries and Energy, Tax, Telecom, Trade Practices Commission, Transport and Communications—of which the Minister's portfolio is a part—and Veterans' Affairs.

Although all of these offices are in Townsville, apparently it was necessary to spend another $200,000 to give the Minister the luxury of having an office there that he uses three days a year. Surely those other government departments in Townsville could keep

SPEECH.PARA: the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia abreast of what was happening in that area.

PARA.TAB: But, one might also ask: if he wants some political on-the-ground information, what is wrong with the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), who is also based in Townsville? Mr Lindsay has an office with three or four staff. Why could he not tell Senator Collins what is going on? In addition to that, Senator Reynolds, a Labor Party senator for Queensland, also has an office in that same town. And not far away is Mr Gayler with four staff and two officers, and Mr Hulls with four staff and two officers. If they cannot tell the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support what is happening, I do not know who can.

I might add that if he needs a bit of extra political clout, there are three State Labor members in Townsville, all with staff and lurks and perks. A couple of them are Ministers. There is also a Labor controlled city council with all of its staff and resources available. So what is that all about? Why was the $200,000 spent on that? What is so wrong with Senator Collins's staff in Townsville that he needs, in addition to them, an office of the aNiMaLS—the National Media Liaison Service—in Townsville? The Service does not have many offices outside capital cities but there is one in Townsville. Senator Collins's ministerial staff in Townsville obviously cannot do the job, so the Government has to throw in an aNiMaLS staff as well.

The cost of the aNiMaLS in Townsville has been estimated—I have the figures here but I will not go through them—at about $100,000. This figure excludes the cost of furnishings and office equipment which, based on the figures I have for Senator Collins's office, would be quite considerable.
The purpose of the aNiMaLS office in Townsville, according to Senator Richardson in answer to a question, is:

SPEECH.PARA: To provide and co-ordinate the provision of accurate and timely information on Government policies and programs throughout Australia.

As I mentioned to Senator Richardson at the time he gave that answer, I have a junior staffer who does exactly that. It takes her no more than two hours every morning to do what the Minister apparently needs the two highly paid public servants in the aNiMaLS office in Townsville to do. Even Senator Richardson is quoted in Hansard as saying at the time, `Well, maybe two aNiMaLS officers for that area is a bit strong'. `A bit strong'—that is the understatement of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has he done about it?
—Well, of course he has done nothing. Senator Richardson did try to justify the aNiMaLS in Townsville by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Fortunately, Senator Macdonald's junior staffer does not have to cover the work of 30 Ministers—that is what the person in Townsville has to do. Again, that is not correct. My junior staffer, in the first couple of hours of a working day, has the responsibility of supplying 32 shadow Ministers with anything in the local papers or on the local radio and television that is related to their work. Yet, it takes two officers and four highly paid staff to do the same thing for the Minister.

PARA.TAB: Why does it take them so long? If one were cynical, one might say that maybe the aNiMaLS are there to provide Mr Lindsay, Senator Reynolds and other ALP politicians—and maybe the Mayor and the State members, for all we know—with political information on a daily basis that they need to try to keep themselves in government. It will not work. Maybe that is what it is all about. Maybe it is for pure political purposes. It would be disgraceful if that was so. But there seems to be no other justification for that sort of expenditure.

If we add up the cost of Senator Collins's office and the aNiMaLS office in Townsville, the amount is over $300,000. This is the cost of sustaining a fully staffed office designed to cater for eight people—not just the two that are there now; and who knows what we are going to get in the future—which the Minister admits he uses once in 12 months.

In addition to that, there is the fully staffed office of the aNiMaLS—the National Media Liaison Service—which performs the function that my junior staffer does in a couple of hours each morning. All of these functions could be performed by the local ALP politicians and the local Commonwealth Government staff in those areas.

If the Government has $300,000 to throw around and waste in that sort of way in the Townsville region, I suggest that the people of Australia may well be much better served if that $300,000 was spent on fixing the absolutely atrocious state of the Bruce Highway up that way. People cannot drive anywhere on that highway without breaking windscreens or springs. Regrettably, there are far too many fatalities in that area because of the shocking state of the roads on which the Government has no money to spend. But the Government has $300,000 to spend on a couple of offices to serve the political purposes of this ALP Government.

Why cannot the Government use that $300,000 to keep the animal production unit at the CSIRO Davies Laboratory at Townsville? That unit has to be moved because there is no money to keep it there. But we have $300,000 to be used for the Minister's political purposes. If the Government wanted to spend $300,000 in the Townsville area, why not move the School of Artillery up there? That might interest Senator Ray. That money could be used to help move the School of Artillery to that area, as his predecessor promised a couple of weeks before the last Federal election would happen. That was obviously said in an attempt—successful as it was—to keep the ALP member, Mr Lindsay, in a seat which contains the Lavarack Barracks. The Minister's predecessor promised to move the School of Artillery there two years ago. Since then we have heard not one peep about it.

I understand that the Minister was not even aware that that arrangement had been made. I understand from both the Minister's office and Mr Lindsay's office that maybe it is not now going to happen. As I said, just a couple of weeks before the last Federal election people were told, obviously with the Army vote in mind, that the School of Artillery was going there. If the Government has $300,000 to spare, why does not the Minister use it there?

If the Government has $300,000 to spend in the Townsville area, maybe the Minister could use it to assist Senator Richardson's much publicised push in Townsville to help fund the dredging of the port which is needed to keep the Booloo nickel factory going and save a thousand jobs in the Townsville area. But that is not going ahead. There is an awful lot of uncertainty about that although another thousand of our fellow Australians could well be thrown out of work because no-one wants to pay for the dredging of the port.

If the Government has a spare $300,000 to throw around for political services maybe—just maybe—that money might be able to be used for dredging the port which would help save a thousand jobs in the Townsville region. Finally, if the Government has $300,000 to spare, maybe it could throw a bit of it to the Ravenshoe creditors, people who lent money to the Ravenshoe Mill because they thought the Government was looking after the $7m of taxpayers' money it pumped into that mill. Because the creditors thought the Government was looking after $7m of the money of the people of Australia—it was not—they gave that credit and then found that someone had whisked away the money. In many instances, people lost their businesses and, in some cases, their homes as well. That measly sum of $300,000 could be used far better in compensating most of those people than in spending it on a couple of political offices for the Minister.

I just wanted to draw to the attention of the Senate the blatant waste of that money on those offices in the Townsville region. It is a completely unwarranted lavishness with taxpayers' money that cannot under any circumstances, particularly the circumstances I have outlined, be justified in this day and age. It shows a complete underutilisation of the Public Service there and is an unethical provision of staff services to assist in political matters. I hope that Senator Collins will do the right thing in relation to those offices. He should shut down both offices and use the $300,000 and more spent on those services each year on other services in the Townsville region which would really help the people of that area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Friday, I, with a number of colleagues, had the opportunity to travel to the University of New England at Armidale. There is a proposal to establish at Armidale a cooperative research centre for the Australian beef industry. Honourable senators would be aware that the Federal Government initiated a series of cooperative research centres in an effort to better address the costs of research and the needs of industry. The first round of 15 cooperative research centre proposals was completed last year. We are now in the second round of approvals. It is an indictment of the priorities of this anti-rural Federal Labor Government that no rural research centres were established in the first round of 15 new centres. In fact, this centre at Armidale is the first rural centre to be contemplated under the new arrangements.

PARA.TAB: The proposal seeks a minimum of $2m of Commonwealth funds a year for five years for the cattle and beef industry, which is the fastest-growing rural export industry in this country. The beef industry in Australia is dynamic. I have told the Senate many times about the tremendous expansion that has occurred in this industry in a relatively short time. We have seen an explosion in the number of new beef breeds available in Australia. There has been exciting research into nutrition, genetic selection and manipulation, housing, transport, husbandry, economics, and management. In fact, at the moment, researchers are even at the stage of getting very close to being able to sex semen. They will be able to identify semen that will produce bull calves and semen that will produce heifer calves.
The new proposal for the CRC will bring together the best of all that research. As the promotional brochure suggests:

SPEECH.PARA: The CRC involves diverse interest groups pulling together to secure value added rewards for Australians.

The research will be done by world-class scientists from the University of New England, CSIRO and the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and Fisheries, and will put Australia in the lead in understanding how to produce export beef to specification. No longer will scientists, beef producers, consumers or end use customers all be working in different directions. Scientists will know what the end user wants and develop ways and means that allow the beef producer to produce an animal for that market.

PARA.TAB: We must not forget that Australia's future lies in South East Asia. It is an enormous and expanding export market for Australia. We have to learn what that market wants and produce it. I believe we can do that. Whether our customers want young beef or old, with one millimetre of fat or heavily marbled, Australia has the capacity to produce just that meat.

Our biggest problems at the moment are, first, that we do not know what our markets want, and secondly, that we have great beef producers but few who know how to condition their cattle to suit that specified market. Traditionally, in Australia farmers bred cattle, fattened them to a certain age—as long as it rained, of course—depending largely on breed and availability of pasture to fatten them, and then sold them on the local market. The advent of feedlots changed that and it will continue to expand its increasing influence on the Australian beef industry.

There is an enormous amount of capital tied up in our feedlots. Many are overseas owned and are producing for specific markets such as those in Japan and in Korea as well. Yet even the people running those specialised feedlots would like more knowledge on the best breeds to use, the best ages, and the best feed rations to maximise profit. The CRC will be able to deliver that sort of information.

One of the publications that it has put out is called Winning Market Share. . . through positioning Australia's beef industry towards 2000 and beyond. One of the areas that is mentioned is animal health and welfare, and it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Many areas of animal health and welfare, peculiar to the feedlot industry, need urgent investigation if the industry is to mature and prosper in a community which is becoming increasingly aware of and concerned for these issues.
That is what the newly formed Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs will be examining in the next year or so, as well, to help centres such as the CRC.

PARA.TAB: The publication also says:
The feedlot industry is becoming a major contributor to winning market share for Australian high quality beef.
To correctly position the feedlot industry for the future, an integrated research and development programme incorporating an education and training function needs to be established in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I say `Hear, hear!' I entirely agree with that.

PARA.TAB: It will not only target feedlot users, but it will also benefit people in the pasture fed industries. The Australian beef industry is presently worth some $3.5 billion annually, with exports of some $2.3 billion each year.
