We could be producing $2 billion worth of quality beef with an expansion of some 6,000 new jobs, and at least 30,000 part time jobs in associated service industries if we continue to expand the feedlot industry and produce better beef.

This cooperative research centre will enhance our international competitiveness, expand that export income and establish a firm base from which Australia can grow and develop a reputation as a producer of world class beef, just as we have developed a reputation as the world's premier wool producer.

What is holding us back is lack of commitment to that ideal and a lack of financial backing for our research institutions. Additionally, what it will also develop is an excellence in rural education in the form of a school of meat science. From that learning will come our future research scientists, feedlot managers, and agricultural economists with particular expertise in the meat industries.

This proposal already has the support of the Australian Meat and Live-Stock Corporation, the Cattle Council of Australia, the Australian Lot Feeders Association, CSIRO and the University of New England. But what it needs is support from other industries such as beef societies, beef producers and those with an interest in investment in the future.

The next round of interviews for this project will be held on 20 November. I cannot contemplate such a vital project as this not having the support it requires from the Federal Government. I am asking the Federal Government sincerely to put in its bit to make sure this proceeds. Here is an opportunity for the Government to do something positive for Australia and for Australian agriculture. The principles involved in the proposal thus far have demonstrated very clearly the need for such a project. They have demonstrated very adequately their ability actually to deliver what they suggest should happen. I wish the project well for the future and I have every confidence that we will see this project come to fruition in a very short time, as long as it has the stimulus of government backing and also the backing of the people in the industry itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great project.

—It is, Senator Macdonald, and it will help the cattle producers in your area as well as in every other area in Australia. I would expect those industries that have done very well out of agriculture and rural Australia to look very closely at financially assisting this centre. The Australian banking industry has done very well out of Australian agriculture, as have insurance and other large investment institutions. It should suit them well to invest some effort into supporting such a research centre, not least because it will bring more viability to the beef industry producers who are the banks' customers.

PARA.TAB: I commend the project to the Senate and I endorse the work that has been done to date. It is a most exciting development for Australia and one that deserves support, encouragement and funding. I make a plea to the Federal Government to look at this project, because it is one where a dollar spent will bring in a lot of extra dollars for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on the same subject as my colleague Senator Crane spoke on—the very sad situation in Kambalda this week. We have heard the term `fast tracking' a lot in recent weeks in the desperate bid by governments and trade unions to find a solution to the appalling unemployment crisis that Australia faces. The situation in Kambalda is indeed an example of a government backtracking as opposed to fast tracking.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Crane has already said, Western Mining Corporation was given an undertaking, in informal as well as formal circumstances, that amendments would be passed to the draconian industrial laws in Western Australia to allow a constant roster and a constant mining of the ore body at Kambalda, which is, as most of us would know, an enormous operation.

My interest in the issue arose when some six months ago I attended a wine-tasting function at Coolgardie with a number of the people from Kambalda. I was taken aside by a number of the miners from Kambalda and these workers alerted me to the fact that Western Mining Corporation was going to implement the new continuous roster. They had some very genuine concerns about the effect that that continuous mining roster would have on the community in Kambalda. Of course, if workers at Kambalda have a five-day roster and are not working on Saturdays or Sundays, they can enjoy a fairly normal lifestyle. They can play football on Saturday afternoons and pursue other normal recreational pursuits and the community life will be quite similar to that in a metropolitan area.

The people at the function were very concerned. Indeed, they asked me to make representations to the Government and to Western Mining Corporation saying that they were bitterly opposed to the proposal and that if it went ahead there would be industrial action, the place would shut down and so on.

But what has happened since then is that Western Mining Corporation and those workers, without much help from the AWU, went into a consultation process. Many of those workers—a majority of them, I believe—now favour the proposal, which Senator Crane very aptly described, for a continuous roster, an increase in take-home pay of about $7,000 a year, and extra holiday entitlements. The community as a whole has accepted the fact that if Kambalda is to survive, if the nickel operation is to survive, we need that continuous roster.

Indeed, as Senator Crane also said, it is a situation that occurs around the rest of Australia and one that our competitors in the nickel mining industry have internationally, and that Western Australia is the odd man out. What is so sad about this is that Western Mining Corporation was given an undertaking by the Premier of Western Australia, and the Deputy Premier, who is the local member for Kalgoorlie, that that would be done. Yesterday, the Deputy Premier, Ian Taylor MLA, backtracked on that proposal. He said that he was not going to do it now because the negotiations with the AWU had broken down.

An important thing about this—there are a number of important things—is that Western Mining Corporation has been negotiating its way through a whole series of hurdles leading to being able to expand the nickel operation at Kambalda, to invest another $105m to create more jobs directly at the mine, and, I presume, to create more jobs in the support industries in the town of Kambalda and in the goldfields generally.

They have had to overcome disadvantages in the cost of transport and the ludicrously high cost of electricity in Western Australia, all sorts of other government regulations and all of the normal problems that anyone seeking to exploit a mineral resource in Australia is faced with. They had this last hurdle to overcome in relation to work practices and the implementation of this continuous roster and they thought they had it beaten. They had agreement from the Government, they had almost unanimous agreement from the local community and the workers. That one last hurdle they were hoping to overcome by an amendment going through the Parliament of Western Australia in the last few days of this year; but the hurdle was raised at the last minute. Any hurdler will tell you that it is pretty hard to win a race if the last hurdle is pushed up just before you get to the finish line.

That is exactly what has happened, and the cost of it directly has been 150 jobs; people are already receiving, either today or tomorrow, their retrenchment notices. It will, of course, create more unemployment in Kambalda and the goldfields in the service industries, in the delicatessens, the bakers, the butchers and the candlestick makers, who will lose trade and go out of business. The effect on the local community will be severe. Unemployment in the regional areas of Western Australia is the highest anywhere in Australia. There are hundreds of thousands of young people out of work in regional Australia, and the goldfields, a major regional centre, will again have a setback. These are the sorts of setbacks that lead to the formation of ghost towns.

The other important issue, apart from the human impact, is the international competitive situation. Senator Kemp talked about a report on impediments to cost competitiveness in the food processing industry and said that the resolution of labour relations issues in itself could see $160m being invested in that industry. Again, it is labour relations in Western Australia which will see $105m of investment go out the window. The worst thing about that is that the price of nickel is set on a world market which we have no control over. We can control all of those things within Australia, but, if we are not internationally competitive, we will not mine our nickel and we will not be able to sell it because it will not be profitable. One of the problems with that is that future investment will be affected. If Western Mining Corporation, which has already got a hole in the ground and has already been mining nickel there for decades, cannot expand its current operations, why would someone else even bother going to explore for nickel or any other ore? Why would they bear all the costs of exploration and try to jump all the hurdles that are put up by the greens and the environmental protection authorities and every other hurdle that is put in the way of development: the Aboriginal heritage issues which we have already heard about at Yakabindie and other government red tape? Why would they even bother when a company that is already established in Kambalda, mining nickel—

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent company; one of the best.

—An excellent company, as Senator Brownhill knows from being involved with that corporation as a parliamentarian. Why would another company even bother to explore? That is very sad for Australia. I am sure Government Ministers and Government members opposite would agree that we need to attract that investment, be it from overseas or be it from the public of Australia investing their hard-earned savings in exploration and mining companies. Why would they bother? It has not only cost 150 jobs in Western Australia; as I speak it is costing potentially thousands and tens of thousands of jobs down the track.

PARA.TAB: This is a matter of great public concern and a matter that needs to be resolved very quickly. I make a plea to the Premier and to the Deputy Premier of Western Australia to reconsider their decision. I make a further plea to them to implement the changes that are required. I also make a plea to the union movement. Only 10 or 15 days ago, Martin Ferguson made a plea for resource development and getting these impediments out of the way of resource developments. Those words came from the President of the ACTU, Martin Ferguson. I make a plea to his AWU brothers in Western Australia to heed the words of Martin Ferguson, to forget their class war or their class struggle or whatever else they are struggling for over there, and to get on with getting this expansion of the Kambalda nickel mine achieved. Let us see it achieved before Christmas and let us at least have a bit of a bright light on the horizon for young people in Western Australia who would like to see their employment prospects improved.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray)—by leave—agreed to:
That the sitting of the Senate be suspended till 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Who is actually controlling the Government of Australia today? Is it the honourable member for Blaxland, the honourable member for Wills, a junta of State Premiers or none of these?

—That is an extraordinary question to put in terms of who is controlling Australia today. The Government in so far as government activities are concerned is led by Mr Hawke as Prime Minister, who is responsible for all Government decisions, and will remain so until the next election and thereafter.

—I refer the Minister for Defence to the members of the Australian defence forces who recently arrived in Cambodia as part of the United Nations Advance Mission in Cambodia called UNAMIC. Can the Minister advise the Senate what assistance and support will be provided to the families of those serving members of the Australian Defence Force?

—As with the situation in the Gulf, the Australian defence forces have made a substantial effort to give assistance to Australian servicemen serving overseas. The Government acknowledges the positive contribution that families make to the morale, performance and retention of ADF personnel. My colleague Gordon Bilney has recently endorsed a new ADF family support policy which provides guidance to the Services and emphasises the importance of providing appropriate support to ADF family members.

PARA.TAB: In regard to specific arrangements for the ADF members forming the Australian contingent of UNAMIC, I can advise Senator West of the following: a majority of the soldiers have been taken from the Second Signal Regiment, Watsonia, in Melbourne. Accordingly, the Second Signal Regiment has been nominated as the fostering unit for all soldiers posted to Cambodia.

A support cell headed by a family support officer, who can call on specialist personnel from the Army community service units throughout Australia, has been established. The family support cell conducted family briefing sessions for all UNAMIC members and their families prior to their moving overseas.

In addition, the families have been provided with the following: an information package on Cambodia; access to the family support officer via an 008 telephone service and a 24-hour paging system; and an 008 number to cover events that have occurred during the previous 24 hours. They have also been provided with an international telephone and fax facility between the Second Signal Regiment and the headquarters of UNAMIC; and, finally, with domestic services such as lawn mowing, shopping trips and home visits when required.

I think honourable senators will agree that these arrangements will provide timely and effective welfare support for the Australian contingent of UNAMIC. They will be reviewed regularly to ensure an appropriate level of support is maintained throughout the duration of the peacekeeping effort.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer The Minister representing the Treasurer to some embarrassment that he is experiencing in explaining to the Senate the proposed changes to the depreciation regime arising from the 12 March industry statement, and an unfortunate deception that was embodied in an answer given during Question Time on Tuesday. Senator Button stated that he felt that emanating from certain sections of industry in respect of the depreciation regime was a view which would have allowed companies to write off equipment over two years and pass it on to a subsidiary which would then write it off again. Was that a genuine and responsible view to represent to the Senate? Secondly, is the Minister aware that there are current income tax provisions relating to depreciation in the Income Tax Assessment Act, particularly sections 59 and 60 and others, that disallow the nonsense that the Minister was alluding to in his answer on Tuesday? Thirdly, can the Minister give an assurance to the Senate that he will treat the issue with greater care and concern, particularly as the depreciation issue was reported to be so central to the industry package of 12 March?

—We are all in favour of care and concern and so am I, and I will certainly give more care and concern to this issue in future. The point about care and concern is that one has something that works—it works efficiently in terms of revenue and works beneficially to companies involved in investments.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the first part of the question, I was asked whether I had put a genuine and responsible view. What I gave the other day was an example, which I freely admit was an extreme example, of some views which were put on the depreciation discussions which took place.

In so far as the existence of current provisions are concerned, I do not want to speak about the application of current provisions in the tax Act to a hypothetical example which was raised in the first part of the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Last week an Australian international vessel, the TNT Capricornia, was subjected to an act of piracy off the coast of Borneo. What action is being taken to prevent a repetition of such acts of piracy against our international trading fleet?

—Fortunately, acts such as the one that occurred recently, which must have been very distressing for the members of the crew involved, are rare. In fact, there have been only three incidents of piracy in the last five years involving Australian shipping, including the most recent one. The other two incidents also occurred in the South East Asian area. In 1986 the ANRO Australia was boarded by pirates in waters between Indonesia and Malaysia; in 1990 the TNT Express suffered a similar fate three miles south of the Raffles light off Singapore.

PARA.TAB: The TNT Capricornia does not usually engage in international trade but was sailing to Singapore for dry docking. It was raided at 2 a.m. on Tuesday, 5 November 330 nautical miles from Singapore. The captain was threatened at knife point and was later tied up after the pirates stole money from the ship's safe and made a quick escape. There were no injuries to the other 30 people on board as only the captain himself was involved in the raid and there was no damage to the ship.

The Australian Maritime Safety Authority advises that piracy attacks on ships are generally confined to the South China Sea, the Caribbean and the West African coast. AMSA reminds Australian ship operators with vessels sailing in these areas to take increased security measures such as additional lookouts to counteract the threat of piracy. This is an international problem which has been the subject of action by the International Maritime Organisation.

As I have already advised the Senate, the IMO has a membership of 135 nation states and its principal conventions apply to 97 per cent of the world's shipping. The IMO biennial assembly, which concluded last week in London, adopted a further resolution on the prevention and suppression of piracy and armed robbery against ships.

AMSA represented Australia at the IMO assembly and strongly supported adoption of the new resolution. The new resolution notes the increasing incidence of piracy and armed robbery against ships. All governments have been urged to increase their efforts to suppress and prevent acts of piracy against ships in or adjacent to their territorial waters. They are also required to provide information to ships transiting their waters concerning the modus operandi of pirates in their particular region. Ships are encouraged to take appropriate precautionary measures when entering waters with a record of piracy and to promptly advise information of threats or attacks by pirates to the coastal authorities concerned. I also note that TNT Shipping is now reviewing its security precautions following last week's incident.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. It relates to a report in last Friday's Johannesburg Weekly Mail that an Australian firm, Alpha Chemicals (Australia) Pty Ltd, was one of 99 companies in South Africa and overseas which broke the arms embargo on South Africa in the mid-1980s. I further note media reports in which the Minister's office said that the export in question—200 kilograms of strontium oxalate—was not for military purposes and did not violate the arms embargo. I ask the Minister: Does he agree that the bill of entry I have supplied to him today clearly shows that the shipment of strontium oxalate went to Swartklip Products Pty Ltd on behalf of Armscor, the Armaments Corporation of South Africa Ltd? Secondly, can the Minister explain why Defence Science officials quoted in last Friday's denials were unaware that strontium oxalate is used in the manufacture of tracer bullets for the targeting of automatic weapons, even though this use is listed in the publicly available Encyclopaedia of Chemical Technology? Thirdly, does the Minister agree that, contrary to statements made by his office, this export is a clear violation of United Nations security resolutions 182 and 418, which impose the arms embargo on South Africa? Finally, will the Government launch an immediate investigation into why this export was not prevented by its much vaunted military export controls, and what other military exports have occurred in violation of the guidelines?

—The South African newspaper Weekly Mail has reported that companies in a number of countries, including Australia, have exported arms and military-related products to South Africa in contravention of the sanctions policies in the UN arms embargo. The report claims to draw on official South African Government documents acquired by the Weekly Mail. The report claimed that an Australian company, Alpha Chemicals of New South Wales, exported 200 kilograms of strontium oxalate to South Africa. The company has confirmed that it made two shipments of this chemical of one tonne each in 1987. The company has cooperated fully with the Australian Government in its inquiries into the matter.

PARA.TAB: My Department has advised that the export of the chemical is not prohibited under regulation 13(b) of the Customs Act, which covers exports of defence and related items; nor is it a substance that has any particular defence application. Strontium oxalate is used as a colouring agent for fireworks and tracers as strontium gives out a bright cherry red colour upon decomposition in a flame.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has also confirmed that it does not fall under regulations 13(c) or 13(d) of the same Act, which cover, respectively, exports to South Africa and the control of export of chemicals that can be used to manufacture chemical weapons. As strontium oxalate does not constitute a defence item, it does not fall under the Australian commitments under the UN arms embargo.It is clear that the exports do not contravene the defence regulations on the export of military equipment. They do not contravene the Australian Government's sanctions policy, the UN arms embargo, or Australian controls of the export of chemicals that can be used in the manufacture of chemical weapons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has not denied that this chemical is being used in the manufacture of tracer bullets. Accordingly, it is very definitely and quite clearly an item that is being used in the manufacture of military items. Will the Minister take steps to ensure that it is covered from here on in the military export guidelines? I return to my other question, which the Minister has not answered. Is he going to start an investigation into the statements that were made on this issue both by his office and by the Defence Science personnel?

—On the latter matter, I thought it was clear that what I have said today is quite consistent with previous statements. As for an investigation, on the information I have provided today, obviously we have investigated the matter.If Senator Spindler says that every possible substance in the world that may have some military application can be banned from Australia, then he totally misunderstands the export guidelines. Next he will be saying we cannot export boot polish because it may be used on troops' boots or whatever else. This is not a critical element in terms of arms, and Senator Spindler knows it well. I am sick of his coming up and saying that my office or some chemical scientists have given evidence to the contrary. There has been no contradiction between that and the answer I have given today.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does the Government have any further information about the shootings that occurred in Dili, East Timor, on 12 November? What response has there been to the Government's expression of concern and call for a full independent inquiry?

—With a certain degree of prescience, I do have a response to Senator Schacht's question. I must say that, in the statements to Parliament yesterday, the Prime Minister and Senator Button foreshadowed that Senator Evans would be raising the matter with the Indonesian Foreign Minister in Seoul; that our Ambassador in Jakarta would be doing likewise with the Indonesian authorities; and that an embassy official would be travelling to Dili to investigate the incident.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans and the Ambassador have now made their representations and the embassy official has arrived in Dili and commenced his investigations. In speaking with Foreign Minister Alatas, Senator Evans reiterated the Government's very deep concern over the killings. Senator Evans made the point very strongly that, at the very least, what was needed was a full and credible inquiry into the incident; that the result of the inquiry should be very much in the public domain; and that in the event that this inquiry showed that there had been significant overreaction or human rights abuses, then appropriate action would have to follow.

Mr Alatas made it clear that he very much shares our concerns about the incident. He acknowledged the need for an inquiry, and one which would be credible so far as the international community was concerned. In this regard, I also welcome reports that the commander of the Indonesian armed forces, General Try Sutrisno, has expressed his regret over the incident and said that there would be a thorough investigation.

Australian Ambassador Flood also made strong representations in Jakarta yesterday to Defence Minister Moerdani, who is currently Acting Foreign Minister. Mr Flood reiterated the Australian Government's deep concern over the incident and repeated our call for the Indonesian Government to conduct a thorough investigation and to publish a full account of what happened.

Our embassy official arrived in Dili on the afternoon of 13 November. He plans to stay in Dili for several days so as to speak to as many people as he can about the incident. We are not yet in a position to speak with any certainty about many of the details of the incident. The Indonesian authorities in Jakarta are themselves continuing with their inquiries and are awaiting the return of a number of key personnel from Dili. General Sutrisno is reported to have told reporters in Jakarta yesterday that, at the most, 50 people died in the incident. Whatever the final number of casualties, it is obvious that an appalling tragedy has occurred.

The Indonesian authorities have also indicated that the incident was provoked by an attack on an Indonesian military officer. Other witnesses claim there was no provocation. We are continuing to investigate these and other aspects of the incident, including with non-government sources. It would be unwise to comment further until we have further details. In particular, we await the return from Dili of our embassy official, so that he can give us a full and considered account.

I am glad that the initial Indonesian reaction recognises the seriousness of the situation, and that there appears to be a recognition that there needs to be a full inquiry. It would be appropriate for Australia to await the outcome of that inquiry, but I hope it will be recognised that, whatever provocation may have occurred, the response by the Indonesian military appears to have been wholly excessive. In a situation as sensitive as East Timor, the need for a measured response by the Indonesian military is particularly important. After all these years, it is clear that the problems of East Timor are not going to be solved by military force.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Will the Minister consider holding a general inquiry into Australian Defence Force air safety standards, following a disturbing number of crashes which have occurred this year? Will the Minister table in Parliament the reports of the Royal Australian Air Force boards of inquiry into each of the crashes which have taken place this year? Following the reported statement of the commanding officer of the Army Parachute Training School that wind conditions were within safety standards on the day when 38 soldiers were injured, some seriously, near Nowra in a training exercise recently, will the Minister review the safety standards applied at the Army Parachute Training School?

—In relation to the second matter raised by Senator Durack, I am awaiting a report on the incident before I make an assessment as to whether we need to review those procedures. Senator Durack is right when he refers to a disturbing number of accidents by the RAAF, in particular, and two in the Army. Some weeks ago I called in the Chief of the Air Staff to discuss these matters because I was concerned. We reviewed every accident that had occurred and tried to find a common theme, and were unable to do so.

PARA.TAB: However, following the tragic Boeing 707 accident, I again called in the Chief of the Air Staff and he is doing a review of some of the practices, especially as regards asymmetric training. I would be happy to table any of the boards' inquiries that Senator Durack seeks. As he would realise, some are still in progress; some have been completed. I am quite happy to make those public.

It is a matter of concern that there have been fatal accidents. I would like to think that there is a common thread so that there could be just one common solution. There seems to be three or four different classes as to why these accidents occurred, ranging from structural faults to pilot error to other factors. These all have to be assessed. I assure Senator Durack that we will be reviewing internally all procedures relating to air safety to make sure that any future such incident can be reduced to an absolute minimum, if not eliminated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. I refer to an article in Monday's Adelaide Advertiser which claims that Australia Post's newer express post service is a rip-off to the community, particularly small business. Can the Minister inform the Senate of initial reaction to the new express post service offered by Australia Post? How does this service differ from the priority paid service and does it offer a good postal alternative for business?

—The Minister for Land Transport has provided me with a response to Senator Foreman's question. The initial market acceptance of the express post service since its launch on 1 October last has exceeded Australia Post's expectations. Australia Post believes that express post is an excellent business product. It is a speed service which guarantees overnight, low cost, next business day delivery of letters, business pages and documents up to 500 grams between capital cities and, within States, between the State capital and the major provincial centres.

PARA.TAB: It is a convenient prepaid service which does not require any documentation or post office attendance. It provides for lodgment up until 6 p.m. in special gold street posting boxes in major business areas or up to 5 p.m. at most normal post offices. It is competitively priced with letters costing between $2.36 and $3.80, depending on their size and the number purchased. It is aimed primarily at the business customer who requires next day delivery where that is not the normal standard.

The express post service is a quite different service from the priority paid service. The priority paid service is not a speed service; it is a head of queue service which ensures that mail gets sorted as a priority over standard mail. It ensures a very high degree of reliability for delivery within Australia Post's normal service standards. Australia Post has undertaken to keep the price of the express post service fixed for two years so that the business community can transfer from courier services to the express post service with confidence. Whilst the priority paid service remains available, the express post service best meets the need for guaranteed, speedy, next day delivery.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Federal Government, at ministerial or officer level, had discussions with the South Australian Government, at ministerial or officer level, with respect to the sale of the State Bank of South Australia or part thereof? Does the Government believe that there needs to be more competition in any aspect of banking in Australia? Is the Government considering extending the availability of foreign licences in any aspect of banking? When will the policy paralysis which is so gripping this Government at the moment pass? When will a decision be made with respect to the entry of further foreign banks into any aspect of banking in Australia?

—I am unable to answer that part of the question relating to any discussions concerning the sale of the State Bank of South Australia. I am able to say that I think it is very unlikely that Commonwealth Government officials have entered into those discussions.
—Will you find out?

—Just a minute. I was just going to say that I will find out for Senator Vanstone and provide her with an answer to that part of the question. In so far as the question of the issue of further foreign bank licences is concerned, perhaps on the same or different terms from earlier foreign bank licences, I understand that there has been a number of suggestions about that. If the Government makes the decision about it, it will be announced at the appropriate time and the Senate will be informed.

PARA.TAB: I do not wish to involve myself in an answer to Senator Vanstone's question about policy paralysis. Whatever we did, that bit of invective would be contained in Senator Vanstone's question, I am sure. We will deal with that as it goes along.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps the Minister could give some indication of when he expects an answer to be provided not only to the matter relating to the South Australian Government but also, in particular, to foreign licences. As the Minister knows, in September last year the Bureau of Industry Economics put forward a proposal to him that there should be an extension of licences. The Industry Commission has made a proposal that there be an extension of foreign bank licences. This is not just some idea out of the blue. This proposal has been before the Minister for more than 12 months. How long does it take for the Minister to take account of a submission and to come to some conclusion? The Minister has had 12 months.

—There are always different views put about these matters. Just as the Bureau of Industry Economics might have in one section of the report dealt with this issue and made a suggestion about it, there are plenty of other suggestions to the contrary.
—When are you going to decide?

—That is the gravamen of Senator Vanstone's question: when are we going to decide. I said in answer to Senator Vanstone's first question that when the Government decides this issue we will let her know.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware of allegations on Radio 3LO this morning that the Department of Social Security has asked pensioners over 80 years of age for their tax file numbers when such pensioners should be exempt from the requirement to provide those numbers? Is there any basis for these allegations?
—When are you going to get a bus licence?

—There has been no attempt to gain one either—no attempt at all. This is a serious question which deserves answering. All honourable senators will recall that when the requirement for the provision of tax file numbers was made all those over 80 years of age were exempted. That certainly remains the policy of the Government. On Melbourne radio today I think a pastor had quite a bit to say about tax file numbers being provided by the elderly. I cannot walk away from the provision of tax file numbers for those who are not 80 years old. Of course, it is possible that in some cases a tax file number could be sought from someone over 80. If it was thought that that person was being incorrectly paid, that certainly might happen.

PARA.TAB: However, there is a difficulty in sending out letters to age pensioners because, in looking at the requirements for tax file numbers, my Department, naturally enough, must comply with privacy guidelines. In complying with those, it has to be remembered that it is specified that when requesting tax file numbers from people, those people have to be informed of the consequences of not providing a number.

I can understand why some pensioners would be disappointed and concerned at receiving letters that suggest that they face consequences if a tax file number is not provided. But those pensioners who are over 80 years of age have, by now, been contacted and told that they do not have to provide a tax file number. Unfortunately, in September some of them received a notice suggesting that they did, and they have received letters of apology. But the great bulk of them have received letters notifying them that they do not have to supply tax file numbers, so that will not be a matter of concern.

But I think all honourable senators understood, in passing the legislation, that if we were going to make a requirement of someone who was not 80 but was, let us say, 79 years of age to provide a tax file number and if we had to follow privacy guidelines—again, as everyone in the Senate understood—then obviously we would have some problems in the wording of letters to those people.

So while I certainly cannot promise that there will be no anguish and no angst amongst those people who are asked to provide tax file numbers, I can assure the Senate that all care has been taken. We shall continue to publicise that only those who are under 80 will have to provide them. We have given people plenty of time and notice—the first time was actually in May—of the need to supply them. I do not believe we will find this a great problem in the future. Where problems do arise, we will act to reassure pensioners quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I understand that, during the Minister's recent visit to north Queensland, he was made aware of a bid by the Future North Syndicate to become a primary node of the Adelaide MFP with the goal of attracting investment for technology development and taking advantage of the existing education and tropical research facilities in that area. Will the Minister confirm that the MFP is to be a truly national project in which Adelaide will serve as a catalyst for linkages with other major centres? Does the Minister believe the other States should be represented on the MFP board? If so, will he lend his influence to encourage representation from other States? Finally, if, because of environmental objections, the Adelaide MFP project is to be scaled down, will the Minister support a transference of parts of the project to other suitable sites in Australia?

—The question is in several parts. The first part relates to my being made aware, during a recent visit to north Queensland, of the Future North Syndicate and its proposals in relation to the MFP. The answer is that in the course of that visit I was not made aware of that, but I am aware generally of its interest and of the enthusiasm of that group in north Queensland. I think my Department is keeping in touch with it.

PARA.TAB: The answer to the second part of the question, as to whether the MFP is to be a truly national project, is yes. One would hope that it will be a truly international project. For that reason we have an international advisory board representative of a wide range of interests in Europe, Asia and North America.

In so far as the third part of the question, which relates to the MFP board—as the honourable senator calls it—is concerned, there is a board of the development corporation in Adelaide. I see no case for having interstate representation on that board because that is what it says it is: a development corporation for the site at Gillman. I see every reason—and it is part of the Commonwealth's role—to involve other States in the MFP project in a variety of ways. But I do not see any special need for the involvement of other States in the Adelaide development corporation, although it is not a suggestion that I am hostile to. I am just not sure of the wisdom of it.

The honourable senator asked about environmental objections in relation to Adelaide. I do not know what that means. An EIS is being conducted at the moment. When that is complete, if there are environmental problems it will be the function of the development corporation to clean them up. I take it that is the issue to which the honourable senator is referring.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister how he would involve the States in other ways. I had hoped that there would possibly be interstate representation on the major controlling board or group of the MFP. If the Minister does not think that is possible, how else would he envisage that the other States might be involved; particularly those States where groups such as the Future North Syndicate come from?

—We may be a little at cross purposes, because undoubtedly people from other States will be on the board of the development corporation. It will not be a parochial Adelaide board in that sense. But what form that representation will take is yet to be determined. It will not necessarily be State government representation which is not always, in the context of our Federation, the most desirable thing. But in so far as the possibility of representation from north Queensland is concerned, that is an issue about which I have an open mind. I am prepared to look at it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to the potential to use government purchasing to assist Australian industry to survive and develop. Can the Minister indicate whether the Government supports such use of its purchasing power? If so, can he say whether the Government is prepared to introduce initiatives to this effect and what initiatives may be under consideration?

—I thank Senator Childs for his question. I know he has taken a deep interest in this area, particularly from the manufacturing industry perspective, for some time. As he would know—and I hope other honourable senators would know it as well—major reforms were made to government purchasing in 1989. Up until that date we had applied a notional preference margin for Australian goods and services. I think it was pretty well recognised that that policy did not work. It sent out the wrong messages to government buyers and it also did not send out the right messages to suppliers. So we put in place a new and different message. Basically, that was that Australian suppliers are equal to, or better than, overseas suppliers and, I think as importantly, Australian suppliers offer all sorts of other advantages such as quicker supply, local technical backup, and other more flexible arrangements.

PARA.TAB: As a consequence of that, over the last 18 months or so we have put in place what is essentially a 10-point program to assist Australian industry to get greater access to government purchasing. That, of course, has been based on the principle which has been espoused in the question: that government purchasing can, and does, play an important role in terms of assisting domestic industry.

The first big step in that 10-point program has been to deregulate the purchasing function itself. It has changed from one which was process ridden to one which now relies heavily on the initiative of the purchasing officer. In that process we also changed the consideration by which government purchases have abided. Now the government purchasing officer has been asked to look at value for money as the prime objective. As a consequence, that means there is an advantage to Australian industry, and technical backup and quicker supply are obviously taken into account more than they have been in the past.

Also, as part of that change there has been an explicit policy of maximising opportunities for Australian and New Zealand industry. The second part of the program has been to establish the Purchase Australian Office. That was established to improve opportunities for local suppliers. It has also assisted in fostering recognition amongst purchasers and suppliers of the role they can play in respect of each other.

Another important part of the office has been to investigate complaints of bias in purchasing as against local industry. We have also embarked on a three-point plan of campaign. One of the most important aspects has been to change the culture of purchasing. To do that we have had to change the culture within the public sector to get it to appreciate the benefits of buying domestically. The Offshore, What For? campaign was developed for that purpose. As well as that, together with David Beddall I have been involved in a program of meet-the-buyers exhibitions, basically to establish contact between suppliers and government purchasers in order that they can both understand how each other works and what government needs are in terms of purchasing. The Purchase Australian campaign continues, and next week I will be launching a new phase directed towards suppliers, once again geared to greater information sharing amongst them all.

An important move was the measure to redress inequity in the system. Government and government suppliers had been exempt from paying import duties, which everyone else was obliged to pay. To send the appropriate signal to buyers and to level the playing field here to assist Australian industry, the duty has now been levied and purchasers are now required to pay equivalent to import duty on the purchases they make from abroad.

The specifications have been changed. We recognise that there is inherent bias in the old system of process ridden specifications. We have now moved towards functional ones. In themselves, they lead to less reliance on off-the-shelf overseas products, which also help to disadvantage Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is becoming a very long answer, Senator Bolkus.
—It is a long answer, Mr President, but Senator Childs has asked an important question.
—Boring!
—I do not think it is boring, nor does Australian industry. However, I will probably need another three minutes to answer it. If I could go on—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—No!

TALK.START.PARA: —I stress the point that we are talking about an important aspect of government purchasing that can assist Australian industry. The Opposition comes in here and asks trivial and irrelevant questions of no concern to anyone.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. This is a debate on an irrelevancy.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, continue the answer.

—I had got to the point of the need to coordinate government purchasing between the States and the Federal Government. One advantage to Australian industry would be to ensure that in the future in a whole range of areas it would not have to go through six or eight different processes with six or eight different provisions of contract. We are working towards common contracts, in cooperation with the States. An important area, and the seventh point in terms of this program, is the recognition by this Government of the need to improve the quality of products of industry within Australia. Next year—

—I raise a further point of order, Mr President. There has to be a limit. Those opposite complained a while ago when a question took over 30 seconds. Are you saying that Senator Bolkus can stand there for the whole of Question Time and read this statement that he ought to be putting down at a later hour?
—Order! Including the interjections, the answer has now gone for five and three-quarter minutes. I suggest that the Minister wind it up.

—Mr President, I am glad you said `including the interjections', because they have been quite frustrating. There are three more points to raise with respect to this matter and I will do that. I mentioned quality.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have told Senator Bolkus to conclude the answer and I believe that he is doing that.

—I raise a separate point of order, Mr President. I know that you have traditionally taken the view that you do not have much discretion in controlling the answers that Ministers give, but I think you are in a position to decide what is an answer and what is not. It is quite clear from what Senator Bolkus has just said that he has three more points to make and he is going to make them irrespective. They have nothing to do with the answer. He is making a statement, and I invite you to rule that this is not an answer to a question.

—I must come in at this point. Senator Childs asked a question about government purchasing. It is an important consideration in the community. I should be given the normal amount of time to finish my answer.
—Order! I ask Senator Bolkus to conclude his answer.

—In terms of these initiatives, we have been exploring other practical ways of assisting Australian industry. The purchasing services group is now seeking the cooperation of suppliers to ensure that components of products they sell to government are maximised in terms of the Australian content.We are establishing procurement plans together with industry. The furniture working group, which has been initiated in recent days, is a great example of this. It has shown that Australian industry can work with government purchasers to advance its cause.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, we have also been targeting environmentally friendly products in order to ensure that a market is created in Australia that we can use to go overseas with. We are aware of the potential of our purchasing power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Resume your seat, Senator Bolkus. I call Senator Boswell.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tate interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Three times I asked Senator Bolkus to conclude his answer. I do not need your help, Senator Tate. Nine minutes have passed from the moment Senator Bolkus stood to answer this question. There have been a number of interjections. It has been a very long answer. I have called Senator Boswell.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. The Minister, Mr Bob Brown, during an answer to a question last Thursday stated that total charges proposed for a six-axle articulated vehicle would be between $7,000 and $8,000 and, by inference, that there would be no further increase before 1995. Senator Collins, in his answer to a question on 15 October, told the Senate that the National Road Transport Commission would recommend charges by 1992 to apply no later than January 1993 and that full cost recovery would be phased in by 1 July 1995, and 2000 for road trains. As there is now total confusion in the transport industry caused by the conflicting statements by Senator Collins and his ministerial colleague Mr Brown, can he inform the Senate whether the total cost recovery will be between $7,000 and $8,000, as these will be the charges in January 1993 and there will be no further charges before 1995, or is the Minister saying that there will be—
—Order! Ask the question, Senator Boswell.

—Or is the Minister saying that a charge of $4,000 will be applied no later than 1 January 1993 and be phased up to full cost recovery of $7,000 to $8,000 by July 1995? Will the Minister clarify the position to confirm Mr Brown's figure—
—Order!
—that $7,000 to $8,000 would be the total registration charge for a 42-tonne six-axle articulated truck?
—Order! I tried to point out twice during the asking of that question that a question that long is another abuse of Question Time.
—We don't need Michael Tate to try to intimidate the President.
—And I do not need that sort of assistance.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I ask Senator Walters to withdraw that offensive remark that I was trying to intimidate you.
—Order! I do not regard it as being offensive. It is a debating point.

—I will attempt to keep my answer to about half the length of Senator Boswell's question. The only confusion that exists is with Senator Boswell. He knows full well that no charges have been set. This is a complex area and it has been subjected to a lot of debate; but even those who have been involved only on the periphery know that the entire process is in the hands of the Premiers Conference. Senator Boswell knows that it is not simply a Federal Government responsibility; it is collectively in the hands of the Prime Minister and the Premiers and Chief Ministers. They have determined that no charges have yet been set.

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell rightly talks about inferences. A whole range of charges has been recommended and suggested by various bodies. It is true that the committees that have assisted the Premiers Conference and other groups have come up with those sorts of figures. The figures do show that, based on the models used at the time, a 42.5-tonne, six-axle articulated truck may be paying something in the vicinity of $7,000 to $8,000, phased in from 1 January 1993 to 1 July 1995. This would be based on a nominated mass approach for vehicles travelling an average distance for their vehicle class. This is what both I and Mr Brown have been saying. I might add that Senator Boswell omitted to say—and it should be said for the clarification of everyone—that Queensland will be nominated as a low cost zone.

I might add that that initiative—from which I take some satisfaction—was brought about as the result of very strenuous representations made by my colleague in the House of Representatives Warren Snowdon; by me as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia; and, I am happy to say, because I helped facilitate the meetings, very effectively made to the Prime Minister personally by representatives from the trucking organisations themselves. As a result of that, the charges in Senator Boswell's State, as he well knows, will be lower than those amounts when they are set.

If the Australian Transport Advisory Council does decide—and this at the moment is a very open question—to move to a mass distance formula, the charging after 1995 will indeed reflect actual distances travelled rather than the average distance for that class of vehicle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has said that the charge will be $7,000 to $8,000 by 1995. He has conceded that point. Mr Brown in the other place has said that the $7,000 to $8,000 will be a total charge. There is still confusion and conflict. Can the Minister tell us whether the $8,000 will be the total charge, or will that be the charge phased in to 1993?

—I direct my question to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. I refer the Minister to yesterday's article in the Telegraph Mirror which states that X-ray services at many medical centres may be forced to close because of a planned reduction in the schedule fee—and, thereby, a reduction in the Medicare rebate—for radiology services provided by these centres. I ask the Minister, firstly, has he or his Department consulted with any group or persons representing the medical centres affected by this change, or the Australian Institute of Radiography about these proposals? If not, why not, and will he give an undertaking to so do at the earliest opportunity? Secondly, how does the Minister respond to claims by the centres that the introduction of these charges will result in the end of radiology services in these centres, the end of bulkbilling of X-rays services and increased, rather than reduced, costs? Finally, has the Minister or his Department ever commissioned any study of the cost of radiology services provided in a 12-hour per day 7-day per week service, which is when they are open? If not, what evidence does the Minister have that these centres are overservicing and will he make this evidence publicly available?

—The Government did announce the restructuring of diagnostic imaging in the recent Federal Budget, as part of its package to reduce Medicare outlays and deal with the unacceptably high growth in diagnostic services, both in radiology and pathology. The proposed restructure of diagnostic imaging services rendered by specialist radiologists under Medicare has been the subject of considerable consultation with the relevant professional groups—the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists and the Australian Medical Association.

PARA.TAB: The consultations have taken place under the banner of the Medicare Benefits Consultative Committee, an informal mechanism established by agreement between the Minister for Community Services and Health and the President of the AMA. This Committee is responsible for the ongoing review of the many sections of the Medicare benefits schedule and for advising the Minister on appropriate changes to it. Membership comprises representatives of the Department, the Health Insurance Commission, the AMA and the relevant professional groups.

The restructure of diagnostic imaging services is based on the advice provided by independent consultants, Coopers and Lybrand, which constructed model practices for comprehensive radiology and other radiology practices which provide for each type of practice costing information, covering for example running expenses, capital expenses and salaries. The Medicare fees that will flow from the consultants' report will provide for a reasonable return for each level of practice where the practice operates efficiently and economically. The new fee structure will remove the potential for unnecessary services by reducing fees for plain X-rays—for example, chest and limbs—based on the model practice, and increasing fees for the more complex diagnostic radiological services.

The model practice produced by the consultant provides for a practice which operates during normal hours. The decision to provide services beyond these hours is a matter for each practice. Medicare fees do not reflect costs associated with after hours services. The restructuring is designed to reduce Medicare outlays for diagnostic imaging by $20m in a full year by removing the financial incentives that currently exist, to render unnecessary services wherever such services are provided. Patient access to radiology services will not be adversely affected, although there will inevitably be some rationalisation within the radiology profession.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the propitious day of 11 November, Senator Panizza asked me a question concerning the alleged, by him, actions of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union in relation to the proposed Moora Straw Based Pulp and Paper Mill. I have a long answer to that question. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr President, I have now had the opportunity to inquire into this matter and I must say at the outset that I am disappointed that Senator Panizza has chosen to misrepresent the intentions of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union.

Mr President, on 11 November, Senator Panizza asserted in his question that this particular union is and I quote `trying to wreck the proposed straw pulp & paper mill at Moora in Western Australia before it gets off the ground'.

The basis of Senator Panizza's concerns emanate, in part, from a letter he received from the union which—rather than wreck the proposal as asserted by Senator Panizza—is a genuine attempt by the union to clarify the position with respect to the likely effects of the Moora proposal on existing domestic manufacturers and employment in the packaging industry in Western Australia.
Clearly the union would, and indeed should, be concerned if jobs were deliberately threatened.
Mr President, the union's principal concerns are twofold.
First, whilst supporting the need for economically viable and competitive new investments in Australia, the union questions the economic feasibility of the proposed Moora project.
Second, the union is concerned that imported packaging product now imported by a potential partner in the Moora proposal is imported at dumped prices and threatening local industry and employment.

Taking these issues seriatim, I am advised that the Australian Wheat Board, a shareholder in the Moora Project, commissioned a consultancy into the economic feasibility of a wheat straw based pulp & paper mill at Moora in Western Australia.

The funds used so far, some $1.2 million, are drawn from the Wheat Industry Fund. The Wheat Board administers the fund in accordance with an Annual Business Plan approved by the Grains Council of Australia.
The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is not involved in approving this Plan, reflecting the grower ownership of this fund.

The Government's main involvement in the fund is through the provision of a guarantee of fund borrowings up to a limit of $100 million for the first five years of the fund's establishment. This guarantee terminates after 1993-94.

The Wheat Marketing Act 1989 sets out the uses of the Wheat Industry Fund and Ministerial approval had previously been given under Section 82(1)(e) of the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 for the Wheat Board to invest money in a manner consistent with sound commercial practice to generate income.
It is under this approval that the Wheat Board has proceeded with its involvement with the Moora Company.

The Moora Project is a commercial project and in that regard, the Wheat Board has advised that the feasibility study for the Project, which was undertaken by Jaako Poyry, is a confidential document to the shareholders of the project namely the Australian Wheat Board, the Riverhouse Group and the Moora Community.
The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has not seen any such reports by Jaako Poyry and therefore cannot comment on them.
Having said that, however, I'm aware that there is considerable debate in Western Australia about the Moora Project and its financial viability.

I am aware that other independent assessments of the financial viability of the Moora Project have been undertaken by reputable consultants, including NLK-Celpap, which have concluded that the project is not financially viable.

Accordingly, in view of the Commonwealth's involvement in guaranteeing the Wheat Board's Wheat Industry Fund, the Government will be taking a keen interest to ensure that should the Moora Project proceed, then it does so on the strength of its commercial viability.

Moving on Mr President, and in relation to the Union's concern that packaging product, now imported by a shareholder in the Moora Project, is imported at dumped prices, I am unable to take this matter any further as it is not a matter for the Government to initiate anti-dumping actions.
Suffice it to say, however, that the packaging industry in Australia is dominated by two suppliers—Australian Paper Manufacturers and Visy Board.
The market in Western Australia consumes about 35,000 tonnes of box packaging per year and Riverhouse Packaging—a shareholder in the Moora Project—is importing around 100 tonnes per month.
In this regard, it is well-known that this Government will not allow unfair competition from dumped imports which damage local industry.

In the March Economic Statement, the Government took steps to immediately strengthen anti-dumping procedures as well as initiating a comprehensive review of anti-dumping procedures and the operations of the Anti-Dumping Authority. The review will be finalised by the end of this year.
The review is comparing the anti-dumping practices of other countries and involves a detailed comparison of the requirements of GATT against current Australian legislation and practices.

In conclusion, Mr President the behaviour of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union is entirely appropriate and their actions have been directed to clarifying the situation surrounding the Moora Project and not wrecking the project as Senator Panizza would have us believe.

TALK.START.PARA: —I conclude by saying that perhaps Senator Panizza ought to have told us whether he is in fact a shareholder in Riverhouse Packaging, one of the shareholder companies in the project.
—I am not. I rise on a point of order. Mr President, I seek your guidance in this matter. I think Senator Cook's statement should be withdrawn.

—Riverhouse.

—Mr President, I rise on that point of order. There is a real dilemma and I seek your guidance. Senator Cook has done that on an innumerable number of times with regard to Robe River and now he is doing it to a senator in the House and you say that there is nothing that you can do about it. —Mr President, on the original point of order which raises a very serious question for resolution by you, under the rules of debate, standing order 193(3) provides that a senator shall not use offensive words and shall not cast imputations of improper motives or any personal reflections on members of either House and, in the event that he does so, those remarks shall be considered highly disorderly.

PARA.TAB: We have just seen Senator Cook making statements which have been vigorously and immediately denied by Senator Panizza. In those circumstances I would have thought that it is incumbent upon Senator Cook to explain himself. He simply cannot cast slurs in that way, have them immediately denied and walk away from them. To the extent that he does, I invite you, Mr President, to rule that they are clearly imputations of improper motives and a personal reflection on Senator Panizza's reputation. In those circumstances, Senator Cook ought to be invited by the Senate to explain himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on the same point of order I wish very briefly to support Senator Alston in drawing your attention to rules of debate, as set out on page 79 of the Standing Orders. It is unfortunate that none of us were alert enough to quickly draw the particular words of standing order 193 to your attention. I believe that if we had been that alert, the point that Senator Alston has made could have led to your ruling that an improper motive was imputed by Senator Cook of Senator Panizza. Clearly, if he was saying that there was a personal financial interest on the part of one senator who had asked a question, it is an improper motive. That is how I have interpreted this. It is offensive to this particular standing order. I do not know whether you can rule now with regard to Senator Alston's point of order. I ask that, in any event, you take this matter into consideration and at a subsequent hour this day you consider asking Senator Cook to withdraw the imputation of an improper motive.

—Order! As I remember the incident, Senator Cook said that Senator Panizza should make it clear whether he was a shareholder. I take that to be a debating point. It was not unparliamentary. I have sought advice on two occasions. I do not believe that there was an imputation in it. I am not going to ask him to withdraw.

—In Question Time yesterday Senator Alston asked me a question about the eligibility of people on a picket line at the Camperdown abattoir in Victoria to receive Jobsearch allowance. The Camperdown abattoir closed in May this year and employees lost their jobs. Many applied for, and received, social security payments. They were not involved in industrial action and, therefore, were not disqualified from receiving social security payments on that basis.

PARA.TAB: The Camperdown abattoir has been picketed by AMIEU members since it reopened recently, using contract labour supplied by Troubleshooters Available. This latter company has achieved publicity through its activities in the construction industry in Victoria. There have been some vigorous exchanges involving the police, picketers and contract labour which have been reported in the press and on television.

The manager of the abattoir has alleged to the Belmont regional office that some of its former employees are regularly involved in the picket. The implication of the allegation is that former employees are receiving Jobsearch allowance and, by virtue of their picketing activities, would have difficulty in satisfying the eligibility requirement that they be actively engaged in looking for work.

Advice on how the regional office should proceed in the light of the information provided by the abattoir's management was sought from national administration. The decision was that the regional office should review the Jobsearch activities of former abattoir's employees receiving Jobsearch allowance. This involves recipients completing a form detailing their intentions regarding employment and the steps taken to obtain it. That is standard practice where whether a person is available for actively seeking work is at issue. The regional office has this process under way. After that there is an interview and then a request for the production of cards from employers.

These two amendments relate to the family allowance supplement and they are the same as the two previous amendments. If passed, they would enable farmers to get free ready access, depending on income, to the family allowance supplement, but that would leave the rest of the assets test in place. In amendment No. 4 we would be taking out only the family farm and, in amendment No. 5, the family owned small business.

PARA.TAB: I remind honourable senators that the family allowance supplement was put in place to help fulfil the promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that, `No child will be living in poverty by 1990'. It seems that we are now passing through this place legislation that does, indeed, leave some children, in particular rural children, very much below the poverty line.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

Amendment No. 6 will take from the assets test on all benefits the family farm and, in the case of amendment No. 7, which I will move later, small business. I want to emphasise the need to act now to relieve the hardship in rural Australia. It is by no means the only solution or the ultimate solution. It just gives farmers some breathing space if they are able to access unemployment benefits.

PARA.TAB: After all the debate on this Bill and the previous debates we have had in this chamber about the rural crisis, if people are still not convinced I will read into Hansard a couple of paragraphs from an article in today's Australian entitled `Farmers' incomes collapse into red' by a rural writer, Tim Stevens:
Average incomes for Australia's 125,000 farmers are forecast to fall into the red this financial year for the first time, confirming the rural crisis as the worst on record.
The figures—as yet unreleased—mean the rural sector may be spending several hundred million dollars more than it is earning.

A revision of the Federal Government's farm income forecast, expected to be released next week, is in response to the worsening drought and new figures from a joint government-National Farmers Federation survey.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics is expected to release the survey at next week's general council meeting of the NFF and it will spark fresh calls for increased government assistance to the rural sector.
The figures coincide with a comprehensive survey by the National Australia Bank which says farmers could lose as much as $300 million this financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: I urge honourable senators to support this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is that this amendment completely excludes farmers from assets testing for social security. There has got to be some targeting. We have gone to great lengths today to set an assets test limit that is high and then to allow for hardship provisions to get around it. This amendment says that farmers in social security—period—should not be subjected to an assets test. That is just not targeting. I am afraid that the Government could not possibly accept it. I do not think the Opposition does either.

—This amendment may be as the Minister for Social Security has characterised it, but it is a fact that within this legislation it can be possible, with imagination, actually to achieve something that helps farmers immediately. When we look at some of the other arrangements that are made, their complexity is such that in effect it is difficult to see an immediate result for farmers. For example, if we take the rural assistance scheme, part C, by the time the farmer has made the decision that he should apply for, be eligible for and actually receive assistance under such a scheme, the decision has to be made to leave the farm. That is not a decision that can be made overnight. Yet immediately that decision is made, the family—three or four generations of which may have earned their income from that farm—is faced with an entirely different lifestyle arrangement and future from that which they have been used to for some generations.

PARA.TAB: The regulations might look as if they can help the farmers, but actually to have them apply and bring immediate relief is very rare indeed. As a matter of fact, there are very few who are able to fit that category. The suggestions Senator Lees has been making in the amendments have been to bring immediate relief. I remind the Minister that this latest amendment would not mean that every farmer would immediately become eligible for social security payments, because the income test would still remain. There is no suggestion that that is the purpose behind Senator Lees's amendment. The purpose is to bring immediate financial relief to those families suffering hardship at the moment. If a slight change to a few words would bring about that relief, surely we ought to be looking at that instead of finding excuses why it cannot be done.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a matter of finding excuses why it cannot be done. I have been bending over backwards and have found a way to do some of these things. It is just not responsible to say that no-one in the rural community should face assets testing. I do not even hear anyone in the National Party advocate that. It is just not responsible. No government that is trying in any way to control social security spending—and $28 billion is coming out of the portfolio this year—could responsibly agree to this amendment.

PARA.TAB: I am not going to go into RAS because we are going to debate that the week after next, but it is not anticipated that farmers are suddenly going to talk to the RAS people about their situation. The farmers who are going to be assisted by this or who finish up going off the land have been talking to the RAS people for a long time. Farmers do not suddenly wake up and realise that they have got a non-viable farm. That is something that occurs over time, and they seek assistance for their problems over time. No-one is saying that they are suddenly going to RAS as a result of this. The RAS scheme people talk to farmers on an ongoing basis.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lees's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Amendment negatived.
