SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) relating to the economy and employment and to move to take note of the statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia today is at a point of historic convergence: the hurt of the recession is at its point of maximum impact; yet, simultaneously, and by no means coincidentally, the gains and rewards of the long hard process of restructuring are within our grasp.

PARA.TAB: The immediate focus of this statement is on the problem of unemployment. But through that prism, we want today to look ahead—to the prospects and promise for this nation.

In this statement today we bring to the people of Australia a message of fundamental confidence. It is a message grounded firmly on the facts, not only the factual evidence of recovery, but upon the most important fact of all—that the work of this Government over the years, and the response of the Australian people, have brought us together to the threshold of a new era of achievement.

In the specific context of unemployment, we begin with this unqualified assertion: this Labor Government has an unalterable commitment to preventing the present levels of unemployment from becoming a permanent feature of the Australian economy and the Australian society. I say to this House what the Prime Minister has said repeatedly outside: he has not spent the whole of his 33 years in public life in the Labor movement of Australia to acquiesce in allowing the present high levels of unemployment to continue.

Some weeks ago, the Prime Minister initiated an examination of what action the Government could take to respond to the current severe unemployment situation. In the same period, the Parliamentary Labor Party's working group on unemployment under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Page, Mr Harry Woods, has worked with great diligence to produce a constructive report. Further, in accordance with undertakings the Prime Minister gave in his address to the ACTU Congress in September, he met with representatives of the ACTU on 29 October to consider their proposals to alleviate unemployment. The Prime Minister has also had the benefit of consultation within the Economic Planning Advisory Council.

As an outcome of these analyses and these consultations, we shall be detailing, later in this statement, measures related to the unemployment problem. These measures build on the strategy for reducing unemployment already put in place by the Budget. The measures include:

SPEECH.PARA: -initiatives in the post—secondary area to ensure that our young men and women have access to training, in the long term, as well as in the short term. High quality investment in additional training now will deliver a work force better suited to the challenges of the future;

-a further expansion of labour market programs to assist the unemployed obtain and upgrade skills. This will not only help prepare for the recovery but will ensure a proper safety net is provided for those who have been most affected by the recession;

-the acceleration of infrastructure projects in the areas of road, rail, post-secondary education, and science, with benefits for our traded goods industries and for the quality of teaching and research in our educational and scientific institutions; and
-facilitation of the development of new industries and restructuring of existing industries.

PARA.TAB: These measures total some $313m in calendar year 1992. They are measures which meet the critical tests of advancing our economic strategy, while maintaining the integrity of the Budget.

Since the Budget, we have been carefully watching economic developments to ensure that the Budget strategy for sustainable recovery with low inflation is on track. It is on track, and we are determined that it stay on track. This Government will not be diverted from its fundamental economic strategy and its goals:

SPEECH.PARA: -sustainable recovery to provide sustainable job growth, and rising living standards
-and, above all, the goal of building an internationally competitive economy.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, there may be some who would argue that the Government, satisfied as we are that the fundamental economic strategy is on track, should pay no regard to the representations of the ACTU, and others, on the matters dealt with in this statement.

Not only do we reject that argument, but we go further. The very fact that our strategy is on track—the fact that the great objective of creating a restructured, low inflation, internationally competitive economy is now within our grasp—is in large measure a result of the constructive cooperation and restraint that has been practised by the working men and women of Australia. That is, precisely, a reason to listen to those who represent them.

Their members have experienced unemployment, not only through the recession, but through the process of long term industrial restructuring we are pursuing. Yet in the representations they have made to us they have not asked for this process to be slowed. They understand, accept and are committed to its continuation, in the knowledge that it is in the long term interest of their country.

And, of course, Mr President, the views of the union movement reflect the growing concern at all levels of the community, as the statistical projection of unemployment of more than 10 per cent, made in May, has become the harsh reality.

Nobody feels this concern more deeply than the Prime Minister. It is a concern fully shared by every member of the Government. That is why we accept it as our inescapable duty to take whatever action we responsibly can to restore sustainable job growth as soon as possible.

Given this Government's unsurpassed record of job creation since 1983, there can be no doubt about our commitment to this goal and our capacity to achieve it. This is a Government which from its inception has been absolutely committed to sustainable job growth.

Budget-time forecasts were for growth of around 3 3/4 per cent through the course of 1991-92. The main sources of growth were expected to be business restocking, housing investment, and moderate growth in private consumption. Net exports were also expected to contribute to growth.

Indicators available since the Budget support those forecasts: we are coming out of recession. The early stages of recovery are clearly evident in the trend growth now apparent in the housing and retail sectors, and there are now positive signs pointing to recovery in other sectors. Building approvals for private dwellings increased by around 15 per cent in the September quarter. Retail sales have shown renewed strength, growing by 2.9 per cent in real terms in the September quarter. Indexes of consumer sentiment are significantly above their levels of a year ago. Business surveys indicate that the outlook for sales, profits, and investment is beginning to improve.

Our international trading performance has improved markedly. We are on track to record a current account deficit in the order of $14 billion in 1991-92, considerably lower than in recent years both in absolute terms and as a proportion of GDP.
While unemployment has reached unacceptable levels, the level of employment has stabilised in the last four months, halting the falls in employment that have been occurring since mid-1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are choking on what you are saying.
—If Senator Parer ever had to read anything as long as this, he probably would himself.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are pathetic! The recent improving trend in full time employment is encouraging.

PARA.TAB: All this is consistent with the view that the economy is in the early stages of recovery. This is not to deny that unemployment may rise further. But the essential point is that the evidence of the recovery has begun to appear.

A central objective of the Budget strategy is to ensure that, as the recovery proceeds, the Budget will move back into surplus. This will free national savings for productive investment by the private sector. In this way, the current account will be safeguarded and the economy set on a sustainable growth path.
Since the Budget was drawn up, the immediate risk that private calls on national savings would grow faster than public calls were falling has lessened.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stumbling again.
—I am sorry. I will put my glasses on. I am not like Senator Newman with perfect insight.

SPEECH.PARA: This lessening is attributable to two main factors:
-first, the forecast reductions in inflation have been factored into community expectations more rapidly than we had hoped;
-and second, there has been a worsening of the drought, leading us to be less sanguine about prospects for the rural sector.

PARA.TAB: These domestic developments have taken place against the background of some uncertainties about the economic prospects for our major trading partners.

The changes have not been of a magnitude to cause us to revise the Budget forecasts for overall activity. However, they have reduced the risk that any supplementary measures would see the public sector's call on national resources become unsustainably high. This reduced risk is particularly true of measures targeted to the period immediately ahead.
In short, there is now some scope to do more to prepare for new jobs and opportunities.
But, we must continue to recognise the limits which responsible economic management imposes, at this critical point in the recovery.

To fail to do so would be to throw away the real gains which underlie the present economic situation, and which underpin the splendid prospects ahead for this nation, as a strong, competitive, low inflation economy, enmeshing itself in the economies of the world's fastest growing region.
To maximise the benefit to the economy at this stage of the cycle, the measures we announce today are concentrated in calendar year 1992 and, wherever possible, in the first half of 1992.
Mr President, we have said that a major thrust of these measures is directed towards expansion of education and training programs.
In this area, we announce today proposals involving gross expenditure in calendar year 1992 of $130m.

Education and training are basic to the Government's strategy of building a competitive Australia. And they are basic to the more immediate hopes and aspirations of many thousands of individual Australians, especially among our young people.

Community demand for education and training is at its highest level ever. The proportion of our young people remaining to the end of secondary school has virtually doubled in a decade and student numbers at our universities have risen by over 50 per cent.

A different situation, however, applies in vocational education and training, including TAFE. While student demand for TAFE and training has continued to increase strongly, labour market conditions and budgetary priorities of State governments, who have the responsibility in this area, have combined to limit the training opportunities made available in this essential sector. In consequence, the level of unmet demand for TAFE has risen steeply in recent years.

This situation demands urgent action. I may say, Mr President, that one of the major disappointments arising from the Premiers' decision not to attend the Special Premiers Conference in Perth next week is that it will make resolution of these problems even more difficult.

The problem has been highlighted by the Finn report on post—compulsory education and training. The Finn report poses major challenges for all governments, State and Commonwealth. We must respond to these challenges. It is time TAFE took its rightful place within the education system of Australia.

The Government has decided to provide extra funding in 1992 to enable additional enrolments in post-school education, mainly in TAFE. In total, a sum of $115m will be provided for post-secondary education and training. A further $15m in higher education capital funding will be brought forward from 1994. This additional funding will be allocated mainly to provide additional TAFE places, and to meet urgent needs for equipment and building refurbishment in both TAFE and universities.

For 1992, the Government expects that these measures will provide an additional 40,000 students with opportunities to gain vocational skills. The States will be required at least to maintain their expenditure in real terms in 1992, pending the negotiation of longer term arrangements. They have also agreed to cooperate in maximising the number of places provided from the additional Commonwealth funding.

Looking to the longer term, the Commonwealth will continue to pursue its offer to the States of a new set of funding arrangements for vocational education and training, designed to upgrade the capacity and status of our

SPEECH.PARA: TAFE and training institutions. We see this as an urgent national priority.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, the unemployed have borne the heaviest cost of the recession. Despite the economic recovery which is now under way, the number of long term unemployed will continue to rise for some time to come. If we are to harness in full the opportunities provided by recovery, we must strengthen the skills of job seekers and particularly the long term unemployed. It makes economic sense to do so—by ensuring that skills shortages do not emerge during the recovery. More importantly, social justice demands that we do so.

Today, we announce enhancements to the employment access program, Skillshare and the self-employment assistance program to enable larger numbers of the long term unemployed to obtain the skills needed to take advantage of new job and business opportunities as these emerge from the recovery.
The enhancements will provide increased opportunities for some 56,000 unemployed people in 1992, including:

SPEECH.PARA: .an increase in training places that will prepare an additional 31,000 people for labour market re-entry;
.an increase in the Jobstart program, providing an additional 15,500 job subsidy placements;
.an increase in the special intervention program to provide an additional 9,000 especially disadvantaged with assistance early in their period of unemployment.

With these enhancements, in addition to those announced with the implementation of the Newstart program, at least 300,000 unemployed people will be assisted by the CES through labour market programs in 1992. This additional assistance will involve gross expenditure of $78m in 1991-92 and $124m in 1992-93. This will raise total labour market program expenditure from $400m in 1990-91 to an estimated $774m in 1992-93.

PARA.TAB: We have identified areas where some major Commonwealth infrastructure spending could be accelerated—spending which would have occurred anyway because of its essential nature or high economic returns for the nation. Today we announce expenditures totalling $112m in calendar year 1992 to improve our economic infrastructure. Such improvements will bear directly on the competitiveness of our export sector.

The task of internationalising the Australian economy requires an internationally competitive transport infrastructure. This year, we have made major advances in this area with the establishment of the National Rail Corporation, the National Road Transport Commission, continuing rapid reform of our shipping industry and dramatic developments in the reform of our waterfront industry.

We will bring forward $82m of roads expenditure on the national highway system and arterial roads, and provide $20m for what will become the rail network of the NRC. This spending will provide industry with a better, more efficient transport system. In doing so, it will support the continued expansion of our export sector. At the same time, it will provide a direct boost to employment and confidence.

We also announce today that we will provide $10m immediately to CSIRO to upgrade its facilities. These funds will be fully spent in 1992. This decision will ensure that CSIRO researchers will have the physical infrastructure necessary to maintain their vital work.
The Government is acutely aware of the problems that are being encountered as the Australian economy undertakes its essential restructuring:

SPEECH.PARA: -our exporters are entering new, highly competitive markets;
-many of our traditional firms are confronting radical change and a requirement to make substantial new investments;
-new firms are struggling to establish themselves and, often, new technologies.

Today we announce measures designed to assist in each of these areas. The Government will allocate an additional $10m to the Development Import Finance Facility (DIFF) in 1992. The funds will enable us to offer finance to Australian firms for significant new projects in China, India and South East Asia. The decision will allow the DIFF to meet more of the demand on its funds. The existing backlog meant that projects in power, communications, transport and resource processing had been held over. In all those sectors, Australia is rapidly establishing international competitiveness.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, since the Prime Minister's March statement, a number of companies in the textile, clothing and footwear industries have demonstrated their commitment to the Government's objective of creating strong and viable industries—industries which will be competitive and in which jobs will be secure. To reinforce this commitment, the Government will bring forward $15m in calendar year 1992, to be available for restructuring purposes approved by the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority.

The Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) has recorded a profit of $9.6m for 1990-91. The Corporation has asked to retain this profit as additional capital to help meet the demand for equity in new project development. We recognise that additional capital is needed particularly for new investments in resource processing. The Government has therefore agreed that the profit should be retained by the Corporation. The Government has also decided to extend the Commonwealth guarantee on the Corporation's liabilities to 1998. This recognises the importance of the Corporation's role in industry development, by enabling it to minimise its borrowing costs.

In the March statement, the Prime Minister announced a major extension of sales tax exemptions available to business. The legislation is currently before the Senate. Allowing for the flow-on effects of reducing costs earlier in the production chain, the exemptions will provide a total benefit to business of more than $1 billion in a full year.

This statement today focuses, and properly does so at this time, on the matter of most immediate concern to the people of Australia, the problem of unemployment. We do not seek to disguise the magnitude of the problem. We should all acknowledge the fact that even when the recovery is fully under way and job growth restored substantial reduction of unemployment levels will take time. To grasp this reality, one has only to recall the post-recession experience last time. Even when this Government had achieved average job creation of 230,000 a year, as it did over the period to mid-1990, the associated fall in unemployment was gradual compared with the spectacular growth in jobs.

But in acknowledging that, let me say that it is time—beyond time—to stop talking down the Australian economy. The central fact is that the Budget strategy is on course. The economy is recovering, and we will emerge from the recession with a stronger economy than before. Let me illustrate this truth by pointing to the results of the structural reforms we have already achieved. Exports of manufactured goods have increased by 112 per cent in real terms since 1983-84. Within manufacturing, exports of manufactured metals have risen by 62 per cent and exports of the more complex non-metal manufactured goods have increased by 147 per cent. Over the same period, exports of services have increased by 77 per cent.

The official OECD statistics show that Australia's manufactured export performance in the past five years has been by far the best in the OECD. They show that, in real terms, annual growth of manufactured exports has averaged over 15 per cent in Australia compared with the OECD average of 6 per cent. Australia's rate of manufactured export growth has even outpaced that of the four newly industrialising economies of Asia—South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong. These trends emerged well before the recession and have continued throughout the recession. These facts are a remarkable tribute to the drive and initiative of much of our business sector. It is a performance which presents an example and a challenge to the whole business community.

As I have indicated, the performance in many service areas, notably tourism, has also been strong. Overseas tourist arrivals have more than doubled in just five years. The numbers are expected almost to treble again by the year 2000, to around six million. These projections lend compelling force to the Government's decisions in relation to aviation. Following yesterday's decision by Federal Cabinet to approve the construction of a third runway at Sydney Airport, the Federal Airports Corporation expects preliminary work to begin within a month and major construction contracts to be let early next year.

As well as generating many thousands of sustainable new jobs at the airport and in directly related activities in the years ahead, the third runway will provide the capacity to meet the projected strong growth in tourist traffic. In addition, the Government will shortly examine a proposal for the development of a general aviation airport at Badgerys Creek, Sydney's designated international airport. Based on preliminary design work already completed, it is envisaged that this new aerodrome would be operational in 1994.
The strong performance in the manufacturing and service industries has been buttressed by the continuing strength of the mining sector.
My Government has recently announced a new process aimed at encouraging major development projects including mining and minerals processing, agriculture and forestry.
The process for approving major projects in these areas will be speeded up, although I emphasise that proper environmental standards and Aboriginal and heritage issues will not be by-passed.
The strength of the manufacturing, services and mining industries stands in sharp contrast to the current plight of the rural sector.
Many farmers have been hit by drought, compounding the severe downturn in farm prices, caused mainly by the trade war between the European Community and the United States.

As part of our commitment to easing the burden on the rural sector, the Government has massively increased funding for the rural adjustment scheme—from $62m in 1990—91 to $173m in 1991—92. Further, we have just announced arrangements to link RAS assessments to social security benefits.

It has to be acknowledged, however, that enduring relief will not occur unless there is liberalisation of agricultural trade. The farmers of Australia can be assured that this Government will continue to do all we can, in the coming crucial weeks of the Uruguay Round, to ensure it reaches a successful conclusion.

We now have an historic opportunity to move into the twenty-first century with a dynamic, reinvigorated, modern Australian economy. We have a unique opportunity to break the cycle of boom and bust. We have the opportunity to become one of the vibrant growth economies of the Asia-Pacific region.

To seize this historic opportunity, we as a Government and a nation must embrace a set of key objectives and policies, designed to reinforce and accelerate the internationalisation of the Australian economy.
Australia's course is clear.
We must lock in the gains of low inflation. We must keep our nerve and resist demands for artificial solutions to the recession.
We must ensure that new investment continues to flow into our competitive, international industries with the economic recovery.
We must continue the vigorous pursuit of micro-economic reform.
We must continue the thrust towards the `clever country'. We must continue to assert maximum possible pressure for a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations.
We must, consistent with the commitment to growth, maintain in perpetuity our matchless environmental assets through policies for ecologically sustainable development.
That is this Government's national agenda for growth and reform. It is an agenda for jobs. It is an agenda for lasting, sustainable growth.
The measures we have announced today advance that agenda.

So today, Mr President, we convey to the people of Australia a message of hope and confidence in the future of our great and unique nation. There is, simply, no nation in the world so well-placed by virtue of its inner resources—its material resources, certainly, but much more important, its human, social and political resources—to weather the present storms, at home and abroad, and emerge from them, not only secure, but strengthened. Now is a time for strength of purpose, to ensure that Australia emerges from the recession with resilience, assured of its abilities, confident that it can take its place as a leading competitor in a tough, competitive world.

For our part, we in the Labor Government will not falter. We owe that to those who have suffered through the recession. We owe it to all Australians. We owe it to the splendid future which is within the grasp of Australia,

SPEECH.PARA: as we move towards the twenty-first century together.
I move:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —This statement is the response of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the demands of Mr Keating that jobs go to the top of the agenda, to the similar demand by the ACTU and to the Premiers' demand. It has to be so, because we have just been told in the statement that, according to the Government, the Budget strategy is on track. If the Budget strategy is on track, this statement is unnecessary. But we know that it is Mr Hawke's practice to respond to these demands.

PARA.TAB: What it does, however, is give us the opportunity to assess a number of things: firstly, whether Mr Hawke really appreciates the pain and suffering that is occurring in the Australian community today, or is he now so out of touch with everyday life; and, secondly, whether he understands how deep-seated this recession is—that it is no longer a `last on first off' recession. Does he understand the creation of what could be a generation of unemployed if this figure of 30-odd per cent of young people unemployed continues into the new year? Thirdly, does Mr Hawke really understand how particular sectors of the economy are being devastated by this recession—for example, the rural sector of the economy, and provincial and country towns?

If one looks at this statement in light of that assessment criteria, one cannot help but conclude that it is a statement which is superficial, inadequate, far too late, driven by politics—it is full of Hawkespeak—and in which there is no demonstration of any long term commitment to really restructuring Australia in such a way that Australia might be internationally competitive again.

What does the statement do? It provides a few more TAFE places for next year's unemployed youth—far less than the number the Government has already admitted will be unemployed—with a background of an enormous number of young people who could not get into TAFE last year. It provides a little more training for today's unemployed. It brings forward some money for roads and rail, and that is about it. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) spoke of a little DIFF money and a little TCF money. We have already seen that that TCF money does not necessarily lead to the preservation or provision of extra jobs, as my friend Senator Tierney interjected in relation to the Newcastle experience.

Does the Prime Minister really understand that such an inadequate statement comes with the background of the worst recession this country has faced since the Great Depression? Does he understand the level of unemployment that there is now in the community? Does he understand the consequences of the continuing current account deficit? In fact, in this statement he boasts that the current account deficit will be reduced to some $14 billion this year—a deficit of $14 billion on top of all the previous deficits. Does he understand just how far in debt this nation is now and how difficult it will be to ever repay that debt and provide a legacy for our successors of the type of lifestyle that we were lucky enough to inherit from our parents?

There is no indication in this statement that Mr Hawke understands these issues at all. This statement is about the same rhetoric as the past: how we are sharing the agony. Mr Hawke is not materially, of course; Mr Hawke is sharing it spiritually. We hear about his 33 years of commitment to public life. Would he put Australians in this position so that unemployment would continue in light of his 33 years in public life? He asks us to believe he would not do that, but he has put Australians in a position where it has occurred. It is his Government, his policies and his recession. The recession that he and his then Treasurer said we had to have has put nearly one million Australians out of work.

What does he offer us in this statement—practically nothing. As I have said, it is full of Hawkespeak. It starts with the first sentence of the statement: `Australia today is at a point of historic convergence'—whatever that might mean. It then goes on to talk about the long, hard struggle when we worked together, but it says there is a bright new future. Do the one million unemployed Australians see that bright new future? Do they refer to it as a `splendid future' as Mr Hawke says on the last page of this document? Mr Deputy President, they do not.

This is an unreal reaction from a man whose time in public life has passed, from a man who has lost touch with reality and the hundreds of thousands of Australians who are now suffering as a result of his failings. As a result of that, I will be moving at the end of my speech an amendment to the motion which Senator Button has moved. Senator Button has moved that the Senate take note of the statement. I will add:

SPEECH.PARA: and condemn the Government for causing unnecessary pain and anguish to hundreds of thousands of Australians as a result of its incompetent management of the economy and through the absence of major tax reform, labour market reform and other structural adjustment, offering them so little hope for the future.
This has been a bad year for Mr Hawke; we all understand that. More importantly, it has been a worse year for the nearly one million Australians who are out of work.

PARA.TAB: I will take a few minutes of the Senate's time to look at the principal failings, as I see them, of this Government. The first is that it has failed to set the parameters for a strong, internationally competitive Australia. It started trying to do so with deregulation of the financial sector, but could not go on with it because it was locked in by its vested interests.

Secondly, it erred in continually forcing up interest rates to try to curb imports at a time when all Australians were telling Mr Hawke and his Treasurer that it was crushing the business sector and, what is more important, crushing good business and good business people. They said they could not survive under that level of interest rates, but Mr Hawke and Mr Keating remained deaf. Mr Hawke has driven those people out of business. Many of them have had their lives ruined and they will never be able to return to where they were before.

Thirdly, the Government has failed because it is now in a state of paralysis due to this awful leadership struggle that continues in the most undignified terms of the thugs of the New South Wales Right of the Labor Party. Every day we hear of this contest that is publicly splitting the Party on both sides between Mr Keating, who was promised the job by Mr Hawke and says that he is entitled to a turn in the Lodge—after the recession that he has given us, that is amazing—and Mr Hawke who, when it came to the crunch, was not prepared to forgo power.

Divided the Party they have, with half on each side. They have divided the Cabinet—and we have the campaign managers within the Cabinet in this chamber—the Caucus and the organisation. They are slinging it out in the media. Every day they condemn each other and force a situation of paralysis whereby Mr Hawke, even if he was able to, is not able to make the decisions that he should as Prime Minister.

Each step is as a result of pressure. On interest rates, we heard what Mr Keating said, Mr Hawke responded. With the Commonwealth-State tax relations, Mr Keating lifted the heat and Mr Hawke responded. Even with the jobs policy—as I said at the outset—Mr Keating came on and said, `It's now time to move to a jobs policy' and Mr Hawke felt that he had no alternative but to respond. Mr Keating was driving the agenda with Mr Hawke responding and no decision was made on its economic merits or in the national interest. Every decision is now made on the basis of what will keep the hounds at bay.

Mr Deputy President, just look back over this last year for a few minutes. The first big statement we had was the March industry statement. That was hijacked by the leadership contest. Senator Button was supposed to give it—it was his industry statement. Mr Hawke needed it to promote his leadership in the light of the foreshadowed contest. It was, in its terms:

SPEECH.PARA: directed to the fundamental task facing this nation: improving the productive capacity of an economy that will be more internationally competitive.

That sounds fine, but did it do that? Did it really wrestle with the issue of tax reform? Did it wrestle with the issues of labour market reform and infrastructure reform that are so necessary in this country? Of course it did not. Again, it was couched in all the familiar Hawkespeak of a shared challenge and so forth.

PARA.TAB: Look at the integral part of the statement concerning depreciation rates. For months there were quarrels between the Australian Taxation Office, the Treasury, the Department of Technology, Industry and Commerce and so forth until only now, months later, has industry received those rates. Even the depreciation law is in a form with major shortcomings, as Senator Watson, among others, has demonstrated.

Mr Deputy President, do you remember that other important part of the March statement—the promised resource security legislation? It was legislation which was only necessary because of the promises that Senator Richardson made to the environmental movement at the last election which brought to a halt all resource development projects in this country.
The response of Mr Hawke was to promise resource security legislation. He said in the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: the Government decided on resource security legislation only after receiving unqualified legal advice that it was the sole way the Commonwealth could provide a binding undertaking of the kind necessary to get major projects started which will provide new exports and new jobs.
What has happened? Here we are in November with no legislation, no progress, no major projects, no new exports and, of course, no new jobs.

PARA.TAB: I now move to the August Budget statement. The contents of what we have heard today should have been incorporated therein. Was that Budget one that really addressed the major crisis that was facing this country? Of course it was not, because it was again linked with the leadership problem. The highlight of the statement was funding of $816m to a mad cities fantasy of the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, which was the price of his support for leadership and the price of support for the Left. What will be the consequence of that program if it is implemented? The consequence will be to drive up prices of inner city properties which will have exactly the opposite effect that this Government claims it wants to achieve.

What was the other highlight of the Budget statement? I remind you, Mr Deputy President, that it was the compulsory occupational superannuation tax, which was to be implemented regardless of the state of the economy or the capacity of Australia's crushed industry to bear it. We will never forget that moment of frankness and honesty in the Budget statement when the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) said to us that 1990-91 was:

SPEECH.PARA: a disappointing year for all Australians; a year of lost jobs, squeezed profits and dashed hopes.

That was August. We now have a job statement several months later because nothing worth while has happened in the meantime. That gives Australians no more hope than the acknowledgment of that depressing state of affairs in the Budget. Nothing has changed. Job losses are continuing, business is being squeezed of its profits, more Australians are being reduced to the scrap heap of unemployment and more hopes are being shattered.

PARA.TAB: It is not surprising that Senator Button said earlier this week:

SPEECH.PARA: I confess that the majority of the community are not greatly enchanted with this Government at this present time.
Neither should they be. As I said, what has happened since is more lost opportunities.

PARA.TAB: What has happened to the new federalism process that was supposed to restructure Federal-State relations? Prime Minister Hawke has the gall in this statement to blame the Premiers. After the July Premiers Conference, he promised them tax reform, but he was forced away from that by Mr Keating. I tabled in the Parliament earlier this week the letter of Mr Keating that forced him to do so.

Then, not surprisingly, Mr Hawke having reneged on his promise, the Premiers pulled back. So any opportunity for sensible tax reform and other sensible rationalisation of responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the States is lost. It is not surprising that Mr Hawke is, therefore, condemned by all the State Premiers or that the State Premiers, including the Labor Premiers, recognise the problem as being the leadership contest.

Then we have Senator Button's new fast tracking proposal for industry, grabbed as something that might achieve benefits. It affects a limited number of companies. There is nothing that guarantees its passage through this structural adjustment committee of Cabinet. There is nothing that Australians can really look to as providing any great hope.

I now come to today's big statement, the third and final for the year, in which Australians can now look for hope. I have said that it contains so little. It reminds us of the third runway which, after years of this Government prevaricating, is now being referred to as a fast track operation. It is a project in which Mr Hawke is still not able to indicate that he has the support of the whole ministry. Was there anything in this statement about a change to a more realistic uranium project? No. What about Coronation Hill? Did that get a mention? No. These are the projects that are reduced to the too hard basket.

Even the much vaunted industrial law reform that Senator Cook tells us is so important, this Government cannot get through its accord partner, the ACTU. So, what hope is there for the Australian people out of this statement? There is no hope. What is the future for a Prime Minister who cannot work with the Premiers to the benefit of all Australians? What is the future for a government where the Prime Minister has demonstrated that he does not have the capacity to govern even his party?

It is a tragedy that this Government will not stand up and meet its national responsibility at this time of great need. It will not stand up and meet the need for significant tax reform which the Government acknowledged itself, only a few years ago, was absolutely necessary. It is a tragedy that it will not stand up to the need for real labour market reform to really encourage enterprise bargaining, not Senator Cook's restraints to try to protect vested interests. It is such a tragedy that it will not stand up to the need for major structural reform which is so critical to the economic future of this country. That is why it is necessary for the Opposition to take this opportunity to move the amendment. I move:

At end of motion, add `and condemn the Government for causing unnecessary pain and anguish to hundreds of thousands of Australians as a result of its incompetent management of the economy and through the absence of major tax reform, labour market reform and other structural adjustment, offering so little hope for the future'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague, Senator Hill, and I certainly support his amendment. I have looked closely through the statement by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) looking for some hope, some ray of relief, for Australia's one million unemployed and 125,000 farmers, who are going into debt.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the statement begins with rhetoric and it ends with rhetoric, and there is very little in between the beginning and the end. It is a disappointing statement, and it gives no hope to those young people who are now leaving school and seeking a job. They will also add to the 28 per cent of youth unemployment, and the Government's answer to that is to provide more tertiary places. What Australia needs is jobs, not the most expensive child-minding in the community. It needs real jobs that will be sustainable, that will be there, and that will give some people some courage to go out and look to the future. But what have we found in this statement? Very, very little.

There are 125,000 farmers now hurting by the uncontrolled interest rates, by the drought in many areas of Australia, and by low commodity prices, and the Government's answer to that is that we cannot be too sanguine. What a terribly deprecating way to face one of the major problems in Australia—a throwaway line that we cannot be sanguine. Of course we cannot be sanguine. If Australian farmers go down the chute at the rate that they are going down at the moment, this nation will have no future. It will have no export income—not now and not for a long time into the future. What the Government has done is to provide some rural adjustment money to assist farmers out of trouble, trouble that I may say the Government itself created by high interest rates. What small business, what farmer, can pay up to 23 per cent in interest rates and expect to survive? What we have seen the Government do is provide some social security money, some desperation money, to give those people some sort of living. It is not good enough to create the problem and then give the farmers social security.

Bankruptcies are up 50 per cent in a two-year period. We have seen a 38 per cent increase in bankruptcies this year and 19 per cent last year. No wonder there are a million unemployed. The answer to that, of course, is that the Government is continually increasing charges by inflicting on small business a five per cent superannuation levy, to be stepped up to nine per cent by the year 2000. The businesses which are hanging on by their fingernails now will have to increase their overheads by up to nine per cent. Many of them, I tell Senator Cook, are just surviving now.

One of the considerations the Government has hung its hat on is that it has inflation down, but what a terribly horrific price to pay—a million unemployed, record bankruptcies, and all the Government has to show for it is inflation is down to a lower figure. One of the last paragraphs of the statement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It has to be acknowledged, however, that enduring relief will not occur unless there is liberalisation of agriculture trade. The farmers of Australia can be assured that this Government will continue to do all we can, in the coming crucial weeks of the Uruguay Round, to ensure it reaches a successful conclusion.

I hope for this Government's sake, and for the sake of Australia's farmers, that the Government is confident that it can swing the Uruguay Round to a point where we do get some liberalisation, for the reason that no other government in the world has exposed its farmers to so much risk and got so little return in the free trade talks. This Government will be so embarrassed if the Uruguay Round does not reach a successful conclusion.

PARA.TAB: This Government has reduced tariffs by 60 per cent when the rest of the world has increased its protection by 48 per cent. This Government has reduced tariffs to zero when the rest of the world is flooding Australian markets with its own primary production. I say to Senator Cook, who represents in this chamber the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), that if this Uruguay Round does not reach some conclusion there had better be some fast thinking in the Cabinet to take some action that will stop the flood of imported products into Australia.

Today I have touched on some of the problems that are facing small business and the farming community, but there has not been any reaction or commitment in this document to addressing those problems. It is a very shallow document which represents the Government's third try this year to engender some confidence in the business sector. The more of these documents that appear, the more the Government's credibility decreases and its capacity to engender confidence is lessened. I am terribly disappointed about this document, and anyone on the Government side who is open and honest will share my disappointment.

Where does this document say there is any hope? Yes, there will be a few jobs created on the third runway—very necessary for Australia. There will be $130m put into education, but that will not provide the real jobs. What about the hundreds of thousands of children in years 11 and 12 who will face a 28 per cent rate of unemployment? Where is the hope in this document? I hope someone in the Labor Party can tell me by answering our queries. Where is the hope for those small business people, the ones who are just surviving now, the ones who are looking for some hope in the future? There is nothing in that statement for the business sector of Australia. In fact, there is nothing in that document for anyone, except a few school teachers and TAFE teachers who will be employed. It is just not good enough, and all it will do is drive Australia further down.

I fully support Senator Hill's amendment. I think it could be couched in even stronger terms. It could even be turned into a censure motion; I think it would gain full support from everyone on this side of the House, including the Democrats. There is not a lot more that I can say about this document put down by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), except that he is running out of steam. It is a tired government. It is a government that has lost any vision for Australia. It is a government that has lost its direction, and a government that is hanging in there for another six or eight months until an election is called.

I believe that the sooner that election comes before the Australian people, the sooner they will make a decision for a change in direction of government, with people who are prepared to make a real difference, to create jobs and a better future for the one million unemployed, the 125,000 farmers who are going into debt, and the 28 per cent of our youth who are looking at a very desperate future. I support Senator Hill's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), which must be the most disingenuous statement that has come before this place in a very long time. How can the Prime Minister claim with a straight face that the economy is working when the evidence, the facts, are so absolutely plain that it is not working? One wonders what his index of the economy working really is. The Prime Minister says in this statement in a number of places:

SPEECH.PARA: There may be some who would argue that the Government, satisfied as we are that the fundamental economic strategy is on track. . .

How can the economy be on track with a million people unemployed, with the largest national debt we have ever had, with the spread of wealth becoming more iniquitous? What the hell is he using as an index of the economy being on track? Quite clearly, what the Prime Minister means is that he has adopted some obscure, esoteric index of the economy being on track and has totally ignored the well-being of real flesh and blood Australians.

PARA.TAB: Why has he done that? Because in his Department, in Senator Button's Department, in Senator Evans's Department, and in practically every government department, there are young Turks who are committed to market-driven economic rationalism. They are people who keep an eye on the esoteric economic indices and have no regard whatsoever for the benefit of real flesh and blood Australians. Quite coincidentally, we find in this morning's Canberra Times a very interesting article by Professor Russell Mathews, who really says it all. He says:

The economic policies of governments could not have been more successful if they had deliberately set out to impede economic progress, make it more difficult for businesses to operate profitably, encourage high levels of private consumption for most people while accepting homelessness and poverty for others, reduce the level and quality of public services, encourage imports and discourage exports, discriminate against Australian investment while supporting foreign take-overs of Australian property, destroy the competitive edge of Australia's super-efficient farm and mining industries, prevent manufacturing industries from becoming more efficient, continue to degrade the natural environment, and tolerate massive levels of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: What a catalogue! Against that accurate description of what has happened to the Australian economy since 1983, we have the Prime Minister claiming that the economy is on track. He even has the gall to say that he is observing the facts. What facts is he observing? Again, I suggest that he is simply looking at these obscure economic indices.

PARA.TAB: As I have said before in this place on many occasions, the policies being followed by this Government, which have led to this absolutely disastrous situation, are precisely the same policies which would be followed by the Opposition if it were in government. That is exactly what Professor Mathews goes on to say in this article. He says that the first explanation for the present predicament lies in the advice the economics profession gives to governments. He says further:

SPEECH.PARA: During the past 20 years or so, economics has come to be dominated by free-market economists—the economic rationalists.

As we have seen from the publication of a recent book by Michael Pusey, he has identified 70 per cent of all the senior people in government departments having that particular view of the world—that economic rationalist econometric view of the world. Professor Mathews goes on:

PARA.TAB: Complex econometric models have been constructed to demonstrate the inevitability of unemployment, without recognising that the models cannot adequately represent the real world and that the assumptions that are made to simplify the real world determine the conclusions of the analysis.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister has fallen right into that trap. Professor Mathews continues:
The models therefore reflect the ideologies on which the assumptions are based—
listen to this, because it bears very much on what we hear repeatedly from the Opposition—
for example, that there is perfect competition and that markets operate efficiently.

There we have an explanation of what has gone wrong with the Australian economy and why this Government has been led to a situation in which we have this massive unemployment, which a continuation of those policies cannot redress and will not redress. We need a rejection of those economic rationalist policies and a return to a situation in which the elected government, the elected representatives of the people, place their hands on the economic levers of this country and resume control of the economy and simply do not leave it to those naked economic forces which cannot deliver in relation to the problem of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister goes on to talk about initiatives in the post-secondary area to ensure that our young men and women have access to training. I have recently become the Leader of this Party and we have advertised for 12 people on the Leader's staff. We have had over 200 applications for one of those positions. When I read through those applications, I found that the majority were from university educated people, many of them have several degrees, and many of them are already working in quite menial jobs. Whilst it is certainly true that this Government has run down tertiary education in particular—the universities and the research institutes—we do not need more people crammed into those tertiary institutions at this stage. That is not where the problem lies.

In fact, one could say that the tertiary institutions in this country are essentially awash with people. Many of the applicants for the positions that I have just mentioned are recent graduates, highly qualified people, who simply cannot find a job. To suggest that there is a problem in that post-secondary area, in terms of training, is simply to misread the signs. If anybody looked at any applications for job positions, that situation would become quite obvious.

The Prime Minister talks about accelerating infrastructure projects in the area of road, rail, post-secondary education and science. Certainly, as a country, we spend far too little on science research and development. That is a point that I have made on a number of occasions, as have many other honourable senators in this place. Despite that, we are the most productive country in the world if we look at the number of scientific papers which are published in scientific journals, in referee journals. But we are failing—and we have failed over a number of years—to translate many of those scientific developments into commercial products. Clearly, we need to bridge that gap.

Despite all the efforts of the Government, it has simply failed to deliver on that front. The Government has failed to deliver on that front because it has no clear idea of where Australia needs to go; no clear idea of where Australia needs to be positioned 15 to 20 years down the track. The Government is pursuing its deregulatory, market-driven approach to the economy and assuming that the market will throw up, in some random fashion, the answers to Australia's destiny. It just does not work; the evidence is quite clear that it does not work. The Government must develop a much clearer idea, in consultation with the community, as to where we need to get 10, 15, 20 and 25 years down the track. I am continually reminded of the Swedish Commission for the Future which has a 25-year time horizon and a 40-year time horizon. It develops attitudes in the Swedish community in relation to those very long term social goals. We have nothing like that in Australia.

I refer to the amounts which the Government is talking about. For calendar year 1992, an amount of $313m has been allocated for the facilitation and development of new industries and restructuring existing industries. This is still well down the track. That is the first point one would make. The deregulatory policies of this Government have led to entrepreneur after entrepreneur going down the gurgler to the tune of $2 billion to $3 billion. Where has that money come from? Of course, it has come from the Australian community. It has been misdirected into speculation because of the deregulatory policies of this Government and it has simply been wasted. Compared with the amount of money which has been wasted and which we see appearing in our newspapers day by day as evidence of waste, the amounts which the Prime Minister's paper talks about are paltry in the extreme—$313m in calendar year 1992. Elsewhere in the document we find other amounts measured in tens of millions of dollars.

While on the subject of education, one of the members of the Opposition mentioned the Australian National University in Question Time today. I have a number of colleagues working in universities. Every single one of them tells a story of larger and larger classes, poorer and poorer facilities, lack of maintenance of buildings and equipment and far too little time to carry on any worthwhile research projects; they are simply being worn out by their large teaching loads. That is not the way to progress towards a clever country. As I have said before, we do not need to become a clever country—we are really quite a clever people—we need a much wiser government, something which we simply do not have.

When talking about education and training, the Prime Minister today announced proposals involving gross expenditure in calendar year 1992 of $130m—a paltry sum. Since 1983 the education and research facilities of this country have been run down and run down. At the same time, in an attempt to disguise unemployment, more and more people have been jammed into tertiary education, with no hope of a job at the other end. It really is a woeful and abysmal statement. It indicates that the Prime Minister and his Government have no clear idea of where Australia is going or how it is going to get there; it is simply, `Leave it to the market and we'll try to pick up one or two of the pieces in a very ineffective, paltry and inadequate way'. It will not work; it is not a solution to the problem. The solution to the problem lies in putting one's hands back on the economic levers and taking control of the economy, to re-regulate in selective ways so as to better serve the real interests of the Australian people.

I conclude by quoting a little more of Professor Mathews, who has written a brilliant article in today's Canberra Times. He points to the fact that the Government and, indeed, the Opposition should have known that this would not work. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: The sad thing is that the history of the 1980s and 1990s is the history of the 1920s and 1930s—

he could have said the 1880s and the 1890s; it is all there in history if one wants to read it. The laissez faire approach to the market system simply will not work; it will always produce the conditions in which we now find ourselves. He continues:

repeated in almost meticulous detail, with all the problems that arose from the boom and bust of the earlier period occurring again and all the policies that failed so spectacularly then being once more being put into effect.

PARA.TAB: The political spectrum in Australia and the rest of the world has moved so far to the right that electors no longer have a choice over most aspects of economic policy.
In Australia, for example, both governments and oppositions enthusiastically support free-market policies.

At the federal level, the choice for electors is therefore between the present Government, one of the most conservative and market-orientated governments that Australia has ever had, and an even more conservative and market-obsessed Opposition.
The outlook for the unemployed and for the Australian economy is therefore bleak in the extreme.

SPEECH.PARA: The only difference I would have with Professor Mathews, of course, is that there is an alternative for the electors—that is to vote Democrat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to very strongly support the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, on behalf of the Opposition. The amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add, `And condemn the Government for causing unnecessary pain and anguish to hundreds of thousands of Australians as a result of its incompetent management of the economy and through the absence of major tax reform, labour market reform and other structural adjustments, offering so little hope for the future.
Not only will and should the Senate condemn the Government for this disastrous situation, but so ought—as they do—each and every Australian.

PARA.TAB: This is one of those statements that should never have been made. Indeed, it is only being made because the failing Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of a decaying Government has yielded again to the political blowtorch being applied to the belly by ex-Treasurer Keating—he, along with Mr Hawke, was the architect and implementer of the greatest, cruellest, most unnecessary recession this nation has had for 60 years—and the blowtorch applied from his former mates in the trade union movement, particularly from the ACTU Secretary, Bill Kelty.

The Prime Minister did not want this statement. In his own interests he should not have made it. His statement today will simply renew the leadership speculation. The tactic now of the pretender to the throne, Mr Keating, is to wait for the Prime Minister to fall over, to continue to stumble the way he has in recent months, and today's effort by the Prime Minister is not a stumble; it is one almighty trip.

This statement is, quite frankly, pathetic. It is a cruel statement. It is cruel because it does nothing at all to address the real problems facing this nation. Indeed, the statement does not even seem to recognise the problems and certainly does not even start to acknowledge the bases for those problems. Those problems are very easy to see and identify—a lack of confidence in the nation, a lack of savings, investment, opportunity, incentive, hope and, above all, jobs.

Almost one million people are officially on the unemployment lists in this country. In terms of the underemployed and those who have simply dropped out of the work force because they know that there is no prospect of employment, the figure is of the order of at least 1 1/2 million—1 1/2 million Australians unable to find work or sufficient work. This document is a document of despair.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a document of a lack of leadership.

—As my colleague Senator Chapman says, it is a document that is full of a lack of leadership. Therefore, the despair is all that much greater because the hope of Australians is being shattered day by day.

PARA.TAB: The document is insulting in its shallowness, it is gratuitous and it is disingenuous in its description of our problems and their possible solution. As I said, it gives no recognition to those solutions let alone an analysis of the problems.

No wonder, as appears from the evidence to date, there is a deafening silence from the Government benches in supporting the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in that statement which he mouthed on behalf of the Prime Minister—the Prime Minister who said in the statement that he had spent the whole of his 33 years in public life in the Labor movement refusing to acquiesce in allowing the present high levels of unemployment to continue. A Prime Minister, I might say, who—having just knifed Bill Hayden—when running for election in 1983, said in his policy speech:

SPEECH.PARA: One in ten Australians out of work—a figure no Australian would have believed possible a few years ago, and which no Australian Government should ever be forgiven for creating.

There are now more than one in 10 Australians out of work. That figure would be more like one in eight. It could be even one in seven. One in three young Australians cannot find work, and this Prime Minister has the audacity to come into the Parliament today and make a statement which takes no recognition at all of the fact that the unemployed in this country today are unemployed because of a recession that he, along with his then Treasurer, Mr Keating, deliberately engineered and was made necessary because of a series, over years, of gross policy mismanagements on behalf of the Government.

PARA.TAB: The statement delivered here today is the statement of a fraud. It is the statement of a leader who has deceived the Australian people time and time again. There is the statement I have just quoted from, the 1983 policy speech, and the statement—who will ever forget it?—from the 1987 policy speech that, `No Australian child will live in poverty by 1990', perhaps the cruelest statement that any political leader has ever made in this country.

Today's statement is riddled with inconsistencies, it has no substance at all, and it shows that the only reason that it has been made is that the Prime Minister felt the blowtorch applied to him to get up and say something. The phrase that immediately caught my attention in the statement comes in the second paragraph where, after talking about the hurt of recession, he says:

SPEECH.PARA: The immediate focus of this statement is on the problem of unemployment. But through that prism, we want today to look ahead—to the prospects and promise for this nation.
I think that is a misprint—I presume it is a misprint—because what he is really talking about is the `prison' of unemployment, the prison of hardship and misery that this Government has created.

PARA.TAB: He says in the statement that the Australian economy is on the road to recovery, that the worst has now been experienced and that there is recovery. Where is the factual evidence of recovery in the Australian economy? Look at the statistics that have come out in the last few days. Retail sales fell by 1.8 per cent in September; consumer confidence plummeted in October, as measured by the index of the Morgan Research Centre which dropped to 91.1 per cent compared with 98.1 per cent at its peak in July this year; the Westpac Melbourne Institute index of leading indicators moved up by only 0.1 per cent in September—virtually no change, no indication of heralding a recovery; credit to the private sector shrank by another $220m in September, showing that business confidence in the investment outlook remained absolutely depressed; and over the year to September credit to the private sector grew by just 0.4 per cent, which is the lowest growth on record.

So where is the factual evidence of the recovery? The Prime Minister talks in this statement about the fact that the balance of payments this year will come in at the great old figure of a deficit of `only' $14 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Back to what it was when they came into office.

—Fourteen billion dollars is a figure that was unheard of before this Government came into office. When this Government came into office the largest ever deficit that this country had experienced was a deficit—and I am quoting from memory in response to my friend Senator Archer—of the order of $5 billion, and that was very much a one-off blip in our external balance record.

PARA.TAB: We have had for the last four or five years deficits well in excess of $10 billion every year—indeed, the year before last the deficit reached the staggering figure of $21 billion—and the Prime Minister says, `Gee, we're doing pretty well this year because the deficit is only going to be $14 billion'. That is a fairly optimistic assumption, given the fact that last month alone the deficit zoomed up again from the reductions it had had in the couple of months preceding that, and the deficit last month was double what it had been the month before. There is no evidence at all of any recovery in the economy, other than some peripheral evidence relating mainly to the housing industry.
We have a misleading message of despair in this document. The Prime Minister says:
These measures build on the strategy for reducing unemployment already put in place by the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: If this builds on the strategy that is contained in this year's Budget, then heaven help us as to where we are going to go from here. The total measures announced today will cost $313m in the calendar year 1992. It appears from what the Prime Minister has said in this statement that that is an unfunded series of expenditures. There has been no compensating measures in the fiscal policy in any sense to compensate for this additional spending, yet the Prime Minister says that these measures will not only advance our economic strategy but also maintain the integrity of the Budget.

PARA.TAB: The integrity of the Budget was never there, but it has blown out very considerably since then. One could have no confidence in the forecast on which the Budget was based. Indeed, in relation to one of the key forecasts and parameters underlying the Budget Estimates—namely, investment—there is a major admission on page 4 that private sector investment is going to be much less this year than even was forecast in the Budget. The Budget forecasts themselves showed a fall of 10 1/2 per cent expected in private investment in 1991-92. The statement today reads:
Since the Budget was drawn up, the immediate risk that private calls on national savings would grow faster than public calls were falling has lessened.

SPEECH.PARA: That could only mean that private sector investment is expected to fall by even more than the disastrous 10 1/2 per cent that the Government itself admitted to in the Budget. That fall of 10 1/2 per cent expected in 1991-92 was on top of a fall of similar magnitude the year before. There has been a tremendous collapse in investment in this nation over the last two or three years. That is the factor that underpins any prospect of job creation and economic growth in this country.

PARA.TAB: If we are not going to get investment in the nation, then we are not going to get jobs. The reason today's statement is a litany of despair is that there is not one measure in it designed to lift investment in Australia. The one thing that underpins our requirement for economic recovery is missing. Indeed, it is not even acknowledged in the Budget.

We see in the figures accompanying the statement even greater cause for concern. The figures in the accompanying statistical statement are very difficult to interpret. They are very cursory. They are insufficient to give a proper analysis; they are too general and too vague. But there are some very worrying statistics in them. In particular, the measures estimate that, as a result of today's announcements, there will be a fall of $113m in the calendar year 1992 in unemployment benefits.

That simply means that that will be compensated on the other side of the equation by an expansion of the employment access program, by additional Austudy and by further initiatives in post-secondary education and training of a very significant amount—$100m plus. In other words, the Government's own document is saying that the Government is simply going to move people from one pile to another. It will move them out of the dole and into these other programs. It is fine and a very important thing to increase the level of skills, education and training in our community, but we must accompany it by other measures that are designed to create jobs. There is nothing in this at all to actually create more jobs. What this statement will do is jam the pipeline with more trained people but with nothing for them to do when they come out of that pipeline of training.

I repeat that the only sustainable way to lift economic growth in this country, to create the jobs that are so desperately needed, is to implement measures to lift investment. There is nothing at all in this statement which does that. The statement talks about social justice. After acknowledging that the unemployed have borne the heaviest costs of the recession, the Prime Minister has the hide to say:

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to harness in full the opportunities provided by recovery, we must strengthen the skills of job seekers and particularly the long term unemployed. It makes economic sense to do so. . . More importantly, social justice demands that we do so.

I will tell the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Government in the Senate what social justice demands. Social justice demands a government that is prepared to do things to create growth and jobs. It does not demand governments that undertake mickey mouse measures to try to move people out of unemployment and into training schemes with no hope, no opportunity and no incentive for them at the end of the pipeline. That is the cruelest thing one can possibly do. That is where this Government fails lamentably, cruelly and despairingly in relation to its mouthing of the words `social justice'. The Government does not know what the words `social justice' really mean. In September the Treasurer, Mr Kerin, made a very important speech—it was a very important statement—to the Irish Chamber of Commerce in Melbourne, in which he said:
. . . the most effective anti-poverty policy ever implemented has been sustained economic growth. It has brought increased social justice to hundreds of millions of people on our planet.

The thing that I cannot understand, the thing that the coalition cannot understand and the thing that the people of Australia cannot understand is why on earth this Government seems so bent on acting totally contrary to that very laudable objective.

PARA.TAB: The statement delivered today does nothing to advance the cause of economic development, economic recovery, growth and job creation in this nation. There are many things that it could have done. There are many things that it should have done. There are many things that this nation of ours requires to be done. We need a fundamental reform of taxation and of our whole infrastructure and industry structure in this country. Mucking around in the way the Government has in this statement will achieve nothing.

Indeed, in recent days the coalition has, in preparation for this great statement, run some figures through the most sophisticated economic model in Australia, the so-called Murphy model. We put a series of figures through just to see what would happen to unemployment. One of those scenarios was: let us see what happens if we give an unfunded $250m boost to public spending. What would that do to the September 1991 unemployment rate? The model showed that an unfunded boost to public spending of $250m would decrease the unemployment rate from 10.1 per cent to 10.09 per cent—the ultimate bandaid solution; not one iota of improvement in the unemployment situation. Similarly, when we put a boost of $500m through, it showed that would have no effect on the unemployment rate in 1991-92 and, at best, it would only decrease the unemployment rate by 0.03 per cent in 1992-93; in other words, one-third of one-tenth of one per cent in 1992-93—again, no impact at all.

Similarly, if one put a billion-dollar boost into public spending in the way the Government is doing today, there would be no improvement in unemployment. It proves that there has to be major taxation and structural reform if we are to get anywhere in this country with restoring growth, jobs, investment, hope and opportunity. We need reform that will lower the tax burden on individuals and business; that will lower the cost of business inputs in the production chain. We need reform that will make the tax system fairer, more equitable and more broadly based, simpler and more efficient. We need that reform to give employers and employees the opportunity to discuss together, to negotiate together, to work out together the deal and the arrangements that suit them best so that we can maximise the opportunity, use and scope for greater productivity, growth and improved living standards in this nation.

This statement today has done none of that. It is a typical bandaid attempt by the Government. This Government is decaying day by day and is suffering a policy paralysis. It is so divided that there is no hope that it will ever again give any semblance of effective leadership—if it ever did, and I do not think it did—to this country. The Government stands condemned by this statement today. Senator Hill's amendment says that in the strongest possible terms and deserves the support of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's statement by the Government simply reinforces the fact that this failed Hawke Labor Government is as bankrupt as the country it has misgoverned for nearly nine years. Yet again the Government offers short term bandaids—and inadequate bandaids at that—instead of the fundamental reforms which Australia desperately needs. Most importantly, despite the legacy of Labor's accord, the Government refuses to budge on the most important reform of all—fundamental labour market reform.

PARA.TAB: This shortcoming in today's statement needs a response in plain language—the language of those who have been most grimly affected by Labor's industrial relations policies. I refer to those who have found themselves on the unemployment scrap heap. It is a plain language of lost opportunities, a language of social dislocation. Increasingly, it is a language of despair. It is a language spoken by more and more members of our community—the skilled and the unskilled, blue and white collar. And more yet will learn to speak it until this nation grasps the nettle of genuine reform.

Labor's approach to employment and industrial relations is fundamentally flawed, because it does not give enough freedom to ordinary people to take control of their own lives. It attempts to make decisions in a centralised manner on the wages and conditions of workers all over this country, who face vastly different situations at their workplace level. Workers have been told what wage they must work for and employers what wages they must pay. If employers are unable to meet those conditions, their only option is to reduce the number of people they employ. In light of that, it is no wonder that we face the massive unemployment levels of today.

The accord, on which the Government has placed such great store, by itself has not led to the double digit unemployment that we have today. It took a whole raft of misguided policies to achieve that result, but it has compounded the problem by not allowing the flexibility so sorely needed to alleviate unemployment. People who are out of work, who are desperate to find work, are not allowed under this Government's system to negotiate on their own terms. It is becoming increasingly obvious to all but the most blind ideologues that Labor's centralised system of industrial relations has failed to provide jobs. Indeed, even certain honourable senators opposite have, in their most honest moments, conceded that the accord has made no useful contribution to the Australian economy.

In fact, the situation is far worse than that.
