Labor's accord, through its inability to adjust to our present difficulties, becomes one of the principal factors directly responsible for the extended period of economic stagnation in which we find ourselves—directly responsible for the fact that one million Australians who want to work are unable to find a job. It is easy to bandy about a statistic like one million, yet it is a figure that staggers the imagination. One million people are going through their own private hell under a government that is not prepared to lift a finger to help them. Each one of those one million people is struggling to make ends meet, trying to aspire to the good things in life or to provide them for their children. They are battling to salvage self-esteem in a society where self-esteem is based on social and economic status, on what you do for a living.

The psychological impact on individuals of this sort of dislocation cannot be measured; it will manifest itself in a million different ways. Families will break down, some people will turn to crime, others will adopt even more final and desperate solutions. Any religious or social welfare organisation will say that unemployment places a tremendous and often intolerable strain on family relationships. With little money coming into a household, husband and wife will take out their financial pressures on each other. Mutual recriminations and fault-finding on both sides will tragically in some cases give way to domestic violence. Some will be unable to resolve their difficulties. Separation and divorce statistics will show an increase—statistics that give only a hint of the terrible anguish and despair underlying them. Children will suffer. Unable to understand the causes of their parents' distress, they will only witness the fighting and misery and they will live with the consequences.

Youth unemployment is already of epic proportions. A whole generation of our young people are finding it increasingly difficult, if not impossible, to find work. The next group of young people about to emerge from secondary school will do so with the expectation of extreme difficulty in finding work and, for many, the expectation of an extended period of unemployment. Many have already experienced this. Some who have been unable to find a job for a long time, perhaps have never even held a job, are beginning to wonder why they bother searching for work, day in and day out, only to face continued rejection in an environment that cannot afford to pay them the going rate, and will not allow them to negotiate themselves into employment. Without a job, they will have no autonomy, no social status and no perceived future. A job is everything, even to the young. It is an identity; it is a freedom; it is a sense of purpose.

The Federal Treasurer (Mr Kerin) has recently been unable to decide whether or not we are in the midst of the worst recession in 60 years. As he struggles to make up his mind, and others move quickly to make it up for him, the one million unemployed of this country must wonder what difference it makes. They know that they are suffering under the bankrupt policies of a bankrupt government—a government that has manifestly failed to deliver to them the single greatest promise on which it was originally elected. It has failed to provide them with jobs. That was the great promise of Labor's accord—that by restraining real wages it would deliver a higher profit share to employers, thereby stimulating growth and creating jobs. When all else failed, when the Government could not control the current account or get inflation down or move fast enough with structural reforms, it clung to the accord and pinned all its hopes on it. Now, the Government's promise of more jobs through the centralised control of wages, after floundering for so long on a sea of missed opportunities, has sunk. As Frank Devine put it recently in his column in the Australian, the Government has `succeeded only in creating half a million new jobs, a million of which have now disappeared'.

Australia is not in a recession, however; it is in a bona fide depression, the magnitude of which is eclipsed only by the terrible events of the 1930s. In labelling our current economic malaise a depression, I do not look to any economic indicators—the ongoing pessimism indicated in employer surveys, the increase in the number of long term unemployed, the continuing fall off in job levels in key sectors such as the automobile parts industry, the unprecedented combination of difficulties faced by our farming communities—I look instead to the psychological impact of our economic woes. Not since the 1930s has there been such a destruction of confidence in Australia's future among significant sections of our community. In Victoria and in my own State of South Australia, where State Labor governments have gambled away the living standards of the next generation, people are beginning to wonder whether there is anything that governments, State or Federal, can do to alter what they perceive as a very bleak future.

It has been estimated that by 1993 as many as 350,000 people may be classified as long term unemployed. Although I do not want to dwell on economic indicators, that is a figure worth reflecting on. More and more people are joining the list of the long term unemployed, that is, those who have been unemployed for more than a year. A significant number of these are young people who have never had a job in their lives. What is their view of the adult world into which they have been thrust? What are their hopes for the future? What damage has the depressed state of our nation done to their dreams and aspirations, their attitudes to work, their faith in this country, and in their own capacity to participate?

Is it any wonder that crime is on the increase, and alarmingly so in many areas? Can there be any doubt that if we create an atmosphere in which one in every three young Australians is unable to find work, when we rob young people of all hope, of all faith in themselves, that many will turn to crime? So much of the crime we are seeing today is merely the most desperate articulation of a cry for help that is being heard from all sections of the community. Such is the psychological impact of this, our worst economic dilemma since the Great Depression. To all of this the Federal Government simply proffers its failed accord and this pathetic statement today, its proud record of half a million jobs created and a million destroyed, with vague promises of revitalising industry, of creating greater flexibility, of achieving the structural reform so desperately needed, of additional education in the TAFE sector: all talk but very little concrete action.

To discern the real future direction of this Government, we must look at those who control it, those with the real power since the present Prime Minister's leadership came under threat and was buoyed up by certain sections of the Party—indeed, the left wing of the Labor Party represented by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), who is presently in the chamber, and also the ACTU.The Secretary of the ACTU wants the Government to adopt a pick-a-winner approach to industry policy. He wants the Government to decide which industries are most likely to succeed in export markets and to give them a leg up. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) seems to think that the Government can spend its way out of difficulty, with his better cities program and other infrastructure projects we can ill afford.

To these people the accord in one form or another is sacrosanct and, besides, matches well their own interventionist, centralist solutions. They fail to acknowledge that the Australian economy has faltered, not for want of government intervention but because of it, and it is inappropriate and badly managed intervention. This is why the accord has failed and why the alternative solutions of the Left and the ACTU will also fail. The unemployed of Australia will not get their hope back when they see failed governments interfering even more in the day to day running of the economy. What will restore their faith is to be given an opportunity to wrest back control over their own lives, to negotiate their own wages and conditions, instead of being told that Labor's accord has priced them out of the market. This is the single most important reform to be implemented in Australia. It is also the reform that this Government is least willing and least able to achieve.

What an irony it is, what a terrible farce, that this Government, which would most readily portray itself as a government of compassion, of concern for the underdog, a government for the ordinary working men and women of this country, should in reality be the government that is more concerned with its own internal politics, and who has the jobs within its own structure, rather than with external reality; a government prepared to cling to a mechanism that has failed decisively merely for the sake of satisfying the ideological agenda of those who are really in control; a government that continues to espouse the sterile doctrines of a failed system, rather than recognise the individual needs and aspirations of the unemployed, the victims of its barren ideology.

It must surely be regarded as the big lie of Australian politics that we, the coalition, are the ones who espouse so-called dry policies to the detriment of real men and women and that it is the Government that has compassion and an eye for ordinary people. Nowhere is this big lie exposed more starkly than in the areas of industrial relations and this Government's dismal record on unemployment. For the sake of placating the ACTU, this Government would ignore the plight of one million people who are unemployed. Rather than create the flexible framework so desperately needed and run the risk of upsetting its industrial masters, it would ignore the cries of people who want to work and who would willingly negotiate more flexible arrangements for the opportunity to do so.

Those who are bewildered by the accord's failure are the same people who may be enticed by the populist fantasies of the Left and the ACTU. The accord failed because it attempted to give a central focus to millions of employment decisions made in thousands of workplaces. In other words, it sought to do the impossible, and the result has been stagnation, first in productivity and then in mass unemployment. Whatever made them think it would be otherwise? Employees and employers at the workplace level are the best judges of their own interests—not the Government, not the ACTU. How could the ACTU and the Government time and again thrash out a centralised deal on wages, with scant regard for flexibility in the workplace level and the individual requirements for productivity at the workplace level, and expect anything other than low productivity growth and eventual stagnation?

Still this Government has not learnt its lesson. It talks vaguely about broadening the scope of section 115 agreements without realising that the very system itself is fundamentally flawed. It is ludicrous for a firm that has already reached agreement with its employees to then have to front up to the Industrial Relations Commission to gain approval by passing a public interest test. The public interest will best be served by an environment in which employers and employees are encouraged to be flexible, to take control of their own situation and to act so as to ensure mutual survival. The Government will not create such an environment by taking decisions out of the hands of employers and employees and making their decisions for them.

Much has been written and said of the negative effect of the accord on the capacity of people to avail themselves of more flexible workplace agreements and thereby secure for themselves better long term employment prospects. Not as much has been said about the equally debilitating effect of the accord on the quality of management in Australia. It has been said with some justification that the management practices of many firms in this country leave a lot to be desired in terms of their efficiency, dynamism and willingness to look to the long term.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stevedores.

—As Senator Panizza says, the stevedoring industry is just one example of that. It is surprising, however, that more people have not looked to the accord as a partial explanation for this. Under accord arrangements, there has been little or no incentive for employers to negotiate with or even just get to know their employees. This is because they have not had to arrive at their own outcomes on wages and conditions; these have been dictated to them under the accord. Why bother to establish good relations with your employees when all the fundamental decisions concerning their wages and conditions are made outside the workplace anyway? Management practices have stagnated for much the same reason that labour productivity has: lack of incentive to excel at the personal or workplace level.

PARA.TAB: In the light of these considerations, it is interesting to review the comments by the Industrial Relations Commission in its April national wage case that the industrial relations system in Australia was not mature enough to move to a system of enterprise bargaining. It puts one in mind of the old problem of infant industries. Management and workers will never grow up as long as they are cosseted by a centralised wage fixing structure. The result is a system that may protect many who have jobs but delivers low productivity outcomes and marginalises an increasing number of people who are unable to find work.

This problem will not be resolved by seeking greater flexibility within a centralised system. As the Industrial Relations Commission demonstrated in April, this is a contradiction in terms. A quantum leap is required, a genuine devolution of power and responsibility. Only when workplaces are genuinely responsible for their outcomes on wages and conditions will productivity rise to the extent that it must to create more jobs and greater prosperity for all Australians.

One important factor that is often overlooked is the fact that employers at the workplace level have no control over their wages bill. That is another area where Labor's accord has had a detrimental effect on management practices. Again, it is only if we get away from the centralised wage fixing system that employers will be able to take that responsibility. The legacy of Labor's management of industrial relations and its employment structure is a system that has stagnated, a system that lacks the flexibility to cope with our current economic woes, let alone the dynamism and forward thinking that is required as we move into the twenty-first century.

Until the system is fundamentally reformed, in fact overturned, Australians will continue to suffer social dislocation and one million stories of hardship and poverty will continue and, indeed, be added to. The message is overwhelmingly clear: creating an economy that is capable of providing jobs requires that Labor's accord must go and must be replaced by the industrial relations proposals of the coalition. That is why I support the amendment that has been moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill), particularly as it refers to labour market reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes I wish to take to speak on this ministerial statement I would say, first, that while I am most disappointed in the statement, I am certainly not surprised. To say I am disappointed is an understatement; I am appalled. At a time like this, I often wonder how members of the Labor Caucus, in total, could possibly have agreed to such a statement—or non-statement as the case may be—ever reaching the chamber. Apart from a few gratuitous comments of self-gratification and adulation on the figures that suit the Government's purpose, there is absolutely no reference made to the disasters that go with them.

PARA.TAB: How long will this situation go on? There is not one thing in the document that will change the system that applies now. Unless we change the system and what is wrong with it, it will never get any better. I am not the Prime Minister of this country, but surely the person who is must have people around him who can point out to him that if he does not change the system the results will not change. How many documents do we need? How many promises? How many notes of concern such as, `Nobody is more concerned for the unemployed than is the Prime Minister'? If the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was more concerned for the people, he would have done more. The congratulations on job creation are nothing when the demand is exceeding the creation.

The statement mentions that building approvals are up by 15 per cent, which is a terrific improvement. But up from what? Up from a disgraceful figure, brought about by this Government's action. The statement says that retail sales are up, but it does not say that disposable income is down. Increased sales cannot continue if the discretionary income is down. The statement contains phrases such as, `We are carefully watching economic developments'—like a goldfish in a bowl. What is the Government doing about them? It is just watching them get worse and worse. I look at these scraps of money that are being pushed about here and there in a few itchy spots. It looks like a bobtailed RED scheme all over again. There is not one item of money that is being spent that will achieve any long term improvement—not one; just a pinch here and a pinch there.

Then there is the question of social justice—this well worn phrase used by this Government. It is trying to brush this off against one million unemployed and the children of the unemployed whose opportunities for the future are being damaged irrevocably by the state of affairs that their parents are in now. The statement says that infrastructure payments of $112m will be made. Goodness gracious me! If the Government is going to do something, why not have a very fast train or some project with some capacity in it to take us into the next century and make a difference? The CSIRO is to get $10m. That will provide a few props and a few bits of string and stuff to tie up the buildings and equipment that the Government has allowed to deteriorate to a stage where it is now unworkable. Ten million dollars—goodness gracious me!

The statement says that new firms are struggling. It is not just new firms that are struggling, old ones are too. When I look over the numbers of businesses and industries in my area and see the ones that are struggling or have folded, I wonder why the Prime Minister cannot spend a Saturday morning going around some of the shopping centres and business areas in Sydney, Melbourne or anywhere else in Australia to look at the number of buildings that have `For sale', `For lease', `Selling out sale' or `Gone for good' signs on them. What is he doing about that? We would never know.

In relation to technical and further education, the amount of money that is being talked about will not provide 40,000 places. We know that, as does the Prime Minister. That is the lag of the tertiary sector. In another month we will have another 40,000 students. What about those people? Do we commit them to everlasting damnation as well, just add them to the list? It is time that somebody who knows something about it had a better look at the situation.

As to investment, there is not a dollar being spent that will provide a long term job or an investment in the future. The whole document is absolute junk. I suggest to the Prime Minister and to those opposite that they want to be careful as they are travelling around Canberra because they may well find in the very near future that Senator Richardson will be out having driving lessons in a very large bus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because I know that quite a few of my colleagues want to get off their chests comments on this pathetic statement from a pathetic Prime Minister. When I read through this statement and heard it being spoken about I wondered, `When I go back to my electorate tomorrow and people ask me what was in the statement what can I say?'. I am afraid that all I can say to them is that we had a March statement and nothing has happened of any consequence from that, we had a Budget in August and a few things have come out of that; now we have a November statement; and I guess that we might have another statement in January or February next year to patch up this continuing mess. To my friends who used to own big businesses and who now have small businesses, and to my friends who had small businesses and who are now bankrupt, I suppose I can only say, `Look, there is nothing in this to give me any hope; there is certainly nothing there that should give you any hope'.

PARA.TAB: I remember recently when Senator Alston came to Hobart and we decided we would look at some of the Skillshare schemes. Whilst the schemes that we looked at—the Wilson Training Centre, Glenorchy SkillShare Inc, the Northern Job Link and a few others—are doing the best they can, it is pathetic to see what happens to people when they leave these schemes.

I remember talking to a couple of people who said that they had been unemployed for eight years. They had been put through this scheme to get their confidence back. They were really fired up. They really wanted to go out and get a job. They felt good and they felt well within themselves. I was speaking to some of the tutors afterwards and asked what hope those people had of getting a job. They said, `Very, very little'. We know that they will not get work. What will happen to them? What will happen to all these other people who are being funnelled into these Skillshare schemes as a result of this statement? They will only disappear from the job queues to return in another three months to where they started. They may have a few more skills, but they certainly will not have any more hope.

When I go back to Tasmania, what will I say to the Tasmanians: `Well, we got $3 1/2m extra for roads'? That is a few lousy kilometres of road as compensation for over 11 1/2 per cent unemployment in Tasmania—the highest level in Australia. In Tasmania, we are fast approaching a situation where 40 per cent of our young people will be unemployed—in other words, almost one in two young people will be out of work. What do we say to them? A chap rang me the other day and asked whether I could help his son to get a job. He left a university 12 months ago and still cannot get a job. He has a Bachelor of Commerce degree, with three credits and 11 distinctions, and he cannot get a job. That is the sort of thing that is happening. We hark back to the job queues of the 1930s, but, as Senator Walters would know, the Sheraton Hotel advertised for, I think, 10 part time waiters. There were 500 people queued up right down the street and they waited there all day just to get an interview. That is the situation in this country.

There is a thrust towards the clever country. Where will these people who are going to be recycled through Skillshare, Jobtrain, and all of those other fancy words the Government uses for training schemes, end up? They certainly will not end up in the clever country. I think all honourable senators know that there is no unemployment or recession in Canberra. We have had an increase of 4,000 senior public servants in the last 12 months and, at the same time, we are approaching a situation where one million ordinary Australians are out of work. Canberra does not really know what is going on.

We have to be practical about things. In the 1930s, during the Depression—the worst depression—a former Labor Premier of Tasmania took the bit between his teeth, borrowed #24,000 and built a road to the top of the mountain. At least those people who were out of work had a sore back and a few pounds in their pockets when they got home at night. They knew they had achieved something. The people who are out of work today may be getting the dole and they may be getting some sort of training, but what pride have they left; what can they say to their families when they get home?

I conclude by quoting some words from the last paragraph of this pathetic document, which say, `We owe that to those who have suffered through the recession'. I remind honourable senators that that was the recession we had to have, which was engineered by this Government. It continues, `We owe it to all Australians'. It should have said that all Australians—each man, woman and child—owe the equivalent of $7,600 as a result of the policies of this Government. The Government then has the hide to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We owe it to the splendid future which is within the grasp of Australia.

We know that the future under this Government will see us, as parents and family people, for the first time in the history of this country leaving to our children a worse standard of living than we were able to attain for ourselves.

PARA.TAB: I remember, Mr Deputy President, your making a comment to our New Zealand friends the other night when you referred to the `land of the long weekend'. That is one of the colloquialisms used about Australia. It used to be called the lucky country; the Government is trying to call it the clever country, but I am afraid that under the prime ministership of Mr Hawke this country has become the clapped-out country. It has no incentive, no leadership, no new ideas, no jobs and no hope. It is a country of record bankruptcies, record unemployment, record suicides, record overseas debt and record losses to businesses. This document which has been put out today—this so-called November statement—does not give me any hope for the future of this country, and I am sure that it does not give any hope to the one million unemployed people in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it this afternoon the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I share Senator Archer's abject disappointment at that statement, because it is the greatest non-event I have experienced in my time in this Parliament. The country is in crisis, we have one million people unemployed, and we get a statement as fatuous as this from the Prime Minister. Not one Labor Party senator has risen to his defence in the debate this afternoon. Not only are they disappointed with it, but also I would not be surprised if they are meeting in offices and rooms around this building trying to find a leader, because they clearly do not have a leader at the present time.

PARA.TAB: I do not know what Mr Hawke means by a clever country; I have never known. I suspect it means something akin to a street-smart country where people take advantage and run quickly to hang on to that advantage. I think that would be the limit of Mr Hawke's vision. Clearly, when he is talking about a clever country he is not talking about an intelligent country. I think most of us on this side of the chamber want to live in a competent country. A competent country is certainly an intelligent country which runs its affairs properly, which has a rule of law with equality for everyone before that law, and opportunities for people to fulfil themselves in life by having a strong and vigorous economy—the way we did in the 1950s and 1960s when the Liberal and Country parties produced the golden economic age of this country.

But instead of working economic policies, all we get from this Government are the old cliches—the central point of which is always social justice. I do not see much justice in having one million people out there looking for work. The Labor Party obviously believes it can buy jobs by throwing money around. I do not believe that; I think one has to make an economy go by getting rid of the impediments to success. The Labor Party believes it can buy jobs, yet it has put up only $162m for this grand scheme—a measly sum. I suspect, with the educational measures it is proposing, the central point of its campaign will be to cycle more and more unemployed people through courses. It will not provide any jobs for them.

The expenditure on transport is $60m. When it costs about $1m per mile or two to build a new road, $60m will not do much to improve the transport inefficiencies in this country. What about science; $4m is going to the CSIRO this year. Who wrecked the CSIRO—probably the finest research unit in the world, doing good practical applied research which benefits our export income earning industries? It was wrecked by the Labor Party. Year after year, units were disbanded and money was stripped from it. Now it gets $4m to construct some buildings. But it does not have the people left—the world-class scientists that it once had.

The Government is putting money into the TCFDA—the textile, clothing and footwear group. What a waste of money that is on a bloated group which, even today, enjoys an effective tariff protection of up to 250 per cent on some articles. It is putting money into the ABC of all things; and the AIDC. But none of this deals with Australia's structural problems.

One of my concerns, before I move onto the structural aspects, is the way in which the Government completely neglects rural Australia. People do not seem to understand that Australian business and the Australian economy never do well while rural Australia is in recession. We have great problems in the country. The Australian of today has an article that states that next year the net income of Australia's 125,000 farmers will be negative. Australian farmers will probably be $300m in deficit next financial year. There are estimates around to the effect that more than 20,000 farmers—or 12 per cent of the farming community—will leave the land in the next two to three years. The Government is absolutely oblivious to the crisis in rural Australia which is being exacerbated by one of the worst droughts on record. Sixty-two shires in Queensland have been drought declared and 60 per cent of New South Wales is drought affected.

In my own State, we have not only a drop in commodity prices, but also a severe drought. The estimates are that grain production in Queensland next year will be only 15 per cent of what it was the year before. In the sugar industry, the crop this year is down $300m on what it was the previous year because of the drought. Wool is in crisis. Cotton has gone down about $100 a bale, which is nearly a 25 per cent drop in price. Beef is not very strong. The impact of this rural recession has yet to be felt on the rest of Australia. It has not yet flowed through to the cities, but it will in the next six to 12 months, and this Government will do nothing about it.

Nothing in the statement delivered today will create jobs. As a senator, I have never had as many people writing to me as I have in the past 12 months. Almost every day I receive letters from unemployed people asking me to help them in some way or another to get a job. The Labor Party must also be experiencing this because I pulled out some figures on unemployment in the electorates of the Federal Cabinet Ministers. There is an 18.8 per cent unemployment figure in Footscray, which is in the electorate of the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis. In the electorate of the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, it is 15.8 per cent. In Brunswick, in the Prime Minister's electorate, it is 12.1 per cent. In Dandenong, which is in the electorate of the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, the figure is 15.1 per cent. Government Ministers must come face to face with this. Why can they not do something and realise that the policies that they have been applying in this country have been wrong for the 8 1/2 years they have been in office?

Not one thing in today's statement provides an incentive for investment. If there is no investment, new industries are not created and existing industries do not expand. But money cannot be put into investment until there are profits—and there are no profits in Australia today. There are no profits because the Government will not tackle the structural inefficiencies in the community by getting rid of the red tape so that Australia can work efficiently.

The Government will not do anything to take on the dinosaurs of the union movement, with their totally archaic and restrictive work practices. It will not free up the labour market. It keeps changing the goalposts all the time with pseudoscientific economic theories for the environment. There is a very real scientific base for environmental policies, but this Government tends to follow whatever the extremists in the lobby groups propose at the time. So the goalposts are changing. No-one from overseas can invest in this country when they do not know what will happen in the years ahead if they do invest here.

The Government is simply drifting and dreaming along while Australia is in total disarray and sinking deeper and deeper in debt to the tune of $15 billion a year. The statement before us today is completely in character with the Government's inability to control the economy and is a huge disappointment for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with my colleagues on this side of the chamber. The economic and employment statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is another piece of cheap, hollow rhetoric. It was brought down by the Prime Minister only to stop the battle with the failed ex-Treasurer of this country, Mr Keating. I want to raise a couple of points on the statement by the Prime Minister that came out today. He brought out a point early in his message to us when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a message of fundamental confidence. It is a message grounded firmly on the facts.

That is quite interesting in view of what I read in the paper a couple of days ago. Westpac was reported as saying that we are heading for the longest, worst recession since the 1930s. As we are only a few weeks off having the longest recession since the 1930s, I wonder whether Mr Hawke is basing himself firmly on the facts. The Prime Minister goes on in the statement to say:
. . . undertakings I gave in my address to the ACTU Congress—
This Government is still under the control of the ACTU. Mr Hawke has never got away from the shackles of the ACTU since he left it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never.

—That is right. He has not got away from it since he left it so many years ago. Mr Hawke goes on in his statement to talk of how the ACTU had to be given a commitment. But what about the employees who cannot remain viable because of the intransigence of unions? What about those people who have had problems with unions? What do they have to say about the fact that the Prime Minister has again kowtowed to the trade union movement?

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister then went on to say that the Government's economic strategy is on track. It is very interesting that the former discredited Treasurer, Mr Keating, used to talk about everything being on track, and now Mr Hawke talks about everything being on track. I presume that Mr Keating has now stopped his attack on the Prime Minister and that he will not mount another leadership challenge for a little while.

Is it really ALP strategy to say that everything is on track when we have 10 per cent unemployment, record bankruptcies, increasing suicides and up to 30 per cent of farmers walking off their properties? Does that mean that everything is on track? What a lot of C-R-A-P—conning responsible Australian people. That is what the Prime Minister is trying to do with this statement. It is a C-R-A-P statement—conning responsible Australian people. He then went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Given this Government's unsurpassed record . . .
If the record is so good, why are so many out of work at the moment and where are the jobs created by the temporary, short term illusionary policies of this Government?

PARA.TAB: It is quite interesting to see Senator Maguire sitting on the other side of the chamber at the moment. He always talks in economic debates, but he has been mute today. He has been so quiet today that we can hear the mice scuttling around underneath his desk.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was game, set and match yesterday.
—Senator Maguire has been very quiet. He is usually a very vocal person in any of the economic debates. The Prime Minister then went on in his statement to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . second, there has been a worsening of the drought, leading us to be less sanguine about prospects for the rural sector.
The rural sector has been driven into the ground by the Hawke Labor Government over the years and the Government has done nothing to help people in that area. Mr Hawke then went on to say:
This situation demands urgent action.
He then said that he was very disappointed at the Premiers' decision not to attend the Special Premiers Conference in Perth next week. He said:
. . . it will make the resolution of these problems even more difficult.
It is interesting to think that five out of the six Premiers who do not want to go to the Premiers Conference are Labor Party Premiers. For God's sake, his own team is deserting him at that level.

PARA.TAB: What about all this extra money provided for training? It is great to train people, but there have to be jobs for them when they finish their training. That is something that this Government has not given anyone in Australia.

Mr Hawke talked about internationally competitive transport infrastructure. How will he answer the people who ask why his Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has done nothing to make sure that Western Mining, with its Kambalda nickel mine, could have seven-day, 24-hour shifts and thus be internationally competitive? He has not done anything to help in that area. The Prime Minister talks about bringing forward $82m of roads expenditure. That is just robbing Peter to pay Paul. It is just bringing money forward; it will not be there in the future.

I said that I would speak for five minutes so that many of my other colleagues could speak. However, I want to make one other point before I finish. There is no incentive in this statement for farmers: there is nothing to keep the rural kids at school; there is nothing to help keep farm assets intact; and there is nothing to help keep the national breeding herd, because the Prime Minister said that at this stage he had done enough as far as the drought was concerned by doing a little for the RAS.

Do honourable senators realise that nearly 200,000 children in Australia live in homes in which nobody has a job? It is an indictment of this Labor Government and the Prime Minister. Nothing he has said in this statement will help Australia out of the mess that it is in. The only way that we will get out of the mess we are currently in is to change much of our economic structure and many of our work practices so that people in the system have incentive. The only way they will get that is by having a GST—a goods and services tax. That will give a real incentive to people in the work force. They will want to work harder, work better and take more money home at the end of the week so that everyone will benefit from a better economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that I would start where the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) concluded his last statement made this day, this hour, 245 days ago entitled Building a Competitive Australia. What did we get out of it? In his conclusions, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last eight years, industry has responded well to the challenges of a more competitive Australia. But we cannot relax our efforts to improve our efficiency and respond to the global challenge.
He went on to say:
The Government must deliver the right environment for the development of a more competitive economy.
He then said:
Industry, trade unions, management and workers all have to play their part.

Let us see how this Government and those unions have performed since this statement 245 days ago. We had Kakadu where we had the chance to get some industry going. We had Marandoo where we had the chance to get some industry going. What happened? We have Yakabindie where now we have the third challenge by the Aboriginal heritage group funded through ATSIC by this Government. The Government is spending money to wreck private enterprise's efforts to get industry off the ground. We have the Moora pulp mill and the sly remark from Senator Cook from a question this afternoon. We have had the unions trying to wreck that one.

PARA.TAB: We have Kambalda where the Deputy Premier of Western Australia has sided with the unions to stop a new mine going ahead. The miners have been offered an extra $263 per week to work an extra half an hour per day, which will put their earnings up towards $110,000 per annum. They have all gone out on strike and put Kambalda out of action today. The Deputy Premier of Western Australia, Ian Taylor, who represents the seat of Kalgoorlie, the centre of goldmining in Australia, is siding with the miners who are on strike even though they have been offered an extra $263 a week. There are a lot of unemployed people out there who would like to get $263 a week, let alone an extra $263.

In that last statement I looked for taxation measures in relation to the primary industry. In March, the Prime Minister said with regard to wholesale sales tax that exemptions would apply to goods used in research, development, engineering and technical design products. He also spoke about depreciation and the removal of sales tax from lubricants. Yet 245 days later—about two days ago—the legislation comes into this place. This is what the March statement was worth—absolutely nothing.

Turning to the new statement, I looked straight away to see what was in it for primary industry. I do not want to speak for too long so that my colleagues can also have their say. I found nothing whatsoever about primary industry until I reached the middle of it, and this is what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Budget was drawn up, the immediate risk that private calls on national savings would grow faster than public calls were falling has lessened. This lessening is attributable to two main factors:

PARA.TAB: - first, the forecast reductions in inflation have been factored into community expectations more rapidly than we had hoped;

SPEECH.PARA: Then the rural industry gets a mention:

PARA.TAB: - and second, there has been a worsening of the drought, leading us to be less sanguine about the prospects for the rural sector.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the only time the rural sector was mentioned in this statement this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: Those measures were put in the statement 245 days ago and now he is trying to get more applause for it 245 days later. How can anyone believe this Prime Minister? It says on the front page that with 33 years in public life he will not stand by and see this sort of unemployment. So what has he done? He spent 24 years with the ACTU trying to wreck the businesses and industries of Australia, while a well-led Liberal Government led us through the best period Australia has ever had. He has had nearly nine years of leading from inside and has wrecked Australia by allowing record taxation—new taxes and increased taxes—and outdated work practices to grip Australia. Of course, those interest rates really killed Australia.

Now we have the alternative pretend Prime Minister in Mr Keating, who thinks he can take over Australia and who when he presided over the Treasury wrecked the whole country. Now he thinks he can be an alternative Prime Minister. The only alternative Prime Minister at this stage is Dr John Hewson. He is the only one who will lead us out of the mess that we are in when we get into government very soon.
There is a lot more I could say on the non-event of this statement which is exactly the same as the last one—utterly useless—but I will give time to my colleagues to have their say.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some brief remarks on this statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). They should be brief because it does not deserve much of the Senate's time for consideration. My view is that I captured the Government's feeling about this statement when Senator John Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, sat down. There was not a single `Hear, hear!', or cheer; it was just a damp squib. Most of the honourable senators on the other side of this chamber were probably highly embarrassed by this appalling, lacklustre statement.

PARA.TAB: It reminds me of someone standing outside a freezing cold house full of people who have been out in a storm, freezing cold, wanting to have a hot bath, while someone is outside trying to light the pilot light on the gas hot water system with a box of about 18 matches. We have had 18 economic statements from this Prime Minister, and he was down to his last three matches this year. He lit his first match on 12 March, and that went out. He lit another match in the Budget, and that went out. Today he had his last match, the last hope for all these freezing cold people wanting a bit of hot water, and that match just blew out.That is the sort of hope and despair that the unemployed people in Australia—and, indeed, everyone in Australia—will feel because of this statement.

My honourable Senate colleagues here today have been looking around for words to describe it: words like `shallowness', `despair', `hot air' and even Senator Brownhill's `C-R-A-P'. What it really is is a compromise statement. It is a statement that has been compromised by Paul Keating. It is a statement that has been compromised by the ACTU. It is a statement that has been compromised by the ALP's own policies. It is a statement that has been compromised by the green movement. It is a statement that has been compromised by Aboriginal activists.

The Leader of the Government in the Senate, in his conclusions, says that the course is clear as to where this Government must go and that it will maintain its resolve. He says that we must keep inflation down, but nowhere in the statement does it point to how inflation will be kept down. There has not been one single structural change that would have us believe that inflation can be kept down. It is only down because there is a massive recession, if not depression, keeping it down which has dampened down all demand in this economy.

He has talked about maintaining investment. But some very simple figures in the very important area of investment expenditure in Australia show that, back in 1987-88, $622m was spent on resource development exploration expenditure; in 1989 it was down to $514m; in 1990, $392m; and in the last 12 months, $361m was spent on exploration. Of course, on these investment figures—and we know by the very admission of Senator John Button, the Leader of the Government, in response to a question I asked him recently about Australia's capital crisis—we have the banks in a position where they cannot lend money because they have a $30 billion to $50 billion debt hangover from the last three years. We have prospectus provisions that make it almost impossible or too expensive to raise money through a flotation on the share market and, of course, we have a stupid business tax regime that this Government talks about reforming but does nothing about. Where will the investment come from?

There are also environmental restraints. Senator Button refers to the fact that he will maintain the strictest environmental standards in the world, and in today's issue of The Mining Review the research officer at the United Mineworkers Federation of Australia refers to the greenhouse research and the fact that all the Government's policies in relation to meeting the Toronto targets will probably involve wiping out the entire coal mining industry. It will create negative growth and lost employment. It will fundamentally ensure that, because of the green commitments made by Senator Richardson to get this Government re-elected at the last election, we will have negative growth.

Finally, we talk again about fast-tracking projects. I asked Senator Button in the Senate only a few weeks ago what had happened to the committee that was set up as a result of the March 12 statement to fast-track projects. Senator Button was not even able to tell the Senate whether that committee had met. Suddenly, here we are six months later in a situation where there are no more projects; projects are being wiped across the country. There is no hope, only despair.

I conclude by saying that there are alternatives, and that those alternatives were clearly set out by the next Prime Minister of Australia, Dr John Hewson, in the other place. The alternatives do not need to be reiterated here. The Prime Minister's statement is a compromise statement. It is a joke and it should be thrown out. It should be treated with the contempt it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement put down today by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is one of his typical cruel statements. We all remember very well the statement he made, `No child will live in poverty by the year 1990'—a statement that was so cruel to the homeless youth and to the street children that it was unbelievable that he would have indulged in such a comment, such a throwaway line, during an election campaign.

PARA.TAB: Here again today, with a million people unemployed, the Prime Minister has put down what he calls a statement on the economy and employment. He must surely realise that there are one million people unemployed—some of them 45-year-old male breadwinners who have suddenly been made redundant through his policies, through the recession we had to have, according to the Prime Minister and the previous Treasurer—who are waiting, in great expectation, for something concrete to be done by the Government. The expectation that that would be announced in this statement was very high.

After Senator Button read that statement, he immediately turned on his heel and walked out of the chamber, and I do not blame him. The lack of morale amongst Government senators was staggering. They had not heard the statement before, and as they sat there and watched and listened to what was being said, they knew what the headlines would be tomorrow. The journalists had already said that they did not expect the statement to be any more than just rhetoric, and that is exactly what we got. On the first page of that statement, Senator Button said:

SPEECH.PARA: I say to this House what the Prime Minister has said repeatedly outside: he has not spent the whole of his 33 years in public life in the Labor movement of Australia to acquiesce in allowing the present high levels of unemployment to continue.

The Prime Minister has caused those high levels of unemployment. He, along with the previous Treasurer, deliberately created one million unemployed. They both acknowledged that this was the depression we had to have to get the country back into order. They have presided over the worst work practices ever in this country.

PARA.TAB: When the Prime Minister was the leader of the ACTU, he indulged in these extra work practices about which overseas people shake their heads and say, `How do you ever expect to regain any competitiveness?' It costs more to send a car from Melbourne to Hobart, or across Bass Strait to Launceston, than it does to send the same car from Sydney to Japan. We will never be competitive while we have a past President of the ACTU as the leader of this country. His whole mentality is geared towards the employment angle and the highest wages he can get, the best working conditions he can get, and to heck with the unemployed. The ACTU has never shown any interest in the unemployed. Indeed, before a Senate committee on superannuation Bill Kelty said, `The unemployed are not our problem'. That is the mentality of the leader of this country because he also was a leader of the ACTU. The mentality of the leader of those opposite is that the unemployed are not his problem.

The stark situation is shown in this statement, where the Prime Minister has offered a few dollars for road works and extra training and has refused the development of Coronation Hill, Wesley Vale, and the uranium mining that could be undertaken in this country. He has refused to go down the line of assistance in the short term and he has refused to go down the line of complete tax reform through a goods and services tax, which is the long term method of overcoming unemployment.I remind the Senate that the answer the Prime Minister gave in the Budget was his better cities program—this mad cities fantasy. That is all he can think of. With a million people unemployed, is it any wonder that Dr Hewson says that all that will create is better pavements for people to stand on in dole queues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of this debate, many of my colleagues, in commenting upon the statement that has been made today, have pointed out that it is a statement which is disappointing, lacking in substance and lacking in worth. Indeed, the middle section of the statement dealing with an injection of money to help people through the CES could be called a variation on a theme for staying on the dole, opus 73.

PARA.TAB: Part of the statement on page 8 attracted my particular attention. There is something not quite right in the figures that have been put forward. I refer to the AIDC and to this statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) has recorded a profit of $9.6 million for 1990-91. The Corporation has asked to retain this profit as additional capital to help meet the demand for equity in new project development. We recognise that additional capital is needed, particularly for new investments in resource processing. The Government has therefore agreed that the profit should be retained by the Corporation.

The problem with this is that in yesterday's Australian Financial Review there was an article dealing very briefly with the surprise announcement that Mr Arthur O'Sullivan is to retire immediately from the board and his position as Managing Director—as of yesterday. Furthermore, because of heavy provisioning against bad property loans, the AIDC has a net loss of $8.8m for the year to 30 June 1991. I presume that loss is suffered by AIDC Ltd, which is the operating company of AIDC.

PARA.TAB: This raises many important questions. How is it that the AIDC has made a profit of $9.6m, which it is allowed to retain, and, according to the statement, is going to invest in some way, whereas the press release that has been put out is couched in different terms and seems to have a different aim? At the same time, the operating company, where there is a 20 per cent private shareholding, has made a loss. How is it that the private sector bears the loss of the operating of the AIDC group and yet we get this statement that it made a $9.6m profit?

Those questions deserve answering and they deserve answering right away, particularly as the Government has said that it will continue to extend the Commonwealth guarantee to the Corporation's liabilities until 1998, which will thereupon underwrite its future borrowings to that date and will take away the test that was predicated by Peter Freeman in his editorial yesterday, which said that the ability to raise funds would be quite dramatically affected if that guarantee ceased, as it was meant to, in 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the response of the Australian Democrats to the statement by the Leader of the Government (Senator Button) on the economy and employment.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

The statement of the Leader of the Senate today offers virtually no hope to the 850,000 Australians without a job. There is nothing in the statement which will affect anything more than a marginal increase in the level of economic activity. In total during this financial year the Government is proposing to spend an additional $170 million to reduce unemployment. That is, an additional $170 million out of total predicted spending of over $100 billion this year.
In other words an increase in outlays of less than one fifth of one per cent!

We have heard a lot about how deeply the Government is committed to assisting the unemployed but today we see that when there is a chance for the Government to put its money where its mouth is there is this token response.

The Statement continues the line (that is the Treasury line) that recovery is just around the corner and that the Government daren't intervene because otherwise all the wonderful achievements of the last few years will be put at risk.

The Government always speaks as though the economy is a discrete and separate entity over which the Government has no control. Clearly this is not the case. The public sector is responsible for about a third of all the economic activity in this country. To the extent that the private sector is failing in its task of providing employment it is the duty of the public sector to intervene to correct the misery and social tragedy which large scale unemployment inevitably brings.

This has been implicitly recognised by the very existence of this Ministerial Statement today, although the announced measures are totally inadequate to deal with a situation of unemployment approaching 1 million people.
So when all the rhetoric is stripped away, what has the Government announced today?

Firstly, the particular areas addressed are clearly the correct ones. Labour market programs, education and training programs, transport infrastructure and industry development are the key areas which should be boosted.
However the measures are purely token. Actual jobs will be created by the road, rail and scientific infrastructure measures—these total only $112 million over the calendar year 1992.
Whilst the measures have merit, they will create only a few thousand jobs. Indeed the measures are so ineffectual that the Minister has not even estimated the employment effects of today's proposals.

The training and educational measures, which provide additional opportunities for Australians are worthwhile and are supported but there must be jobs for the participants to go to after the training is completed.
This Statement provided an historic opportunity for the Government to reject the free market approach and to unveil the vision and the plan that would help to get the country back on its feet again.

There is not one industry plan, not one import replacement strategy NOT ONE. Just some embroidery around the current disastrous policies. The Minister has referred glowingly to the recent Caucus report on unemployment produced by Mr Harry Woods—unfortunately the key recommendations of that report have been completely ignored by the Government.

There is no mention of lowering the exchange rate to boost competitiveness, and there is no creation of a national development fund. Instead we have the completely token gesture of allowing the Australian Industry Development Corporation to retain its after tax profit of $9.6 million instead of paying most of it into Consolidated Revenue. Quite frankly this is a joke because the Industry Development Fund proposal involves hundreds of millions or even billions of dollars being put to productive use not a token amount of under $10 million.
Mr Deputy President the Australian Democrats do not oppose any of these measures, merely the total inadequacy of the whole strategy (or lack of it) proposed here today by the Government.

As people often do in this place, it is easy to criticise the Government without providing any constructive alternatives. Let me put on the record what the Democrats argue that the Government should have done.

There should be a serious and responsible national infrastructure program. Such investment will provide short-term relief for some of the unemployed and aid the long-term efficiency of the private sector and hence contribute to the recovery of the economy. The investment should also be directed to sustainable development goals. Priority areas are:
investment in interstate rail transport—not the token $20 million allocated in today's statement;
investment in port facilities and intermodal transport connection to these facilities (eg improved rail access to ports);
investment in sewage treatment and sewerage and stormwater systems. This will provide huge export possibilities for Australian technology eg Memtec's sewage filtration systems;
investment in hard and softwood plantations to facilitate the elimination of logging of native forests;
investment in energy efficiency (ie retrofitting existing premises)—again a huge existing export market;

investment in renewable energy development—this sector has massive future export potential. It is essential that we develop in this area because we are a net energy exporter and this will be curtailed at some time in the future;
investment in national parks;
investment in plant and equipment for recycling

All of these will produce employment and most will assist the private sector's efficiency performance. They will also improve the quality of life of Australians, something which is rarely talked about these days.

The people opposing increased public investment are the federal economic bureaucracy and the Cabinet. They are the people whose mistakes caused the recession and the consequent unemployment—why should they be listened to again now?

More depressing than this, Mr Deputy President, is the reaction of the Opposition who claim that all will be well as long as we cut wages and cut public expenditure. This is a more terrifying scenario and demands urgent revision on the part of the Coalition partners.

This Statement will be remembered more for what it doesn't contain than for what it does, it offers little to those it purports to assist but more importantly it confirms the Democrats' worst fears that the policy direction of the Government has not changed and that the future of the unemployed is being left to market forces.
