SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects.

The Bill will give effect to the announcements in the March Industry Statement that the tax concession for research and development will be retained as a permanent feature and that provision be made for the deductibility of environmental impact study expenditure.
The Bill will exempt from tax the pay and allowances of members of the Australian Defence Forces allotted for duty in Iraq and Kuwait in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
It also contains amendments to support the existing tax file number arrangements.

Another amendment will give effect to the Treasurer's announcement on 13 June to provide relief for small business by deferring the initial payment of company tax in respect of the 1990-91 income year.
The Bill will also give effect to the announcement on 2 August that living-away-from-home allowances paid to offshore oil and gas rig workers will be treated as fringe benefits.

Other announcements to be given effect by this Bill relate to foreign source income measures, gifts to funds administered by cultural organisations, deductibility of Petroleum Resource Rent Tax payments and Medicare levy exemptions.
This Bill will also give effect to certain changes announced in the 1991-92 Budget.
One Budget announcement is an amendment to include the winnings of certain investment related lotteries in the assessable income of the winner.
Another will accord friendly societies and other registered organisations the same treatment for dividend imputation purposes as mutual life companies and government insurance offices.

Other Budget announcements to be given effect by this Bill relate to general mining exploration and prospecting expenditure, the timing of franking credits, capital gains tax and protection levy payments by life insurance companies.

The Bill will also amend the capital gains and loss provisions in the tax laws to address community concerns by allowing shareholders in companies in liquidation to realise capital losses on valueless shares.
The Bill introduces new procedures to be followed by taxpayers seeking review by the Federal Court or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation.
The Bill also simplifies the law by consolidating objection, review and appeal provisions that are common to various taxation laws administered by the Commissioner.
The Bill will also amend the garnishee rules and PAYE provisions of the tax laws as well as propose several minor changes to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987.
Finally, the Bill contains a number of minor technical or consequential amendments of the tax laws.
I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.
The Bill will allow a deduction for expenditure incurred on or after 12 March 1991 on environmental impact studies.

The expenditure, other than for plant and articles, will be written off over the lesser of 10 years or the life of the project to which the studies relate.The cost of plant and articles will be depreciable.
The proposed deduction was announced by the Government in the March 1991 Industry Statement.
The cost of this measure is expected to rise to an estimated cost of $45 million after 10 years.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Exemption of pay and allowances of members of Defence Forces serving in Iraq and Kuwait

SPEECH.PARA: As announced by the Minister for Defence, Science and Personnel on 14 August 1990, the pay and allowances earned by Defence Force personnel allotted for duty in Iraq and Kuwait in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait will be exempt from income tax.

The amendment proposed by this Bill will extend the existing operational area for the exemption to include the countries of Iraq and Kuwait with effect from 23 February 1991. The amendment will also cease the exemption after 9 June 1991.
The revenue cost was in the order of $8.75 million in the 1990-91 income year.

The Bill will implement the change announced in the 1991-92 Budget to the capital gains tax provisions. Taxpayers will now be allowed to offset non-deductible costs such as interest, repairs, rates and taxes and insurance premiums against the taxable capital gain made on disposal of an asset. The change affects assets acquired on or after 21 August 1991 and is not expected to have a significant revenue cost.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Capital Gains Tax and Valueless Shares

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendment to the capital gains and losses provisions addresses community concerns that shareholders in companies in liquidation are unable to realise capital losses on valueless shares.

Honourable senators will remember that in an earlier Second Reading debate on a private member's Bill dealing with this issue, it was indicated that the Government was looking at possible measures to deal with the problem faced by these shareholders.
We felt that the amendment proposed by Senator Watson was not the most appropriate answer.

The amendment proposed by this Bill will apply where a taxpayer owns shares in a company in liquidation and the liquidator has indicated that there is no likelihood of shareholders receiving a distribution in the course of winding up the company. It is considered that the liquidator would be in the best position to accurately determine the financial position of the company concerned.

In these circumstances, if the taxpayer makes an election, the taxpayer will be taken to have disposed of (and immediately re-acquired) the shares for no consideration at the time the liquidator's statement was made.

The amendment will overcome the particular problem facing holders of shares in companies which are in liquidation; due to the operation of the Corporations law these shareholders are prevented from transferring their valueless shares and realising a capital loss.

In circumstances where it is still possible to transfer ownership of a share, for example if a receiver has been appointed to manage the affairs of a company, this problem will not arise. Therefore the application of the amendment is restricted to apply only to the shares of companies which are in liquidation.

The proposed amendment will apply to eligible shares from 11 November 1991, regardless of the date that the liquidation of the company commenced. However the statement by the liquidator and the taxpayer's election must be made after that date.
The amendment is not expected to have a significant impact on revenue.

The tax concession for research and development at the rate of 125% of expenditure incurred will be retained as a permanent feature of the Income Tax Assessment Act beyond 1995. The Government has decided to retain the concession in order to keep promoting research and development activities by industry in Australia.
This Bill will give effect to the Government's decision which was announced in the March Industry Statement.
The estimated cost is $180m per annum in the first year of impact 1996/97 rising to $280m per annum by the year 2000/01.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Direct lodgment of taxation appeals and applications for review

SPEECH.PARA: Under the present law a taxpayer who is dissatisfied with the decision of the Commissioner on an objection against an assessment or similar decision may request the Commissioner to refer the decision to the Federal Court or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This right of appeal or review is given to taxpayers by various taxation laws.

Following an independent review of the processes for resolving taxation disputes, a recommendation was made to the Government that taxpayers should—like litigants in fields other than taxation—lodge their own appeals and applications for review direct with the Court or the Tribunal. The Government has accepted this recommendation.
As a result, this Bill proposes amendments of provisions in various taxation laws to remove the requirement that appeals and applications for review be lodged through the Commissioner.

These changes have also provided an opportunity to simplify the law by consolidating the common objection, review and appeal provisions of the different statutes in the Taxation Administration Act. The new provisions adopt more modern language and drafting approaches.

Existing provisions of that Act which modify procedures in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for taxation matters have been rewritten to take account of the new method for seeking review. Their effect is unchanged except in two minor respects.

One is that many documents formerly supplied by the Commissioner to the Tribunal as a matter of course will only be supplied if the Tribunal calls for them. This will save a lot of unnecessary time and expense.

The other change relates to the review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of decisions of a Training Advisory Body to issue a training advisory certificate under the Training Guarantee legislation. They are not decisions of the Commissioner, and in future, review by the Tribunal of such decisions will not be subject to the procedural modifications I have referred to.

These amendments will apply to all taxation decisions made on or after a date to be fixed by proclamation. Transitional provisions will ensure that the amendments also apply to appeals or applications for review made after the commencement date even though the relevant assessment was made before that date. This means that appeals or applications for review in respect of any objection decision made after the proclaimed commencement date will need to be lodged direct with the Federal Court or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

This Bill will amend the income tax law to provide for the assessment and collection of a tax file number withholding tax where an investor has not quoted a tax file number for certain deferred interest investments.
A separate Bill, the Income Tax (Deferred Interest Securities) (Tax File Number Withholding Tax) Bill 1991, will impose the tax file number withholding tax.

The new arrangements, which will not impact on the revenue, will provide that, where a tax file number is not quoted by the investor for certain deferred interest investments, a tax file number withholding tax will be payable jointly and severally by the investor and the investment body.
Investment bodies which pay the tax file number withholding tax for a deferred interest investment will be able to recover the amount paid from the investor.
As a result of industry consultations, the Government has decided that the new rules will only apply to investments made on or after 1 February 1992.
This will give investment bodies sufficient time to make any necessary changes to their existing practices to give effect to these amendments.
The winnings of certain investment-related lotteries which are drawn or decided on or after the day on which this Bill receives Royal Assent will be treated as assessable income of the winner.
The winnings will not be taxed by this amendment if either the prize won or the right to participate in the investment-related lottery is already liable to tax under existing rules.
Prizes will be taxed only if the lottery is in the nature of a return on an investment. Prizes won in ordinary lotteries such as Lotto are not affected.
The proposal was announced in the 1991-92 Budget.

The amendment has no direct impact on revenue, but will prevent revenue losses by ensuring that otherwise taxable investment receipts such as interest cannot be replaced by non-taxable lottery winnings.
The Bill will accord friendly societies and other registered organisations the same treatment for dividend imputation purposes as mutual life companies and government insurance offices.

A company's tax liability gives rise to franking credits which can be used to frank dividends paid to shareholders. Registered organisations, like mutual life assurance companies and government insurance offices, do not have shareholders and therefore cannot use the franking credits that accrue from the tax paid on their insurance and superannuation business.

This Bill will give effect to the 1991-92 Budget announcement to deny registered organisations the right to maintain a franking account and to cancel any surplus of franking credits held by them at 3.00pm on 20 August 1991.

The measure will have no direct impact on the revenue. However, there are potential revenue savings, in that it will prevent new shareholders of any friendly society that issues share capital, from having access to franking credits accumulated before capitalisation.

The Bill will give effect to the announcement in the 1991-92 Budget to change the basis on which companies receive franking credits under the dividend imputation arrangements. The effect of the measure will be that only the payment of company tax will give rise to a franking credit.

The present law allows companies to pay franked dividends on the basis of imputation credits that are generated when a notice of assessment is served rather than when the assessment is paid. Shareholders are presently entitled to a franking rebate on the franked dividends received, even if the company tax liability that allowed the company to frank the dividends is never paid.

The amendments proposed by this Bill will apply to assessment and other notices increasing tax liability which issue after 20 August 1991. Appropriate transitional measures will cover cases where tax has been paid prior to issue of such notices.

Changing the source of imputation credits from assessment to a payment basis will eliminate the scope for compounding the revenue losses that occur under the present law when companies fail to pay their tax liabilities. These revenue gains, however, cannot be quantified.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Deferral of initial payment of company tax

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will provide the legislation necessary to give effect to the Treasurer's announcement of 13 June to provide relief for small business by deferring the initial payment of company income tax in respect of the 1990-91 income year.

The companies affected are those with a tax liability of $1,000 or more but less than $400,000 and which pay their tax in two instalments. The date for the initial payment of tax was deferred by 7 weeks from the 28th day of the month following balance date to the 15th day of the third month following balance date.

The amount of initial tax payment affects the amount of a company's franking deficit tax and franking credits and debits. The amendments, which will not affect the revenue, will ensure that those amounts will be determined as if there had been no deferral of the initial tax payment.
The Government has always been willing to fine tune the foreign source income measures to ensure their smoother operation.
To this end, three of the amendments proposed by this Bill will operate to relieve double taxation that could arise under the measures.

In the first instance, further relief from double taxation will be provided in relation to an Australian controlled foreign company that has changed its residence from a low tax country to either Australia or a listed (comparable tax) country.

Secondly, corporate unit trusts, public trading trusts and superannuation trusts will be treated similarly to other resident taxpayers, by being granted an exemption from Australian tax for distributions from a controlled foreign company out of income previously attributed to them.
The third amendment will ensure that taxpayers are not disadvantaged by the operation of the rules for the conversion and carry forward of foreign losses incurred before 1990-91.

However, the Government is determined to act against attempts to erode the integrity of the foreign source income measures. Therefore, one amendment will deny taxpayers a tax advantage they have sought to obtain through changing the residence of a controlled foreign company from a comparable tax country to a low tax country. These taxpayers will be denied foreign tax credits on dividends paid by the company out of pre 1990-91 profits accumulated in the comparable tax country.
On 2 August 1991 the Government announced that living-away-from-home allowances paid to offshore oil and gas rig workers will be treated as fringe benefits.
When the fringe benefits tax law was introduced in 1986 it was the Government's intention that these allowances would be subject to fringe benefits tax.
The Bill will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act to achieve that result.
The amendment will have a negligible effect on revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Gifts to Gift Funds of Cultural Organisations

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will give effect to the announcement of 24 March 1991 introducing new arrangements for gifts to gift funds of cultural organisations. The amendment will take effect from 25 March 1991.

Under the new arrangements tax deductible gifts may be made to gift funds listed on a Register of Cultural Organisations. To be listed, a fund must be approved by the Treasurer and the Minister responsible for the Arts.
As a consequence of these new arrangements, the Bill will also remove the names of seven cultural organisations that are presently listed in the gift provisions of the income tax law.
Although the financial impact of the amendment cannot be quantified it is unlikely that the amendment will have a substantial impact on revenue.

The Bill will amend the income tax law to provide for the taxation treatment of various payments associated with the measure to assist policyholders of Occidental Life Insurance Company of Australia Limited and Regal Life Insurance Limited. For instance, protection levy payments will be tax deductible to life insurance companies.
This proposal was announced in the 1991-92 Budget and the estimated cost of the amendments is $25 million.

PARA.EMPHASIS: General Mining Exploration and Prospecting Expenditure

SPEECH.PARA: The mineral exploration and prospecting provision in the income tax law will be amended by this Bill. The requirement that general mineral exploration and prospecting expenditure needs to be incurred on a mining tenement to be eligible for a deduction will not apply on or after 1 July 1991.
The change, which was announced in the 1991-92 Budget, will ensure that deductibility for such expenditure is the same as that which is available to petroleum and quarrying exploration expenditure.
There is expected to be a small but unquantifiable impact on revenue.
The Bill gives effect to the announcement on 9 July of the Government's intention to remove an anomaly which has arisen in the Medicare levy exemption arrangements.
The amendment will continue to guarantee that blind pensioners and sickness beneficiaries are exempt from paying the Medicare levy regardless of the level of their income.
The amendment avoids an additional unintended cost to revenue.

The Bill will amend the garnishee rules in the tax laws so that, in relation to building society shares, only withdrawable shares (and not permanent or fixed shares) in the capital of a building society can be garnisheed from such a society.
This will provide for similar treatment for shares in companies and building societies in relation to the garnishee rules.
The amendment will apply to garnishee notices issued after the date of Royal Assent of the Bill.
The Bill will also amend the pay-as-you-earn (PAYE) provisions in the income tax law. The amendment will restructure and update the definitions contained in the provisions.
The update will clarify the scope of the PAYE arrangements and remove existing references to arrangements between the Governor-General and the States. These references are no longer required.
The amendments will also correct a technical inconsistency between the definition of "employer" and the penalty provisions in the PAYE arrangements.
The amendments will not affect the revenue.

The Bill proposes that all payers of eligible termination payments be required to report such payments to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. This will remedy deficiencies in the current legislation whereby some payers are not required to report such payments because of inadequacies in the existing definition of payer.

The Bill also provides that where a superannuation fund fails to comply with a request by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to commute the excessive component of a pension, the Commissioner may exercise a discretion to treat the fund as though it were a complying fund. The legislation currently provides that a fund which does not commute an excessive component of a pension as requested by the Commissioner becomes a non-complying fund and loses its entitlement to concessional taxation treatment on its income.

The Bill proposes that the existing deadline of 31 December 1991 for applications for pre 1 July 1988 funding credits be removed from the Act and that the date by which applications must be made be prescribed in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations.

The Government foreshadowed when introducing the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 into this House on 9 May 1991, that a minor change in the treatment of Petroleum Resource Rent Tax (PRRT) payments would be made.

Under the existing law, PRRT is deductible for income tax purposes only after the final assessment has been made. Therefore, instalments of PRRT are not deductible until a later income year when an assessment of PRRT is made.

This Bill will allow instalments of PRRT paid on or after 1 July 1991 to be deductible for income tax purposes in the year in which the instalment payments are made. The new provisions will be consistent with general income tax principles. This change will apply to all PRRT instalments paid on or after 1 July 1991.
The estimated cost of the amendment will be $125m in 1991-92 and $205m in 1992-93.
The Bill also contains amendments that relate to the measures enacted by this Government last year requiring the payment of provisional tax on certain salary or wages income.
These amendments, which will have negligible effect on the revenue, are designed to prevent certain taxpayers from receiving an income tax deferral advantage.
The law will also make it clear which amounts are to be taken into account when a taxpayer varies his or her provisional tax.

The Bill will make a number of minor technical amendments to the income tax law. Consequential amendments are also required to bring the income tax law into line with amendments to social security and veterans' entitlements legislation.
A minor technical amendment will also be made to the Wool Tax (Administration) Act 1964.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: TEXTILES, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Collins, on behalf of Senator Button)—by leave—agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Act 1988.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill amends the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Act 1988. The amendments to this Act arise from changes to assistance for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries announced by the Government in the March Industry Statement this year. Reductions in protection will be accelerated by phasing tariffs down to a maximum of 25% by the year 2000, terminating quotas by March 1993 and abolishing bounties by June 1995.

The TCF industries will remain the most highly protected manufacturing sector but the March decision will bring them more into line with the rest of Australian industry. It will encourage the development of a more globally oriented TCF sector, while bringing benefits to the economy through the efficient use of resources and better products at cheaper prices for the consumer.

To help potentially competitive firms survive the pressure of protection cuts and to provide positive direction through this restructuring period, the Government decided to revise the TCF Industries Development Strategy (IDS) administered by the TCF Development Authority.

The purpose of this Bill is to consolidate a number of the Authority's former programs into two stronger and more flexible programs, namely the Incentives for International Competitiveness Program which provides company specific assistance and the broader Infrastructure Support Program.

The new Incentives for International Competitiveness Program will provide assistance aimed at improving the competitiveness of TCF firms by extending assistance for capital re-equipment and rationalisation projects, investment in manufacturing systems and raw materials processing projects.

The amendments to the Act will broaden the eligibility criteria in relation to export orientation and import replacement so that more firms will be able to take advantage of the program. Firms will still be required to demonstrate increases in international competitiveness with projects such as those aimed at export growth, import replacement, quality improvement and cost reductions.

An important element of this strengthened program is the integration of the former Raw Materials Processing Program. The Authority will continue to place high priority on assisting firms to efficiently process a greater percentage of TCF raw materials, such as wool, cotton, hides and skins.

The Infrastructure Support Program is designed to provide assistance in areas such as research and development, skills and training, marketing and management services where such assistance is currently not provided under other Government programs.
The revised TCF Industries Development Strategy will now comprise four main programs

PARA.TAB: the Incentives for International Competitiveness Program;

TAB.TAB: the Infrastructure Support Program;

PARA.TAB: the Capitalisation Grants Program; and
the Import Credit Scheme.
Other legislation covers the last two programs.

In the March Industry Statement commitment was made to the continued provision of up to $120 million through the IDS over the period until 30 June 1995. At the same time the decision was made to increase the annual allocation for the Incentives for International Competitiveness and Infrastructure Programs from $10 million to $15 million and to allow the Authority to roll over funds not spent in any one year to the following year.

SPEECH.PARA: These Programs will assist TCF firms to respond positively to greater import competition. As protection falls, firms will need to review their competitive strategies to focus less on price and more on design, quality and service. Firms may find it necessary to invest in new technologies and processes to be able to provide superior products and services. As a result the industry will require a better trained and more highly skilled workforce.

The revised Industries Development Strategy will enable the Authority to help the TCF industries adapt to a new environment of relatively low protection. The challenge will be for firms to either succeed in export markets or to develop niche markets domestically. At the end of the decade, Australia can expect to have smaller but more dynamic TCF industries which will be viable with low levels of community support.
The amendments to the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Act 1988 have no financial implications beyond those already announced as part of the Government's 12 March 1991 statement.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Overseas Telecommunications Corporations Act provides that, for the purposes of all taxation laws, the merger of Telecom and OTC should be treated in neutral terms. Telecom and OTC have a number of subsidiaries, many of which perform similar activities which, as a result of the merger of Telecom and OTC, might be merged to be brought under the parent company, AOTC.

PARA.TAB: The Act does not currently provide for a tax neutral treatment of the merger of these subsidiaries. The change affects only wholly-owned subsidiaries of Telecom and OTC and relates only to mergers that are a direct result of the merger of Telecom and OTC. It does not relate to commercial restructuring.

As there is no beneficial change in ownership, it would be inappropriate that State-Territory governments should obtain a windfall revenue gain at the expense of the Commonwealth. Any such mergers must take place within 12 months of the merger of Telecom and OTC.

The amendment provides for the Minister for Transport and Communications to make regulations specifying the merging entities which should be treated in a tax neutral manner. The decision as to which entities will be merged will be based on consideration of a recommendation of the AOTC board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I indicate that we will accept the amendment that has been moved by Senator Collins on behalf of the Government. The amendment to the Australian Overseas Telecommunications Corporations Act 1991 will ensure that a merger of wholly-owned subsidiaries of Telecom and OTC that occur as a consequence of the merger of Telecom and OTC will be exempt from tax and will have a tax neutral effect, as the Minister indicated. The intent of this amendment is to ensure that any subsidiaries of Telecom and OTC are treated in exactly the same way as Telecom and OTC. We believe that amendment is appropriate and we will accept it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 8, page 5, proposed section 20AA subsection (5) line 19 after `must not' insert `knowingly or recklessly'.

My original concern was to add the word `knowingly'. On the best advice I can get, I have since been advised that in accordance with common law practice I should add the words `or recklessly'. I am quite happy to accept that advice.

PARA.TAB: This section of the Bill deals with the certifications that are required for aircraft; that is, a certificate of airworthiness and maintenance release. The way the Bill is worded, in subsection (5) it states:

SPEECH.PARA: An owner, operator, hirer (not being the Crown) or pilot of an aircraft must not:
(a) operate the aircraft; or
(b) permit the aircraft to be operated;
so as to contravene subsection (3) or (4).

The point I made in my speech during the second reading debate was that, while the certificate of airworthiness would not necessarily be invalidated, a maintenance release does have an expiry point on it; either in terms of calendar months or in hours flown in the aircraft. It would be quite possible for someone to hire an aircraft, or have access to an aircraft—which would be beyond the control of the owner of the aircraft—and infringe the requirements of the maintenance release without the knowledge of the owner of the aircraft. In that circumstance, it is not reasonable to subject the owner to a penalty for something over which he has no control. I am led to believe, on a careful reading of the Bill, that it is not the Government's intention to have that interpretation put on the Act. It is quite a minor amendment. I am led to understand the Government is quite happy to accept it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct. As far as the Government is concerned, the amendment is not necessary because the offence in proposed subsection 20AA(5) is not a strict liability offence in the pure sense. A court will interpret an offence as a strict liability offence only if the offence expressly excludes the mental element. In the current provision the court would imply knowledge into the offence. Senator MacGibbon is quite correct: the Government will not oppose the amendment as it is only stating the common law position. The Government will not be opposing it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

I take it from the smile on Senator Collins's face that that would be the very last thing any Labor Government would think of doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Naturally, we would like to maintain air traffic control.

—On reflection, I have been assured that it is not possible to separate these on that basis. I have been told that the fees for licensing and for the regulatory functions are indeed the minor part of the fees gathered by the Authority. The principal ones are for those charges that fall in the category of a service or a facility. I would like confirmation from the Minister that that is so. If I get that confirmation I will not proceed further with my proposed amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the philosophical base adopted by Senator MacGibbon and I appreciate his reasons for considering an amendment. However, I am grateful to him for indicating his position. I can confirm that advice, and I thank Senator MacGibbon for agreeing not to pursue his amendment.

—Finally, in relation to the Civil Aviation Authority, I refer to new clause 9AA where the operations of Commonwealth jurisdiction aircraft are defined. May I ask the Minister for an explanation as to why this provision is proposed to be added to the legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —This relates to the question of wake vortices from aircraft. The purpose of the amendment is to clarify that the CAA does have the power to investigate cases of damage to property caused by wake vortices and to make arrangements for compensation. It is a beneficial change to the legislation for people so affected. The CAA has a discretion as to whether it will pay compensation, or alternatively may make arrangements to repair the damage.

PARA.TAB: The amendment gives effect to a recommendation of the report of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Aircraft Noise, the HORSCAN Committee. HORSCAN recognised that there is little action people can take against government agencies such as the CAA or airline operators, and recommended that the Government meet the cost of repair in proven cases of damage from wake vortices. The Government accepted that recommendation. Damage to aircraft in flight has been excluded. I know I will not have to explain this to Senator MacGibbon as these incidents raise extremely complex issues of liability in terms of the actual cause. These matters are far better resolved in the courts.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may take the matter a little further, Commonwealth jurisdiction aircraft by definition would be airline aircraft, not Crown aircraft, general aviation or others. One of the principal concerns seems to be the requirement to investigate damage to property caused by wake vortices. What is the history of damage from wake vortices to property? I would have thought that there were very few heavy commercial aircraft flying at 50 feet or so over urban areas. I am not opposed to it, but I am at a total loss to see the need for the clause to be in the legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon is correct to say that these are not frequent occurrences in the sense that they happen on a daily basis, but complaints are made on a regular basis. In fact, I am advised that there have been four such complaints about damage to houses from wake vortices in the past month.
—I am surprised at that. I would appreciate being provided with some further information on those inquiries in due course, if that is possible.
—Certainly.

—My next question on these provisions is as follows: why is a discretionary compensation created? It seems a little unusual to me. Either there is a responsibility here or there is not. Why has it been decided to grant a discretion?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason is to simplify the process. It is a distinct improvement for the householder on the previous position. The discretion has to lie somewhere and the Government wants it to rest with the CAA.

PARA.TAB: Let me explain the kind of circumstance that could occur—not that I am suggesting anyone would actually do this. It could well be that, for example, a claim for damage to roof tiling is made by a householder. Under this legislation the CAA would inspect the damage and the expert inspectors may determine that perhaps the tiles came off the roof because of their age, bad maintenance or whatever and were not damaged as a direct result of wake vortices from aircraft. In that case the discretion will lie with the CAA as to whether it agrees that there is a real case to be made for fixing the tiles. I might add that the CAA will be scrupulous in carrying this out as part of its operations. It may well decide that that is not the case; the discretion lies with it as to whether the people have a case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to pursue that point, but surely the matter would have to be determined on the basis of whether it was a reasonable claim and whether it was likely that that had happened. I do not see that there needs to be a discretionary clause for that.

PARA.TAB: My final question on this point is: what action can the Authority take to protect its own financial interest? It seems to me that there is nothing in this part that requires the Authority to protect itself from charges here or, indeed, that puts in place anything it can do to protect its own financial place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly have confidence in the Authority to carry out this task in a reasonable fashion. The Authority does in fact have the power to protect its own interest by the discretion that it has. If the Authority determines that the case is not reasonable because of the condition of the damage—in fact, in the example I just gave it was old tiles which fell off the roof and it was a try-on—it will not pay compensation or repair the damage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek your guidance. Because this is an omnibus Bill, we have a raft of advisers present. They cannot all fit into the advisers' box at once. I do have an answer for Senator Coulter and I am happy to provide it at the appropriate time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Minister is happy to provide that afterwards, I am quite happy to move to part 6, which relates to the amendments to the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcast Act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, the advisers were listening and have come into the chamber. The response to Senator Coulter's question is that the questions regarding fishing vessel mother ships and pilot licensing are completely separate. Where fishing vessel support ships transit the inner route of the Great Barrier Reef within the compulsory pilotage area, they will be subject to exactly the same laws as any other vessel. If they are over 70 metres in length, in order to be exempted from the requirement to carry a pilot they will need to demonstrate that no greater risk will be offered to the fragile environment of the Great Barrier Reef than if they carried a pilot. The amendment in no way derogates from the legislation protecting the Great Barrier Reef through compulsory pilotage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for an answer to a question which I had not even asked. That is real efficiency. However, if I may pursue that for a minute, section 29 says that the regulations `may specify', et cetera. Although the Minister has given those assurances, the regulations are not actually in the Act and presumably we are going to see some regulations further on in connection with this. I seek the Minister's assurance that the regulations, when we do see them, will in fact give effect to exactly what he said.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The response that I just gave to Senator Coulter in fact does apply directly to the question that he asked, but I concede—and I apologise to Senator Coulter—that he did ask for details of the conditions and I do have those. I will provide them now. Following representations in the International Maritime Organisation and other international bodies, the Government achieved international agreement to compulsory pilotage within the area of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park as an appropriate method to protect the sensitive environment of the Great Barrier Reef.

PARA.TAB: The reason I want to make that point is that, as I have said on previous occasions here, it was no mean feat to achieve that. It was in fact a significant step forward and AMSA deserves to be congratulated for making the successful representations that got international approval to declare this as a special area. I am sure that Senator Coulter would know, for commercial and all sorts of other reasons, that this is a proposition which is often stoutly resisted by other maritime nations.

Amendments were made to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act earlier this year to introduce a compulsory pilotage regime for ships using the inner route of the Great Barrier Reef and Hydrographers Passage. These amendments provide that regulated ships must carry a pilot licence under Commonwealth, State or Territory law. Pilotage is presently carried out by pilots of the Queensland Coast and Torres Strait Pilot Service who are licensed by the Queensland Government under the Queensland Marine Act.

It was considered inappropriate in an internationally sanctioned regime to have a system of pilotage relying totally on State law. In addition, industry has expressed concern regarding the monopoly position of this service and the allegedly high cost of pilotage. Amendments to the Navigation Act will enable regulations to be made to provide alternatives to the present pilotage arrangements and, in particular, to define who is qualified to be a pilot.

Pilot standards under Commonwealth law will be introduced only after extensive consultation with industry interests, including the present pilots, unions and national and international ship operators. Subject to the outcome of these consultations—and I have to stress that that is the one caveat I have to put on this—it is likely that the standards under Commonwealth legislation will include basic qualifications, that is, a master class 1 certificate of competency, medical and health standards, regular medical checks, experience in ship handling in a range of vessels, experience in the waters of the Great Barrier Reef itself and regular checks on performance. It might also be desirable to specify compliance with particular sets of operating procedures and standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —On that point, am I correct in understanding the Minister to have said something about there being a monopoly and complaints about the charges? That would lead me to ask: have there been changes under the recent amendments to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act, or whatever was amended recently? I might be a few years out of date, but I thought there was indeed no monopoly, that anyone could provide a pilotage service provided he had the experience to hold a licence and could meet the infrastructure of being able to pick up ships all around Torres Strait or at the southern end. It used to be a fact that the pilotage fees were set by the Queensland Government, not by the Queensland Coast and Torres Strait Pilot Service. If that is still so, there really is no case.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —To answer the first part of Senator MacGibbon's question, no, this monopoly does not come about as part of any legislation or regulatory requirement that has actually been promulgated. It comes about simply because this is the only way pilots can currently be registered under State law in Queensland. I cannot specifically answer Senator MacGibbon's question as to whether the fees are actually set by the State Government or by the pilot service, but really it is not particularly relevant.

PARA.TAB: I might also add that there have been complaints. At this stage I would not be prepared to assert whether the complaints are justified, but complaints have been made and arrangements will be entered into which will provide for the registration of pilots so that this monopoly situation that currently occurs will not continue. In fact, this is a step in that direction. I do not think anybody would disagree that, in order to maintain a credible system of enforced protection of the reef, the pilots have to be properly registered and have recognised qualifications.

TALK.START.PARA: —On that point, is it a fact—I think I refer to Senator MacGibbon's question—that some years ago a lot of pilotage was provided by the Department of Harbours and Marine, certainly for vessels coming in through Hydrographers Passage? It is my understanding—the Minister might correct me if I am wrong—that some years ago the pilotage service was privatised. Bearing in mind that pilots are fairly scarce—it is not the sort of job, because of the qualifications required, where an advertisement is put in the paper and a pilot is picked up—many of those pilots then joined up with the Torres Strait pilot group. That is the position. There is certainly no legislation which entrenches a monopoly. Anyone who is available can come into that game. It is simply that these people have banded together through the Torres Strait pilot group.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm Senator Parer's advice that the groups are privatised. The monopoly comes in because, although it is a private company, it is registered under the Queensland marine legislation, and that is a situation which is likely to change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Coming to part 6, I move:

PARA.TAB: Part 6, clauses 33 to 35, page 17, delete the clauses.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment seeks to delete part 6. I believe this part has arisen because the parliamentary proceedings and the proceedings of the various committees of the Parliament attract privilege. When Parliament was broadcast by radio, those radio broadcasts, which were complete broadcasts of the proceedings, also attracted privilege. It seemed at first blush, when I looked at this the other day, that all that was happening here was an extension of that privilege to the televising of Parliament and the committees and various other procedures that go on in the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: On further reflection, one recognises that not all of the parliamentary proceedings are televised; they are televised only in part. There is a certain selectivity going on in relation to which parts are broadcast and which are not. While I make no reflection at all on the present telecasting of Parliament—I think the job that is being done in this place is absolutely excellent—it would be possible at some future time for some person with less professional ability or somebody using less care to select parts of the parliamentary proceedings and to telecast those in a selective way. If this part were passed in its present form, those broadcasts would attract privilege and no action could be taken against them.

It seems to me that a potentially very dangerous situation is being created here. It may be, if later a television station were to begin broadcasting all the proceedings of the Parliament, as the radio broadcasts all the proceedings of the Parliament, that that situation would be overcome. In the meantime, it would seem that the deletion of this part of the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill would be quite adequately covered by section 10 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a defence to an action for defamation—
that is the way in which this sort of thing is likely to arise—
that the defamatory matter was published by the defendant without any adoption by the defendant of the substance of the matter, and the defamatory matter was contained in—
and these are the relevant words—
a fair and accurate report of proceedings at a meeting of a House or a committee.

It goes on. It seems to me that those words provide the necessary protection for those who would broadcast, but at the same time they leave the door ajar if some inaccurate or unfair broadcast were made and somebody were to take offence at that. For those reasons, it seems to me that it is premature to include a part such as this at a time when the whole of the Parliament is not being telecast, to extend the privilege to those parts which are broadcast, and perhaps selectively broadcast, and create a fault against which a person who has offended would have no possible cause of action. Accordingly, I have moved the amendment for the deletion of part 6 of this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the coalition, I advise the Committee that we will support the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. We share their concern that the Government's proposals could leave a person open to being defamed by the use of various excerpts from the televised proceedings of Parliament placed in a preconceived juxtaposition which would lead to a senator, member or third party being defamed. If the Government's proposals were passed into law, that person would not have a defamation action. We believe that freedom should be available to people to take such action if they are defamed in that way. On that basis, we support the Democrats' amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is indebted to the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, for drawing this problem to our attention. I thank him for that. The Government agrees with the detailed statement just delivered by Senator Coulter, and the Government will also be supporting this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion deals with three substantive amendments to the Telecommunications Act passed earlier this year. Two of these amendments are of a technical nature, while one makes a limited change to normal disallowance procedures for subordinate instruments. Might I say that there has been some extensive discussion between the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats on this issue. All parties have indicated that they understand the reason this has to be done.

PARA.TAB: The first group of amendments relates to changes proposed to section 137 of the primary Act. This section was intended to give carriers the right both to interconnect their networks and to have their communications carried by other carriers. It was also intended to allow carriers flexibility in determining the means for such carriers. During recent negotiations between the bidders for the second carrier and Telecom Australia-OTC Ltd, it has become clear that there is a difficulty in the coverage of this provision in that it may not cover leased capacity or international services provided using carrier facilities that are outside Australia or a range of telecommunications services which carriers may quite legitimately need to provide to other carriers. The amendments to section 137 and associated consequential amendments address this difficulty by recasting the central concept of network and by recasting the underlying right to carriage in terms of a right to telecommunications services which now clarifies the position.

The second amendment to the primary Act is intended to close off a possible loophole in section 194 of the Act, which requires carriers to provide publicly available tariffs of the basic carriage services they supply to the public generally. The intention of this provision was that, whenever a carrier supplies a service to a person other than a carrier, the carrier should tariff it so as to give transparency to the provision of services and to assist in the enforcement of the discrimination provisions of the Act. The amendment to section 194 is simply intended to put this issue beyond doubt.

Those are the two technical amendments. The third group of amendments inserts two new sections into the principal Act to modify the disallowance provisions under the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 for a limited period. A number of instruments under the primary Act, most notably carrier licence conditions, the ministerial determination of interconnect pricing principles under section 140 and regulations exempting carriers from State laws are crucial to both carriers. The sale of the second carrier and, consequently, the commencement of network competition in telecommunications is therefore dependent on the bidders having certainty about the regulatory regime in which they will be operating.

The proposed amendments are intended to allow the sale process to be completed by the end of this year by modifying the disallowance period under section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act as it applies to regulations and other disallowable instruments made under the primary Act from 15 days to five days, both for the period within which a disallowance motion may be moved and for the period of further consideration following a motion for disallowance. The provisions will also allow each House of Parliament, respectively, the ability to approve the relevant regulation or instrument earlier if it saw fit.

The amended operation of the Acts Interpretation Act is strictly quarantined to instruments tabled before 31 December this year. It provides for a sensible balance between allowing the Parliament the opportunity to scrutinise the relevant delegated legislation, which it can, while recognising that we do have a special set of circumstances which recognise commercial realities so as not to delay the commencement of competition in this vital industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Chapman, I indicate that when I said it was no longer relevant I was mistaken. I was mistaken because the amendment says `after clause 35 insert such and such' and we do not have a clause 35 any more. But I am told there is no problem.

—On behalf of the coalition, I indicate that we will accept each of these three amendments. With regard to the first amendment, we believe it is important that a carrier has the right to interconnect its facilities to the network of another carrier and that any doubt be removed, as it will be by the repeal of the originally proposed new section 137 and the substitution of this proposed new section. If the proposed reform of telecommunications is to operate effectively, then that right to interconnect is very important and must be made very clear in the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The second amendment regarding tariffing we also believe is important because it is essential, if competition is to be truly introduced into this industry, that transparency be evident. So we support that amendment.

In relation to the third amendment, we understand the need for the period of disallowance to be reduced from what would normally apply, given the onset of the Christmas period and the importance of having this legislation and its associated regulations in place so that the potential investors in this industry do have some certainty that the regulations will be operable. They can, therefore, make their commercial decisions on that basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand why we are passing these amendments. Of course, the Minister would not be surprised to know that we still have not changed our original position on what is happening to telecommunications in this country. Senator Chapman says that he understands the importance of the right to interconnect, and within this framework so do we. But I want to ask about the right to connect at what rate. I have a question in relation to carriers' rights to interconnect—the repeal of section 137; I am talking about page 7 of the amendments, (3)(a), parts (i) to (iii). I understand that Telecom asked for clarification of the effect this would have on it and that Mr Beazley responded. I ask the Minister: what is the effect of this particular section on Telecom? Does it in fact mean that it will be possible for the second carrier to interconnect at a less than marketable rate?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —To clarify that, the answer is no. The actual pricing matters are dealt with separately under section 140 of the Act and this is simply in order to clarify the intent of the original section. It certainly will not allow the opportunity for bargain basement prices to be levied by the second system at all. But that is dealt with separately under section 140.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also wish to object to the reduction of the period of disallowance from 15 to five days. We understand the commercial interests waiting in the wings, but we also understand that the period of 15 days for disallowance has been set for a very long period for very good reasons, to allow not only the members of this chamber but also people outside to become aware of what is being done and to voice objections. For those commercial interests out there to essentially use the Parliament like a puppet on a string to suit their particular and immediate commercial interests, I think sets a very dangerous precedent. Whilst the Minister has assured us that this is for a limited period only, having created that precedent, we may well see it with other legislation and other powerful commercial interests.

PARA.TAB: We do not intend to call a division on this matter, but we simply voice objection to this process because we think it sets a very dangerous precedent and it puts the interest of the commercial people above the parliamentary procedures.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to that very briefly. I want to clarify the position absolutely. That is not the case at all. This Parliament is not dancing like a puppet on a string because commercial interests are applying this pressure; the Government is, and I might add that the Opposition is making it clear. I understand the Democrats' position on this and respect it. The Opposition and the Government have a different view on the matter. There is not one iota of pressure from any commercial interest. The Government is anxious to have this reform in place. We want to negotiate it successfully and we want to have it in place by the end of the year. Clearly, we do not consider this to be a practice that should be adopted as a matter of course. That is precisely why it is structured in the way it is. It is absolutely quarantined so that it will not be applied as a matter of course.

PARA.TAB: Frankly, considering the depth and extent of the debate in this Committee on these amendments—and I am prepared to concede, having worked closely and cooperatively with Senator Kernot on this, that the Democrats are as familiar with the details of this matter as anyone else in the chamber—I have no doubt about the ability of this chamber to provide effective scrutiny of this matter, despite the shortening of the time. I stress again that the pressure is certainly coming from the Government to implement this policy of providing competition, and I know that it is supported by the Opposition.

I conclude by providing Senator Kernot and Senator Coulter with a piece of additional advice about pricing under section 140. The determination on pricing that will be made in section 140 is in fact a disallowable instrument and it will be subject to the scrutiny of this chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask the Minister one question. Is it not the case that two bidders have made it quite clear to the Government that they want to operate in a climate of certainty and that that is where some of the pressure is coming from?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not particularly want to run around this track again. That is correct. I might add that I would have thought that would be a prudent commercial concern of any company. The Government—and I have no doubt the Opposition and, frankly, the Democrats also—wants them to operate in an atmosphere of certainty, which is why we are asking the Parliament for this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
