DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TAFE ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Collins)—by leave—proposed:

That Government Business Order of the Day No. 3 (States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 and two related Bills be called on forthwith and have precedence over all other business until determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Opposition supports the cognate debate and we will speak to the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 and two related Bills together, but I want to make one point. There is inadequate debate on education Bills in the House of Representatives and, whilst we have always accepted a cognate debate in the Senate, I do not want it to be understood that the Opposition regards the education Bills as unimportant. This is one of two occasions in the year that we get to debate these important Bills that touch upon higher education, TAFE and schools. I believe that, together with our colleagues in the House of Representatives, we need to lift the parliamentary attention that is given to the state of education in this country. I support the motion.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be opposing the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 and two related Bills which are now being cognately debated in the Senate. The three Bills are in the normal annual format and provide Commonwealth financial support to the three major areas of education, that is, higher education, technical and further education and schools.

PARA.TAB: The first thing to notice about these Bills is that they show no move on the part of the Government to draw back from the policy path that it has followed under the present Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and his compliant assistant, Mr Baldwin, which is the path of greater centralised control by Canberra. I say to the Government senators opposite and to the representatives of the Department who are present as advisers, that there has been no drawing back over recent months—indeed, over recent years—from greater centralised control by Canberra in all matters that relate to education.

Let it be clear that with the election of the coalition to government that will end, and we will see an abrupt change in the arrogance that centralises power in education matters in Canberra. Great insight and ability to make decisions lie with the education institutions and beneficiaries of education, that is, families and students. On our election to government we will see an end to this increasing accretion of powers to the Minister and the bureaucracy in Canberra.

The Bills before us tonight again demonstrate this greater intrusion into the decision making of education institutions, and more bureaucratic requirements for the unnecessary provision of detailed information to the Department by those institutions. Many times in the past the Opposition has criticised the Government's whole approach to education policy. We shall go on doing so until members of the Australian public not only recognise this malaise, this problem, but also cry out—as they are already—for a change in education policy. This Government is impenetrable and such a change requires a change of government. We desperately need a change of government to achieve education reform.

These Bills fail to show any change of heart on the Government's part. There is no new initiative and there is nothing creative in them. The Bills plod on with the inhibiting centralism of which the education industry at every level has now had a gutful.

The Bills are limited to continuing the Government's same old basic approach. This is particularly so in the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No.2) 1991. There may be some benefits to be gained from setting up advanced engineering centres, running a pilot scheme where the Government and employers will jointly fund a few extra student places, and there is a faint attempt to begin to reward improved quality in higher education institutions, yet the overall provisions maintain the framework of the unified national system—the straitjacket that Mr Dawkins has placed on Australian higher education.

We see no response in these Bills by the Government to the views of the Industry Commission, for example. What has the Government ever said about the Industry Commission's report into education in this country? This is a commission appointed by this Government. The Industry Commission recently described the current approach to the regulation and funding of higher education as `fundamentally flawed'. I will repeat it: this Government's Industry Commission described this Government's approach to higher education as `fundamentally flawed'.

The only way to get education reform in this country is to see a change of government. The Opposition sees no sign of the Government being willing to take seriously other options for higher education policy such as the Industry Commission's detailed analysis and advocacy of flexibility. Where is the flexibility in the way that higher education operates in this country? Where is the advocacy of a more decentralised system?

For five years I have been commending the 15 years that I call the Karmel years in Australian education policy and decision making. They were years of rationalisation in which quite a deal of initiative was taken in Canberra. They were so successful that we do not need a period like that to be repeated ad infinitum, we need an ability for creativity to be given an open door in education institutions. This Government has taken the wrong cue from the 15 years of what I will call Karmel success. It wants more of the same—more rationalisation, more amalgamation of colleges and universities, and more centralisation in Canberra. For five years, at least, we have been going down the wrong path. I agree with the Industry Commission that higher education is fundamentally flawed in the policies of this Government.

I will come to the—let me be honest—reluctant conclusion, even as an Opposition member, that the only way to get education reform into the thick heads of the Government's policy decision makers is to throw them out and bring in a completely new team. We need a change of government if we are going to get the kind of new energy in education policy that this country desperately needs.
Accordingly, on behalf of the Opposition, as an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, I move:
At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)its determination to maintain a flawed funding mechanism for higher education;
(b)its pursuit of a policy which prevents over 30,000 qualified Australian students from gaining places;
(c)its failure to address adequately the issues of quality and diversity in higher education;
(d)its failure to address the serious inequities of current higher education funding arrangements; and
(e)its decision to deal with overcrowding mainly by excluding even more Australian students from university places".
This amendment, which condemns the Government, ought to be adopted by the Senate, and I am confident that the Australian Democrats will join with the Opposition and see this amendment passed tonight.

PARA.TAB: I turn now to the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No.2) 1991. This legislation in itself leaves us none the wiser about the Government's policy intentions. We have just had a major inquiry into technical and further education, the Finn report. It is a very important report and a report which I, on behalf of the Opposition, in broad, commend. We are not embarrassed by the Finn report but the Government is. As I said before, there are only two occasions in the year when we significantly address education matters like this: this is one of them. In this six months the Government is not addressing the Finn report. We do not know what the Government will do about TAFE and yet it is the area in Australia crying out the most for new initiatives.

Before I entered the Senate, back in the early 1970s, I remember giving several addresses in my own State of South Australia asking, `What about the workers? What about the supervisors? What about the trained technicians?'. We have beautiful university facilities for doctors, engineers and lawyers—I see across the way Senator Tate. We have training for education—I see Senator Tierney here. Those who have attended our universities over many decades have had very good facilities. But what about those who have been trained in what we call technical and further education? Too often this country has given them a back shed and hoped they could get some training over a three-year period, or part time over a two-year period. Often they have the inadequate provision.

We have called over the last decade for various reforms in TAFE. We have now seen this major inquiry and report, the Finn report. What about the students in technical and further education? Does anyone seriously believe that we are contributing to their education in a comparable way to those trained in the universities' professions? I do not think there is any voice; there is not one person. If Australia is to become, to quote a common phrase these days, the clever country—to live up to our potential not only economically, but also in terms of the lifestyle and the fulfilment of individuals—we must invest more resources into technical and further education.On behalf of the Opposition, I make a firm promise that we will invest increased resources in technical and further education.

In this Bill, on the Labor Government's part, there is nothing new. There is no response to the Finn report, however current and recent it is. We have the same vacuum. Now the Minister, Mr Dawkins, has said he will take over TAFE from the States, but all of that has been jettisoned by the Caucus overruling the Prime Minister, in this struggle with Mr Keating about the relationship between the Federal decisions and responsibilities, and the State decisions and responsibilities. Who knows what is going to happen to these lone voice statements of Mr Dawkins about the Commonwealth's initiatives in TAFE? Who knows what is going to happen? There is nothing in this legislation. I say on behalf of the Australian people, at least in my State, who are using TAFE facilities: let this Government give some lead, because it is dismally failing TAFE in particular.

There is a vacuum in this legislation. It is by no means clear what the exact final outcome will be from the negotiations between Federal and State governments concerning the future responsibility for the funding of TAFE. Mr Dawkins has, characteristically, gone into these negotiations bold and brave up front, but he does not represent anyone in Cabinet, except himself. He does not have the Prime Minister's support, and his mate Mr Keating is out in the cold, so we are none the wiser.

The pressing need is for a substantial improvement in Australia's training effort, and it is not actually even what Mr Dawkins has said on his own behalf. We do not want increased bureaucratic control from Canberra, which is what he has advocated and which has so alienated his Labor mates who are Ministers in the States that they have come out against him. They do not want centralised bureaucratic control in Canberra for TAFE.

The only way forward for education reform, I say clearly to the Senate, is a change of Government. This Government has got to go and we have to see a new team. We have to see a new approach, not only to higher education but also to technical and further education, and it will only come from the election of a coalition Government here in Canberra.

Now I turn to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991. It offers no major break with past policy; it is the same old stuff. The old restrictions on schools continue. There are two small steps in the right direction. Firstly, there is funding for national projects to increase the number of students in country areas finishing year 12—a small, inadequate step in the right direction. Secondly, there is the school language and literacy program which was developed in the context of the White Paper on Australian language and literacy policy.

The White Paper is too slow, too late. It was 10 years ago that, as Chairman of the Senate Committee on Education and the Arts, I had the honour to move in this Senate an inquiry into a national language policy. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will recall this major report which came before the Senate, and one of the Clerks at the table will remember that in another life he was secretary of that inquiry. It was a very important inquiry, and it was unanimous. No-one has criticised this report. It set out an approach to a national language policy for Australia. It was followed by the Joe Lo Bianco draft report for the Government response to this—an excellent response—and eventually by what is called a White Paper on language policy. There was some implementation of little bits and, in this legislation, we have another little bit of it.
On behalf of the Opposition, as an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, I move:
At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)its failure to adequately recognise the role of technical and further education in Australia's education and training systems;
(b)its continuing emphasis on centralist solutions to issues arising in relation to technical and further education; and
(c)its failure to recognise the need for more flexible TAFE institutions which can be more responsive to student and industry demands".
That amendment follows my remarks with regard to TAFE. As an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, I move:
At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a)its restrictive policies in providing general recurrent and capital funding to non-government schools;
(b)its restrictive and excessively regulated school policies, especially its bureaucratic accountability requirements imposed on non-government schools and the operation of the New Schools Policy;
(c)its failure to recognise the real problems of language and literacy in Australia, as evidenced in the White Paper on the Australian Language and Literacy Policy; and
(d)the failure to adequately address the retention problem in rural and remote areas".

I have now moved three amendments to the motion for the second reading of the Bills, one for each of the three Bills before us. I commend those amendments to all honourable senators and hope that we may gain the support of the Senate for those amendments.

PARA.TAB: With regard to language policy, I wish to add a reference to recommendation No. 87 on page 162 of the Senate Committee report to which I referred earlier. That recommendation reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee thus recommends that education authorities should identify those languages of major relevance to the majority of schools. Funds available for the teaching of languages should be directed mainly to such languages, although a substantial portion should also be reserved for other languages.

I hope the Minister has not taken that as his cue for arrogating to himself in this legislation a power to determine unilaterally, centrally, in Canberra what languages will be learnt in all the schools and universities of Australia. That is not what we meant in the national language policy report of the Senate. We meant that there should be a sensibly determined list of languages—I have in mind 17 languages—in which the Commonwealth ensures that there are well developed teaching materials, so that there can be a choice in universities and in schools. Each institution that presents a course will be able to weigh what is best and appropriate for its own community and consult, in the case of schools with parents and students and in the case of universities with the students, to ensure that they are presenting what is most relevant and most valued by those who are going to receive those courses.

PARA.TAB: For the record, so that I can be held to account, there are 11 languages that I recommended then, and still do, that schools should be fully equipped to make available: English; one Aboriginal language, and I suggest Pitjantjatjara; Chinese, Japanese and Indonesian—the three most important Asian languages; French, German and Spanish—the three most important international languages; Italian and Modern Greek—the two community languages with the greatest number of speakers in this country; and Latin, which is important for all of them. With regard to university education, all 11 languages must be available, plus the following six: Arabic, Russian, Hebrew, Classical Greek, Hindi and Korean. I mention Hindi and Korean because after the three I mentioned, they are the principal Asian languages that we ought to have some Australians with expertise in; I mention Old Testament Hebrew and Classical Greek because they are the languages of the foundations of our Western culture; and Arabic and Russian are also major world languages.

There are many other languages of community importance in Australia and of importance to our economy and in many other ways. There ought to be freedom for Australians to choose those other languages if they see that that is necessary. I am arguing that there should be 17 languages in which there should be proper preparation. But I will oppose a Minister in Canberra of any political persuasion determining what the choice of those 17 languages should be in any school or in any university. Let the universities themselves determine that; let the schools determine that.

I wish to refer briefly to the non-government schools policy of the present Government, which has been a total disaster. It is one of the blights on Australia that there has been a sop thrown to the left wing of the Labor movement by way of a virtual ban on new non-government schools in this country. I say `a virtual ban' because every kind of impediment has been placed in their way. It was attempted first under Minister Ryan and it has been fully put into place under Minister Dawkins.
Let me give the statistics on the results. There was a 10 per cent rise in the number of schools in the five years from 1981 to 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: It was then that the new schools policy was announced. As a consequence of that disastrous policy, brought in by a Labor government as a sop to the left wing for ideological reasons, there was a one per cent increase in the five years after 1985. The left wing ideologues in the Labor Party are cheering about that, and the Australian public is totally shattered by the policies of this Government. I give the promise now, on behalf of the Opposition, that this will be completely changed by a coalition government. We will open the doors to make it possible, as it was before this policy was introduced, for responsible new non-government schools to be added to the offerings for Australian school children.

PARA.TAB: About 27 per cent of Australian school children attend non-government schools by choice. Another 23 per cent at least want to attend non-government schools, and we will make it possible for them. They are the middle income families of Australia; they are the swinging voters of Australia . We are opening the door for them to be able to choose a non-government school that has an education policy that will realise the full potential of their children. The only way that will be achieved is by a change of government. It is essential that we have a coalition government elected at the next election to give a choice of education for those families that are looking for this for their children.

One of the broader issues underlying the three Bills before us is the expression `the clever country'. It is an aspiration for Australia increasingly heard in our national discussions of education issues. What is this clever country and how is it best achieved? In the concluding minutes available to me, I wish to address this issue. I have some OECD statistics setting out public spending on education as a proportion of gross domestic product; and education enrolment in Australia in comparison with the other OECD countries. I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate two tables into Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —These tables will show that, in terms of the resources we make available for public education, Australia is behind almost all of the OECD countries. For example, we are behind the USA and Canada. We are behind the European countries of Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Finland—all the Scandinavians. We are behind the Netherlands, France, Italy, Belgium, the UK and Ireland. We are behind Austria and Switzerland and Japan. In fact, we come seventeenth out of the 25 OECD nations.

PARA.TAB: Whatever criticisms I have made of Government policy, I want to say this to my own colleagues as much as to the Government: the way to ensure that we become a clever country, the way to ensure our economic prosperity, is to make the investment to reap that reward. We have to sow before we reap. Let me give a warning that we are not providing the kinds of resources, as measured in OECD terms, that we need to provide. I am an advocate for increased resources—I am much more an advocate for quality and the way in which those resources are used—to ensure that in the priority area of TAFE we have the skilled technical supervisors that we need to enable us to live up to our economic potential.

In terms of the proportion of age groups enrolled in education, we are significantly falling behind the United States and three countries which are closely associated with each other in Europe—Germany, Belgium and Denmark. We are about the same as Norway and the Netherlands. So there still needs to be a growth in Year 11 and 12 enrolments, preschool enrolments and TAFE enrolments. There are international lessons for us to learn and we ought to be paying attention to them. That is why I have made comparisons with OECD countries. I would like to have referred to a number of other areas and said some things that would have been greatly embarrassing to the present Government. I would like to have quoted what has been said by some education commentators in this country. However, my speaking time has almost expired. This is the one time in every six months that we have a chance to make assessments in this area.

I conclude my speech by reminding the Senate that I have given up on this Government. There has been no education reform. The Government's thinking is blinkered. The only way that education reform will be achieved is through a change of government. All I can say is, `Come quickly the next election'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us three Bills related to education funding—the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991. These Bills essentially deal with three major levels of education services which are substantially funded at a Federal level, namely schools, TAFE and universities.

PARA.TAB: The Bills seek to implement decisions made in the Budget and the March industry statement by providing for recurrent and capital grant funding to the end of the 1994 triennium and by supplementing existing appropriations for 1991 to 1993 to take into account increasing costs. Additional funding is provided for several specific programs ranging from schools language and literacy, grants for advanced engineering centres at universities and the country areas program. The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) also provides for an increase in the higher education contribution scheme—otherwise known as HECS—paid by students through the taxation system on completion of their studies.

As we are debating these Bills cognately, I will deal briefly with each one separately and take the opportunity to make a few remarks about some of the issues raised by these Bills, including the current state and nature of funding for the separate branches of education. The Australian Democrats support the view that autonomy, diversity and freedom of choice in training and education should be maintained but that planning on a national scale is required if resources are to be most effectively and efficiently used to achieve the objectives of education and training.

To this extent, the Commonwealth has a responsibility to coordinate the development of education and training in Australia, from school to postgraduate level, in consultation with the States on funding and policy measures, to ensure that both unity and diversity in the provision and delivery of education services is maintained. At present, the Commonwealth has less control over the direction of school and TAFE education than it does over universities, even though a large slice of funding to the States comes from Commonwealth Consolidated Revenue.

The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991 seeks to implement a number of programs and appropriate funds for 1991 and 1992 by way of additional recurrent, capital and targeted grants for school education. In all, a total of nearly $2.6 billion in Commonwealth funds is allocated to schools by this piece of legislation before us.

The Australian Democrats broadly support the measures outlined in this Bill and are particularly pleased to see the Government implement aspects of the school and language literacy program. The Australian Democrats believe that a second language should be accepted as an integral part of the learning of every Australian. Any measures designed to improve and enhance the teaching of second languages and of basic literacy in Australian schools must be commended. In 1990, only 11.68 per cent of Year 12 students studied a language other than English and this, as the White Paper points out, is a massive decline from the 40 per cent of students who studied a second language in 1967.

I note that of the 14 priority languages listed in the White Paper, six are Asian languages. In addition, Aboriginal languages are included. Particular attention must be given to ensuring that young Aboriginal people are encouraged to maintain and study their mother-tongue throughout school years. We must not ignore the long heritage of our indigenous people. The priority languages list reflects the concern of many in the community to ensure the long term survival of Aboriginal culture.

The geographical position in the South East Asian region means that efforts must be made to ensure that Asian languages are taught in schools at an early age so that in the long term we are more fully able to participate in the region economically, culturally and socially. The teaching of Chinese, Indonesian, Japanese, Korean, Thai and Vietnamese not only indicates the increasing importance of the region to Australia but also reflects the impact of these communities on urban life in this country.

However, in so doing, we should not ignore our European heritage—the classical languages, thinking and ideas that have shaped our institutions, laws and social fabric. To that extent, I would support Senator Teague's contention that Latin should be added to the list of 14 languages. However, I would not be so presumptuous as to presume that hieroglyphics should also be added. French, German, Italian, modern Greek, Russian, Spanish and Arabic have been accorded the status of priority languages. This is an indication of the rich multicultural mix of community languages that are widely spoken in Australia today.

In addition to the provisions regarding language policy, the Bill also provides over $3.2m in funding for a national component to the country areas program. This measure is designed to enhance retention rates in rural areas of young people to Year 12. The Finn review indicated that `Year 12 completion rates remain about five percentage points lower in non-metropolitan areas than in metropolitan areas'. A recent report by the National Board of Education, Employment and Training cited figures of 59 per cent for metropolitan areas and 54 per cent for non-metropolitan areas. There is clearly a great deal of room for growth in retention rates in country regions, particularly in the remote parts of Australia. To this extent, we are very pleased to see the Government recognise its responsibility, although for many it is probably a case of too much, too little, too late.

It is to be hoped that the additional funding for the country areas program will directly assist in increasing the completion rates for young Aboriginal people. According to the Finn review into post-secondary education, the retention rate of Aboriginal youth to Year 12 `is about half that of the national figure'. In 1988, 62.9 per cent of all students completed Year 12. If Finn's assessment is followed, this means that only about 30 per cent of all Aboriginal students are continuing their studies to this level. This appalling statistic must be addressed by Federal and State governments and by education service providers in rural areas if Aboriginal young people are going to have any chance of finding meaningful employment or increased mobility through post-secondary education.

I turn to the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991, a Bill which seeks to implement Budget measures related to TAFE funding by providing for an increase of $1.66m in recurrent grants for 1991, approximately $158m for 1992 and maximum capital grants of $215m for next year. This latter figure represents a marginal increase of just over $3m on capital grants for 1991, a figure which falls far short of the additional funds needed to rapidly expand the TAFE sector in order to meet the goals set by the Finn review.

The issue of funding for TAFE is a thorny one. It has received a great deal of attention in recent weeks, following the release of the Finn review and subsequent debate. Currently, the Commonwealth funds 68 per cent of capital grants to the States for TAFE education, and provides only 9 per cent of recurrent funding. If the Finn review's target of having 95 per cent of all 19-year-olds in post-secondary education by the year 2001 is to be met, the Commonwealth will assume an enormous responsibility for funding additional places and capital growth. We are in fact talking about a 54 per cent increase in TAFE student places if the Finn review's recommendations are to be implemented. It will certainly require more than the 3.4 per cent increase in funding for TAFE, outlined in the Budget and presented to us in this Bill.

The Commonwealth-State working party has put the funding needs for this TAFE expansion at somewhere in the vicinity of $5 billion over and above the Commonwealth's expectations for the next 10 years. The same report believes that as many as 200,000 students will miss out on TAFE places in 1992, which represents an enormous number of young people who will be unable to upgrade or obtain new skills.

The Australian Democrats believe that urgent attention should be given to this problem, especially for those unemployed young people who cannot get a job without obtaining more training. Additional funding must be targeted at the young unemployed so that they have some chance to improve their skills and, therefore, job prospects. It is soul destroying for so many to leave school only to find that there is no place for them at university or TAFE institutions and no job.

It is totally unacceptable that so many may be turned away from TAFE institutions next year and, to this extent, we urge the Government to look carefully at the funding proposals suggested by the working party. I

SPEECH.PARA: note that in today's statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a great deal of money—somewhere in the vicinity of $130m—has been injected into the system. This will, hopefully, go some way to funding an extra 50,000 places for students next year.

PARA.TAB: An issue of concern to the Democrats is that the funds needed to expand the TAFE sector may in future be drawn from students by way of up-front fees or HECS-style arrangements. The possibility of $1,000 a year course fees has already been raised by the New South Wales Minister for Further Education, Mr John Fahey. Students already pay an administration charge of $430 for diploma or associate diploma courses; $65 for one semester courses; and $130 for all other courses, including certificate courses. Exemptions are provided for pensioners and needy students. According to some reports, this has resulted in a 17 per cent decline in enrolments in New South Wales.

The Australian Democrats believe that the imposition of fees for TAFE—certainly in New South Wales this must be regarded as a distinct possibility, given the Federal coalition's policy of full up-front fees for higher education—would be a retrograde step for TAFE education. Clearly, if the imposition of a fee of less than $500 has resulted in a 17 per cent drop in enrolments in New South Wales, any move to impose larger fees will impact heavily on young unemployed people, particularly women and those from lower socioeconomic backgrounds. The result will be an even more alienated youth, frozen out of TAFE and universities, unable to get a job and unable to afford training.

The Australian Democrats will watch with interest the progression of discussions with the States, such that they are, on the issue of TAFE funding. Post-secondary education funding should not be counted as a cost but rather as an investment in Australia's future, an investment in the skills of our work force and in the future of our young people.

The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1991 is, for the most part, supported by the Australian Democrats. We will, however, seek to remove from the Bill a clause which increases the de facto tertiary education fees payable by students. The main purpose of this Bill is to increase the amount of funding provided to tertiary institutions, both to finance further student intakes and to boost capital development. The Bill also provides for a wider definition of capital development to be adopted so that activities which effectively increase an institution's capacity, but do not involve actual building projects, will be eligible for capital works funding. Some works which were budgeted for 1994 will be brought forward to 1992, thus speeding up the expansion of our higher education system.

These provisions of the Bill are very timely, even vitally necessary, for the viability of our education sector which suffers greatly from overcrowding and lack of resources. But will they be enough? The recent National Day of Action on Overcrowding brought to light many examples of intolerable conditions on our campuses, which detract from their efficiency as teaching institutions. As an example, the first year English courses at Adelaide University were so overenrolled at the beginning of this year that the faculty was forced to issue tickets to allow a limited number of students to attend lectures. At Macquarie University, students were actually locked out of lecture theatres because there was not enough room for them.

The condition of our halls of learning continues to deteriorate. The library at the University of Sydney is the largest academic library in Australia and contributes enormously to the ability of our scientists and other researchers to keep apace with the literature about developments in their specific fields. Many journals are so specialised that only a major institution has the resources to maintain subscriptions to a significant body of them. Yet the recurrent funding for this institution will be cut next year, because the university cannot afford to maintain its existing collection, let alone expand it.

Since the passing of the original Higher Education Funding Act in 1988, there have been four separate increases in the total allocation which is specified in section 17(3) of the principal Act. Each of these increases has been achieved by legislation. In counting the minor amendments passed in Act No. 138 of 1988, there have been five amending Acts passed on this legislation in three years and we are now debating the sixth. The total maximum grant in 1991, for instance, was originally specified as $2,288.299m—a rather large figure, I might add. This was increased in four stages to its present value. The Bill now before us seeks to increase the amount to approximately $2.7 billion—up 3.5 per cent from the Higher Education Amendment Bill earlier this year.

While this proliferation of funding legislation is good news for the press secretary of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), who is thus enabled every six months or so to trot out a media release saying, `Government passes legislation to boost university funding', one wonders whether it would not have saved a lot of parliamentary time if the Minister had simply got the figures right in the first place.

The higher education contribution scheme fees are automatically indexed to inflation, and it is difficult to see why at least the predictable factors affecting allocations could not have been dealt with in a similar manner. Whilst this year's round of increases in this Bill are marginally ahead of inflation, the fact is that the number of students enrolled has been growing even faster than the number of Higher Education Funding Amendment Bills and there is still not enough money to go around.

The Government needs to look at sources for increased funding to tertiary institutions, such as the industries which profit from the pool of highly skilled labour produced by universities and TAFE. The elimination of the unjustified tax lurks enjoyed by large corporations and the Labor Party's mates in big business would go a long way towards providing the necessary money.

While the corporate borrowers and speculators who brought the interest rates crisis upon us are apparently exempt from contributing to the real cost of education, students are not. Under this Labor Government we have seen the effective reintroduction of the student fees which were abolished by its more ethical predecessor, the Whitlam Government. Under the so-called higher education contribution scheme, which was introduced under the Higher Education Funding Bill in 1988, students are currently paying $1,993 per year of full time study.

Clause 12 of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill before us seeks to increase this fee by an amount that is $144 greater than the normal indexation increase—to $2,250. The Democrats consider this increase in the HECS fee to be unjustified. In the committee stage I will be moving that this clause be deleted.

With this exception, the Democrats support the Bills before the Senate. The Australian Democrats are firmly committed to education as a national priority. Without it our country can develop neither the technological expertise required to compete in the international marketplace nor the human knowledge we need to create social justice at home.

While the Government talks about its commitment to higher education, anyone who has actually attended a university recently, as I have, knows that courses are overcrowded, conditions are inadequate and cutbacks abound. It is time for the Government to leave its fantasy world of flat earth economics and address the real problems faced by real people. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, in regard to the Opposition's amendment to the second reading of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, I move:
Omit paragraphs (a), (b) and (c).

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill, I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit paragraph (b).

SPEECH.PARA: We will be supporting in full the Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion related to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2). On that note I would commend the Bills to the Senate with those provisos. I look forward to supporting a number of these amendments moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address my remarks to one of the three Bills now before the Senate; specifically, the proposal to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988. Although I do not oppose the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 Bill as a whole, I must point out to the Senate the glaring inadequacies of this Bill and the failure of this Labor Government to properly address the crisis that is facing higher education institutions in this country.

PARA.TAB: The Government claims that these amendments, and the funding policies of the Government that they contain, will promote quality and diversity in the development of higher education throughout the 1990s. In fact, the proposed amendments invite exactly the opposite. They will only add to the bureaucratic administration of higher education in Australia and increasingly centralise funding to universities with government policy determining who gets the funds and for what reasons.

The amendments will allow the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) to approve grants to higher education institutions for proving that they will use the grant to maintain or enhance the quality of higher education provided by the institution. Exactly on what basis are comparisons of quality of education between institutions to be made? Do we look at the facilities available? Do we judge on the basis of the courses available to students? Do we attempt to compare the teaching philosophy and methods of practice? It is preposterous to suggest that any rational comparison of quality can be made by looking at different universities' teaching methods or making any other comparison, as quality has so many facets that it simply cannot be measured.

The Government in its proposal hopes to establish a national structure to determine exactly the criteria of sustained quality education. Where this has been tried overseas it has been a failure, because what is being attempted is not possible with any degree of validity or reliability. If the Minister has discretion to award these grants for quality performance, the result will be that the universities are going to be competing for desperately needed funds. The universities that win the grants will be those with better reputations. Thus, the rich will get richer—so much for equity. Obviously, the students in the other universities will just have to make do with poorer resource levels.

This is another flawed policy from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) which will serve only to stifle the innovative and pioneering work of which our universities are capable. Yet again, this Government is centralising further our system of higher education. How are our universities meant to become autonomous and develop a diversity of knowledge throughout this country if the purse strings are constantly held by the Government? Under this scheme, money is wasted on an irrelevant national bureaucracy to administer yet another program when approximately 29,000 young people in this country are turned away from universities every year.

The obvious alternative to this centralised bureaucracy is for the universities themselves to decide how to spend the money that is allocated to them. Only by having autonomy will Australia's universities be able to maintain and expand an internationally competitive higher education system with world class standards. I concur with Dr Kemp when he states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's policies encourage competition for bureaucratic favours rather than healthy competition in the educational marketplace.
This opinion is corroborated by comments of Professor Hill of the University of Wollongong, to which I will return later.

PARA.TAB: The Bill also provides for extra financial assistance of approximately $31m over three years for additional Australian Research Council grants. Once again, the Government is preventing the universities from flourishing by having strings attached to funding. Australian universities should not be centrally controlled. Educational processes can only be compromised by Government authorities when university funding is tied to meeting an ill-defined set of criteria set by the Government.

It is widely observed that the Australian Research Council discourages university researchers rather than helping them. Earlier this year, Professor James Hill of the Mathematics Department of the University of Wollongong called on the Federal Government to review the operations of the ARC. In the Australian newspaper he was reported as saying that serious researchers were wasting their time applying to the Council for funds rather than directing their activities to more productive research pursuits. Professor Hill stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government needs to address the inefficiencies and absurdities in the system and the constant wastage and under-utilisation of our academic resources.
He went on to say:
The present arrangements encourage time wasting and inefficiency and have a resultant effect of detracting from research activity rather than assisting it.

When questioned on who was receiving grants from the ARC, the Professor said that in the present situation researchers were being funded either because they had a significant research reputation or because the thrust of their proposals happened to fall within the range of interests or priorities of a member of the relevant ARC subcommittee. He knew of several good research projects, led by distinguished researchers and involving research with obvious industrial, export and employment potential, which had failed to attract ARC funding.

PARA.TAB: To further show the inadequacies for the proposed reforms suggested in this Bill regarding grants, we can look at a study by the Department of Administrative, Higher and Adult Education studies at the University of New England. This study, reported in the Australian in July this year, found that many high quality research projects are not being funded. The report went on to say that the existing system supports safe science and stifles creativity and flexibility.

This is clearly illustrated by the case of Professor John White of the Australian National University, and his work on the tremendously exciting and dynamic field of superconductivity. When a new discovery of carbon with superconductive qualities was announced, Professor White and his team from the ANU felt they should join the race to lead this field by drawing on their considerable expertise. They drew on their abilities, technical resources and the research students at the university to design this project.

They flew to the United Kingdom to use unique facilities there and encountered a team from the world renowned Bell Laboratories working on a similar project. The race was on. Fortunately, Professor White's results were much more comprehensive and accurate and the ANU's reputation in this field has jumped ahead in leaps and bounds.

The important thing is that this expertise is Australian. It is a vital asset as this industry moves closer and closer to adopting superconductivity in production. This is an example of how the ability to be adaptable and flexible in our funding arrangements can keep Australia at the forefront of science and technology. If Professor White had applied to the ARC for the funds for this experiment through the ARC research grants system, he would be waiting still and Bell Laboratories of the United States would have the lead in technology, much to Australia's loss.

The Government has created this situation by maintaining its policy of centralisation and not giving the universities the flexibility to act on problems as best suits their particular circumstances. Because the universities are so hemmed in by regulations from Canberra, they are also unable to act on the overcrowding problems that they face. Instead of giving the universities the chance to solve these problems, the Government in this Bill has practically ignored them.

This Bill, it is claimed by the Government, addresses the problem of enrolment and overcrowding pressures in our higher education institutions by allocating just under $10m for additional student intakes next year. The people who are lucky enough to make it into a university are now subjected to the worst overcrowding of universities that this country has yet seen. The fact that the Government feels that it is adequately addressing this problem by allocating only $10m shows that it truly does not grasp the fundamental problems that our universities are experiencing.

The allocation under this Bill of $3.5m for a pilot scheme with Government and employers sharing the costs of providing for the creation of 600 new student places in 1992 will be scant comfort for the 29,000 eligible applicants who were turned away from tertiary education in 1991. It is due to the incompetence of the Government, and the bureaucratic wastage of resources that it encourages, that these students are unable to fulfil their potential in tertiary education.

It is typical of this Government that it cannot see that the current economic recession, induced by failed former Treasurer, Paul Keating, is impacting on the critical problem of overcrowding in our universities. Young people are lining up to enter these institutions as an alternative to receiving unemployment benefits. The National Union of Students has voiced its concern at the current direction of Government policy regarding higher education. The President of the NUS, Ms Brigid Freeman, has been reported as saying that the Federal Government appeared to look at the problems of overenrolment at universities and high youth unemployment in `isolation' without recognising the possibility of a connection between the two issues.

The Government also fails to recognise that it has established a political system for the distribution of resources. This system has very little capacity to respond to the demands of those seeking its services. A major cause of this inability to respond is the degree to which the bureaucracy in Canberra dictates restrictions to our higher education institutions through the education profile process. The executive director of the AVCC, Mr Frank Hambly, has strongly criticised this system, and the broken promises of reform, stating:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is scope for much more government control over higher education than there was in the past. For example, through the educational profile process, the Government has considerable scope for telling institutions what they can teach, what research they can undertake and how they should manage their affairs'.

An excellent example of the restrictive effects of the Government's policy is given through the Northern Rivers campus of the University of New England in Lismore. The stifling centralist policies of this Government are preventing this university from reaching its full income generating potential, thereby meeting the increasing educational demands that are being placed upon it. This institution is working hand in hand with industry to produce a more highly skilled work force. The university has created training programs, tailor-made for clients' needs, ranging from associate diploma to MBA and covering all of the clients' management levels. The revenue received from this innovative program meets approximately 15 per cent of the costs of Northern Rivers campus. The problem begins, however, because demand, which in this particular area is potentially enormous, is stifled due to pricing restrictions from Canberra.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that the most sensible arrangement would be to give the institution the power to negotiate on its own behalf and charge for its services as it sees fit. But a host of red tape from Canberra results in the inadequate development of alternative funding sources and, as a result, supply cannot meet demand. When these programs are up and running they provide a source of funds from which profits can be redirected to other areas so inadequately financed, thereby continuing to increase supply.

To conclude, this Government must come to the realisation that the ideological blinkers that it wears are only hurting the universities of this country. We urgently need to address the real problems facing higher education, and this can only happen in a more decentralised and autonomous university environment. The new provisions contained in this Bill, allowing more money for grants, will not be fully effective due to the operation of the Australian Research Council and the compromises that go with submissions to the Council. Strings-attached grants serve only to misallocate the desperately needed funds away from where the market actually requires it.

The money put aside in this Bill for additional student intake is far too little, too late. Unmet demand for tertiary studies will increase across the country, and will continue to do so until the Government adopts a more flexible pricing regime and allows institutions to set a range of charges for various courses. The Government needs to address the fundamental, underlying causes of the problems facing higher education. The Government has not yet recognised this, and the bandaid solutions such as those contained in this Bill will not resolve the problem in the long term.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a series of Bills to do with the education of our fellow Australians at various levels. I will first deal with the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991, which has various elements that should commend themselves to the chamber. In fact, I think that broadly they do, although some straw arguments were set up, particularly by Senator Teague in some rhetorical flourishes which need to be refuted.

PARA.TAB: In particular, in relation to the school language and literacy program, I know that Senator Teague has a paternal rather than a paternalistic attitude in this area following his work in the Senate committee from which many good recommendations flowed. It must be emphasised that in relation to the language and literacy policy which has flowed from the White Paper of that very title, the priority language incentive element for schools is designed in a way that does not lead to a centralised imposition from Canberra of the languages that must be taught in any particular school or institution, whether in the government or non-government sector.

It must be emphasised that, of the 14 priority languages, as I understand it, each State Minister will select eight and, having declared those eight languages funding will flow to the State in relation to the number of students who undertake studies in those languages, whether in the government or non-government sector. In fact, the money that is sent to the State or non-government sector can be for any language training in those sectors.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that reassurance.

—I would like that to be on the record because it is an important reassurance. It indicates that this Government in formulating a national policy has nevertheless been sensitive to the proper position of the States and the non-government schools and block sectors which deliver the education to our young Australians. I believe that this language policy is very important for the future of Australia, and I agree with the general comments in that regard made by both Senator Teague and Senator Sowada.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the Bill, I find it difficult to understand why Senator Sowada said that she would be supporting paragraph (d) of the Opposition's second reading amendment. The new national element of the country areas program, providing funds for national projects to increase the number of students in country areas completing 12 years of schooling, is a marvellous program. Indeed, when one looks at the way in which certain areas declared by the Commonwealth Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), on the basis of advice from State education Ministers, as being those which should receive funding under the country areas program, I think that the scheme that has been worked out is a very important contribution in trying to ensure that rural students, particularly those from low socioeconomic backgrounds, get a better chance to participate in the education system and to be retained in the education system. It will be of interest to Senator Sowada that this will also reduce the gender-oriented distortions that exist in the participation rates of, particularly, young women in country areas in some sectors of the curriculum.

I believe that the priority of targeting schools in prescribed country areas serving students from low socioeconomic backgrounds should commend itself to the Democrats. I would hope that the proposed expenditure of $3.2m for each of the next three years, 1992 to 1994, to support those programs, will prompt Senator Sowada and the other Democrats to show that flexibility which they pride themselves on having and reject paragraph (d) of the amendment moved by the Opposition. On the whole, I think there is general agreement that the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991 does attempt to serve a very good purpose indeed.

The States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 implements the Budget decision to provide for a real increase of 5 per cent in Commonwealth recurrent grants to TAFE. Of course, this follows from the 1990 Deveson report on training costs. This Bill alone provides a real increase of 5 per cent in Commonwealth recurrent grants to TAFE. The fact that this Bill is being presented to the Senate raises a very real question mark over assertions that have been made that this Government has not seen technical and further education and vocational training as priorities.

In fact, we see them as desperate priorities within the Australian educational system. We are very conscious of the fact that it is not good enough for Australia to be a clever country; it must also be a capable country. It is no use simply having intellectual endeavour. We must have the technologists, the skilled trades people who can implement those innovative, creative ideas, which might be those of other people or themselves, of course. We need to have the skills to be able to put ideas into effect.

That is one of the lessons that Australia has had to learn. Sometimes those innovative and creative ideas do not get put in practice because of lack of entrepreneurial, daring skill on the part of those who profess to be interested in the market operation of the economy, but partly also because of a lack of those with the vocational and technical expertise to put some of these ideas into effect, or at least the lack of a sufficient pool of such people to enable manufacturing or other bases to be set up in Australia.

We know that the current unmet demand of TAFE is some 150,000 places. That is totally unacceptable to this Government and to Australia. How we tackle those problems quite clearly will require national co-operative arrangements. I would remind Senator Teague that there can be no advance in the area of TAFE without co-operation and collaboration between the various levels of government, and that is what the education Ministers are embarked on now. Their discussions have been well publicised over recent weeks and are well known to all senators.

Current funding arrangements are such that the States fund about 92 per cent of the recurrent costs in TAFE; the Commonwealth funds 8 per cent. The mere fact that this Bill for a real increase in Commonwealth funding of 5 per cent is now being debated in this chamber indicates the Government's priorities and intentions in regard to meeting that funding gap which prevents so many young Australians from getting the vocational technical training they deserve.

Of course, that is backed up by the announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) today of a further sum of $115m for post-secondary education and training. That will provide 40,000 students with opportunities to obtain vocational training. That is a very real commitment, indeed—one which I certainly applaud and one which I believe the Senate should also applaud.

As I have said, the need to secure a longer term secure funding basis for TAFE is a matter for Mr Dawkins, who is pursuing the matter now with State Ministers. We have offered to take over funding responsibility for TAFE and I believe that whilst ongoing management and administration will be a matter for the States within national policy guidelines, the Commonwealth's offer to take over the funding responsibility is surely a most attractive one and one that is proper if we are to achieve our national goal of being not only a clever country, but also a capable country.

In relation to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) of 1991, the proper funding of our higher education sector has, of course, been a matter of long debate in the Australian community over the last several years. The very considerable funds allocated for the support of higher education—the almost 3,000 additional student intake that is provided for in 1994, the extra capital works additional funds, the millions devoted to maintaining the quality of higher education in Australia—are all matters which can be readily absorbed by those who are interested in reading, for example, the second reading speech of the Minister for Education (Mr Dawkins).

Perhaps of more interest is the exploration being undertaken of the quality of higher education, and the Higher Education Council is being asked to undertake a very special role there. Once again, I believe that only following wider consultation with the higher education sector can a national structure independent of government be established to report on the application and effectiveness of quality enhancement measures developed by institutions, and in that context all those references to independence from government and measures developed by institutions are worth emphasising.

As has been adverted to by Senator Tierney, balancing public accountability with institutional autonomy is difficult. One is very conscious of it, particularly in relation to universities. There will always be a question of whether the balance has been exactly struck, but we are very conscious of the need for that balance to be struck in a way which encourages institutions to make decisions which accord with national goals.

The only matter of contention, really, as I understand the foreshadowed comments by the Democrats' spokesman, is in relation to the higher education contribution scheme increases. From next year the annual course contribution for a full time student undertaking a standard program of study will increase to $2,250, an increase of $144 above the normal indexation increase.

As I think students recognise, their contribution is a part contribution to the education they receive from the various institutions in which they enrol. They also appreciate, I believe, that the increases that they are being asked to bear, either immediately or in a deferred way, will actually go to provide funds for the further expansion of the higher education system. I honestly believe that there is sufficient altruism within the Australian higher education student community to understand that they are making a contribution which, in fact, will provide more places and more opportunities for fellow students to obtain this sort of education.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I am very conscious that we would all like to get this Bill passed tonight before we rise. I commend the Bills to the Senate and look forward to their support by all parties and independents in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering three Bills. The Australian Democrats wish to oppose clause 12 of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. I consider it would be simplest if the three Bills were taken as a whole for debate in committee and if the Australian Democrats were to move an amendment to omit clause 12 of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2).

PARA.TAB: The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2), I move:

PARA.TAB: That clause 12, page 5, lines 8 to 14, be omitted from the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Australian Democrats I rise to oppose clause 12 of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill, which seeks to increase the higher education contribution scheme charge from $1,993 effectively to $2,250. The Australian Democrats have consistently opposed the notion of user pays education and finds this measure particularly obnoxious. Clause 12 raises the HECS charge $144 above the normal indexation increase and, in addition, sets a new baseline for the calculation of the HECS liability. This represents a 13 per cent increase in the HECS charge, well in excess of inflation and far greater than most students expected.

PARA.TAB: We are, in effect, witnessing the introduction of fees by stealth. An increase of this magnitude next year will result in a single year HECS liability standing at $2,540 in 1993. In addition, I point out to the chamber that the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) has already printed a HECS handbook for students which details the new fee before the legislation increasing the charge has actually been passed by this Parliament. This is a great presumption on the part of the Government and the Minister, in particular, who might have had the good grace to wait until we had had an opportunity to pass these Bills. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not support the Australian Democrats' amendment. This decision to increase the HECS liability in regard to students contributing to the cost of their education is a Budget decision. There is no doubt that if we in the Opposition were to support the Australian Democrats in this matter we would suffer a compensating amount in the provision for higher education generally. With that clear predictable outcome in mind, we do not oppose what the Government has decided in the Budget and has announced in this regard.

PARA.TAB: I also draw the attention of the Committee of the Whole to the fact that there may be a minor drafting defect in the Democrats' amendment, in that it makes no mention of amending clause 2 to delete the reference in clause 2 to clause 12, which is a necessary consequential amendment. In other words, there is a reference to clause 12 in clause 2 which would be redundant if clause 12 were omitted from the Bill. That is only a tiny pedantic point. For the substantial reason to which I referred, the Opposition is not supporting the Democrats' amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. This is typical of the Democrats' woolly headed thinking on education that we have heard so often in this place. It reminds me of former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, who felt that he could make education free. The result of those disastrous policies for higher education in the 1970s was that the whole sector was grossly underfunded and students were turned away from universities. Those sorts of policies led to the situation that we have today of students not being able to get into higher education places.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats should really consider why this Government has been forced in the past seven years to change from the Whitlam policies and to bring in, first, an administration charge and, more recently, fees at a low level and then increase them, as Senator Sowada has indicated, way above the inflation rate. The reason is that we are turning away 30,000 students each year from higher education. The only way people will get places in higher education is if we find alternative sources of funding. Students paying part of their fees is a way of obtaining funding. It is a just way of obtaining funding because the people who gain most of the benefit pay for that benefit. On that basis I oppose and the coalition opposes this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reasons I gave in my concluding remarks in the second reading stage, the Government will not support this particular amendment, which amounts to a deletion of the increase in the HECS fee which is proposed in this Bill to the Committee. I believe that, as I indicated, whilst it will be something of an additional burden for individual students, they realise that they are making only a part contribution to the costs of the education which they receive and, secondly, they also understand, as Senator Teague pointed out, that moneys raised from this particular levy will help expand educational opportunities for their fellow Australian students. That is also something which appeals to their altruism and enables them to bear this particular cost with some grace. I indicate that the Government will not support this amendment.

—Clearly, the arguments that have been put forward not only in this debate but elsewhere about students having to pay something for their education have a considerable amount of merit. I think it is fairly well generally accepted now that, in this particular field where qualifications that lead to those students obtaining employment which returns a fairly high level of income, contributions are made by those persons for the education they receive.

PARA.TAB: I do not think that is necessarily the reason that Senator Sowada is seeking to oppose this clause. I will vote on this—it is not really an amendment; it is really opposing the clause—with the Australian Democrats because of one or two things she said. She pointed out pretty clearly that the increase is very substantially above the consumer price index. It came as a bit of a shock to me at all events that this was to be the case. I am sure it will come as a surprise to a number of university students as well that the increase is so far above the CPI, and, therefore, I will support Senator Sowada's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the fourteenth report of the Committee concerning a matter raised by a person under Privilege Resolution 5 of 25 February 1988. On 13 November 1991, the President, Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa, referred a letter from Ms Jeannie Cameron relating to remarks made by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, during debate on 17 October 1991 to the Committee of Privileges as a submission under Privilege Resolution 5. The Committee has considered the submission and recommends that a response agreed to by Ms Cameron and the Committee be incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: As previously indicated to the Senate, in matters of this nature the Committee does not judge the truth or otherwise of statements made by honourable senators or persons but, rather, it ensures that a person's submission, and ultimately the response recommended by the Committee, accord with the criteria set out in Privilege Resolution 5.

On behalf of the Committee I also remind honourable senators of other methods available to persons mentioned in the Senate to make their views known. The response read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: RESPONSE BY MS JEANNIE CAMERON
AGREED TO BY MS CAMERON
AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES
PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7)(B)
OF THE SENATE OF
25 FEBRUARY 1988
I have been referred to by Senator Richardson during the committee of the whole stage of the Appropriation Bills in the Senate on 17 October 1991 (Hansard, pages 2237 and 2242).

Although Senator Richardson did not mention me by name, I am readily identified as the person he was speaking about. I am Senator Newman's Defence research officer and I telephoned the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS) regarding a transcript of an interview of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Gordon Bilney. Further, of Senator Newman's staff I have the most contact with the media and I was the most likely to be speaking with the NMLS. People who know Senator Newman's staff would have identified this person as me.

I believe that Senator Richardson raised matters which were unfair and untrue, and they have adversely affected my reputation. In many instances, not only in the Senate, people have said to me "So you're the one that was rude on the phone". There is an unwarranted belief that I was rude.
I was not rude and I have never been rude to anyone whom I have spoken to, either in person or on the phone, as a representative of Senator Newman.
Jeannie Cameron
Defence Research Officer
