DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Funding of Independent Schools in ACT

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to draw this Parliament's attention to the absolutely disgraceful decision made by the ACT Follett Labor Government in recent weeks whereby funding from the ACT Budget to three independent schools has been withdrawn. Funding has not been withdrawn from categories other than categories one to three. The Follett Government's action is blatantly inequitable. It reeks of invective and favouritism; it is made, by the Government's own admission, on ideological grounds; and it flies in the face of an undertaking made in 1985 by the Federal Minister for Education. The then Minister, Senator Susan Ryan, gave an unqualified commitment that per capita grants would be maintained at their 1986 level in money terms until they reached the appropriate real level.

PARA.TAB: In deference to that commitment, which has been honoured by Federal and ACT governments in subsequent years, those schools have planned and budgeted. They have made long term financial commitments and incurred liabilities on the basis that the Government undertaking would be honoured. ACT Government funding is now to be withheld at the whim of a vocal anti-non-government school lobby that has muscled in on the present Labor Government. One can only assume that its silent agenda includes a caprice to adopt a policy already discarded and discredited in eastern Europe and the Soviet Union—that is, to herd the young students of Canberra into one amorphous, monolithic state-controlled education system, with no freedom of choice and little or no opportunity to strive for excellence.

The ACT is the only State or Territory in Australia to allocate grants in direct proportion to the Commonwealth's categorisation. It is of great concern that while such doubt hangs over the fairness of this categorisation the three schools in question should be discriminated against. The schools in question are the Canberra Grammar School, which is category one, and the CCEGGS and AME, which are both category three. These schools will have their funding cut by some $520,000. That figure is of more than passing interest when one reflects on the cost of the ACT Government's recent decision to reopen two apparently redundant primary schools at a cost of close to $600,000 for a total of 125 children—a cost of $4,800 per pupil.

With regard to the treatment of category one and category three schools, the proposal will reduce the ACT Government grant to AME and CCEGGS by over 20 per cent. It will reduce the ACT grant to Canberra Grammar by 50 per cent, which is $350,000 per year on current enrolments. In fact, it will make Canberra Grammar the lowest funded school in Australia by a very big margin. ACT Government recurrent grants for 1991 for category one and category three secondary schools stood at $585 per pupil. This will now reduce to $300 for category one schools and $460 for category three schools in 1992. Compare this with the $945 recurrent grants to category 10 secondary schools and the ACT government schools receiving $5,210 for years 7 to 10 and $5,800 for years 11 and 12.

As I mentioned earlier, there is little doubt that the decision has been made to appease hardline elements opposed to government funding for non-government schools. It is an attack on a small number of schools perceived to be elite. That perception is ill founded and totally irrational. In fact, statistics prove that children at these schools come from diverse socioeconomic backgrounds. In many cases, both parents are working; in the case of Canberra Grammar School, 82 per cent of current families have both parents working. Both parents, via the taxation system, contribute to the funding of government schools which their children do not attend.

As my colleague the shadow Minister for education in the other place has said, the Federal Labor Government's new schools policy is a manifestation of its hostility towards the non-government sector. It is a policy that seeks to curb development and stymie the ability of parents to exercise their right to choose. In the five years to 1985, the number of private schools in Australia rose from 2,261 to 2,502, a rise of 10.6 per cent. The number of students rose from 687,996 to 775,336, a rise of 12.7 per cent. In that period—1981-85—the non-government sector's share of students rose from 23 per cent to 25.8 per cent. With the new schools policy in place over the five years between 1986 and 1990, the number of private schools increased by only 0.8 per cent, from 2,496 to 2,517.

One can almost liken the ideological pursuit of Ms Follett and her Labor Government to the St Bartholomew massacre and the persecutions of Oliver Cromwell. Does Ms Follett model herself on Oliver Cromwell or the Medicis? Education is civilisation progressing. This ACT Government decision retards that progress. It is all about a perceived impression that those parents who wish to send their children to independent schools are rich and unworthy of a share of Commonwealth funding. The perception is just that. The 1986 census showed that 58 per cent of Australian Capital Territory families in the highest family income group sent their children to government schools. Many children whose parents have less income attend non-government schools. That is their priority and their right to choose.

One does not need to be Socrates to realise that the cost per pupil in a non-government school is much lower than the cost to taxpayers of state education. These proposed funding cuts could well lead to a move from the three schools back to the government school sector, and the ACT taxpayers and the taxpayers of Australia will have to foot the greatly increased bill.

The Liberal Party, at both Federal and State levels, speaks for fairness and equity. The withdrawal of funding to the three schools in question is thoroughly ill-founded and an unworthy decision. I only hope, having raised this issue tonight, that the ACT Assembly, led by the Labor Party, will reconsider its stance and, in consultation with those most affected, restore funding in line with the Federal Labor Government's former Senator Susan Ryan's commitment of 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise only to support every word of the speech of my colleague, Senator Parer. It is a serious situation when, in the ACT, we see a hit list of three schools, such as former Senator Ryan envisaged back in 1984, now revisited upon her own Capital Territory. On the hit list that she had in 1984 there were 41 schools around the nation. She could not get away with it across the whole nation of Australia because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) intervened, but she and her colleagues who are still in the Labor Party in the ACT can get away with it because they appear to be in government in this Territory. It is an attack upon tall poppies; it is envy politics; it is an attack upon family choice; it is chopping down elites; it is a total sop to the ideological Left of the ALP; and it is totally rejected by every Opposition senator in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: I implore the Government and Senator McMullan, who represents this Territory, to get this decision reversed. It certainly will be reversed in a change of government when the coalition comes into power in the ACT. Nevertheless, I ask that there be action now, not in the future, to reverse this most unfortunate and unfair decision. Senator Reid, I and all my Opposition colleagues support the summary that has been given by my colleague the shadow Minister for the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a few weeks, some 240,000 school leavers will find themselves looking for work or looking for further education. For most of them, the first choice would be to look for employment. But those 240,000 school leavers across this nation face a bleak prospect without employment because of the failure of this Government's economic policies. When we look at the task of creating a nation with prosperity, with opportunity, and with a prospect of a decent future for those young Australians, we must look with despair at the lack of opportunities which they have been given.

PARA.TAB: I refer, in passing only of course, to the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) today. It is an interesting statement. The opening sentence is interesting and says:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia today is at a point of historic convergence.

By that, I assume he means Australia is between a rock and a hard place, because if one is a school leaver in this nation today there is very little opportunity to go and get a job; there is very little opportunity to find meaningful employment. The only sop that this Government can offer school leavers is more study in TAFEs and other places, which will not lead to meaningful employment at the end of that period but will merely take them off the unemployment queue, to lessen the public criticism of this Government's economic failing.

PARA.TAB: We have to look very closely at what this Government has done, because over and over it talks about a clever country; over and over it talks about a bright and rosy future. But what has it given us? The highest number of unemployed people in the history of this nation. What has it given us? The worst recession—depression—since the 1930s. What has it given us? A nation where industry and the farming sector have been devastated and where families bear the cruel burden that this so-called government of the workers, the so-called party of the workers, has bequeathed to them. The truth is that the people who sit on the opposite side of the chamber, the members of the Labor Party, are incapable of making the right economic decision, are incapable of getting any industry going in this country, and have been responsible year after year for the shedding of Australian jobs.

This Government talks about job creation. It could easily have created jobs by saying yes to Wesley Vale, by saying yes to Coronation Hill, by ensuring that Kambalda continued to flourish. But, no, the Government has refused to do so. Why? It is not out of concern for the workers but out of some twisted, almost moronic ideology that constrains it to deal with its ACTU mates and its Green supporters. We have the absurdity of this Government having a three-mine uranium policy, as though uranium from those three mines is somehow more pure or more sanctified than any other uranium that might be dug out of the ground in this nation. It was only a sop in the first place, but what it has done has cost this nation millions and millions of dollars in lost export earnings. That is what it has done.

We have a Government that refuses to accept the fact that in the 1990s we need a change in industrial relations so that workers can take their own futures into their own hands. But this Government does not believe that ordinary workers have a right to determine how they will work, or for how much, or for whom. This Government believes that it and the ACTU can make a better decision for millions of Australian workers than they can themselves. That is not a particularly flattering view of the intellect of the Australian worker, but that is in effect what it is doing because this Government has repeatedly failed to implement a system of voluntary employment agreements that would return negotiations of working conditions to the place where those negotiations ought to take place, and that is the shop floor.

Instead, the Government likes negotiations tied up in its club of industrial relations specialists, the lawyers and the men in the suits, who do not understand what the workplace is like, who do not understand what industry is like and who, seemingly, do not understand that its so-called wage deals, its so-called accord, has just cost the jobs of thousands of thousands of Australian workers from one end of this country to another.

This Government tells us that the end is in sight, that the recovery is coming. Not only will Christmas beat the recovery, but in June I could have said that Christmas would beat the recovery and I still would have been right. It may be if this Government continues on its current track that Christmas 1992 will beat the recovery as well, because there is not one policy this Government can enunciate that will do anything about the decline in the competitiveness of Australian industry. There is not one policy it can put forward that will improve investment across Australia. There is not one policy it can put forward that will give to the workers a right to determine for themselves how, when and where they will work.

That is why this Government has failed to meet the aspirations of hundreds of thousands of Australians. The Government has lost perspective; it fails to understand what motivates Australians. Australians are concerned with security for their families, with security of employment, and with the opportunity to do the best they can for themselves. This nation was not built on sweetheart deals in boardrooms, in ACTU meeting rooms or in industrial relation commissions. This nation was built on hard work, determination and perseverance, yet this is the same Government that wants to tax those who have determination and perseverance. It wants to tax those people who put the hard work in that generates the wealth that is important for this nation.

This is the same Government that can look at a balance of payments deficit of $14 billion and congratulate itself on its economic success—absolutely incredible! If I went to my bank manager and said, `I've just run a loss this month of $10,000, but don't worry because it's right on target', he would be picking up the telephone and calling the men from the funny farm. That is what we ought to do with the Government because it does not understand that its economic policies are bleeding this nation dry at the rate of $14 billion a year. It congratulates itself for it. It fails to understand that that balance of payments deficit represents not only dollars that go overseas, but also jobs that go overseas.

This is the same Government that has been busy dismantling the tariffs around Australia. Ultimately, that is a good thing but what tariffs do not do—whilst encouraging overseas competition—is actually make Australia more competitive. The restrictive system of wage agreements that the Government has negotiated with its ACTU buddies is costing thousands and thousands of Australians their jobs.

I can assure this Senate of one thing: that Christmas 1991 will be a bleak Christmas indeed, not only for the families of the 240,000 school leavers but also for the families of the one million unemployed in this nation and for the families of those who, though not unemployed, face the prospect of unemployment.

I note that the November 1991 Westpac Market Insights publication predicts the possibility that the unemployment rate could go as high as 11 per cent. We have a prospect of rising unemployment and this Government tells us that the recovery has started! It defies logic to say that the recovery has already started when people are still losing their jobs. The only possibility of this country experiencing a recovery is if those opposite lose their jobs, and that is what they ought to do.

If people are working in a business and do not perform, they lose their jobs. But it seems that this Government can fail to perform year after year, can destroy the aspirations of over one million Australian families and can spread this voodoo economics around the country and tell everybody that things are good. The fact is, things are not good and we know they are not. One of the Government's responses to the current situation has been this mad cities fantasy. The Government is going to spend $500m on its mad cities fantasy when the people really in need in this country are the people who live outside the capital cities, the people who live on the land, the people who live in towns dependent on people who live on the land.

It is disturbing to note that this Federal Government and its State parliamentary colleagues in Queensland, faced with one of the worst droughts in Queensland's history, could find only $200 a family for the farm families affected by the drought. That is pathetic. It was a pathetic attempt by the Government to appear to do something when the reality was that it had no interest and no inclination to do anything at all. The Government can find $500m for its mad cities fantasy, but it cannot find the necessary money to ensure that there is decent drought relief, decent roads, decent hospitals and decent communication facilities for people outside the city.

For all of these reasons, as I said, the only way that this country will experience a recovery is if those opposite lose their jobs. I say on behalf of many millions of Australians, the sooner that happens, the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —I promise that, notwithstanding the temptation to respond to that tawdry little exercise, I will be very brief. Given that two of the speeches were in relation to the ACT, I will respond briefly. Unlike the two honourable senators who spoke, I actually know something about the matters that they were referring to, having spoken to many of the parents concerned who are constituents of mine. It is a very complex and difficult issue.

PARA.TAB: The only thing I want to say in response here is that it is a matter for the ACT Government. A bit of grandstanding in this place does no good. It is not our place to make decisions for the ACT Government any more than it is our place to make decisions for the governments of Victoria or New South Wales. The ACT is a self-governing Territory and the Government there is entitled to make its own decisions, as governments are entitled to everywhere else.

A consistent theme of spokespersons opposite, which was reflected in Senator O'Chee's remarks, is that they advocate massive cuts in public spending—they want $4 billion in cuts—but every time anybody cuts anything they protest, and every time a payment is made it is never enough. They have not yet learned the fundamental truth that the whole equals the sum of the parts. If they want a $4 billion cut, they cannot go around increasing everything.
My only response to Senator O'Chee's speech is to say that the Queensland National Party should be ashamed of itself for replac-

SPEECH.PARA: ing a person of such substance as Senator Stone with someone who could deliver such a pathetic and cliche ridden little contribution as that which we just heard. I did not agree with Senator Stone very often, but I always respected the quality of his contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 23 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why was the Defence Forward Estimates detail, (see page 3.61 Budget Paper No. 1 1990-91) under `Part II Analysis by Function—Defence' omitted from the 1991-92 Budget Paper No. 1.
(2) Will it be re-installed in the next Budget; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) In 1991-92 the text in Statement 3 of Budget Paper No. 1 was reworked and tightened to reduce the overall length of the document while maintaining its status as a document of record. Material

ANSWER.PARA: relating to the Defence forward estimates was included in the `Overview' section (see page 3.27 Budget Paper No. 1 1991-92), the section on `Trends in Defence Outlays' (see page 3.30) and under the sub-heading `Trends' at the end of each sub-function, for example Personnel Costs and Retirement Benefits (see page 3.35).

PARA.TAB: (2) At this stage it is planned to prepare Statement 3 for the next Budget using a similar format to 1991-92.
